original: Sabbādīnaṃ vītihāre dve bhavanti. Pubbassa syādilopo ca, aññassa aññassa bhojakā aññamaññassa bhojakā, evaṃ itarītarassa.
analyzed: sabba ādīnam vītihāre dve bhavanti pubbassa sya ādi lopaḥ ca aññassa aññassa bhojakāḥ aññam aññassa bhojakāḥ evam itarītarassa
translated: When all the above are omitted, there are two: the first has the elision of the syllable ya, and the second has the substitution of bho for aññassa, aññassa, and the substitution of aññamaññassa for itarītarassa.

original: 1,57. Yāvabodhaṃ sambhame🔽Turitenā+pāyahetupadassanaṃ sambhamo, tasmiṃ sati vattu yāvantehi saddehi so+ttho
analyzed: yā avabodham sambhame  turitena apāya hetu padassanam sambhamaḥ tasmin sati vattu yāvantehi saddehi sotthaḥ
translated: The combination is according to the number of syllables.

original: viññāyate, tāvanto payujjante. Sappo sappo sappo, bujjhassu bujjhassu bujjhassu,
analyzed: viññāyate tāvantaḥ payujjante sappaḥ sappaḥ sappaḥ bujjhassu bujjhassu
translated: The combination is the showing of the reason for the omission of the syllable ā quickly. When that is present, as many syllables as are necessary to make the meaning understood are used. Snake, snake, snake; wake up, wake up, wake up;

original: bhinno bhikkhusaṅgho, bhinno bhikkhusaṅgho.🔽Bhaye kodhe pasaṃsāyaṃ, turite kotūhala+cchare;
analyzed: bhinnaḥ bhikkhu saṅghaḥ bhinnaḥ bhikkhu saṅghaḥ  bhaye kodhe turite
translated: the Community of monks is split, the Community of monks is split.🔽In fear, anger, praise, quickly, in wonder, in haste;

original: Hāse soke pasāde ca, kare āmeḍitaṃ budho.
analyzed: hāse soke pasāde ca kare āmeḍitam budho
translated: in laughter, in grief, in confidence, the wise one makes āmeḍita.

original: Saṅkhyākaṇḍa🔽Atha saṅkhyāsaddā vuccante. Ekādayo aṭṭhārasantā saṅkhyeyyavacanā. Vīsatiādayo “bhikkhūnaṃ
analyzed: saṅkhyā kaṇḍa  atha saṅkhyā saddāḥ vuccante eka ādayaḥ saṅkhyeyya vacanāḥ vīsati ādayaḥ bhikkhūnam
translated: The Chapter on Numerals

original: vīsatī”tiādīsu saṅkhyāvacanā, “vīsati bhikkhavo”tiādīsu saṅkhyeyyavacanā. Ekasaddo
analyzed: vīsati itiādīsu saṅkhyā vacanā vīsati bhikkhavaḥ tiādīsu saṅkhyeyya vacanā eka saddaḥ
translated: Now the numeral words are stated. The numerals from one to eighteen are used for the countable. The numerals from twenty onwards are numeral words in “twenty bhikkhus” etc., and countable words in “twenty bhikkhus” etc. The word one

original: sabbādīsu vuttova. Dvādayo aṭṭhārasantā bahuvacananthāva.
analyzed: sabba ādīsu vuttaḥ uva dva ādayaḥ aṭṭhārasa ntāḥ
translated: is used in all the above. The numerals from two to eighteen are only in the plural.

original: 219. Yomhi dvinnaṃ duve+dve
analyzed: yomhi dvinnam duvedve
translated: I am of two, two each

original: Yomhi dvissa savibhattissa duve+dve honti paccekaṃ. Duve dve, duve dve, dvīhi dvībhi.
analyzed: dvissa savibhattissa duve dve honti paccekam duve dve duve dve dvīhi dvībhi
translated: I am of two, two each, in the case of the case endings. Two each, two each, by two, by two.

original: 220. Duvinnaṃ naṃmhi vā
analyzed: duvinnam naṃmhi vā
translated: Of two, of them, or

original: Naṃmhi dvissa savibhattissa duvinnaṃ hoti vā. Duvinnaṃ, aññatra –
analyzed: naṃ mhi dvissa savibhattissa duvinnam hoti vā duvinnam aññatra
translated: Of two, of them, in the case of the case endings. Of two, except

original: 47. Naṃmhi nuka dvādīnaṃ sattarasannaṃ
analyzed: nam mhi nu ka dva ādīnam sattara san nam
translated: Of them, of the twenty, of the seventeen

original: Dvādīnaṃ sattarasannaṃ saṅkhyānaṃ nuka hoti naṃmhi vibhattimhi. Ukāro uccāraṇattho,🔽kakāro antāvayavattho. Ettha nāgamo vibhattissa ādyāvayavo ce, “āgamā tagguṇībhūtā
analyzed: dvi ādīnam sattarasannam saṅkhyānam hoti nam vibhattimhi ukāraḥ uccāraṇa atthaḥ  kakāraḥ anta avayava tthaḥ ettha na āgamaḥ vibhattissa ādya avayavaḥ ce āgamā tagguṇībhūtā
translated: Of the twenty, of the seventeen, the number nuka is in the case ending of them. The letter u is for the purpose of pronunciation,🔽the letter k is for the purpose of the final part. Here, if the case ending has the first part, “The prefix is included by the word that is its base,”

original: taggahaṇena gayhante”ti ñāyā nāgamopi taṃgahaṇena gayhatīti “sunaṃhisū”ti dīghappasaṅge🔽pakatiyā antāvayavabhūte sarantatā natthīti na dīgho. Dvinnaṃ, dvīsu.
analyzed: tad gahaṇena gayhanta iti ñāyā na āgamaḥ pi tad gahaṇena gayhati iti dīgha ppasaṅge  pakatiyāḥ anta avayava bhūte sa ranta tā natthi iti na dīghaḥ dvinnam dvīsu
translated: by the rule, the prefix is also included by the word that is its base. Therefore, “of them” is long in the Dīgha collection.

original: 207. Pume tayo+cattāro🔽Yomhi savibhattīnaṃ ti+catunnaṃ tayo+cattāro honti yathākkamaṃ pulliṅge. Tayo, tayo, tīhi tībhi.
analyzed: pume tayocattāraḥ 🔽sa vibhattīnam ti catunnam tayocattāraḥ honti yathākkamam pul liṅge tayo tīhi tībhi
translated: There is no natural final part in the case of the twenty, therefore it is not long. Of two, in two.

original: 49. Ṇṇaṃ+ṇṇannaṃ tito jhā🔽Jhasaññito tito naṃvacanassa ṇṇaṃ+ṇṇannaṃ honti. Tiṇṇaṃ tiṇṇannaṃ, tīsu.🔽Itthiyaṃ –🔽205. Tisso catasso yomhi savibhattīnaṃ🔽Vibhattisahitānaṃ ticatunnaṃ yomhi tisso+catasso honti itthiyaṃ yathākkamaṃ. Tisso, tisso, tīhi tībhi.🔽204. Naṃmhi ticatunna+mitthiyaṃ tissa+catassā🔽Naṃmhi ticatunnaṃ tissa+catassā honti+tthiyaṃ yathākkamaṃ. Naṃmhīti catutthīchaṭṭhīnaṃ🔽sāmaññavacanaṃ, no ce naṃsūti vadati, yathākkamaṃti saddadvayāpekkhaṃ. Eva+mīdisa+maññampi. Tissannaṃ tīsu.🔽206. Tīṇi+cattāri napuṃsake
analyzed: ṇ ṇ ṇ ṇ naṃ t itaḥ jhā  jha saññitaḥ t itaḥ naṃ vacanassa ṇ ṇ ṇ n nam honti ti ti nam tīsu  itthiyam  tissaḥ catassaḥ yaḥ omhi sa vibhattīnam  vibhatti sahitānam ti catunnam yomhi tisso catassaḥ honti itthiyam yathākkamam tissaḥ tissaḥ tīhi tībhi  nam mhi ti catunnam itthiyam tissa catassā  nam mhi tissa catassāḥ honti itthiyam yathākkamam nam iti catutthī chaṭṭhīnam  sāmañña vacanam no ce vadati tīsu  tīṇi cattāri napuṃsake
translated: 49. The forms of the three and four are as follows:

original: Catussa savibhattissa yomhi caturo hoti vā pulliṅge. Caturo cattāro. Kathaṃ “caturo
analyzed: catussa sa vibhattissa yaḥ mhi caturaḥ hoti vā pulliṅge caturaḥ cattāraḥ katham caturaḥ
translated: In the fourfold, I am four, or four in the masculine. Four, four.

original: nimitte nāddasāsi”nti, liṅgavipallāsena siddhaṃ, cattāri nimittānīti attho. Vipallāso
analyzed: nimitte liṅga vipallāsena siddham cattāri nimittāni iti atthaḥ vipallāso
translated: In the four declensions, I am four, or in the masculine. Four, four. How? “You did not see the four signs,” it is established by the reversal of the gender, the meaning is: the four signs. Reversal

original: tividho liṅgavipallāso vacanavipallāso vibhattivipallāsoti. Catūhi catūbhi. Catunnaṃ, catūsu.
analyzed: tividhaḥ liṅga vipallāsaḥ vacana vipallāsaḥ vibhatti vipallāsaḥ iti catūhi catūbhi catunnam catūsu
translated: is threefold: reversal of gender, reversal of speech, and reversal of case endings. With four, with four. Of four, in four.

original: Itthiyaṃ catasso. Catasso. Catūhi catūbhi. Catassannaṃ. Catassannaṃ. Catūsu.
analyzed: itthiyam catasso catasso catūhi catūbhi catassannam catassannam catūsu
translated: In the feminine, four. Four. With four, with four. Of four, of four. In four.

original: Napuṃsake cattāri. Cattāri. Catūhi catūbhi. Iccādi pumeva.
analyzed: napuṃsake cattāri cattāri catūhi catūbhi it ca ādi pum eva
translated: In the neuter, four. Four. With four, with four. And so on, only in the masculine.

original: 169. Ṭa pañcādīhi cuddasahi
analyzed: ṭa pañca ādīhi cut dasahi
translated: . Ṭa with the five and so on up to fourteen

original: “Sutte liṅgavacanamatta”nti ñāyā ṭa-iti vuttaṃ. Pañcādīhi cuddasahi saṅkhyāhi yonaṃ ṭa hoti. Pañca. Pañca. Yonaṃ ṭā+ṭenivatthanatthaṃ ṭa-vidhānaṃ.
analyzed: sutte ñāyāḥ ṭa iti vuttam pañca ādīhi saṅkhyāhi yonam ṭa hoti pañca pañca
translated: It is said “ṭa” according to the rule “In a sutta, only the gender and speech are stated.” Ṭa is used for the feminine with the numbers five and so on up to fourteen. Five. Five. The rule for ṭa is for the purpose of changing ṭā to ṭe.

original: 90. Pañcādīnaṃ cuddasanna+ma
analyzed: pañca ādīnam cud dasan nama
translated: . Of the five and so on up to fourteen

original: Pañcādīnaṃ cuddasannaṃ sunaṃhisva hoti. Etta+dīghāpavādo+yaṃ. Apavādati bādhetīti
analyzed: pañca ādīnam hoti
translated: Hisva is used for the feminine of the five and so on up to fourteen. This is the exception to the long e. The exception contradicts, it obstructs.

original: apavādo. Tasmā “pakapyāpavādavisayamussaggā abhinivisante”ti ñāyā “suhisva+sse” “sunaṃhisu”ti
analyzed: apavādaḥ abhinivisantā iti ñāyā
translated: and the exclusion is “suhisva+sse, sunaṃhisu”.

original: ca ussaggā “pañcādīnaṃ cuddasanna+ma” iti apavādavisayaṃ na pavisanti, sāmaññattā.
analyzed: ca ussaggā pañca ādīnam iti apavāda visayam na pavisanti sāmaññattā
translated: Because of the similarity, they do not enter the exclusion-subject, “pañcādīnaṃ cuddasanna+ma”.

original: Eva+muparipi “pañcamiyaṃ parassa” “ādissā”ti. Pañcahi pañcabhi pañcannaṃ. Pañcannaṃ.
analyzed: evam upari pi pañcamiyam parassa ādissāti pañcahi pañcabhi pañcannam pañcannam
translated: Similarly above, “pañcamiyaṃ parassa, ādissā”. With five, with five, with five. With five.

original: Pañcasu. Evaṃ chādayo aṭṭhārasantā.
analyzed: pañcasu evam cha ādayaḥ
translated: In five. Thus with six, etc., there are eighteen.

original: “Catthe”ti eko ca dasa cāti cattasamāse “amādī”ti ekena adhikā dasāti tatiyāsamāse vā kate “ekatthatāya”nti vibhattilopo. Eva+mupari ca.
analyzed: catthā iti ekaḥ ca dasa ca ati catta samāse ama ādi iti ekena adhikāḥ dasa ati tatiyā samāse vā kate vibhatti lopaḥ evam upari ca
translated: “Catthe” means “eko ca dasa cā” . In the compound “amādī” , “ekatthatāya” is the elision of the case-ending, after the addition of one to ten, or after the making of the third case compound. Similarly above.

original: 3,102. Ekaṭṭhāna+mā
analyzed: ekaṭṭhānamā
translated: In the case of the single

original: Ekaaṭṭhānaṃ ā hoti dase pare.
analyzed: ekaaṭṭhānam ā hoti dase pare
translated: Ā is in the place of the single, when ten follows.

original: 3,103. Ra saṃkhyāto vā
analyzed: ra saṃkhyātaḥ vā
translated: Ra from a numeral

original: Saṃkhyāto parassa dasassa ra hoti vibhāsā. Sa ca “pañcamiyaṃ parassā”ti vattamāne
analyzed: saṃkhyātaḥ parassa dasassa ra hoti vibhāsā sa ca pañcamiyam parassa ati vattamāne
translated: Ra is in the place of the ten, when it follows, by way of analysis. And that is “pañcamiyaṃ parassā” .

original: “ādissā”ti dakārasseva hoti. Ekārasa ekādasa. Ekārasahi ekādasahi. Ekārasannaṃ ekādasannaṃ.
analyzed: ādissa ati dakārassa iva hoti ekārasaḥ ekādasaḥ ekārasahi ekādasahi ekārasannam ekādasannam
translated: When it is said, “ādissā”, it is only the final vowel that is lengthened. Ekārasa ekādasa. Ekārasahi ekādasahi. Ekārasannaṃ ekādasannaṃ.

original: Ekārasasu ekādasasu. Eva+mekādasaiccādipi.
analyzed: ekārasasu ekādasasu evam ekādasa e c ca ādi pi
translated: In the eleven, in the eleven. Thus eleven, etc.

original: 3,94. Ā saṃkhyāyā satādo nāññatthe
analyzed: ā saṃkhyāyāḥ sa ta ādaḥ na aññatthe
translated: Ā is for number, in the sense of “not other than.”

original: Saṃkhyāya+muttarapade dvissā hoti asatādo nāññatthe.
analyzed: saṃkhyā ayam uttara pade dvissā hoti a sata adaḥ na aññatthe
translated: In the sense of “not other than,” dvīsu becomes dvīhi when the following word is a number.

original: Āviṭṭhaliṅgattā saṃkhyāyaṃ uttarapade saliṅgeneva visesanaṃ bhavati.
analyzed: uttara pade sa liṅgena iva visesanam bhavati
translated: Because of the inclusion of the gender, the following word is a gender-specific determinative, as it were, when it is a number.

original: Suddhaṃ missañca saṃkiṇṇaṃ, upasajjanameva ca;
analyzed: suddham missam ca saṃkiṇṇam upasajjanam eva ca
translated: Pure, mixed, and compounded, and also connected,

original: Āviṭṭha+matha vā+byattaṃ, chadhā liṅgaṃ vivaṃyate.🔽Ettha yathākkamaṃ rukkho latā paṇṇaṃti suddhaṃ. Ghaṭo ghaṭī, vajiro vajiraṃ, vedanā🔽vedanaṃti missaṃ. Taṭo taṭī taṭaṃti saṃkiṇṇaṃ. Sukko paṭo, sukkā paṭi, sukkaṃ vatthaṃti
analyzed: āviṭṭham atha vā a byattam chadhā liṅgam  ettha yathākkamam rukkhaḥ latā suddham ghaṭaḥ ghaṭī vajiraḥ vajiram vedanā  vedanam ti missam taṭaḥ taṭī taṭam ti saṃkiṇṇam sukkaḥ paṭaḥ sukkā paṭi sukkam vattham ti
translated: included, and also indefinite: the gender is divided into six kinds.

original: upasajjanaṃ. Rājā saraṇaṃ, guṇo pamāṇaṃti āviṭṭhaṃ. Tuvaṃ ahaṃ kati pañcāti abyattaṃ.
analyzed: upasajjanam rājā saraṇam guṇaḥ pamāṇam ti āviṣṭham aham kati abyattam
translated: Here, a tree, a creeper, a leaf: pure. A pot, a pot, a diamond, a diamond, a feeling, a feeling: mixed. A bank, a bank, a bank: compounded. A white cloth, white cloths, a white cloth: connected. A king, a refuge, a quality, a measure: included. You, I, how many, five: indefinite.

original: Iti liṅgaṃ veditabbaṃ. Dvādasa.
analyzed: iti liṅgam veditabbam dvādasa
translated: Thus the gender should be understood. Twelve.

original: 3,98. Bā cattālīsā do
analyzed: bā cattālīsā do
translated: Bā cattālīsā do

original: Dvissa bā vā hoti cattālīsā do nāññatthe. Rāde se bārasa.
analyzed: dvissa bā vā hoti cattālīsā daḥ na aññatthe ra āde se bārasa
translated: In the sense of “not other than,” dvīsu becomes dvīhi or bā when cattālīsā is the following word. In the sense of “other than,” dvīsu becomes dvīhi or bā when bārasa is the following word.

original: 3,95. Tisse
analyzed: tisse
translated: Tisse

original: Saṃkhyāya+muttarapade tissa e hota+satādo nā+ññatthe.
analyzed: saṃkhyā yam uttara pade tissaḥ e hota sata ādaḥ na aññatthe
translated: After a numeral, e is the substitute for the preceding hundred, etc., in the sense of ‘not’.

original: 3,104. Chatīhi ḷo ca
analyzed: chatīhi ḷo ca
translated: After chatti, ḷo and ro.

original: Chatīhi parassa dasassa ḷo hoti ro ca. Teḷasa terasa.🔽3,100. Catussa cuco dase
analyzed: chatīhi parassa dasassa ḷaḥ hoti raḥ ca teḷasa terasa  catuḥ sa cucaḥ dase
translated: After chatti, ḷo and ro are the substitutes for the preceding dasa. Teḷasa, terasa.🔽After catussa, cu and co, or dase.

original: Catussa cu+co honti vā dase pare. Dvitte cuddasa coddasa catuddasa.🔽3,99. Vīsatidasesu pañcassa paṇṇa+pannā
analyzed: catussa cucaḥ honti vā dase pare dvitte cuddasa coddasa catuddasa  vīsatidasesu pañcassa paṇṇa pannā
translated: After catussa, cu and co are the substitutes for the preceding dase. Dvitte, cuddasa, coddasa, catuddasa.

original: Vīsati sesu paresu pañcassa paṇṇa+pannā honti yathākkamaṃ. Pannarasa pañcadasa.
analyzed: vīsati sesu paresu pañcassa paṇṇa pannāḥ honti yathākkamam pannarasa pañcadasa
translated: After vīsatī and dase, paṇṇa and panna are the substitutes for the preceding pañca. Pannarasa, pañcadasa.

original: 3,101. Chassa so
analyzed: chassa saḥ
translated: After chassa, so.

original: Chassa so-icca+ya+mādeso hoti se pare. Soḷasa sorasa. Sattarasa sattadasa. “Ekaṭṭhāna+mā”ti ā, aṭṭhārasa aṭṭhādasa.
analyzed: chassa so iti ayam ādesaḥ hoti se pare soḷasa sorasa sattarasa sattadasa eka ṭṭhānam āti ā aṭṭhārasa aṭṭhādasa
translated: After chassa, so is the substitute for the preceding se. Soḷasa, sorasa, sattarasa, sattadasa. “Ekaṭṭhāna+mā”ti ā, aṭṭhārasa, aṭṭhādasa.

original: Ūnā ca sā vīsati cāti “visesana+mekatthene”ti visesanasamāse “itthiyaṃ bhāsitapumi+tthī pume+vekatthe”ti pumatte ca kate ekena ūnā vīsatīti tatiyāsamāse ekūnavīsati.
analyzed: ūnā ca sā vīsati ca ati visesanam ekatthena iti visesana samāse itthiyam bhāsita pumitthī pum eva ekatthā iti pum atte ca kate ekena ūnā vīsati iti tatiyā samāse ekūnavīsati
translated: Ūnā ca sā vīsati cāti “visesana+mekatthene”ti visesanasamāse “itthiyaṃ bhāsitapumi+tthī pume+vekatthe”ti pumatte ca kate ekena ūnā vīsatīti tatiyāsamāse ekūnavīsati.

original: Vīsatiādayo ānavutiyā itthiliṅge+kavacanā. Bho ekūnavīsati. Ekūnavīsatiṃ. Ekūnavīsatyā ekūnavīsatiyā. Ekūnavīsatyaṃ ekūnavīsatiyaṃ ekūnavīsatyā ekūnavīsatiyā. Matisamaṃ.🔽Evaṃ vīsati, ekavīsati, dvāvīsati bāvīsati, tevīsati catuvīsatippabhutayo. Paṇṇaādese paṇṇavīsati pañcavīsati. Evaṃ chabbīsati, sattavīsati, aṭṭhavīsati.🔽Ekena ūnā tiṃsati tiṃsā vāti ekūnatiṃsati ekūnatiṃsā vā. Karaṇe ekūnatiṃsāya. Ekūnatiṃsāya,

original: Pa parā apa saṃ anu ava o ni du vi adhi api ati su u abhi pati pari upa ā ime vīsati pādayo. Pādayo hi jotakā, na vācakā.
analyzed: pa parā apa sam anu ava o ni du vi adhi api ati su u abhi pati pari upa ā ime vīsati pādayaḥ pādayaḥ hi jotakāḥ na vācakā
translated: For pādayo are mere markers, not denotators.

original: Tattha pa-saddo pakārā+dikamma, padhāna+ntobhāva, viyoga, tappara, bhusattha, sambhava,
analyzed: tattha pasaddo pakāra ādi kamma padhāna antobhāva viyoga tad para bhusattha sambhava
translated: Herein, the word pa is a prefix, a root, an indeclinable, a separation, a superlative, an intensifier, an origin,🔽a satisfaction, an unpolluted state, an aspiration, and so on.

original: titti, anāvila, patthanādīsu. Yathā pakāre-paññā. Ādikamme-vippakataṃ, padhāne-paṇītaṃ,🔽antobhāve-pakkhittaṃ, khittanti peraṇaṃ, pakkhittanti antokaraṇaṃ, dhātvatthassa
analyzed: titti anāvila patthana ādīsu yathā pakāre paññā ādi kamme vippakatam padhāne paṇītam  antobhāvepakkhittam khittanti peraṇam pakkhittanti antokaraṇam dhātvatthassa
translated: As a prefix: paññā (wisdom). As a root: vippakataṃ (done). As an indeclinable: paṇītaṃ (excellent).🔽As an indeclinable: pakkhittaṃ (thrown). Khittanti peraṇaṃ (thrown is an outer action). Pakkhittanti antokaraṇaṃ (thrown is an inner action). Because the meaning of the root is overridden.

original: bādhitattā. Vutthañhi –
analyzed: bādhita ttā
translated: For this is said:🔽“Some override the meaning of the root,🔽Some conform to it,

original: Dhātvatthaṃ bādhate koci, koci taṃ anuvattate;
analyzed: dhātvattham bādhate koci koci tam anuvattate
translated: Some distinguish it in a particular way,

original: Tameva+ñño viseseti, upasaggagatī tidhāti.
analyzed: viseseti upasagga gatī tidhā ti
translated: By prefix, by case-ending, and by word-group.”

original: Ettha ca “anuruddhakā me saṅgāmayuddhe”ti ca ime upasaggā dhātvatthaṃ visesenti nāma.
analyzed: ettha ca anuruddhakāḥ me ca ime upasaggāḥ dhātu attham visesenti nāma
translated: And here the prefixes anuruddhakā me saṅgāmayuddhe (I have no enemies in the battle of the war of the Saṅgha) distinguish the meaning of the root.

original: Viyoge-pavāsī, tappare-pācariyo, bhusatthe-pavuddhakāyo, sambhave-himavantā gaṅgā
analyzed: viyogepavāsī gaṅgā
translated: As a separation: pavāsī (one who lives apart). As a superlative: pācariyo (teacher of teachers). As an intensifier: pavuddhakāyo (one whose body is well developed). As an origin: himavantā gaṅgā (the Ganges from the Himalayas).

original: pabhavati, tittiyaṃ-pahūta+mannaṃ, anāvile-pasanna+mudakaṃ, patthane-paṇihitaṃ.🔽Parāiti parihāni, parājaya, gati, vikkamā+masanādīsu. Yathā parihāniyaṃ-parābhavo. Parājaye-parājito, gatiyaṃ-parāyanaṃ, vikkame-parakkamati, āmasane-aṅgassa parāmasanaṃ.
analyzed: pabhavati tittiyam pahūtam annam an āvila pasannam udakam pattha nepaṇihitam  parāiti parājaya gati vikkama āmasana ādīsu yathā parihāniyam parābhavaḥ parājaye parājitaḥ gatiyam parāyanam vikkame parakkamati āmasane aṅgassa parāmasanam
translated: (It means) abundance, satisfaction, plenty of food, clear, unclouded, pure water, and what is placed in a bowl.🔽(It means) loss, defeat, destination, and going, etc. As in loss: (it means) defeat. In defeat: (it means) defeated. In destination: (it means) refuge. In going: (it means) he goes forth. In touching: (it means) touching a limb.

original: Apaiti apagata, garaha, vajjana, pūjā, padussanādīsu. Yathā apagate-apamāno apeto, garahe-apagabbho, vajjane-apasālāya āyanti vāṇijā, pūjāyaṃ-vuddhāpacāyī, padussane-aparajjhanti.
analyzed: apaiti apagata garaha vajjana pūjā padussana ādīsu yathā apagate apamānaḥ apetaḥ garahe apagabbhaḥ vajjane apasālāya āyanti vāṇijā pūjā āyaṃvuddha apacāyī padussane aparajjhanti
translated: (It means) gone away, removed, blame, censure, worship, and transgression, etc. As in gone away: (it means) measureless, departed. In blame: (it means) free from the womb. In censure: the merchants come to the house without a roof. In worship: one who honours the elders. In transgression: they do not transgress.

original: Saṃiti samodhāna, sammāsama, samantabhāva, saṃgata, saṃkhepa, bhusattha, saha+ppattha,
analyzed: saṃiti samodhāna sammāsama samantabhāva saṃgata saṃkhepa bhusattha sahappattha
translated: (It means) combination, right concentration, all-round state, connection, summary, abundance, together with,

original: pabhavā+bhimukhabhāva, vidhāna, punappuna, karaṇa, samiddhādīsu. Yathā samodhāne-sandhi,
analyzed: pabhava abhimukha bhāva vidhāna punappuna karaṇa samiddha ādīsu yathā
translated: (it means) facing, arrangement, again and again, doing, and success, etc. As in combination: (it means) a bond,

original: sammāsame-samādhi, sampayutto, samantabhāve-saṃkiṇṇaṃ, samullapanā, saṃgate-saṅgamo,
analyzed: sampayuttaḥ samanta bhāve saṃkiṇṇam samullapanā saṃgate saṅgamaḥ
translated: in right concentration: (it means) concentration, associated, in all-round state: mixed, arising, in connection: a gathering,

original: saṃkhepe-samāso, bhusatthe-sārattho, sahatthe-saṃvāso, appatthe-samaggho, pabhave-sambhavo,
analyzed: saṃkhepe samāsaḥ bhu satthe sāratthaḥ saha atthe saṃvāsaḥ appatthe samagghaḥ pabhave sambhavaḥ
translated: In the sense of ‘collection’ (samukti) it is ‘a collection’ (samuha); in the sense of ‘abundance’ it is ‘meaningful’ (sārtha); in the sense of ‘hand’ it is ‘living together’ (saṃvāsa); in the sense of ‘not enough’ it is ‘united’ (samagga); in the sense of ‘origin’ it is ‘origin’ (sam-bhava);

original: abhimukhabhāve-sammukhaṃ. Saṃgate-saṃgaṇhāti, vidhāne-saṃvutaṃ, punappunakaraṇe-sandhāvati,
analyzed: abhimukha bhāve sammukham saṃgate saṃgaṇhāti vidhāne saṃvutam punappunakaraṇe sandhāvati
translated: in the sense of ‘facing’ it is ‘in front’ (sammukha). In the sense of ‘coming together’ it is ‘he gathers’ (saṃgaṇhāti); in the sense of ‘arrangement’ it is ‘controlled’ (saṃvuta); in the sense of ‘repeated action’ it is ‘he runs’ (saṃdhāvati);

original: samiddhiyaṃ-sampanno.🔽Anuiti anugatā+nupacchinna, pacchāttha, bhusattha, sādissa, hīna, tatiyattha, lakkhaṇi+tthambhūtakkhāna,
analyzed: samiddhiyam sampannaḥ  anuiti anugata anupacchinna pacchāttha bhusattha sa ādissa hīna tatiyattha
translated: in the sense of ‘being well-developed’ it is ‘accomplished’ (sampanna).

original: bhāga, vicchādīsu. Anugate-anveti, anupacchinne-anusayo, pacchātthe-anurathaṃ, bhusatthe-anuratto,
analyzed: bhāga vicchā ādīsu anugate anveti anupacchinne anusayaḥ pacchātthe anuratham bhusatthe anurattaḥ
translated: In the sense of ‘following’ it is ‘followed’ (anugata); in the sense of ‘not cut off’ it is ‘latent tendency’ (anusaya); in the sense of ‘after’ it is ‘after’ (anuratha); in the sense of ‘abundance’ it is ‘pleased’ (anuratta);

original: sādisse-anurūpaṃ, hīne-anusāriputtaṃ paññavanto, tatiyatthe-nadi+manvavasitā senā,
analyzed: hīneanusāri puttam paññavanto senā
translated: in the sense of ‘suitable’ it is ‘suitable’ (anurūpa); in the sense of ‘inferior’ it is ‘follower’ (anusāriputta); in the sense of ‘third’ it is ‘not crossed by the river’ (nadi+manvavasitā);

original: lakkhaṇerukkha+manuvijjotate vijju, itthambhūtakhyāne-sādhu devadatto mātara+manu,
analyzed: lakkhaṇe rukkham anu vijjotate vijju ittham bhūta khyāne sādhu devadattaḥ mātaram anu
translated: in the sense of ‘having such a characteristic’ it is ‘the tree shines with lightning’ (rukkha+manuvijjotate vijju); in the sense of ‘having such an origin’ it is ‘well done, Devadatta, with your mother’ (sādhu devadatto mātara+manu);

original: bhāge-ya+dettha maṃ anu siyā, taṃ dīyatu, vicchāyaṃ-rukkhaṃ rukkhaṃ anu vijjotate cando.
analyzed: mam anu siyā tam dīyatu vicchāyaṃrukkham rukkham anu vijjotate cando
translated: in the sense of ‘part’ it is ‘whatever is here for me, let that be given’ (ya+dettha maṃ anu siyā, taṃ dīyatu); in the sense of ‘separation’ it is ‘the moon shines from tree to tree’ (rukkhaṃ rukkhaṃ anu vijjotate cando).

original: Avaiti adhobhāga, viyoga, paribhava, jānana, suddhi nicchaya, desa, theyyādīsu. Adhobhāge-avakkhittacakkhu,
analyzed: avaiti adhobhāga viyoga paribhava jānana suddhi nicchaya desa theyya ādīsu adhobhāge avakkhitta cakkhu
translated: Avaiti is found in the sense of ‘downward’, ‘separation’, ‘contempt’, ‘knowing’, ‘purity’, ‘certainty’, ‘place’, and ‘theft’ etc.🔽In the sense of ‘downward’ (there is) one whose eyes are cast down.

original: viyoge-avakokilaṃ vanaṃ, paribhave-avajānanaṃ, avamaññati, jānane-avagacchati. suddhiyaṃ–vodānaṃ
analyzed: viyoge avakokilam vanam paribhave avajānanam avamaññati jānane avagacchati suddhiyam vā udānam
translated: In the sense of ‘separation’ (there is) the Kokila wood. In the sense of ‘contempt’ (there is) despising, despising. In the sense of ‘knowing’ (there is) understanding. In the sense of ‘purity’ (there is) purification.

original: (rūpasiddhi), Nicchaye-avadhāraṇaṃ, dese-avakāso, theyye-avahāro.
analyzed: rūpa siddhi dese avakāsaḥ
translated: (rūpasiddhi), In the sense of ‘certainty’ (there is) a definition. In the sense of ‘place’ (there is) an opportunity. In the sense of ‘theft’ (there is) a robbery.🔽Oiti is seen in the sense of ‘descending’, ‘taking out’, and ‘purity’ etc.

original: Oiti oroharaṇa, nīharaṇa, suddhiādīsu dissati. Orohaṇe-pāsādā orohati, nīharaṇe-omukkupāhano, suddhiyaṃ-odātaṃ.
analyzed: o iti oroharaṇa nīharaṇa suddhi ādīsu dissati orohaṇe pāsādā orohati
translated: In the sense of ‘descending’ (there is) descending from a palace. In the sense of ‘taking out’ (there is) a removal of the yoke. In the sense of ‘purity’ (there is) white.

original: Niiti, nissesa, niggata, nīharaṇa,+ntopavesanā+bhāva, nisedhana, nikkhanta, pātubhāvā+vadhāraṇa,🔽vibhajana, upamu+padhāraṇā+vasāna, cheka, nīharaṇā+varaṇādīsu. Nissese-nirutti, niggate-nikkileso,
analyzed: niiti nissesa niggata nīharaṇa anta upavesana abhāva nisedhana nikkhanta pātubhāva avadhāraṇa  vibhajana upam upadhāraṇa avasāna cheka nīharaṇa āvaraṇa ādīsu nissese nirutti niggate nikkilesaḥ
translated: Niiti is found in the sense of ‘without remainder’, ‘gone out’, ‘taking out’, ‘absence of internal entry’, ‘prohibition’, ‘having gone forth’, ‘manifestation’, ‘definition’,🔽‘distinction’, ‘simile’, ‘placing’, ‘conclusion’, ‘excellence’, ‘taking out’, ‘covering’ etc. In the sense of ‘without remainder’ (there is) a language. In the sense of ‘gone out’ (there is) a faultless one.

original: niyyāti, nīharaṇe-niddhāraṇaṃ, antopavesane-nikhāto, abhāve-nimmakkhikaṃ, nisedhe-nivāreti,
analyzed: niyyāti nīharaṇe niddhāraṇam antopavesane nikhātaḥ abhāve nimmakkhikam nisedhe nivāreti
translated: In the sense of ‘going out’ (there is) a removal. In the sense of ‘taking out’ (there is) a removal. In the sense of ‘internal entry’ (there is) a burial. In the sense of ‘absence’ (there is) a non-grease. In the sense of ‘prohibition’ (there is) a prevention.

original: nikkhante-nibbānaṃ, pātubhāve-nimmitaṃ, avadhāraṇe-nicchayo, vibhajane-niddeso. Upamāyaṃ-nidassanaṃ,
analyzed: nikkhantenibbānam pātubhāvenimmitam avadhāraṇenicchayaḥ vibhajaneniddesaḥ upamāyam nidassanam
translated: In going forth, in appearing, in determining, in analysis, in illustration,

original: upadhāraṇe-nisāmanaṃ, avasāne-niṭṭhitaṃ, cheke-nipuṇo, nīharaṇe-nīharati, issa dīgho. Āvaraṇe-nīvaraṇaṃ.🔽Duiti asobhaṇā+bhāva, kucchitā+samiddhi, kiccha, virūpatādīsu. Asobhaṇe-duggandho,
analyzed: avasāneniṭṭhitam chekenipuṇaḥ nīharaṇenīharati dīghaḥ āvaraṇenīvaraṇam  asobhaṇa abhāva kucchi tā samiddhi kiccha virūpa tā ādīsu
translated: in reminding, in conclusion, in skill, in drawing out, in long, in obstruction.🔽In ugliness, in badness, in abundance, in difficulty, in ugliness, etc. In ugliness, in bad smell,

original: abhāve-dubbhikkhaṃ, kucchite – dukkaṭaṃ. Asamiddhiyaṃ-dussassaṃ, kicche-dukkaraṃ,
analyzed: a bhāve dubbhikkham kucchite dukkaṭam
translated: in non-existence, in famine, in badness, in non-abundance, in difficulty, in hard to do,

original: virūpatāyaṃ-dubbaṇṇo dummukho.🔽Viiti visesa, vividha, viruddha, vigata, viyoga, virūpatādīsu. Visese-vimutti, visiṭṭho, vividhe-vimati, viruddhe-vivādo, vigate-vimalaṃ, viyoge-vippayutto, virūpatāyaṃ-virūpo.
analyzed: dummukhaḥ  viiti visesa vividha viruddha vigata viyoga virūpa tā ādīsu visese vimutti visiṭṭhaḥ vividhe vimati viruddhe vivādaḥ vigate vimalam viyoge vippayuttaḥ virūpa tā ayam virūpaḥ
translated: in ugliness, in ugly-faced.🔽In distinction, in variety, in contradiction, in absence, in separation, in ugliness, etc. In distinction, in freedom, in distinguished, in variety, in disagreement, in stainless, in unassociated, in ugly.

original: Adhiiti adhiki+ssarū+paribhāvā+dhibhavana+jjhāyā+dhiṭṭhāna, nicchaya, pāpuṇanādīsu.
analyzed: adhi iti
translated: In excess, in abundance, in surpassing, in subduing, in meditation, in resolve, in determination, in attaining, etc.

original: Adhike-adhisīlaṃ, issare-adhipati, adhi brahmadatte pañcālā, uparibhāve-adhirohati,
analyzed: adhike adhisīlam issare adhipati adhi brahmadatte pañcālā upari bhāve adhirohati
translated: In the sense of ‘more’ (adhika) and ‘higher virtue’ (adhisīla), in the sense of ‘lord’ (issara) and ‘master’ (adhipati), in the sense of ‘Brahmadatta’ (adhibhaddanta) and ‘Pañcāla’ (adhipañcāla), in the sense of ‘higher state’ (adhiroha) and ‘rising up’ (uparibhāva),

original: pathaviṃ adhisessati, adhibhavane-adhibhavati, ajjhāyane-byākaraṇa+madhīte, adhiṭṭhāne-bhūmikampādiṃ
analyzed: pathavim adhisessati adhibhavane adhibhavati ajjhāyane byākaraṇam adhīte adhiṭṭhāne bhūmikampa ādim
translated: In ‘higher morality’ (adhike-adhisīlaṃ), in ‘the lord’ (issare-adhipati), in ‘the Brahmadattas of the Pañcāla country’ (adhibhavane-adhibhavati), in ‘he studies the grammar’ (ajjhāyane-byākaraṇa+madhīte), in ‘he resolves on an earthquake, etc.’ (adhitiṭṭhāne-bhūmikampādiṃ

original: adhiṭṭhāti, nicchaye-adhimokkho, pāpuṇane-bhogakkhandhaṃ adhigacchati.
analyzed: adhiṭṭhāti pāpuṇane bhoga kkhandham adhigacchati
translated: adhiṭṭhāti), in ‘the resolve’ (nicchaye-adhimokkho), in ‘he obtains’ (pāpuṇane-bhogakkhandhaṃ adhigacchati).

original: Apiiti sambhāvanā+pekkhā, samuccaya, garaha, pañhādīsu. Sambhāvanāyaṃ-api dibbesu
analyzed: api iti sambhāvanā apekkhā samuccaya garaha pañha ādīsu sambhāvanā ayam api dibbesu
translated: ‘Even’ (api) is a supposition, a look, an addition, a censure, in questions, etc. In supposition: ‘Even the divine

original: kāmesu, merumpi vinivijjhitvā gaccheyya, apekkhāyaṃ-ayampi dhammo aniyato, samuccaye-itipi
analyzed: kāmesu merum pi vinivijjhitvā gaccheyya apekkha ayam ayam pi dhammo aniyataḥ samuccaye iti pi
translated: pleasures … would go through even Mount Meru.’ In a look: ‘This rule too is not fixed.’ In addition: ‘He is also

original: arahaṃ, antampi antaguṇampi ādāya, garahe-api amhākaṃ paṇḍitaka, pañhe-api bhante bhikkhaṃ labhittha.
analyzed: araham antam pi anta guṇam pi ādāya garahe api amhākam paṇḍitaka pañhe api bhante bhikkham labhittha
translated: an Arahant.’ In censure: ‘Even our clever one.’ In a question: ‘Even, venerable sir, did you get alms?’

original: Atiiti atikkamanā+tikkantā+tisaya, bhusatthādīsu. Atikkame-atirocati amhehi, atīto, atikkante-accantaṃ, atisaye-atikusalo, bhusatthe-atikodho, ativuddhi.
analyzed: ati iti atikkamana atikkanta atisaya bhusattha ādīsu atikkame atirocati amhehi atītaḥ atikkante accantam atisaye atikusalaḥ bhusatthe atikodhaḥ ati vuddhi
translated: ‘Over’ (ati) is a going beyond, a gone beyond, a surpassing, in much, etc. In a going beyond: ‘He outshines us.’ In a gone beyond: ‘He is beyond.’ In a surpassing: ‘He is very skilled.’ In much: ‘He is very angry.’ In a growth: ‘He has grown very much.’

original: Suiti sobhaṇa, suṭṭhu, sammā, samiddhi, sukhatthādīsu. Sobhaṇe-sugandho, suṭṭhu+sammādatthesu-suṭṭhu gato sugato, sammā gatotipi sugato, samiddhiyaṃ-subhikkhaṃ, sukhatthe-sukaro.
analyzed: su iti sobhaṇa suṭṭhu sammā samiddhi sukha attha ādīsu sobhaṇe sugandho suṭṭhu sammā datthesu suṭṭhu gataḥ sugataḥ sammā gataḥ iti pi sugataḥ samiddhiyam subhikkham sukha atthesu karo
translated: Su means beautiful, good, right, complete, easy, etc. In beautiful, good-smelling, good, right, in the sense of right, gone well, gone right, also gone well, in complete, well-favoured, in easy, easy to do.

original: Uiti uggatu+ddhakamma, padhāna, viyoga, sambhava, attalābha, satti, sarūpakathanādīsu.
analyzed: padhāna viyoga sambhava atta lābha satti sarūpa kathana ādīsu
translated: U means to rise, to rise up, to effort, to separation, to origination, to gain of self, to a kind of tree, to the telling of one’s own form, etc.

original: Uggate-uggacchati, uddhakamme-āsanā uṭṭhito, ukkhepo, padhāne-uttamo, lokuttaro,
analyzed: uggate uggacchati uddha kamme āsanā uṭṭhitaḥ ukkhepaḥ padhāne uttamaḥ lokuttaro
translated: In rising, it rises; in rising up, he rises from his seat, throwing up; in effort, supreme, transcendent;

original: viyoge-ubbhāsito, sambhave-ubbhuto, attalābhe-uppannaṃ ñāṇaṃ, sattiyaṃ-ussahati gantuṃ,
analyzed: sambhave ubbhutaḥ atta lābhe uppannam ñāṇam sattiyam ussahati gantum
translated: in separation, it shines forth; in origination, it originates; in gain of self, knowledge that has arisen; in a kind of tree, it is able to go;

original: sarūpakathane-uddisati suttaṃ.🔽Abhiiti abhimukhabhāva, visiṭṭhā+dhiku+ddhakamma, kula, sāruppa, vandana, lakkhaṇi+tthambhūtakkhāna,
analyzed: sarūpa kathane uddisati suttam  abhi iti abhimukha bhāva visiṭṭha adhikuddha kamma kula sāruppa vandana
translated: in the telling of one’s own form, it recites a sutta.

original: vicchādīsu. Abhimukhabhāve-abhimukho, abhikkamati, visiṭṭhe-abhidhammo, adhike-abhivasati,
analyzed: viccha ādīsu abhimukha bhāve abhimukhaḥ abhikkamati visiṭṭhe abhidhammaḥ adhike abhivasati
translated: Abhi means facing, pre-eminent, rising up, family, suitable, paying homage, characteristic, and the time of the destruction of the world, etc. In facing, facing, it advances; in pre-eminent, the Abhidhamma; in superior, it lives in;🔽in

original: uddhakamme-abhiruhati. Kule-abhijāto, sāruppe-abhirūpo, vandane-abhivādeti, lakkhaṇādīsu purimasamaṃ.
analyzed: uddha kamme abhiruhati kule abhijātaḥ sāruppe abhirūpaḥ vandane abhivādeti lakkhaṇa ādīsu purima samam
translated: In the sense of “rising up” (uddha): he ascends (abhi-ruhati). In the sense of “noble birth”: he is of noble birth (abhi-jāto). In the sense of “handsome”: he is handsome (abhi-rūpo). In the sense of “worshipping”: he worships (abhi-vādeti). In the sense of “characteristic” and so on, it is the same as above.

original: Patiiti paṭigata, paṭiloma, paṭinidhi, paṭidāna, nisedha, nivattana, sādissa, paṭikaraṇā+dāna,
analyzed: patiiti paṭigata paṭiloma paṭinidhi paṭidāna nisedha nivattana sādissa paṭikaraṇādāna
translated: In the sense of “going back”: it is the opposite (paṭigata), going against the grain (paṭiloma), a pupil (paṭinidhi), a gift in return (paṭidāna), a prohibition (nisedha), turning back (nivatta), a substitute (sādissa), a gift in return (paṭikaraṇā+dāna),

original: paṭibodha, paṭicca, lakkhaṇitthambhūtakkhāna, bhāga, vicchādīsu. Paṭigate-paccakkhaṃ,
analyzed: paṭibodha paṭicca lakkhaṇitthambhūtakkhāna bhāga vicchādīsu paṭigatepaccakkham
translated: a reply (paṭibodha), a condition (paṭicca), a characteristic (lakkhaṇa), a part (bhāga), a covering (vicchādi), and so on. In the sense of “the opposite”: it is evident (paccakkhaṃ).

original: paṭilome-paṭisotaṃ, paṭinidhimhi-ācariyato pati sisso, paṭidāne-telatthikassa ghataṃ
analyzed: paṭilome paṭisotam paṭinidhimhi ācariyato sissaḥ paṭidāne telatthikassa
translated: In the sense of “going against the grain”: it is against the stream (paṭisotaṃ). In the sense of “a pupil”: a pupil (paṭinidhi) is one who is a pupil of a teacher. In the sense of “a gift in return”: one gives a pot (ghataṃ)

original: paṭidadāti, nisedhe-paṭisedheti, nivattane-paṭikkamati, sādisse-paṭirūpakaṃ, paṭikaraṇe-paṭikāro,
analyzed: paṭidadāti nisedhe paṭisedheti nivattane paṭikkamati sādisse paṭirūpakam paṭikaraṇe paṭikāraḥ
translated: in return (paṭidāna) for oil. In the sense of “a prohibition”: one prohibits (paṭisedheti). In the sense of “turning back”: one turns back (paṭikkamati). In the sense of “a substitute”: it is a substitute (paṭirūpakaṃ). In the sense of “a gift in return”: it is a gift in return (paṭikāro).

original: ādāne-paṭiggaṇhāti, paṭibodhe-paṭivedho, paṭicce-paccayo, lakkhaṇādīsu purimasamaṃ.
analyzed: ādāne paṭiggaṇhāti paṭibodhe paṭivedhaḥ paṭicce paccayaḥ lakkhaṇa ādīsu purima samam
translated: In the sense of “receiving”: one receives (paṭiggaṇhāti). In the sense of “a reply”: it is a reply (paṭivedho). In the sense of “a condition”: it is a condition (paccayo). In the sense of “characteristic” and so on, it is the same as above.

original: Pariiti samantatobhāva, pariccheda, vajjanā+liṅgana, nivasana, pūjā, bhojanā+vajānana,
analyzed: samantatobhāva pariccheda vajjana āliṅgana nivasana pūjā bhojana avajānana
translated: In the sense of “all around”: it is all around (samantato), a boundary (pariccheda), a fault (vajjanā), a sign (liṅga), a dwelling (ni

original: dosakkhāna, lakkhaṇādīsu. Samantha- tobhāve-parivuto, paricchede-pariññeyyaṃ, vajjane-pariharati,
analyzed: dosa kkhāna lakkhaṇa ādīsu paricchede pariññeyyam vajjane pariharati
translated: Surrounded by the state of being together, in the section, what is to be fully understood, in the case of what should be avoided, he avoids,

original: āliṅgane-parissajati, nivasane-yo vatthaṃ paridahessati, pūjāyaṃ-paricariyā, bhojane-bhikkhuṃ
analyzed: āliṅgane parissajati nivasane yaḥ vattham paridahessati pūjā ayam paricariyā bhojane bhikkhum
translated: in the case of embracing, he gives up, in the case of wearing, he who will put on a robe, in the case of worship, service, in the case of eating, a monk

original: parivisati, avajānane-paribhavati. Dosakkhāne-paribhāsati, lakkhaṇādīsu-rukkhaṃ pari
analyzed: parivisati avajānane paribhavati dosa khāne paribhāsati lakkhaṇa ādīsu rukkham pari
translated: serves, in the case of despising, he despises, in the case of the expression of anger, he reproaches, in the case of characteristics, etc., he thoroughly

original: vijjotate vijju iccādi.
analyzed: vijjotate vijju i t cādi
translated: knows a tree. Vijjotate vijju, etc.

original: Upaiti upagamana, samīpū+papatti, sādissā+dhiku+paribhāvā+nasana, dosakkhāna, saññā,
analyzed: upaiti upagamana samīpa upapatti saññā
translated: It approaches, going near, coming near, being similar, being superior, being reproached, being destroyed, in the case of the expression of anger, perception,

original: pubbakamma, pūjā, gayhākāra, bhusatthādīsu. Upagamane-nisinnaṃ vā upanisīdeyya, samīpe-upanagaraṃ,
analyzed: pubba kamma pūjā gayhākāra bhusattha ādīsu upagamane nisinnam vā upanisīdeyya samīpe upanagaram
translated: previous action, worship, the manner of being concealed, in the case of being abundant, etc. In the case of going near, he would sit down or sit near, in the case of being near, near the city,

original: upapattiyaṃ-saggaṃ lokaṃ upapajjati, atha vā upapatti=yutti, yathā upapattito ikkhatīti
analyzed: upapatti yaṃsaggam lokam upapajjati atha vā upapatti yutti yathā upapattitaḥ ikkhati iti
translated: in the case of coming near, he is reborn in the heavenly world, or else coming near = reason, just as he looks from the reason,

original: upekkhā, sādisse-upamānaṃ, upamā, adhike-upakhāriyaṃ doṇo, uparibhāve-upasampanno,
analyzed: upekkhā sā ādisse upamānam upamā adhike upakhāriyam doṇaḥ upari bhāve upasampanno
translated: equanimity, in the case of being similar, a simile, a comparison, in the case of being superior, a gift to be given, a measure, in the case of the state of being above, one who has gone forth,

original: anasane-upavāso, dosakkhāne-paraṃ upavadati, saññāyaṃ-upadhā, upasaggo, pubbakamme-upakkamo,
analyzed: an asane upavāsaḥ dosa kkhāne param upavadati saññā ayam upadhā upasaggaḥ pubba kamme upakkamaḥ
translated: In non-offence: Upavāsa. In confession of offences: He reviles another. In perception: Upadhā. In prefix: Upasagga. In prior action: Upakkama.

original: upakāro, pūjāyaṃ-buddhupaṭṭhāko, mātupaṭṭhānaṃ, gayhākāre-soceyyapaccupaṭṭhānaṃ,
analyzed: upakāro mātupaṭṭhānam gayhākāresoceyya paccupaṭṭhānam
translated: In assistance: Upakāra. In worship: Buddha-u-paṭṭhāko. In attendance on one’s mother: Mātu-paṭṭhāna. In the mode of carrying: Soceyya-paccupaṭṭhāna.

original: bhusatthe-upādānaṃ, upāyāso, upanissayoti.
analyzed: upāyāsaḥ upanissayaḥ ti
translated: In a vehicle: Upādāna. In anxiety: Upāyāsa. In dependence: Upanissaya.

original: Āiti abhimukhabhāvu+ddhakamma+mariyādā+bhividhi, patti+cchā, parissajana, ādikamma,
analyzed: ā iti
translated: It comes, it is raised up, it is a boundary, it is a mode, it is an attainment, it is a letting go, it is a beginning,

original: gahaṇa, nivāsana, samīpa, āvhānādīsu. Abhimukhabhāve-āgacchanti, uddhakamme-ārohati,
analyzed: gahaṇa nivāsana samīpa āvhāna ādīsu abhimukha bhāve āgacchanti uddha kamme ārohati
translated: it is a grasping, it is a dwelling, it is near, it is a calling, etc. In the sense of ‘it comes’: It comes. In the sense of ‘it is raised up’: He ascends.

original: mariyādāyaṃ-āpabbatā khettaṃ, abhividhimhi-ākumāraṃ yaso kaccāyanassa, pattiyaṃ-āpattiṃ🔽āpanno, icchāyaṃ-ākaṅkhā, parissajane-āliṅganaṃ, ādikamme-ārambho, gahaṇe-ādīyati,
analyzed: khettam abhividhimhi ākumāram yaso kaccāyanassa pattiyam āpattim  āpannaḥ icchā idam ākaṅkhā parissajane āliṅganam ādi kamme ārambhaḥ gahaṇe ādīyati
translated: In the sense of ‘it is a boundary’: The field is bounded by the mountain. In the sense of ‘it is a mode’: The glory of Kaccāyana is up to the prince. In the sense of ‘it is an attainment’: He has attained an attainment.🔽In the sense of ‘it is a wish’: Desire. In the sense of ‘it is a letting go’: Embracing. In the sense of ‘it is a beginning’: Commencement. In the sense of ‘it is a grasping’: It is grasped.

original: āliṅgati, (ālimpati, rū), nivāse-āvasatho, āvāso, samīpe-āsannaṃ, āvhāne-āmanteti.🔽Pa parā+pa sa+manva+va, o ni du rabhi byā+dhisu;
analyzed: āliṅgati ālimpati nivāse āvasathaḥ āvāsaḥ samīpe āsannam āvhāne āmanta iti 🔽pa parāpa samanvava o ni du rabhi byādhisu
translated: It embraces, it is clothed, it is a dwelling, it is a monastery, it is near, it is called.

original: Ati ni ppati pari apayo, upa ā iti vīsati;
analyzed: ati ni ppati pari apayaḥ upa ā iti vīsati
translated: Ati ni ppati pari apayo, upa ā iti vīsati;

original: Esa hi bho upasagga-vidhi+kkamato kathito.
analyzed: esa hi bho upasagga vidhi kkamataḥ kathitaḥ
translated: Esa hi bho upasagga-vidhi+kkamato kathito.

original: Ettha ca –
analyzed: ettha ca
translated: Ettha ca –

original: Upasagga+nipātā ca, paccayā ca ime tayo;
analyzed: upasagga nipātā ca paccayā ca ime tayo
translated: Upasagga+nipātā ca, paccayā ca ime tayo;

original: Neke+nekatthavācakā, iti neruttikā+bravuṃ.
analyzed: iti
translated: Neke+nekatthavācakā, iti neruttikā+bravuṃ.

original: 118. Asaṃkhyehi sabbāsaṃ
analyzed: asaṃkhyehi
translated: . Asaṃkhyehi sabbāsaṃ

original: Avijjamānasaṃkhyehi parāsaṃ sabbāsaṃ vibhattīnaṃ lopo hoti. Na santi ekavacanādisaṃkhyā
analyzed: a vijjamāna saṃkhyehi parāsam sabbāsam vibhattīnam lopaḥ hoti na santi ekavacana ādi saṃkhyā
translated: Avijjamānasaṃkhyehi parāsaṃ sabbāsaṃ vibhattīnaṃ lopo hoti. Na santi ekavacanādisaṃkhyā

original: etesanti asaṃkhyā, tesaṃ asaṃkhyānaṃ vibhattīnaṃ bhede asatipi syādividhānaṃ “mā
analyzed: asaṃkhyā tesam asaṃkhyānam vibhattīnam bhede sya ādi vidhānam mā
translated: etesanti asaṃkhyā, tesaṃ asaṃkhyānaṃ vibhattīnaṃ bhede asatipi syādividhānaṃ “mā

original: no ajja vikantiṃsū”tiādo vibhatyantattā padattasiddhīti vo+noādīnaṃ siddhiyā ca tesaṃ
analyzed: no ajja ca tesam
translated: no ajja vikantiṃsū”tiādo vibhatyantattā padattasiddhīti vo+noādīnaṃ siddhiyā ca tesaṃ

original: paṭhamādiatthe dassanato ca hoti. Pahāro parābhavo apahāro saṃhāro avahāro ohāro iccādi hoti.
analyzed: paṭhama ādi atthe dassanato ca hoti pahāro parābhavaḥ apahāro saṃhāraḥ avahāraḥ ohāraḥ iccādi hoti
translated: paṭhamādiatthe dassanato ca hoti. Pahāro parābhavo apahāro saṃhāro avahāro ohāro iccādi hoti.

original: Upecca+tthaṃ sajantīti, upasaggā hi pādayo;
analyzed: upecca attham sajanti iti upasaggāḥ hi pādayaḥ
translated: Upecca+tthaṃ sajantīti, upasaggā hi pādayo;

original: Cādī padādimajjhante, nipātā nipatantīti.
analyzed: ca ādī pada ādi majjha ante nipātāḥ nipatanti iti
translated: Cādī padādimajjhante, nipātā nipatantīti.

original: Opasaggikapadaṃ.
analyzed: opasaggika padam
translated: Opasaggikapadaṃ.

original: Samuccaya+vikappana+paṭisedha+pūraṇādiatthaṃ asattavācikaṃ nepātikaṃ.
analyzed: samuccaya vikappana paṭisedha pūraṇa ādi attham asatta vācikam nepātikam
translated: Nepātika is a word of non-existence, in the sense of ‘accumulation’, ‘alternative’, ‘prohibition’, ‘fulfilment’, etc.

original: Ca-iti samuccayā+nvācaya+itaretarayoga+samāhārā+vadhāraṇādīsu. Vā-iti vikappanu+pamāna+samuccaya+vavatthitavibhāsādīsu.
analyzed: ca eti samuccaya anvācaya etaretara yoga samāhāra avadhāraṇa ādīsu vā iti vikappan upamāna samuccaya vavatthita vibhāsa ādīsu
translated: Ca is used in the sense of ‘accumulation’, ‘consequence’, ‘reciprocal connection’, ‘combination’, ‘definition’, etc. Vā is used in the sense of ‘alternative’, ‘comparison’, ‘accumulation’, ‘distinction’, ‘discrimination’, etc.🔽Na, no, mā, a, alaṃ, halaṃ are used in the sense of ‘prohibition’.

original: Na, no, mā, a, alaṃ, halaṃ iccete paṭisedhe. “Dve paṭisedhā pakatiatthaṃ gamayantī”ti
analyzed: na no mā a alam halam icca ete paṭisedhe dve paṭisedhā pakati attham gamayanti iti
translated: “Two prohibitions convey the meaning of the natural state” (P. 11).

original: ñāyā “na tesaṃ pana rūpānaṃ paccayā na ca hontī”ti ettha na ca na honti-hontevāti🔽pakatiatthaṃ gamayati. Alaṃ pariyatti+bhūsanesu ca.
analyzed: ñāyāḥ na tesam pana rūpānam paccayāḥ na ca honti iti ettha na ca na honti hontā iva ati  pakati attham gamayati alam pariyatti bhūsanesu ca
translated: “But they are not conditions for those forms, and they are not non-existent” (P. 11). Here na ca na honti conveys the meaning of the natural state. Alaṃ is used in the sense of ‘sufficient’ and ‘ornamentation’.

original: Pūraṇatthaṃ duvidhaṃ attapūraṇaṃ padapūraṇañca, tattha atha, khalu, vata, atho, assu,
analyzed: pūraṇa ttham duvidham atta pūraṇam pada pūraṇam ca tattha atha khalu vata atho assu
translated: Pūraṇa is twofold: fulfilment of oneself and fulfilment of a word. In the fulfilment of a word, atha, khalu, vata, atho, assu,

original: yagghe, hi, carahi, naṃ, taṃ, ca, tu, vā, vo, pana, have, kīva, ha, tato, yathā,
analyzed: yat he hi nam tam ca tu vā vaḥ have kī iva ha tatas yathā
translated: yagghe, hi, carahi, naṃ, taṃ, ca, tu, vā, vo, pana, have, kīva, ha, tato, yathā,

original: sudaṃ, kho, ve, haṃ, enaṃ, (evaṃ, rū) seyyathidaṃ iccevamādi padapūraṇe. Tattha atha-iti
analyzed: sudam kho ve haṃ enam evam pada pūraṇe atha eti
translated: sudaṃ, kho, ve, haṃ, enaṃ, (evaṃ, rū) seyyathidaṃ are used. Atha is used in the sense of ‘then’, ‘at that time’, ‘at that moment’, ‘at that instant’, ‘at that very moment’, ‘at that very instant’, ‘at that very time’, ‘at that very moment’, ‘at that very instant’, ‘at that very time’, ‘at that very moment’, ‘at that very instant’, ‘at that very time’, ‘at that very moment’, ‘at that very instant’, ‘at that very time’, ‘at that very moment’, ‘at that very instant’, ‘at that very time’, ‘at that very moment’, ‘at that very instant’, ‘at that very time’, ‘at that very moment’, ‘at that very instant’, ‘at that very time’, ‘at that very moment’, ‘at that very instant’, ‘at that very time’, ‘at that very moment’, ‘at that very instant’, ‘at that very time’, ‘at that very moment’, ‘at that very instant’, ‘at that very time’, ‘at that very moment’, ‘at that very instant’,

original: pañhā+nantariyā+dhikārādīsu ca. Khalu-iti paṭisedhā+vadhāraṇa, pasiddhīsu ca. Vata+iti🔽ekaṃsa, khedā+nukampa, saṃkappesu ca. Atho-iti anvādese ca. Hi-iti hetu, avadhāraṇesu
analyzed: pañha anantariya adhikāra ādīsu ca khalu iti paṭisedha avadhāraṇa pasiddhīsu ca vata eti  ekaṃsa khedānukampa saṃkappesu ca athoiti anvādese ca hiiti hetu avadhāraṇesu
translated: and in the questions, the immediate (offences), the (formal) acts, etc. Khalu-iti means ‘indeed’, ‘certainly’, ‘verily’, and in prohibitions, and in definitions, and in well-known (things). Vata-iti means🔽‘just’, ‘only’, and in (expressions of) grief, and in (expressions of) compassion, and in (expressions of) doubt. Atha-iti means ‘then’, and in (expressions of) advice. Hi-iti means ‘because’, ‘for’, and in definitions,

original: ca. Tu-iti visesa, hetu, nivattanādīsu ca. Pana-iti visesepi. Have+ve iccete ekaṃsatthepi.
analyzed: ca tu iti visesa hetu nivattana ādīsu ca pana eti visese pi have ve icca ete ekaṃsatthepi
translated: and in (expressions of) certainty. Tu-iti means ‘but’, ‘however’, ‘nevertheless’, and in (expressions of) distinction, and in (expressions of) reason, and in (expressions of) prevention, etc. Pana-iti means ‘but’, ‘however’, ‘nevertheless’, and in (expressions of) distinction. Have and ve have the same meaning as tu.

original: Haṃ-visāda, vimhesupi. (Visāda, sambhavesu, rū). Seyyathidaṃti taṃ katamaṃti atthepi.
analyzed: haṃ visāda visāda sambhavesu tam katamam ti atthe pi
translated: Haṃ-iti means ‘alas’, ‘oh’, and in (expressions of) grief, and in (expressions of) doubt. (Rū) Seyyathidaṃ means ‘such as this’, and means ‘what is that?’ in the sense of ‘fulfilling the meaning’.

original: Atthapūraṇaṃ duvidhaṃ vibhattiyuttaṃ avibhattiyuttañca. Atthi, sakkā, labbhā iccete
analyzed: attha pūraṇam duvidham vibhatti yuttam a vibhatti yuttam ca atthi sakkā labbhā icca ete
translated: There are two kinds of fulfilling the meaning: that which is connected with a case-ending, and that which is not connected with a case-ending. Atthi, sakkā, labbhā, etc.🔽are (examples of fulfilling the meaning) in the first (case-ending). Āvuso, ambho, hambho, are, hare, re, je, etc.

original: paṭhamāyaṃ. Āvuso ambho hambho are hare re je iccete āmantaṇe. Divā bhiyyo (namo,
analyzed: āvuso ambho hambho are hare re je iccā ete āmantaṇe divā bhiyyas namo
translated: are (examples of fulfilling the meaning) in the vocative. Divā, bhiyyo, (namo, rū) etc.🔽are (examples of fulfilling the meaning) in the first and second (case-endings). Sayaṃ, sāmaṃ, saṃ, sammā, kinti, etc.

original: rū) iccete paṭhamādutiyāsu. Sayaṃ sāmaṃ saṃ sammā kinti iccete tatiyatthe. So+to+dhāpaccayantā
analyzed: rū iti ete paṭhamā dutiyāsu sayam sāmam sam sammā kinti iti ete tatiya tthe
translated: are (examples of fulfilling the meaning) in the third (case-ending). So, to, dhā, paccaya, etc.

original: ca suttaso padaso aniccato dukkhato ekadhā dvidhā iccādi. Tave+tuṃ paccayantā catutthiyāva,
analyzed: ca suttasaḥ padasaḥ aniccataḥ dukkhataḥ ekadhā dvidhā iccādi tava itum paccayantā catutthiyā ava
translated: and in the Suttas, in the words, “Impermanently, unpleasantly, and void,” “In one way, in two ways,” etc. But in the case of the fourth case, the locative, the locative ending is tuṃ, tu, tuṃ, tu,

original: kātave dātave, kātuṃ kāretuṃ, (dātuṃ, rū) dāpetuṃ iccādi. So+topaccayantā pañcamiyatthe,
analyzed: kātave dātave kātum kāretum dātum iti ādi sotā paccaya ntā pañcamiya tthe
translated: kātave, dātave, kātuṃ, kāretuṃ, dātuṃ, dāpetuṃ, etc. In the fifth case, the dative, the dative ending is so, so, so, so,

original: dīghaso oraso rājato vā corato vā iccādi. To satta- myatthepi tra+tthādipaccayantā
analyzed: dīghasaḥ orasaḥ rājataḥ vā corataḥ vā iti ca ādi taḥ satta mi atthe pi trattha ādi paccaya ntā
translated: dīghaso, oraso, rājato, vā corato, etc. In the seventh case, the ablative, the ablative ending is ta, ta, ta, ta,

original: ca, ekato purato pacchato passato piṭṭhito pādato sīsato aggato mūlato, yatra yattha
analyzed: ca ekatas puratas pacchatas passatas piṭṭhitas pādataḥ sīsataḥ aggataḥ mūlataḥ yatra yattha
translated: ca, ekato, purato, pacchato, passato, piṭṭhito, pādato, sīsato, aggato, mūlato, yatra yattha,

original: yahiṃ tatra tattha tahiṃ iccādi. Samantā sāmantā parito abhito samantato ekajjhaṃ
analyzed: tatra tattha tahiṃ iccādi samantā sāmantā paritas abhitas samantataḥ ekajjham
translated: yahiṃ, tatra tattha, tahiṃ, etc. In the locative, the locative ending is samantā, sāmantā, parito, abhito, samantato, ekajjhaṃ,

original: ekamantaṃ heṭṭhā upari uddhaṃ adho tiriyaṃ sammukhā paramukhā āvi raho tiro uccaṃ
analyzed: eka mantam heṭṭhā upari uddham adhas tiriyam sammukhā para mukhāḥ āvi raho tiras uccam
translated: ekamantaṃ, heṭṭhā, upari, uddhaṃ, adho, tiriyaṃ, sammukhā, paramukhā, āvi, raho, tiro, uccaṃ,

original: nīcaṃ anto antarā antaraṃ ajjhattaṃ bahiddhā bāhirā bāhiraṃ bahi oraṃ pāraṃ ārā ārakā
analyzed: nīcam antaḥ antarā antaram ajjhattam bahiddhā bāhirā bāhiram bahi oram pāram ārā ārakā
translated: nīcaṃ, anto, antarā, antaraṃ, ajjhattaṃ, bahiddhā, bāhirā, bāhiraṃ, bahi, oraṃ, pāraṃ, ārā, ārakā,

original: pacchā pure huraṃ pecca iccete sattamiyā. Sampati āyati ajja aparajjha suve sve uttarasuve
analyzed: pacchā pure huram pecca icca ite sattamiyā sampati āyati ajja aparajjha suve sve uttarasuve
translated: pacchā, pure, huraṃ, pecca, iccete sattamiyā. In the locative, the locative ending is sampati, āyati, ajja, aparajjha, suve, sve, uttarasuve,

original: (kisu, rū) hiyyo pare (parasuve, rū) sajju sāyaṃ pāto kālaṃ kallaṃ divā rattaṃ niccaṃ
analyzed: kisu rū pare parasuve rū sajju sāyam kālam kallam divā rattam niccam
translated: (Kisu, rū) hiyyo pare (parasuve, rū) sajju sāyaṃ pāto kālaṃ kallaṃ divā rattaṃ niccaṃ

original: satataṃ abhiṇhaṃ abhikkhaṇaṃ muhuṃ muhuttaṃ bhūtapubbaṃ purā yadā tadā (kadā, rū)
analyzed: satatam abhiṇham abhikkhaṇam muhum muhuttam bhūta pubbam purā yadā tadā kadā
translated: Satataṃ abhiṇhaṃ abhikkhaṇaṃ muhuṃ muhuttaṃ bhūtapubbaṃ purā yadā tadā (kadā, rū)

original: iccādayo kālasattamiyaṃ. Iti vibhattiyuttāni.
analyzed: iti vibhatti yuttāni
translated: Iccādayo kālasattamiyaṃ. Iti vibhattiyuttāni.

original: Avibhattiyuttesu appeva appevanāma nu iccete saṃsayatthe. Addhā aññadatthu taggha
analyzed: a vibhatti yuttesu appa iva appa iva nāma nu icca ete saṃsa yatthe addhā añña datthu taggha
translated: Avibhattiyuttesu appeva appevanāma nu iccete saṃsayatthe. Addhā aññadatthu taggha

original: jātu kāmaṃ sasakkaṃ iccete ekaṃsatthe. Evaṃ iti avadhāraṇe. Kacci nu nanu kathaṃ
analyzed: jātu kāmam sa sakkam iti ete ekaṃsatthe evam iti avadhāraṇe kacci nu nanu katham
translated: Jātu kāmaṃ sasakkaṃ iccete ekaṃsatthe. Evaṃ iti avadhāraṇe. Kacci nu nanu kathaṃ

original: (kiṃsu, rū) kiṃ iccete pucchanatthe. Evaṃ iti itthaṃ iccete nidassanatthe. Iti hetu+vākyaparisamattīsu
analyzed: kiṃsu rū kim icca ete pucchana atthe evam iti ittham icca ete nidassana atthe iti hetu vākya parisamattīsu
translated: (Kiṃsu, rū) kiṃ iccete pucchanatthe. Evaṃ iti itthaṃ iccete nidassanatthe. Iti hetu+vākyaparisamattīsu

original: ca. Yāva tāva yāvatā tāvatā kittāvatā ettāvatā kīva iccete paricchedanatthe. Evaṃ
analyzed: ca yāva tāva yāvatā tāvatā kittāvatā ettāvatā kīva iti ca ete paricchedana atthe evam
translated: Ca. Yāva tāva yāvatā tāvatā kittāvatā ettāvatā kīva iccete paricchedanatthe. Evaṃ

original: sāhu lahu opāyikaṃ paṭirūpaṃ āma sādhu iccete sampaṭicchanatthe. Tathā yathā yatheva
analyzed: sāhu lahu opāyikam paṭirūpam sādhu icca ete sampaṭicchana tthe tathā yathā yathā iva
translated: Sāhu lahu opāyikaṃ paṭirūpaṃ āma sādhu iccete sampaṭicchanatthe. Tathā yathā yatheva

original: tatheva evaṃ evameva evampi yathāpi seyyathāpi seyyathāpināma viya iva yathariva🔽tathariva yathānāma tathānāma yathāhi tathāhi yathāca tathāca iccete paṭibhāgatthe.🔽Yathāiti yoggatā+vicchā+padatthānativatti+nidassanesu ca. Evaṃiti upadesa+pañhādīsu🔽ca. Kiñcāpiiti anuggahatthe. Dhiiti garahe. Ahoiti garaha+pasaṃsana+patthanesu. Nāmaiti
analyzed: tathā iva evam evam eva evam pi yathā api seyyathā api seyyathā api nāma viyaḥ iva yathar iva  tathariva yathānāma tathānāma yathāhi tathāhi yathāca tathāca it ca ete paṭibhāga tthe  yathā iti ca evam iti upadesa pañha ādīsu  ca kiñca api iti anuggaha tthe dhi iti garahe aho iti garaha pasaṃsana patthanesu nāma eti

original: saddhiṃ amā (samaṃ, rū) iti samakriyāyaṃ. Vinā rite vippayoge. Nānā puthu bahupakāre.
analyzed: iti vinā rite vippayoge nānā puthu bahu pakāre
translated: Together with, with, equal to, is the equal-making. Without, apart from, is the separation. Different, various, is the many-helping.

original: Puthu visuṃ asaṅghāte ca. Duṭṭhu ku kucchāyaṃ (jigucchāyaṃ, rū). Puna appaṭhame.
analyzed: puthu visum a saṅghāte ca duṭṭhu ku kucchāyam jigucchāyam
translated: Various, separate, uncombined, is the many-separate. Disgusting, is the many-disgusting. Again, not first, is the many-again.

original: Kathaṃ cikicchatthe. Dhā kkhattuṃ so kiñcaiti saṃkhyāvibhāge. Īsakaṃ appamānesu (appamatte,
analyzed: katham cikicchatthe dhāḥ kkhattum saḥ kiñca eti saṃkhyā vibhāge īsakam appamānesu appamatte
translated: How? Is the seeking. How many times? Is the counting. A little, is the measuring.

original: rū). Saṇikaṃ mandatthe. Khippaṃ araṃ lahuṃ āsu tuṇhaṃ aciraṃ sīghatthe. Ciraṃ cirassaṃ
analyzed: rū saṇikam manda tthe khippam aram lahum āsu tuṇham aciram sīgha tthe ciram cirassam
translated: Slowly, is the slow. Quickly, easily, lightly, is the swift. Silent, is the soon. Swiftly, is the quick. For a long time, is the long.

original: dīghakāle. Ce yadi saṃkā+vaṭṭhāne. Dhuraṃ thirā+vadhāraṇesu (dhuvaṃ thirā+vadhāraṇesu,
analyzed: dīgha kāle ce yadi saṃka avaṭṭhāne dhuram thira avadhāraṇesu dhuvam thira avadhāraṇesu
translated: If, is the place. The burden, is the support.

original: rū). Hā visāde. Tuṇhī abhāsane. Sacchi paccakkhe. Musā micchāalikaṃ asacce. Suvatthi āsiṭṭhe iccādi.
analyzed: rū hā visāde tuṇhī abhāsane sacchi paccakkhe musā micchāalikam asacce suvatthi āsiṭṭhe iccādi
translated: Alas, is the sorrow. Silent, is the not-speaking. Truly, is the witness. False, is the wrong-speaking. Well, is the well-being. Thus, etc.

original: Tuna+ktvāna+ktvāpaccayantā ussukkanatthe bhavanti. Yathā passituna passiya passitvāna
analyzed: tunaktvānaktvāpaccaya ntāḥ ussukkana tthe bhavanti yathā
translated: Having done, having done, is the cause. Seeking, is the seeking. As seen, having seen, is the having-seen.

original: passitvā, disvā disvāna dassetvā dātuna datvāna datvā upādāya dāpetvā viññāya viceyya
analyzed: passitvā disvā disvāna dassetvā dātuna datvāna datvā upādāya dāpetvā viññāya viceyya
translated: having seen, having seen, having seen, having shown, having given, having given, having taken, having caused to give, having known, having examined,

original: vineyya samecca nihacca upecca ārabbha āgamma iccādi.
analyzed: vineyya samecca nihacca upecca ārabbhaḥ āgammaḥ iccādi
translated: having abandoned, having abandoned, having collected, having thrown down, having passed over, having had recourse to, having come, etc.

original: Vibhattiyā kato bhedo, saliṅgānaṃ bhave tathā;
analyzed: vibhattiyā kataḥ bhedaḥ bhave tathā
translated: The division made by the case-endings is likewise in the same way with words of the same gender;

original: Tumhādīnaṃ tva+liṅgesu, neva+tthi pādi+cādinaṃ.
analyzed: tumha ādīnam tu a liṅgesu na iva atthi pa ādi cādinam
translated: But in the case of tumhākaṃ, etc., and tvaṃ, etc., and ādi, etc., it does not exist.

original: Evaṃ nāmākhyātopasaggehi vinimuttaṃ etaṃ nipātapadaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: evam nāma ākhyāta upasaggehi vinimuttam etam nipāta padam veditabbam
translated: Thus this class of indeclinable words should be understood as being free from the names and the prepositions.

original: Nepātikapadaṃ.
analyzed: nepātika padam
translated: The indeclinable word.

original: Pulliṅgaṃ itthiliṅgañca, napuṃsaka+mathā+paraṃ;
analyzed: put liṅgam itthi liṅgam ca napuṃsakam atha aparam
translated: The feminine gender, the neuter gender, and then the common gender,

original: Tiliṅgañca aliṅgañca, nāmikaṃ pañcadhā ṭhitaṃ.
analyzed: tiliṅgam ca aliṅgam ca nāmikam pañcadhā ṭhitam
translated: The masculine gender, and the genderless, the gendered is established in five ways.

original: Iti payogasiddhiyaṃ nāmakaṇḍo dutiyo.
analyzed: iti nāmakaṇḍaḥ dutiyaḥ
translated: Thus ends the second chapter in the Path of Composition called “The Chapter on Names.”

original: 3. Kārakakaṇḍa
analyzed: kāraka kaṇḍa
translated: . The Chapter on the Categories

original: Atha vibhattīna+matthabhedā vuccante.🔽Tattha ekampi atthaṃ kammādivasena ekattādivasena ca vibhajantīti vibhattiyo, syādayo.
analyzed: atha vibhattīnam attha bhedāḥ vuccante  tattha ekam pi attham kamma ādi vasena ekattā ādi vasena ca vibhajanti iti vibhattiyaḥ syādayaḥ
translated: Now the different meanings of the case-endings are stated.🔽Herein, they are case-endings because they divide the one meaning into the one, etc., and the many, etc., by way of the action, etc. The case-endings are the case-endings beginning with the first.

original: Tā pana paṭhamādibhedena sattavidhā. Tā yathā “paṭhamā+tthamatte”ti paṭhamāvibhatti
analyzed: tāḥ pana paṭhamā ādi bhedena sattavidhā tāḥ yathā
translated: They are of seven kinds by way of division into first, etc. They are, namely, the first case-ending, the second case-ending, etc.

original: hoti. Sissa okāra+lopa+a-mādesesu naro itthī napuṃsakaṃ.🔽Sakattha+dabba+liṅgāni, saṃkhyā+kammādipañcakaṃ;
analyzed: hoti si ssa okāra lopa ama ādesesu naraḥ itthī napuṃsakam  sa kattha dabba liṅgāni saṃkhyā kamma ādi pañcakam
translated: There is. In the case of pupils, the removal of the vowel o, the vowel a, and the vowel ā, a man, a woman, a neuter.

original: Nāmattho tassa sāmañña-matthamatthaṃ pavuccate.
analyzed: nāmatthaḥ tassa sāmaññam attham attham pavuccate
translated: The meaning of a word, its general and specific meanings, are said to be the basis, the tree, the gender, the number, the action, etc., the five.

original: So nāmattho ca –
analyzed: saḥ nāmatthaḥ ca
translated: And that meaning of a word is

original: Jāti kriyā guṇo dabbaṃ, tathā nāmanti pañcadhā;
analyzed: jāti kriyā guṇaḥ dabbam tathā pañcadhā
translated: The class, the action, the quality, the substance, and likewise the name, are the five kinds;

original: Saddassa+ttho sa saddopi, pañcadhāva+tra bhijjate.
analyzed: sa saddaḥ api pañcadhā atra bhijjate
translated: The meaning of a word, and the word itself, are divided here into five kinds.

original: Kathaṃ jātisaddo guṇasaddotyādinā.
analyzed: katham jāti saddaḥ guṇa saddaḥ ityādinā
translated: How? By the class word, the quality word, etc.

original: Bhinnesva+bhinnadhī+saddā, sabalādīsu yabbalā;
analyzed: bhinnesu abhinna dhī sad dā sa bala ādīsu yap balā
translated: The words for the different things, the different words for the strong, etc.,

original: Vattante jāti esā+ssa, mālā sutta+mivā+nvitā.🔽Adabbabhūtaṃ kattādi-kārakaggāmasādhiyaṃ;
analyzed: vattante jāti esā assa mālā suttam iva anvitā  a dabba bhūtam kattā ādi kāraka ggāma sādhiyam
translated: Occur in this class, like a garland following a thread.🔽The substance that is not a quality, the agent, etc., the case, the village, etc.,

original: Padatthaṃ kattukammaṭṭhaṃ, kriya+micchanti tabbidū.
analyzed: pada ttham kattu kamma ṭṭham kriyam icchanti tad bidū
translated: The meaning of a word, the meaning of the verb, the action, they desire to be different from that.

original: Dabbassito tato bhinno, nimitto tappatītiyā;
analyzed: dabbassitaḥ tatas bhinnaḥ nimittaḥ tad patītiyā
translated: Distinguished from the substance, the indicative, the cause of that,

original: Vinassanasabhāvo ca, nigguṇova guṇo+ccate.
analyzed: ca nigguṇaḥ uva guṇa uccate
translated: The nature of destruction, and the quality without a quality, are mentioned.

original: Ettha paṭo sukkoti vinassanasabhāvo ca casaddena vipulo ākāsoti avinassanasabhāvo ca attani visuṃ guṇarahito guṇo+ccate tyattho.
analyzed: ettha paṭaḥ sukko ti vinassana sabhāvo ca ca saddena vipulaḥ ākāso ti a vinassana sabhāvo ca attani visum guṇa rahitaḥ
translated: Herein, the cloth is the “light” in the sense of liable to destruction, and the “vast space” is the “light” in the sense of not liable to destruction. The meaning is that a quality is stated separately in each instance as a quality devoid of the other.🔽Whatever is specified,

original: Yaṃ yaṃ visessate kiñci, taṃ taṃ dabba+miho+ccate;
analyzed: yam yam visessate kiñci tam tam dabbam iha uccate
translated: That is called the “light” .

original: Jātyādinopya+to tādi, dabbattaṃ parikappate.
analyzed: jāti ādinā upyataḥ ta ādi dabba ttam parikappate
translated: And so with “birth” and so on.

original: Ettha gojāti assajātīti vutte jāti dabbaṃ. Nīlo guṇoti ca guṇo dabbaṃ. Pacanakriyāti ca gamanādikriyāto visesiyatīti kriyāva dabbaṃ.
analyzed: ettha go jāti assa jāti iti vutte jāti dabbam nīlaḥ guṇaḥ iti ca guṇaḥ dabbam pacana kriyā ati ca gamana ādi kriyātaḥ kriyā ava dabbam
translated: Herein, when “ox-birth” and “horse-birth” are specified, it is birth that is the “light” . And when “blue” is specified, it is a quality that is the “light” . And when “cooking” is specified, it is action that is the “light” , since it is specified by way of action such as going, etc.

original: Nāmarūpena sadabbe, kvaci saññī kathīyate;🔽Nāmanti taṃ yathā citto, saññā saddo tu taddhanī.
analyzed: nāma rūpena kvacid saññī kathīyate  tam yathā cittaḥ saññā saddaḥ tu tad hanī
translated: In some places, when the light is name-and-form,🔽Consciousness is called the “perceiver” .

original: Nāmassa dabbattepi cittotyādi nāmeneva pasijjhati, no ghaṭa+paṭādayova dabbattena,
analyzed: nāmassa dabba tte pi citta utyādi nāmena iva pasijjhati no ghaṭa paṭa ādayaḥ iva dabba ttena
translated: Herein, although it is name that is the “light” , still consciousness, etc., are established as the “perceiver” by way of the term “name” , not by way of the “light” such as pot, cloth, etc.

original: tasmā nāma+miti saññī kathīyate, taṃvācakattā tabbatī cittādi saññāsaddoti nicchiyateyya+dhippāyo.
analyzed: tasmā nāmam iti saññī kathīyate taṃ vācaka ttā citta ādi saññā saddaḥ ti
translated: Therefore consciousness, etc., are called the “perceiver” because they are the denotors of that , and the term “perceiver” is established as a property of that . This is the method.

original: Ayaṃ pañcavidhopi attho saddattho ceva sāmatthiyā gamyamānattho cāti dubbidho. Tathā
analyzed: ayam pañcavidhaḥ api attho saddattho ca iva sāmatthiyā gamyamānattho ca ati dubbidhaḥ tathā
translated: This fivefold meaning is the meaning of a word and the meaning to be understood by capability.

original: hi “pīno divā na bhuñjeyya”miti bhuttinirākati saddattho. Rattibhutti tu sāmatthiyā+vagamyate. Tene+taṃ vuccati –
analyzed: hi pīnaḥ divā na bhuñjeyyam iti saddattho ratti bhutti tu sāmatthiyā avagamyate tena itam vuccati
translated: Thus, the word “fat” in the sentence “He who is fat should not eat during the day” is the meaning of a word. But eating at night is understood by capability. Therefore it is said:

original: Atthappatītiyaṃ sadda-byāpāro tividho bhave;
analyzed: atthappatītiyam sadda byāpāraḥ tividhaḥ bhave
translated: The function of a word in this way becomes threefold:

original: Mukhyo lakkhaṇa+byañjana-sabhāvo cāti ettha tu.
analyzed: mukhyaḥ lakkhaṇa byañjana sabhāvaḥ ca ati ettha tu
translated: The primary, the characteristic, and the literal meaning. But here,

original: Mukhyo tu nirantaratthe, lakkhaṇo tu tirohite;
analyzed: mukhyaḥ tu nirantaratthe lakkhaṇaḥ tu tirohite
translated: The primary is in the immediate meaning, the characteristic in the remote meaning,

original: Atthe+taro tu vākyassa, attheyeva pavattati.
analyzed: atthetaraḥ tu vākyassa attheya iva pavattati
translated: The literal meaning occurs only in the meaning of a sentence.

original: “Mañce”ti nirantaratthe vattamāno mukhyo, “mañcā ugghosantī”ti tirohitatthe vattamāno lakkhaṇo, gāthādisakalavākyassa+tthe vattamāno byañjanasabhāvo.
analyzed: mañca iti nirantara atthe vattamānaḥ mukhyaḥ mañcāḥ ugghosanti iti tirohita atthe vattamānaḥ lakkhaṇaḥ vattamānaḥ byañjana sabhāvaḥ
translated: “On the bed” occurs in the immediate meaning, the primary. “The people are crying out on the bed” occurs in the remote meaning, the characteristic. The literal meaning occurs in the meaning of the entire sentence such as a verse.

original: Byāpārassa pabhedena, tidhā saddopi vācako;
analyzed: byāpārassa pabhedena tidhā saddaḥ api vācakaḥ
translated: By the division of function, a word is also threefold in its expression:

original: Lakkhaṇiko byañjakoti, tadatthopi tidhā mato.
analyzed: lakkhaṇikaḥ tad atthaḥ api tidhā mato
translated: The characteristic, the literal, and the meaning of that is also considered threefold.

original: Vacco lakkhaṇiko byaṅgyo, cevaṃ saddo suvācako;
analyzed: vaccaḥ lakkhaṇikaḥ byaṅgyaḥ ca ivam saddo su vācako
translated: Speech is characteristic, figurative, and literal. Thus a word is well-spoken;

original: Vuttakamena jātyādi-bhedena pañcadhā bhaveti.
analyzed: jāti ādi bhedena pañcadhā
translated: It is of five kinds according to the kinds of birth, etc., mentioned.

original: 38. Āmantaṇe –
analyzed: āmantaṇe
translated: In addressing:

original: Ti āmantaṇādhike atthamatte paṭhamāvibhatti hoti. Bho nara, bho itthi, bho napuṃsaka.
analyzed: ti āmantaṇa adhike attha matte paṭhamā vibhatti hoti bho nara bho itthi bho napuṃsaka
translated: The first case-ending is in the vocative, which is a mere addition to the meaning, as in “Bho, man! Bho, woman! Bho, neuter!”

original: Saddenā+bhimukhīkāro, vijjamānassa vatthuno;
analyzed: saddena abhimukhīkāraḥ vijjamānassa vatthunaḥ
translated: The vocative is the facing of one who is present,

original: Āmantaṇaṃ vidhātabbe, natthi “rājā bhave”ti+daṃ.
analyzed: āmantaṇam vidhātabbe na atthi rājā bhava iti dam
translated: When it is to be done, there is no “king” here.

original: Kriyā nimittaṃ kārakantu kamma, kattu, karaṇa, sampadāna, avadhi, ādhārabhedena chabbidhaṃ, taṃ yathā –
analyzed: kriyā nimittam kārakantu kamma kattu karaṇa sampadāna avadhi ādhāra bhedena chabbidham tam yathā
translated: The object is of six kinds as action, reason, instrument, cause, source, and location.

original: 2,2. Kamme dutiyā🔽Karīyati kattukiriyāya sambandhīyatīti kammaṃ, tasmiṃ kammakārake dutiyāvibhatti
analyzed: kamme dutiyā  karīyati kattu kiriyāya sambandhīyati iti kammam tasmin kamma kārake dutiyā vibhatti
translated: In the object the second:

original: hoti. Taṃ tividhaṃ nibbatti, vikati, patti bhedena, tattha nibbattikamme mātā puttaṃ
analyzed: hoti tam tividham nibbatti patti bhedena tattha nibbatti kamme mātā puttam
translated: The object is that which is to be done, that is, is related to the action of the doer. The second case-ending is in the object. It is of three kinds as production, transformation, and acquisition. Herein, in production, the mother produces the son,

original: vijāyati, āhāro sukhaṃ janayati, kaṭaṃ karoti datto. Vikatiyaṃ kaṭṭha+maṅgāraṃ karoti,
analyzed: vijāyati āhāraḥ sukham janayati kaṭam karoti dattaḥ vikatiyam kaṭṭham aṅgāram karoti
translated: nourishment produces pleasure, Datta makes a bowl. In transformation, he makes charcoal of wood,

original: suvaṇṇaṃ kaṭakaṃ karoti, vīhayo lunāti. Pattiyaṃ datto gharaṃ pavisati, ādiccaṃ passati,
analyzed: suvaṇṇam kaṭakam karoti vīhayaḥ lunāti pattiyam dattaḥ gharam pavisati ādiccam passati
translated: He makes a golden ornament, he shears the sheep. When given a message he enters the house, he sees the sun,

original: dhammaṃ suṇāti, paṇḍite payirupāsati.
analyzed: dhammam suṇāti paṇḍite payis upāsati
translated: he hears the Dhamma, he attends on the wise.

original: Vuttañca –
analyzed: vuttam ca
translated: And it is said:

original: Nibbatti+vikati+patti-bhedā kammaṃ tidhā mataṃ;
analyzed: kammam tidhā matam
translated: “The deed is reckoned threefold, as rebirth-producing, as development, and as acquisition;

original: Kattukriyābhigammantaṃ, sukha+maṅgāraṃ+gharaṃ yathāti.🔽Kaṭaṃ karoti vipulaṃ dassanīyanti attheva guṇayuttassa kammatā, vipulaṃ karoti, dassanīyaṃ
analyzed: sukham aṅga araṃgharam yathā ati  kaṭam karoti vipulam dassanīyanti atthā iva guṇa yuttassa kamma tā vipulam karoti dassanīyam
translated: It is the doing of the action, the going to do it, and the being ready to do it, like a house with a pleasant hearth.”

original: karotīti kriyāya sambandhiyamānattā. Odano paccateti odanasaddato kammatā nappatīyate,
analyzed: karoti iti odanaḥ odana saddataḥ kamma tā na patīyate
translated: “He makes a big, beautiful basket” is the state of being a deed in the sense of the action of making, for the meaning of “He makes it big, he makes it beautiful” is related to the meaning of “He makes.” The state of being a deed is not recognized in the word “rice” in the expression “The rice is cooked,”

original: kiñcarahi ākhyātato.🔽Icchitakammaṃ yathā-gāvuṃ payo dohati, gomantaṃ gāvaṃ yācati, gāva+mava rundhati
analyzed: kiñcarahi ākhyātataḥ  icchita kammam yathā gāvum payaḥ dohati gomantam gāvam yācati gāvam ava rundhati
translated: for what reason? Because of the verb.🔽The desired deed is like this: “He milks the cow,” “He asks for the cow with the calf,” “He drives the cow,”

original: vajaṃ, māṇavakaṃ maggaṃ pucchati, gomantaṃ gāvaṃ bhikkhate, rukkha+mavacināti phalāni,
analyzed: vajam māṇavakam maggam pucchati gomantam gāvam bhikkhate rukkham avacināti phalāni
translated: “He asks the youth the way,” “He begs for the cow with the calf,” “He points out the fruit from the tree,”

original: rukkhātyattho. Sissaṃ dhammaṃ brūte. Ettha payo, gāvaṃ iccādi icchitaṃ, gāvuṃ, gomanta+miccādi
analyzed: sissam dhammam brūte ettha payaḥ gāvam iccādi icchitam gāvum gomantam iccādi
translated: The meaning of “tree” is the meaning of “forest.” He speaks Dhamma to the pupil. Here, “cow” is desired in the sense of “cow,” “ox” is desired in the sense of “ox,” etc.

original: anicchitaṃ. Eva+manicchitepi kaṇṭakaṃ maddati, visaṃ gilati. Yaṃ nevi+cchitaṃ, nāpi
analyzed: an icchitam evam an icchite api kaṇṭakam maddati visam gilati yam na iva icchitam na api
translated: “Cow” is not desired in the sense of “ox,” etc. Even in the desired, “He beats the thorn,” “He swallows the poison.” That which is neither desired nor

original: anicchitaṃ, tatrāpi gāmaṃ gacchanto rukkhamūla+mupasappati.
analyzed: an icchitam tatra api gāmam gacchantaḥ rukkha mūlam upasappati
translated: not desired, there too, “Going to the village, he approaches the foot of the tree.”

original: Ādhāre adhisi+ṭhā+sānaṃ payoge ca, pathaviṃ adhisessati, gāma+madhitiṭṭhati, rukkha+majjhāsateti.
analyzed: ādhāre payoge ca pathavim adhisessati gāmam adhitiṭṭhati rukkham ajjhāsata iti
translated: In the case of the base and the locative, in the usage, “He will settle on the earth,” “He stands over the village,” “He sits in the middle of the tree.”

original: Ettha pathavinti pathaviyanti attho. Eva+mabhi, nipubbavisassāpi, dhamma+mabhinivisate,
analyzed: ettha pathavinti pathaviyanti attho evam abhi nipubba visassa api dhammam abhinivisate
translated: Here, “earth” means “on the earth.” In the same way, “He is intent on,” “He is intent on the Dhamma,” “He is intent on the Dhamma.”

original: dhamme vā. Tathā upa, nva+jjhā+pubbavasatissa, gāma+mupavasati, gāma+manuvasati,
analyzed: dhamme vā tathā upa nu ajjhāpubbavasatissa gāmam upavasati gāmam anuvasati
translated: Likewise, “He dwells near,” “He dwells near the village,” “He dwells near the village,”

original: vihāra+madhivasati, gāma+māvasati, agāraṃ ajjhavasati, ettha gāmanti gāmetyattho.
analyzed: vihāram adhivasati gāmam āvasati agāram ajjhavasati ettha gāmanti
translated: “He dwells in the monastery,” “He dwells in the village,” “He dwells in the house,” here “village” means “in the village.”

original: Tathā tappānā+cārepi, nadiṃ pibati, gāmaṃ carati, nadiyaṃtyattho. Sace maṃ nālapissatīti
analyzed: tathā tad pāna ācāre pi nadim pibati gāmam carati sace mama na ālapissati iti
translated: In the same way, in the case of the usage of the locative, “He drinks the river,” “He wanders in the village,” the meaning is “in the river.” “If he will not speak to me,”

original: mayā saddhiṃtyattho. Vihitāva paṭi-yogepi dutiyā, paṭibhantu taṃ cunda bojjhaṅgā,
analyzed: mayā saddhim ti atthaḥ paṭiyoge api dutiyā tam cunda bojjhaṅgā
translated: The meaning is: together with me.🔽Even though the second is enjoined, the second is used with the words paṭibhantu and paṭibhāti.🔽The meaning is: may the factors of enlightenment occur to me, may the factors of enlightenment be manifest to me.

original: tampaṭi bojjhaṅgā bhāsantūti attho. Upamā maṃ patibhāti, upamā maṃ upaṭṭhātityattho.
analyzed: tampaṭi bojjhaṅgāḥ bhāsantu iti attho upamā mam patibhāti upamā mam upaṭṭhāti iti attho
translated: The meaning is: a simile occurs to me, a simile presents itself to me.

original: Dhātunāyutte “tassa nappaṭibhātī”ti chaṭṭhī.
analyzed: dhātunā ayutte tassa na paṭibhāti iti chaṭṭhī
translated: In the compound nappaṭibhāti, the sixth case is used because of the absence of a noun in apposition.

original: 3. Kāladdhāna+maccantasaṃyoge
analyzed: kāla d dhāna mac canta saṃyoge
translated: In the compound of time, space, and extreme,

original: Kāladdhānaṃ dabba+guṇa+kriyāhi accantasaṃyoge tehi kāladdhānavācīhi dutiyā hoti.
analyzed: kāladdhānam dabba guṇa kriyāhi ac c anta saṃyoge tehi kāladdhāna vācīhi dutiyā hoti
translated: The second is used with the words for time and space when they are in apposition with the words for extreme.

original: Kāle-sattāhaṃ gavapānaṃ, māsaṃ maṃsodanaṃ, saradaṃ ramaṇīyā nadī, sabbakālaṃ ramaṇīyaṃ
analyzed: māsam maṃsodanam saradam ramaṇīyā nadī sabbakālam ramaṇīyam
translated: The meaning is: for a time, for a week, drinking cow’s urine; for a month, eating rice gruel; for the autumn, the river is pleasant; for all time, the Nandana grove is pleasant;

original: nandanaṃ, tayo māse abhidhammaṃ deseti. Addhani-yojanaṃ vanarāji, yojanaṃ dīgho pabbato, kosaṃ sajjhāyati.
analyzed: nandanam tayaḥ māse abhidhammam deseti addha niyojanam vana rāji yojanam dīghaḥ pabbataḥ kosam sajjhāyati
translated: for three months, he teaches the Abhidhamma. The meaning is: a forest-grove of a league in extent; a mountain a league in length; he recites the treasury.

original: Pubbanhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā, ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā, imaṃ rattiṃ cattāro mahārājānoti
analyzed: pubbanha samayam nivāsetvā ekam samayam bhagavā imam rattim cattāraḥ mahā rājāno ti
translated: The meaning is: having dressed in the morning; at one time the Fortunate One; this night the Four Great Kings;

original: evamādīsu kālavācīhi accantasaṃyoge dutiyā, bahulaṃvidhānā vibhattivipallāso vā.
analyzed: evamādīsu kāla vācīhi a c c anta saṃyoge dutiyā bahulam vidhānā vibhatti vipallāsaḥ vā
translated: and so on. In these examples the second is used when time is in apposition with extreme, or there is a change of case endings because of the general rule.

original: Māsenā+nuvāko+dhīto, kosenā+nuvāko+dhītoti karaṇatthe tatiyā.🔽4. Gatibodhāhārasaddatthākammakabhajjādīnaṃ payojje
analyzed: māsena anuvākaḥ udhītaḥ kosena anuvākaḥ udhītaḥ iti karaṇa atthe tatiyā  gati bodha āhāra saddattha a kammaka bhajja ādīnam payojje
translated: The instrumental is used in such expressions as: ‘The lesson was learnt by the month’, ‘The lesson was learnt by the quarter’.🔽. The locative is used in the case of the purpose of going, of understanding, of eating, of sound, of action, of the purpose of the division, etc.
