analyzed: ekatthe samāhāre saṃkhyā ādi napuṃsaka liṅgam bhavati tayaḥ samāhaṭā cittena sampiṇḍitā
translated: In a compound of the kind, the number, etc., are neuter. The three worlds are compounded = combined by the mind,

original: tiṇṇaṃ lokānaṃ samāhāroti vā vākye visesanasamāse kate iminā napuṃsakattaṃ bhavati.
analyzed: tiṇṇam lokānam samāhāraḥ iti vā vākye visesana samāse kate iminā napuṃsaka ttam bhavati
translated: or the compound is made by the analysis “of the three worlds the compounding”, and then the neuter is formed by this rule.

original: Samāhārasse+kattā ekavacanameva, tilokaṃ, bho tiloka, tilokaṃ, tilokena iccādi. Evaṃ
analyzed: samāhārassa ekattā ekavacanam eva tilokam bho tiloka tilokam tilokena iccādi evam
translated: Because of the compounding, there is only the singular, thus tilokaṃ, bho tiloka, tilokaṃ, tilokena, etc.🔽Likewise

original: tayo daṇḍā tidaṇḍaṃ, tīṇi malāni samāhaṭāni, tiṇṇaṃ malānaṃ samāhāroti vā timalaṃ,
analyzed: tayaḥ daṇḍā ti daṇḍam tīṇi malāni samāhaṭāni vā ti malam
translated: tiṇṇaṃ daṇḍānaṃ samāhāroti vā timalaṃ,

original: tilakkhaṇaṃ, catusaccaṃ, pañcasikkhāpadaṃ, chaṭṭhāyatanaṃ, sattāhaṃ, aṭṭhasīlaṃ,
analyzed: ti lakkhaṇam catu saccam pañca sikkhāpadam chaṭṭha āyatanam satta aham aṭṭha sīlam
translated: tilakkhaṇaṃ, catusaccaṃ, pañcasikkhāpadaṃ, chaṭṭhāyatanaṃ, sattāhaṃ, aṭṭhasīlaṃ,

original: navalokuttaraṃ, dasasīlaṃ, satayojanaṃ. Dve rattiyo samāhaṭā dvirattaṃ.
analyzed: nava lokuttaram dasa sīlam sata yojanam dve rattiyaḥ dvi rattam
translated: navalokuttaraṃ, dasasīlaṃ, satayojanaṃ. Dvirattaṃ.

original: 12. Naña
analyzed: nañaḥ
translated: Naña

original: Naūccetaṃ syādyantaṃ syādyantena sahe+katthaṃ hoti. Ññakāro “ṭa nañassā”ti visesanattho
analyzed: naḥ u cca itam syādi antam syādi antena saha ikattham hoti ññakāraḥ nañassa ati visesana atthaḥ
translated: This nañ is formed with a suffix and is followed by a suffix. It is formed with a suffix and then the suffix is added. The ññ is for the purpose of distinguishing the ṭ of nañ.

original: ‘pāmanaputtādīsu nassa ṭo mā hotū’ti. Na brāhmaṇo abrāhmaṇo, “ṭa nañassā”ti nassa
analyzed: pāmana putta ādīsu nassa ṭaḥ mā hotu iti na brāhmaṇaḥ a brāhmaṇaḥ ṭa nañassa ati nassa
translated: ‘Let there be no mā after pāmanaputta, etc.’ Na brāhmaṇo = abrāhmaṇo. ‘The ṭ of nañ’ means that the nañ gets the ṭ.

original: ṭādeso. Ñña-kāro ettheva visesanattho.
analyzed: ṭādesaḥ ññakāraḥ ettha iva visesana tthaḥ
translated: The suffix -tā is the place-marker. The suffix -ña is the differentiator.

original: Na-nisedho sato yutto, desādiniyamaṃ vinā;
analyzed: sataḥ yuttaḥ desa ādi niyamam vinā
translated: Without restriction of place, etc., the negative is not appropriate;

original: Asato vā+phalo tasmā, katha+mabrāhmaṇotice.
analyzed: asataḥ katham abrāhmaṇā utice
translated: Or else, the result of the negative is that “he is not a brahmin.”

original: Nisedhatthānuvādena, paṭisedhavidhi kvaci;
analyzed: nisedha ttha anuvādena paṭisedha vidhi kvaci
translated: In some instances the negative is a mode of prohibition by way of a statement of negation;

original: Parassa micchāñāṇattā+khyāpanāyo+papajjate.
analyzed: parassa micchā ñāṇa ttā khyāpanāya upapajjate
translated: It is applied to the purpose of making known the other’s wrong knowledge.

original: Duvidho ca+ssa nassa attho pasajjapaṭisedha+pariyudāsavasena. Tattha yo “asūrikapassārājadārā”tiādīsu
analyzed: duvidhaḥ ca assa nassa atthaḥ pasajja paṭisedha pariyudāsa vasena tattha yaḥ
translated: And it is of two kinds, as exclusion and prohibition. Herein, that which, like “The king’s wives are not women” ,

original: viya uttarapadatthassa sabbadā abhāvaṃ dīpeti, so pasajjapaṭisedhavācī nāma. Yo pana
analyzed: viya uttara padatthassa sabbadā abhāvam dīpeti so pasajja paṭisedha vācī nāma yaḥ pana
translated: shows the non-existence of the meaning of the latter term at all times, is called a statement of exclusion. But that which,

original: “abrāhmaṇa+mānayā”tiādīsu viya uttarapadatthaṃ pariyudāsitvā paṭikkhipitvā taṃsadise
analyzed: a brāhmaṇam ānaya ati ādīsu viyas uttara padattham pariyudāsitvā paṭikkhipitvā tad sadise
translated: like “Do not honour the non-brahmin” , having excluded the meaning of the latter term, having prohibited it,🔽indicates the action to be done in the case of a subject of the kind beginning with “brahmin” ,

original: vatthumhi kāriyaṃ paṭipādayati, so pariyudāsavācī nāma. Vuttañca –
analyzed: vatthumhi kāriyam paṭipādayati saḥ pariyudāsa vācī nāma vuttam ca
translated: is called a statement of prohibition. And it is said:🔽The characteristic of a statement of exclusion

original: Pasajjapaṭisedhassa, lakkhaṇaṃ vatthunatthitā;
analyzed: pasajja paṭisedhassa lakkhaṇam vatthu natthi tā
translated: Is the non-existence of the subject;🔽The usage elsewhere than in the subject

original: Vatthuto+ññatra yā vutti, pariyudāsalakkhaṇaṃ.
analyzed: vatthutaḥ uññatra yā vutti pariyudāsa lakkhaṇam
translated: Is the characteristic of a prohibition.

original: Yatra abrāhmaṇādīsu, vatthuṃ pariyudassati;
analyzed: yatra a brāhmaṇa ādīsu vatthum pariyudassati
translated: Where it excludes the subject

original: Takriyāyuttarājādiṃ, vade so pariyudāsako.
analyzed: vade saḥ
translated: “The ‘other’ is the opposite, etc.,

original: Pasajjapaṭisedho tu, vatthantara+manādiya;🔽Kiñcivatthunisedhassa, pasaṅgo na bhaveyya so.
analyzed: pasajja paṭisedhaḥ tu  kiñci vatthu nisedhassa pasaṅgaḥ na bhaveyya so
translated: And the ‘exclusion’ is the ‘other’🔽In the sense of ‘not that.’🔽The ‘other’ is the opposite,

original: Tadañño ca taṃviruddho,
analyzed: tad añño ca tad viruddhaḥ
translated: And the non-existence is the ‘other’

original: Tadabhāvo ca naññattho.
analyzed: tad abhāvaḥ ca naññattho
translated: In the sense of ‘not that.’

original: Tadaññatthe – abrāhmaṇo, brāhmaṇato añño taṃsadisoti vuttaṃ hoti. Evaṃ amanusso,
analyzed: tad añña tthe abrāhmaṇaḥ brāhmaṇataḥ aññaḥ tad sadisaḥ ti vuttam hoti evam amanussaḥ
translated: In the sense of the ‘other’ : a non-brahmin is one who is not a brahmin, who is like a brahmin. So too, a non-human being,

original: assamaṇo, na byākatā abyākatā dhammā. Tabbiruddhatthe-na kusalā akusalā, kusalapaṭipakkhāti
analyzed: assamaṇaḥ na byākatāḥ abyākatāḥ dhammāḥ tad viruddha atthena kusalāḥ akusalā kusala paṭipakkhā ati
translated: a non-ascetic, unproclaimed and unproclaimable ideas. In the sense of the opposite: not profitable, not unprofitable, the opposite of profitable.

original: attho. Evaṃ alobho, amitto, ayaṃ pariyudāsanayo. Tadabhāve-na katvā akatvā, akātuna
analyzed: evam alobhaḥ amitto ayam tad abhāvena katvā a katvā
translated: So too, non-greed, an enemy, this is the ‘exclusion’ method. In the sense of non-existence: having not done, not having done, not having caused to be done,

original: puññaṃ, akaronto, abhāvo bhavati. Ayaṃ pasajjapaṭisedhanayo.
analyzed: puññam a karontaḥ abhāvaḥ bhavati ayam pasajja paṭisedhanayo
translated: having not made merit, not doing, non-existence. This is the ‘exclusion’ method.

original: Ettha ca ubhosu pariyudāse brāhmaṇā añño brāhmaṇadhamme appatiṭṭhito khattiyādi brāhmaṇasadisova
analyzed: ettha ca ubhosu pariyudāse brāhmaṇāḥ aññaḥ brāhmaṇa dhamme a patiṭṭhito khattiya ādi brāhmaṇa sadisaḥ uva
translated: And here in the case of both ‘exclusions’ a non-brahmin is one who is not established in the brahmin’s True Idea, who is like a brahmin, a noble, etc.,

original: abrāhmaṇoti vutte patīyate. Itarasmiṃ pana pakkhe kenaci saṃsayanimittena khattiyādo
analyzed: a brāhmaṇaḥ iti vutte patīyate itarasmin pana pakkhe kenaci saṃsaya nimittena khattiya ādaḥ
translated: when it is said ‘a non-brahmin.’ But in the other case, by some reason for doubt, a noble, etc.,

original: brāhmaṇoti vuttassa micchāñāṇanivutti karīyati “brāhmaṇo+yaṃ na bhavati abrāhmaṇo”ti,
analyzed: brāhmaṇaḥ iti vuttassa micchā ñāṇa nivutti brāhmaṇā iyam na bhavati abrāhmaṇā iti
translated: The expression “He is not a brahmin, he is not a non-brahmin” is made about one called a brahmin by a wrong view.

original: brāhmaṇattajjhāsito na bhavatītyattho. Tattha sadisattaṃ vinā micchāñāṇāsambhavā
analyzed: na na
translated: The meaning is that he is not called a brahmin by the true state of the case. Herein, since a wrong view is impossible without similarity,

original: payogasāmatthiyā ca sadisapaṭipatti, taggatā ca liṅga+saṅkhyā bhavanti. Atoyeva uccate
analyzed: payoga sāmatthiyā ca taggatā ca liṅga saṅkhyā bhavanti atoyā iva uccate
translated: and since the similarity of practice, the state of being directed to that, and the gender and number of the word “brahmin” are possible,

original: “naññivayutta+maññasadisādhikaraṇe, kathā hi atthasampaccayo”ti.
analyzed: nañ ñi va yutta mañ asa disa adhikaraṇe kathā hi attha sampaccayaḥ ti
translated: therefore it is said: “The negative is construed with the word ‘brahmin’ in the sense of similarity, for the statement is a statement of meaning.”

original: 75. Ana sareti🔽Nañasaddassa sare ana, na asso anasso, na ariyo anariyo. Evaṃ anissaro, aniṭṭho,
analyzed: ana sara iti  naña saddassa sare na assaḥ an assaḥ na ariyaḥ an ariyaḥ evam anissaraḥ aniṭṭhaḥ
translated: . The negative ana

original: anāsavo. Na ādāya anādāya, anoloketvā icchādi. Bahulādhikārā ayuttatthehi kehici🔽hoti. Puna na gīyantīti apunageyyā gāthā, anokāsaṃ kāretvā, amūlāmūlaṃ gantvā, acandamullokikāni
analyzed: anāsavaḥ na ādāya an ādāya icchā ādi bahula adhikārāḥ ayutta atthehi kehici  puna na gīyanti iti a puna geyyāḥ gāthāḥ an okāsam kāretvā a mūla a mūlam gantvā
translated: The negative na becomes ana before the word asso, ariyo, etc., thus: na asso = anasso, na ariyo = anariyo. So too: anissaro, aniṭṭho, anāsavo. Na ādāya = anādāya. Anoloketvā = anoloketvā. Icchādi. By the influence of bahula, it is used in the sense of impossibility with some words.

original: mukhāni, asaddhabhojī, alavaṇabhojī.
analyzed: mukhāni a saddha bhojī a lavaṇa bhojī
translated: Again: apunageyyā = gāthā na puna gīyantī. Anokkāsaṃ = kāretvā. Amūlāmūlaṃ = gantvā. Acandamullokikāni = mukhāni. Asaddhabhojī = alavaṇabhojī.

original: 13. Kupādayo nicca+masyādividhimhi
analyzed: kupa ādayaḥ
translated: . Kupādayo nicca+masyādividhimhi

original: Kusaddo pādayo ca syādyantena sahe+katthā honti niccaṃ syādividhivisayato+ññattha.
analyzed: ku saddaḥ pādayaḥ ca syādi antena saha ikatthāḥ honti niccam
translated: The word ku is always compounded with the words pāda and -antena, in the sense of “together with”, in the sense of “in the place of syā-ādi-vidhi”, in another sense.

original: Ettha abyabhicāripādisahacaraṇatthena kuiti nipātova, na pathavīvācako kusaddo. Syādividhivisayo
analyzed: ettha abyabhicāri pādi sahacaraṇa atthena nipātaḥ uva na pathavī vācakaḥ ku saddo
translated: Here the word ku is a particle in the sense of “going together with” such invariable things as pāda, not a word denoting earth. In the sense of “in the place of syā-ādi-vidhi”,

original: nāma “lakkhaṇitthambhūtā” dinā patiādīnaṃ visaye katadutiyā, tañca anvaddhamāsanti
analyzed: nāma lakkhaṇa itthambhūtā dinā pati ādīnam visaye tat ca
translated: which is called “made in the place of pati, etc., which are the basis for the characteristics”, and that is “every half-month”,

original: asaṃkhyasamāsa+miva mā hotūti “asyādividhimhī”ti nisedho. Kucchito brāhmaṇo kubrāhmaṇo,
analyzed: asaṃkhya samāsam iva mā hotu uti nisedhaḥ kucchitaḥ brāhmaṇaḥ ku brāhmaṇaḥ
translated: so that it is not a compound with an uncountable number, the prohibition “in the place of syā-ādi-vidhi” is made. A brahmin from the Kuci clan is a kubrāhmaṇa,

original: niccasamāsattā asapadena viggaho.🔽107. Sare kada kussu+ttaratthe
analyzed: nicca samāsa ttā a sa padena viggahaḥ  sare kada kus su ttara tthe
translated: because of the invariable compounding, the separation is with the word asa.🔽. In the sense of “having risen from”, with sara,

original: Kussu+ttaratthe vattamānassa sarādo uttarapade kadādeso hoti. Īsakaṃ uṇhaṃ kaduṇhaṃ, kucchitaṃ annaṃ kadannaṃ, kadasanaṃ. Sareti kiṃ, kuputtā, kudārā, kudāsā, kudiṭṭhi.
analyzed: kussuttara tthe vattamānassa sarādaḥ uttara pade kad ādesaḥ hoti īsakam uṇham kaduṇham kucchitam annam kadannam kadasanam sara iti kim ku puttā ku dārā ku dāsā ku diṭṭhi
translated: In the sense of “having risen from”, the word sara has the substitution of kada in the following word. A little heat is kaduṇhaṃ, a little food is kadannaṃ, kadasanaṃ. With sara. What? Kuputtā, kudārā, kudāsā, kudiṭṭhi.

original: 108. Kā+ppatthe
analyzed: kāppatthe
translated: . In the sense of “having reached”,

original: Appatthe vattamānassa kussa kā hotu+ttarapade. Appakaṃ lavaṇaṃ kālavaṇaṃ. Evaṃ kāpupphaṃ.
analyzed: appatthe vattamānassa kussa kā hotu uttara pade appakam lavaṇam kālavaṇam evam kāpuppham
translated: In the sense of “having reached”, the word ku has the substitution of kā in the following word. A little salt is kālavaṇaṃ. Thus kāpupphaṃ.🔽. In the sense of “having gone to”, with gacchati,

original: 109. Purise vāti
analyzed: purise vāti
translated: 109. In a man, etc.

original: Kussa kā vā. Kucchito puriso kāpuriso, kupuriso vā. Pakaṭṭho nāyako panāyako, padhānaṃ
analyzed: kussa kā vā kucchitaḥ puriso kāpurisaḥ ku purisaḥ vā pakaṭṭhaḥ nāyako panāyakaḥ padhānam
translated: In a man, a bad belly is a bad man, or a bad person. A man who is manifest, a leader, a guide, is a leader, a guide.

original: vacanaṃ pāvacanaṃ bhusaṃ vaddhaṃ pavaddhaṃ sarīraṃ, samaṃ sammā vā ādhānaṃ samādhānaṃ,
analyzed: vacanam pāvacanam bhusam vaddham pavaddham sarīram samam sammā vai ādhānam samādhānam
translated: A word that is good is a good word, a word that is false is a false word. A body that is well-developed is well-developed, a body that is not well-developed is not well-developed. A state that is even, right, is even, right.

original: vividhā mati vimati, vividho visiṭṭho vā kappo vikappo, adhiko devo atidevo, evaṃ🔽adhidevo, adhisīlaṃ. Sundaro gandho sugandho, kacchito gandho duggandho, suṭṭhu kataṃ🔽sukataṃ, duṭṭhu kataṃ dukkataṃ abhi siñcanaṃ abhisekoti sananto, atisayena katvā,🔽kataṃ pakaritvā, pakataṃ, atisayena thutaṃ atitthutaṃ, atikkamma thutaṃ atitthutaṃ,🔽īsaṃ kaḷāro ākaḷāro, suṭṭhu baddho ābaddho.

translated: A variety of thought is a variety of thought, a variety of thought is a variety of thought. A variety of thought is a variety of thought, a variety of thought is a variety of thought. A god that is superior is a superior god, a god that is superior is a superior god.

original: Atikkanto mañcaṃ atimañco. Atimālo, “ghapassa+ntassā+ppadhānassā”ti mālāsadde ghassa rasso. Eva+muparipi ghapānaṃ rasso.
analyzed: atikkantaḥ mañcam atimañcaḥ atimālaḥ mālā sadde ghassa rassaḥ evam upari pi gha pānam rassaḥ
translated: Atikkanto mañcaṃ atimañco. Atimālo, “ghapassa+ntassā+ppadhānassā”ti mālāsadde ghassa rasso. Eva+muparipi ghapānaṃ rasso.

original: Avādayo kuṭṭhādyatthe tatiyāya
analyzed: ava ādayaḥ kuṭṭha ādi a tthe tatiyāya
translated: Avādayo kuṭṭhādyatthe tatiyāya

original: Avakuṭṭhaṃ kokilāya vanaṃ avakokilaṃ, avamayūraṃ. Avakuṭṭhanti pariccattaṃ.
analyzed: avakuṭṭham kokilāya vanam ava kokilam ava mayūram avakuṭṭhanti pariccattam
translated: Avakuṭṭhaṃ kokilāya vanaṃ avakokilaṃ, avamayūraṃ. Avakuṭṭhanti pariccattaṃ.

original: Pariyādayo gilānādyatthe catutthiyā
analyzed: pariya ādayaḥ gilāna ādi atthe catutthiyā
translated: Pariyādayo gilānādyatthe catutthiyā

original: Parigilāno+jjhenāya pariyajjheno.
analyzed: parigilāna ujjhenāya
translated: Parigilāno+jjhenāya pariyajjheno.

original: Nyādayo kantādyatthe pañcamiyā
analyzed: ni ādayo kanta ādi atthe pañcamyā
translated: Nyādayo kantādyatthe pañcamiyā

original: Nikkhanto kosambiyā nikkosambi. Asyādividhimhīti kiṃ, rukkhaṃ pati vijjotate.
analyzed: nikkhantaḥ kosambiyā nikkosambi asya ādi vidhimhi iti kim rukkham pati vijjotate
translated: Nikkhanto kosambiyā nikkosambi. Asyādividhimhīti kiṃ, rukkhaṃ pati vijjotate.

original: 14. Cī kriyatthehi
analyzed: cī kriyatthe hi
translated: . Cī kriyatthehi

original: Cīpaccayanto kriyatthehi syādyantehi sahe+kattho hoti. Amalīnaṃ malīnaṃ karitvāti
analyzed: cī pacca yantaḥ kriyatthehi syādi antehi saha ika tthaḥ hoti a malīnam malīnam karitvā ati
translated: Cīpaccayanto kriyatthehi syādyantehi sahe+kattho hoti. Amalīnaṃ malīnaṃ karitvāti

original: viggayha “abhūtatabbhāve karā+sa+bhūyoge vikārācī”ti cīpaccayekate iminā samāso.
analyzed: viggayha a bhūta tad bhāve kara asa bhū yoge vikārāci iti cī paccaye kate iminā samāsaḥ
translated: viggayha “abhūtatabbhāve karā+sa+bhūyoge vikārācī”ti cīpaccayekate iminā samāso.

original: Ettha ca-kāro “cī kriyatthehī”ti visesanattho. “Pyo vā tvāssa samāse”ti pya hoti,
analyzed: ettha cakāraḥ cī samāse iti
translated: Ettha ca-kāro “cī kriyatthehī”ti visesanattho. “Pyo vā tvāssa samāse”ti pya hoti,

original: pa-kāro “pye sissā”ti visesanattho. Malinīkariya.
analyzed: pakāraḥ pye sissāti visesana atthaḥ malinīkariya
translated: The letter pa is the meaning of the word “and” in the sense of “and also”. Malinīkariya.

original: 15. Bhūsanā+darā+nādaresva+laṃ+sā+sāti
analyzed: bhū san ādara an ādare su alaṃsa āsā ati
translated: . Alaṃ, sā, sādhikara, cariccā, in the sense of adorning, etc.

original: Bhūsanādīsva+tthesva+la+mādayo saddā ekatthā honti. Alaṃ karitvā sakkaritvā asakkaritvāti
analyzed: bhūsana ādīsu atthesu alam ādayo saddāḥ ekatthāḥ honti alam karitvā sakkaritvā a sakkaritvā ati
translated: The words alaṃ, sā, sādhikara, cariccā have the same meaning in the sense of adorning, etc. Having adorned, having honoured, having dishonoured.

original: viggayha samāse kate pye ca “sā sādhikarā ca cariccā”ti cādeso pararūpañca. Alaṃkariya,
analyzed: viggayha samāse kate pye ca sā sādhikarā ca carit ca ati ca ādesaḥ para rūpam ca
translated: When the compound is made by the method of separation, there is the change of sā to sādhikara and cariccā, and the addition of the form of the other word. Alaṃkariya,

original: sakkacca, asakkacca.🔽16. Aññecā+ti suttena samāse kate… ettha yathā dvāraṃ vivarāti vutte pakaraṇato aggala+miti🔽viññāyati, eva+midhāpi nipātapabhāve aññe cāti sāmaññaṃ ce+ti āgamānusārena labbhamānavibhatyantapaṭirūpanipātāva🔽viññāyanti. Aggato bhavitvā purobhuyya, antarahito hutvā tirobhūya, antaradhānaṃ
analyzed: sakkat ca a sakkat ca  suttena samāse kate ettha yathā dvāram vutte pakaraṇataḥ aggalam iti  viññāyati evam idha api nipāta pa bhāve aññe ca ati sāmaññam ca iti āgama anusārena labbhamāna vibhati anta paṭirūpa nipātāḥ  viññāyanti aggataḥ bhavitvā purobhuyya antarahitaḥ hutvā tirobhūya antaradhānam
translated: sakkacca, asakkacca.🔽. Aññe cāti, when the compound is made by the method of the sutra… Here, just as when it is said “open the door”, it is understood from the context that it is the bolt that is meant,

original: katvā tirokariya, urasi katvā urasikariya, manasi katvā manasikariya, majjhe katvā🔽majjhekariya, tuṇhī bhavitvā tuṇhī bhūya.
analyzed: katvā tirokariya urasi katvā urasikariya manasi katvā manasikariya majjhe katvā 🔽tuṇhī bhavitvā tuṇhī bhūya
translated: so too, in the case of the indeclinable words aññe cāti, the indeclinable words that are understood by the method of the tradition are only those that are suitable to the case-ending. Aggato bhavitvā, purobhuyya, antarahito hutvā, tirobhūya, antaradhānaṃ katvā, tirokariya, urasi katvā, urasikariya, manasi katvā, manasikariya, majjhe katvā, majjhekariya, tuṇhī bhavitvā, tuṇhī bhūya.

original: 17. Vā+neka+ññatthe
analyzed: vā an ekaññatthe
translated: 17. In the sense of ‘many and one’

original: Anekaṃ syādyantaṃ aññassa padassa atthe ekatthaṃ vā hoti.
analyzed: anekam syādi antam aññassa padassa atthe ekattham vā hoti
translated: A word ending in a plural is used in the sense of one word or in the sense of another.

original: Padantarassa yassa+ttho, padhānaṃ liṅga+massa ca;
analyzed: pada antarassa yaḥ atthaḥ padhānam liṅgam assa ca
translated: The meaning of the other word, the predominance, and the gender of the latter,

original: Samāso so+ya+maññattho, bahubbīhiparavhayo.
analyzed: samāsaḥ saḥ yam aññatthaḥ bahup bīhi para vhayaḥ
translated: That compound is called ‘in the sense of one’, and is called ‘bahubbīhi’.

original: So ca navavidho dvipado, bhinnādhikaraṇo, tipado, na-nipātapubbapado, sahapubbapado, upamānapubbapado, saṅkhyobhayapado, disantarālattho, byatihāralakkhaṇo cāti.
analyzed: so ca navavidhaḥ dvi padaḥ bhinna adhikaraṇo ti padaḥ na nipāta pubba pado saha pubba pado upamāna pubba pado saṅkhyā ubhaya padaḥ disa antarāla ttho byatihāra lakkhaṇo ca ati
translated: And that is of nine kinds: a two-word compound, a compound with different heads, a three-word compound, a compound with a negative particle as the first word, a compound with a conjunction as the first word, a compound with a simile as the first word, a compound with a numeral as the first word, a compound with a direction as the first word, and a compound characterized by hyperbole.

original: 1. Tattha dvipado tulyādhikaraṇo kammādīsu chasu vibhatyatthesu bhavati.
analyzed: tattha dvipadaḥ tulya adhikaraṇaḥ kamma ādīsu chasu vibhati atthesu bhavati
translated: . Therein, the two-word compound is in six cases, in the accusative and so on, with a common head.

original: (Ka) tattha dutiyatthe tāva-āgatā samaṇā imaṃ saṅghārāmanti āgatasamaṇo saṅghārāmo. So ca duvidho tagguṇā+tagguṇavasena. Vuttañhi –
analyzed: ka tattha dutiya tthe tāva āgatā samaṇāḥ imam saṅgha ārāmanti āgata samaṇaḥ saṅgha ārāmaḥ saḥ ca duvidhaḥ tagguṇa a tagguṇa vasena vuttam hi
translated: (Ka) Therein, first of all, in the sense of ‘second’: ‘The ascetics who have come to this monastery’ = ‘The ascetics who have come to the monastery’. And that is of two kinds, as having the same quality and as not having the same quality. For this is said:

original: Tagguṇo+tagguṇo ce+ti,
analyzed: tagguṇa utagguṇaḥ ca iti
translated: ‘Having the same quality and not having the same quality’,

original: So samāso dvidhā mato.🔽Taṃ yathā ‘nīyataṃ lamba-
analyzed: saḥ samāsaḥ dvidhā mataḥ  tam yathā lamba
translated: That compound is considered twofold.🔽That is, ‘the ear that is reached by sound’🔽‘the ocean that is seen’.

original: Kaṇṇo+’ ‘yaṃ diṭṭhasāgaro’.
analyzed: kaṇṇaḥ yam diṭṭha sāgaraḥ
translated: ‘Ear’ is ‘yaṃ diṭṭhasāgaro’.🔽

original: Tesu yattha visesanabhūto attho aññapadatthaggahaṇena gayhati, so tagguṇasaṃviññāṇo,
analyzed: tesu yattha visesana bhūtaḥ atthaḥ añña padattha ggahaṇena gayhati saḥ tad guṇa saṃviññāṇaḥ
translated: Herein, that which is known as having the special quality is that where the meaning of the special quality is found by the inclusion of the word of another part of speech,

original: yathā ‘lambakaṇṇa+mānayā’ti. Yattha pana na gayhati, so atagguṇasaṃviññāṇo, yathā
analyzed: yathā yattha pana na gayhati saḥ a tad guṇa saṃviññāṇaḥ yathā
translated: as in ‘lambakaṇṇamānayā’ . That which is not known as having the special quality is that where it is not found,

original: ‘bahudhana+mānayā’ti.
analyzed: bahu dhana mānayā ati
translated: as in ‘bahudhanamānayā’ .

original: Idha visesanassa pubbanipāto. Ettha ca āgatasaddo ca samaṇasaddo ca attano atthe
analyzed: idha visesanassa pubba nipātaḥ ettha ca āgata saddo ca samaṇa saddo ca attano atthe
translated: Here the special quality is placed first. And here the word ‘come’ and the word ‘monk’

original: aṭṭhatvā dutiyāvibhatyatthabhūte saṅghārāmasaṅkhāte aññapadatthe vattanti, tato samāseneva
analyzed: saṅghārāma saṅkhāte añña padatthe vattanti tatas samāsena iva
translated: do not stand for their own meaning, but they occur in the meaning of the second case, which is the other part of speech called ‘monastery’,

original: kammatthassa abhihitattā puna dutiyā na hoti. Tathā āgatasamaṇā sāvatthi, āgatasamaṇaṃ🔽jetavanaṃ. Paṭipannā addhikā yaṃ paṭipannaddhiko patho, abhirūḷhāva, ṇijāyaṃ nāvaṃ
analyzed: kammatthassa abhihita ttā puna dutiyā na hoti tathā āgatasamaṇā sāvatthi āgatasamaṇam  jetavanam paṭipannāḥ addhikāḥ yam paṭipannaddhikaḥ pathaḥ abhirūḍhau nijāyam nāvam
translated: so by the compound itself the meaning of the case is stated, and so the second case is not made again. Likewise ‘come-monks Sāvatthī’, ‘come-monk Jetavana’;

original: sā abhirūḷhavāṇijā nāvā.
analyzed: sā abhirūḍha vāṇijā nāvā
translated: the road that is gone along is ‘gone-along-road’; the ship that is boarded is ‘boarded-ship’.

original: (Kha) tatiyatthe-jitāni indriyāni yena so jitindriyo samaṇo, evaṃ diṭṭhadhammo, pattadhammo,
analyzed: indriyāni yena saḥ jitindriyaḥ samaṇaḥ evam diṭṭha dhammo patta dhammo
translated: (Kha) In the third case: the monk who has conquered the faculties is ‘one who has conquered the faculties’; likewise ‘one who has seen the state’, ‘one who has attained the state’,

original: katakicco. Vijitā mārā anenāti vijitamāro bhagavā, paṭividdhasabbadhammo. Karaṇatthe-chinno🔽rukkho yena so chinnarukkho pharasu.
analyzed: kata kiccaḥ vijitāḥ mārāḥ anena ati vijita māraḥ bhagavā paṭividdha sabba dhammo karaṇa atthe chinnaḥ  rukkhaḥ yena saḥ chinna rukkhaḥ pharasu
translated: has done what had to be done. The Blessed One is called “one who has conquered Māra” because he has conquered Māra by overcoming all the taints. The axe is the implement by which a tree is felled.

original: (Ga) catutthiyatthe-dinno suṅko yassa so dinnasuṅko rājā, dinnaṃ bhojanaṃ assāti dinnabhojano.
analyzed: suṅkaḥ yassa saḥ dinna suṅkaḥ rājā dinnam bhojanam assa ati dinna bhojanaḥ
translated: (Ga) In the fourth-locative sense: The king to whom the stake was given is the “one to whom the stake was given” . The one who was given food is the “one who was given food” .

original: (Gha) pañcamiyatthe-niggatā janā yasmā so niggatajano gāmo, niggato ayo=sukhaṃ yasmāti nirayo, nikkile- so. Apetaṃ viññāṇaṃ asmāti apetaviññāṇo matakāyo, apagatabhayabheravo arahā.
analyzed: gha pañcamiya tthe niggatāḥ janāḥ yasmā saḥ niggata janaḥ gāmaḥ niggataḥ ayaḥ sukham yasmā ati nirayaḥ nikkile saḥ apetam viññāṇam asmā ati apeta viññāṇaḥ mata kāyaḥ apagata bhaya bheravaḥ arahā
translated: (Gha) In the fifth-locative sense: The village from which people have departed is the “one from which people have departed” . The place from which iron has departed is the “one from which iron has departed” = the happy place . The one from whom defilements have departed is the “one from whom defilements have departed” . The body of a dead person from whom consciousness has departed is the “one from whom consciousness has departed” . The one from whom fear and trembling have departed is the “one from whom fear and trembling have departed” = the arahant.

original: (Ṅa) chaṭṭhiyatthe-chinnā hatthā yassa so chinnahattho. Evaṃ paripuṇṇasaṅkappo khīṇāsavo,🔽vīto rāgo assāti vītarāgo. Dve padāni assāti dvipado, dvihattho paṭo. Tevijjoti ettha
analyzed: hatthāḥ yassa saḥ chinna hatthaḥ evam paripuṇṇa saṅkappaḥ khīṇa āsavaḥ  vītaḥ rāgaḥ assa ati vīta rāgaḥ dve padāni assa ati dvipadaḥ dvi hattho paṭaḥ tevijjaḥ ti ettha
translated: (Ṇa) In the sixth-locative sense: The one whose hands have been cut off is the “one whose hands have been cut off” . The one whose every wish has been fulfilled is the “one whose every wish has been fulfilled” . The one whose cankers have been destroyed is the “one whose cankers have been destroyed” .

original: tivijjo evāti sakatthe ṇo vuddhi ca. Catuppado, pañca cakkhūni assāti pañcacakkhu
analyzed: ti vijjaḥ eva ati saka atthe ṇaḥ vuddhi ca catuppadaḥ pañca cakkhūni assa ati pañcacakkhu
translated: The one who is free from passion is the “one free from passion” . The one who has two feet is the “one with two feet” . The cloth with two hands is the “one with two hands” . The one who has three knowledges is the “one with three knowledges” . Here the ṇo is in the sense of “own” and the vuddhi is in the sense of “increase” . The one with four feet is the “one with four feet” . The one with five eyes is the “one with five eyes” .

original: bhagavā, chaḷabhiñño, “ghapassā”dinā rassattaṃ. Navaṅgaṃ satthusāsanaṃ. Dasabalo,
analyzed: bhagavā chaḷabhiññaḥ ghapassādinā rassattam navaṅgam satthu sāsanam dasa balo
translated: The Blessed One, the One of the Six Kinds of Knowledge, “ghapassā” etc., the One of the Nine-fold Doctrine. The One of the Ten Powers,

original: anantañāṇo. Tīṇi dasa parimāṇa+mesaṃti tidasā devā, idha parimāṇasaddasannimānato🔽dasasaddo saṅkhyāne vattate. Ayaṃ paccayo etesanti idappaccayā, uttarapade “imassi+daṃ
analyzed: tīṇi dasa tidasāḥ devāḥ idha  dasa saddaḥ saṅkhyāne vattate ayam paccayaḥ etesanti idappaccayāḥ uttara pade imassa idam
translated: the One of Infinite Knowledge. The Three Tens are the measure of these, thus they are the Thirty Gods. Here the word “ten” is used in the sense of measure.

original: vā”ti imassa idaṃ. Ko pabhavo assāti kiṃ pabhavo kāyo. Vigataṃ malaṃ assāti vimalo,🔽sundaro gandho assāti sugandhaṃ candanaṃ, evaṃ susīlo, sumukho, kucchito gandho assāti🔽duggandhaṃ kuṇapaṃ, dummukho, duṭṭhu mano assāti dummano, evaṃ dussīlo. Tapo eva
analyzed: vāti imassa idam kaḥ pabhavaḥ assa ati kim pabhavaḥ kāyaḥ vigatam malam assa ati vimalaḥ  sundaraḥ gandhaḥ assa ati su gandham candanam evam su sīlaḥ su mukhaḥ kucchitaḥ gandhaḥ assa ati  duggandham kuṇapam dummukhaḥ duṭṭhu manaḥ assa ati dummanaḥ evam dussīlaḥ eva
translated: These are the conditions for these, thus they are the conditions for this. In the subsequent word “imassi+daṃ vā” this is that. What is the light of this? What is the body? The one who is free from stain is the stainless one.

original: dhanaṃ assāti tapodhano. Khantisaṅkhātaṃ balaṃ assāti khantibalo. Indoti nāmaṃ etassāti indanāmo.
analyzed: dhanam assa ati tapodhanaḥ khanti saṅkhātam balam assa ati khanti balaḥ indo iti nāmam etassa ati inda nāmo
translated: The one who has a good smell is the one with good scent. The one who has a bad smell is the one with bad scent. The one who has a bad face is the one with a bad face. The one who has a bad mind is the one with a bad mind. Thus the one with bad virtue. The one who has wealth in the form of austerity is the one with austerity as wealth. The one who has the strength called patience is the one with patience as strength. The one who has the name Indra is the one with the name Indra.

original: Chandajātādīsu visesanavisesitabbānaṃ yathicchitattā ubhayaṃ pubbaṃ nipatati, kamātikkame
analyzed: chanda jāta ādīsu visesana visesitabbānam yathicchita ttā ubhayam pubbam nipatati kama atikkame
translated: In the case of “chandajāta” etc., both are placed first because of the desire to specify the particular.

original: payojanābhāvā. Jāto chando assāti jātachando, evaṃ chandajāto. Sañjātapītisomanasso,
analyzed: payojana abhāvā jātaḥ chando assa ati jāta chandaḥ evam chanda jātaḥ sañjāta pīti somanassaḥ
translated: because of the absence of a purpose. He has a desire, thus he is one who has desire, so too one who has arisen desire. He has arisen with rapture and joy,

original: pītisomanassasañjāto. Māsajāto, jātamāso. Chinnahattho, hatthachinno.
analyzed: pīti somanassa sañjātaḥ māsa jātaḥ jāta māsaḥ chinna hatthaḥ hattha chinno
translated: thus he is one who has arisen with rapture and joy. He has a month, thus he is one who has a month. He has a cut hand, thus he is one who has a cut hand.

original: Dīghājaṅghā assāti dīghajaṅgho, ettha pumbhāvo, “ghapassā”dinā rasso ca. Tathā pahūtajivho.
analyzed: dīghājaṅghā assa ati dīghajaṅghaḥ ettha pumbhāvaḥ gha passa ādinā rasso ca tathā pahūta jivho
translated: He has long shanks, thus he is one who has long shanks. Here the masculine gender is used. And also short by “ghapassā” and so on. So too one who has a large tongue.

original: Mahantī paññā assāti mahāpañño. “Itthiyaṃ bhāsitapumi+tthī pume+ve+katthe”ti vīpaccayābhāventassa
analyzed: mahantī paññā assa ati mahā paññaḥ itthiyam bhāsita pumitthī pum eva ekatthā iti vī paccaya a bhāventassa
translated: He has great understanding, thus he is one who has great understanding. “In a woman’s speech a man’s and a woman’s in a man’s” . Because of the absence of a change of vowel,

original: ṭādeso rassattañca. Itthiyanti kiṃ, khamādhano. Bhāsitapumāti kiṃ, saddhādhuro. Paññāpakatiko,
analyzed: ṭādesaḥ itthiyanti kim kim saddhādhuraḥ
translated: the -ā ending is short. In a woman, what? A woman of good wealth. In a woman’s speech, what? A man of good strength. One who has understanding by nature,

original: paññāvisuddhiko, ettha “ltvitthiyūhi ko”ti ko. Gaṇḍīvadhanvāti pakatantarena siddhaṃ.🔽Nānā=ppakārā dumā nānādumā, nānādumehi patitāni nānādumapatitāni, nānādumapatitāni
analyzed: ettha kaḥ iti kaḥ gaṇḍīvadhanvā iti paka tantarena siddham  nānā ppakārāḥ dumāḥ nānā dumāḥ nānā dumehi patitāni nānā duma patitāni nānā duma patitāni
translated: one who has purified understanding. Here “ko by ltvitthiyūhi” , thus ko. A bow with a string, is established by a different rule.🔽Various kinds of trees are various trees. Fallen from various trees are fallen from various trees. And they are fallen from various trees

original: ca tāni pupphāni ceti nānādumapatitapupphāni, tehi vāsitā nānādumapatitapupphavāsitā,
analyzed: ca tāni pupphāni ca iti nānā duma patita pupphāni tehi vāsitā nānā duma patita puppha vāsitā
translated: and they are flowers, thus they are fallen from various trees and flowers. Perfumed by them are perfumed by fallen from various trees and flowers.

original: nānādumapatitapupphavāsitāsānuyassaso nānādumapatitapupphavāsitasānu pabbato, ayaṃ
analyzed: nānā duma patita puppha vāsita āsānu yassasaḥ nānā duma patita puppha vāsita sānu pabbataḥ ayaṃ
translated: The mountain called Anuyassa, which is perfumed by flowers fallen from various trees, and the mountain called Anupassa, which is perfumed by flowers fallen from various trees,

original: visesana+amādisamāsagabbho tulyādhikaraṇaaññapadattho.🔽(Ca) sattamyatthe-sampannāni sassāni yasmiṃ so sampannasasso janapado. Sulabho piṇḍo
analyzed: visesana ama ādi samāsa gabbhaḥ tulya adhikaraṇa añña padatthaḥ  ca sattamī atthe sampannāni sassāni yasmin saḥ sampanna sassaḥ janapadaḥ sulabhaḥ piṇḍaḥ
translated: is the womb of a compound consisting of a noun with a post-position, having a different word as its head.🔽(Ca) In the sense of the locative case: The country in which the crops are good is called sampannasasso. The country in which alms-food is easily obtained is called sulabhapiṇḍo.

original: imasminti sulabhapiṇḍo deso. Ākiṇṇā manussā yassaṃ sā ākiṇṇamanussā rājadhānī. Bahavo🔽tāpasā etasminti bahutāpaso assamo. Upacitaṃ maṃsalohitaṃ asminti upacitamaṃsalohitaṃ
analyzed: imasmin ti sulabha piṇḍaḥ desaḥ ākiṇṇāḥ manussāḥ yassam sā ākiṇṇa manussā rājadhānī bahavaḥ  tāpasāḥ etasmin ti bahu tāpasaḥ assamaḥ upacitam maṃsa lohitam asmin ti upacita maṃsa lohitam
translated: The capital city in which the people are crowded is called ākiṇṇamanussā. The hermitage in which there are many ascetics is called bahutāpaso.

original: sarīraṃ. Bahavo sāmino asminti bahusāmikaṃ nagaraṃ, bahū nadiyo asminti bahunadiko,
analyzed: sarīram bahavaḥ sāminaḥ asmin ti bahu sāmikam nagaram bahū nadiyaḥ asmin ti bahu nadikaḥ
translated: The body in which flesh and blood are accumulated is called upacitamaṃsalohitaṃ. The city in which there are many owners is called bahusāmikaṃ, the country in which there are many rivers is called bahunadiko,

original: īkārantattā kapaccayo. Evaṃ bahujambukaṃ vanaṃ, bahavo kattāro asmiṃ assa vāti bahukattuko
analyzed: īkāra anta ttā ka paccayaḥ evam bahu jambukam vanam bahavaḥ kattāraḥ asmin assa vāti bahu kattukaḥ
translated: because of the ending in -ika. In the same way, the forest in which there are many jackals is called bahujambukaṃ, the country in which there are many makers is called bahukattuko,

original: deso, evaṃ bahubhattuko, “ltvitthiyūhi ko”ti ko.
analyzed: desaḥ evam bahu bhattukaḥ l tu itthi yūhi kaḥ iti kaḥ
translated: in the same way, bahubhattuko, “bahu + itthi + ū + ko”.

original: 2. Bhinnādhikaraṇo yathā-ekarattiṃ vāso assāti ekarattivāso, samānena janena saddhiṃ🔽vāso assāti samānavāso puriso. Ubhato byañjana+massāti ubhatobyañjanako, vibhatyalopo🔽“vā+ññato”ti ko ca, chattaṃ pāṇimhi assāti chattapāṇi, evaṃ daṇḍapāṇi, satthapāṇi,🔽vajirapāṇi, khaggahattho, pattahattho, dāne ajjhāsayo assāti dānajjhāsayo dānādhimuttiko,
analyzed: bhinna adhikaraṇaḥ yathā eka rattim vāsaḥ assāti eka ratti vāsaḥ samānena janena saddhim  vāsaḥ assa ati samāna vāsaḥ puriso ubhatas byañjanam assa ati ubhatobyañjanakaḥ  vāññataḥ ti ko ca chattam pāṇimhi assa ati chatta pāṇi evam daṇḍa pāṇi sattha pāṇi  vajirapāṇi khagga hatthaḥ patta hatthaḥ dāne ajjhāsayaḥ assa ati dāna ajjhāsayaḥ dāna adhimuttiko
translated: 2. With different bases: As in “He will stay one night,” “He will stay one night” (ekarattiṃ vāso assāti ekarattivāso), “He will stay with the same people,” “He will stay with the same people” (samānena janena saddhiṃ vāso assāti samānavāso puriso). “He has both sexes,” “He has both sexes” (ubhato byañjana+massāti ubhatobyañjanako), the case-ending is elided🔽“He has a parasol in his hand,” “He has a parasol in his hand” (chattaṃ pāṇimhi assāti chattapāṇi), likewise “He has a staff in his hand,” “He has a sword in his hand,” “He has a bowl in his hand,”🔽“He is intent on giving,” “He is intent on giving” (dāne ajjhāsayo assāti dānajjhāsayo dānādhimuttiko),🔽

original: buddhabhattiko, saddhammagāravo iccādi.
translated: 2. When the words are in different case-relations, as in the following: “He has a stay of one night” = ekarattivāso; “He has a stay with a companion” = samānavāso puriso. “He has a member on both sides” = ubhatobyañjanako; the case-ending is elided. “He has a fan in his hand” = vātapānahattho; “He has an umbrella in his hand” = chattapāṇi; so also daṇḍapāṇi, satthapāṇi, vajirapāṇi, khaggahattho, pattahattho. “He has a disposition to giving” = dānajjhāsayo; he is intent on giving. “He has a devotion to the Buddha” = buddhabhattiko; “He has a respect for the True Idea” = saddhammagāravo.

original: 3. Tipado yathā-parakkamenā+dhigatā sampadā yehi te parakkamādhigatasampadā mahāpurisā.🔽Evaṃ dhammādhigatabhogā. Onīto pattato pāṇi yena so onītapattapāṇi. Sīhassa pubbaddhamiva
analyzed: tipadaḥ yathā parakkamena adhigatā sampadā yehi te parakkama adhigata sampadā mahā purisā  evam dhamma adhigata bhogā onītaḥ pattataḥ pāṇi yena saḥ onīta patta pāṇi sīhassa pubbaddham iva
translated: . When the words are in the same case-relation, as in the following: “They are men who have won prosperity by their own valour” = parakkamādhigatasampadā mahāpurisā.

original: kāyo assāti sīhapubbaddhakāyo. Mattā bahavo mātaṅgā asminti mattabahumātaṅgaṃ vanaṃ.
analyzed: kāyaḥ assa ati sīha pubbaddha kāyaḥ mattāḥ bahavaḥ mātaṅgāḥ asmin ti matta bahu mātaṅgam vanam
translated: So also dhammādhigatabhogā. “He is one who has lowered his hand from the bowl” = onītapattapāṇi. “His body is like the front part of a lion” = sīhapubbaddhakāyo. “This wood has many mature elephants” = mattabahumātaṅgaṃ vanaṃ.

original: 4. Na-nipātapubbapado yathā-natthi etassa samoti assamo, “ṭa nañassā”ti nassa ṭo.🔽Evaṃ appaṭipuggalo, aputtako, ahetuko, kapaccayo, eva+muparipi ñeyyaṃ. Natthi saṃvāso
analyzed: na nipāta pubba padaḥ yathā an atthi etassa samaḥ ti as samaḥ ṭa nañassa ati nassa ṭaḥ  evam appaṭipuggalaḥ aputtakaḥ ahetukaḥ ka paccayaḥ evam upari pi ñeyyam natthi saṃvāso
translated: 4. A prefix-noun in the first place, as in: “There is no equal to him” = “asamo” (unequalled), “na-nipātapubbapado yathā-natthi etassa samoti assamo, “ṭa nañassā”ti nassa ṭo”.

original: etenāti asaṃvāso, na vijjate vuṭṭhi etthāti avuṭṭhiko janapado, abhikkhuko vihāro.
analyzed: etena ati a saṃvāsaḥ na vijjate vuṭṭhi ettha ati avuṭṭhikaḥ janapadaḥ abhikkhukaḥ vihāro
translated: Thus: “No equal” = “appaṭipuggalo”, “No son” = “aputtako”, “No cause” = “ahetuko”, “No condition” = “kapaccayo”, “No companion” = “eva+muparipi ñeyyaṃ”. “Natthi saṃvāso” = “asaṃvāso”, “No purification is found here” = “avuṭṭhiko janapado”, “No alms are found here” = “abhikkhuko vihāro”.

original: Evaṃ anuttaro “ana sare”ti ana, evaṃ anantaṃ, anāsavo.
analyzed: evam anuttaraḥ sara iti anaḥ evam anantam anāsavaḥ
translated: Thus: “No superior” = “anuttaro”, “No end” = “anantaṃ”, “No canker” = “anāsavo”.

original: 5. Paṭhamātthe sahapubbapado yathā-saha hetunā vattati so sahetuko sahetu vā, “sahassa🔽so+ññatthe”ti sahassa so, evaṃ sappītikā, sappaccayā, sakileso, saupādāno, saparivāro
analyzed: paṭhamā tthe saha pubba padaḥ yathā saha hetunā vattati saḥ sa hetukaḥ sa hetu vā  so uññattha iti sa evam sappītikā sappaccayā sa kilesaḥ sa upādānaḥ sa parivāraḥ
translated: . A prefix-noun in the first place together with a second noun, as in: “Together with a cause he goes” = “sahetuko”, “Together with a cause” = “sahetu vā”, “sahassa

original: sahaparivāro vā, saha mūlena uddhaṭo samūluddhaṭo rukkho.
analyzed: saha parivāraḥ vā saha mūlena uddhaṭaḥ sa mūla uddhaṭaḥ rukkho
translated: so+ññatthe”ti so = “sahassa so”, “Together with happiness” = “sappītikā”, “Together with conditions” = “sappaccayā”, “Together with defilement” = “sakileso”, “Together with attachment” = “saupādāno”, “Together with a retinue” = “sapparivāro”, “Together with a retinue” = “sahaparivāro”, “Together with the root it is dug up” = “samūluddhaṭo rukkho”.

original: 6. Upamānopameyyajotakaivayutto upamānapubbapado paṭhamāya yathā-nigrodho iva parimaṇḍalo
analyzed: upamāna upameyya jotaka eva yuttaḥ upamāna pubba padaḥ paṭhamāya yathā nigrodhaḥ iva parimaṇḍalaḥ
translated: . A prefix-noun in the first place together with a simile, as in: “Like a banyan tree it is round” = “parimaṇḍalo nigrodho iva”.

original: yo so nigrodhaparimaṇḍalo. Saṅkho viya paṇḍaro ayanti saṅkhapaṇḍaro, kāko viya sūro
analyzed: yaḥ saḥ nigrodha parimaṇḍalaḥ saṅkhaḥ viya paṇḍaraḥ ayanti saṅkha paṇḍaraḥ kākaḥ viya sūraḥ
translated: He who is round like a banyan-tree, is white like a conch, is called a conch-white crow.

original: ayanti kākasūro. Cakkhu iva bhūto ayaṃ paramatthadassanatoti cakkhubhūto bhagavā.
analyzed: ayanti kākasūro cakkhu iva bhūtaḥ ayam parama attha dassanato ti cakkhu bhūtaḥ bhagavā
translated: He is the one who is round like a banyan-tree’s root. He is white like a conch, thus he is the White- Conch-Like One. He is bright like a crow, thus he is the Crow-Bright One. He is the one who is like an eye in the sense of seeing the ultimate truth, thus he is the Eye-Like One, the Blessed One.

original: Evaṃ atthabhūto, dhammabhūto, brahmabhūto, andhabhūto. Muñjapabbajamiva bhūtā ayaṃ🔽muñjapabbajabhūtā kudiṭṭhi. Tantākulamiva jātā ayaṃti tantākulajātā.
analyzed: evam attha bhūtaḥ dhamma bhūtaḥ brahma bhūtaḥ andha bhūtaḥ muñja pabbajam iva bhūtā ayam  muñja pabbaja bhūtā tantā kulam iva jātā tantā kula jātā
translated: Thus he is the One who is the Meaning, the One who is the Truth, the One who is the Divine, the One who is the Blind, the One who is the Muñja-Grass-Like, the One who is the Kuṭiṭṭhī-Grass-Like, the One who is the Entangled-Thread-Like.

original: Chaṭṭhyatthe-suvaṇṇassa vaṇṇo viya vaṇṇo yassa so suvaṇṇavaṇṇo bhagavā, majjhapadalopo.
analyzed: chaṭṭhī atthe su vaṇṇassa vaṇṇaḥ viya vaṇṇaḥ yassa saḥ suvaṇṇa vaṇṇaḥ bhagavā majjha pada lopaḥ
translated: In the sense of ‘having the colour of’ the compound is in the sixth case, as in ‘He is the one who has a colour like the colour of gold, thus he is the Golden-Coloured One, the Blessed One’, with elision of the middle term.

original: Nāgassa gati viya gati assāti nāgagati. Evaṃ sīhagati, nāgavikkamo, sīhavikkamo,
analyzed: nāgassa gati viya gati assa ati nāga gati evam sīha gati nāga vikkamaḥ sīha vikkamaḥ
translated: He is the one who has a gait like the gait of a nāga, thus he is the Nāga-Gaiter. Thus he is the Lion-Gaiter, the Nāga-Striding, the Lion-Striding,

original: sīhahanu. Eṇissa viya jaṅghā assāti eṇijaṅgho. Brahmuno viya saro assāti brahmassaro.
analyzed: sīha hanu eṇissa viya jaṅghā assa ati eṇi jaṅghaḥ brahmunaḥ viya saraḥ assa ati brahmassaraḥ
translated: the Lion-Jawed. He is the one who has calves like a black antelope, thus he is the Black-Antelope-Calved. He is the one who has a voice like Brahmā’s, thus he is the Brahmā-Voiced.

original: 7. Vāsaddatthe saṅkhyāubhayapado yathā-dve vā tayo vā dvatti, dvattayo ca te pattā
analyzed: saṅkhyā ubhaya padaḥ yathā dve vā tayaḥ vā ca te
translated: In the sense of ‘having a number of’ the compound is in the sixth case, as in ‘two or three or two and three’, ‘two and three’, ‘two and three’,

original: ceti dvattipattā, “tisva”iti tisadde pare dvissa attaṃ. Dvīhaṃ vā tīhaṃ vā dvīhatīhaṃ,
analyzed: ca iti ti sadde pare dvissa attam dvīham vā tīham vā dvīha tīham
translated: The word dvīhaṃ, “two days,” and tīhaṃ, “three days,” are formed in the same way.🔽The words chappañcavācā, “six or five words,” and sattaṭṭhamāsā, “seven or eight months,” are formed in the same way.

original: cha vā pañca vā vācā chappañcavācā, evaṃ sattaṭṭhamāsā, ekayojanadviyojanāni.
analyzed: cha vā pañca vā vācā chappañca vācā evam satta ṭṭha māsāḥ eka yojana dvi yojanāni
translated: The words ekayojanadviyojanāni, “one, two leagues,” are formed in the same way.

original: 8. Disantarālattho yathā-pubbassā ca dakkhiṇassā ca disāya yadantarālaṃ sā pubbadakkhiṇā vidisā. Ettha –
analyzed: dis antarāla atthaḥ yathā pubbassā ca dakkhiṇassā ca disāya yat antarālam sā pubba dakkhiṇā vidisā ettha
translated: The word pubbadakkhiṇā, “south-east,” is formed by the addition of the locative case-ending to the words pubbā and dakkhiṇā.

original: 69. Sabbādayo vuttimatteti
analyzed: sabba ādayaḥ vuttimattā iti
translated: All the above are used only in the sense of “direction.”🔽The words sabbā, etc., which are feminine in form, are used only in the sense of “direction” in the masculine.

original: Itthivācakā sabbādayo vuttimatte pumeva honti. Evaṃ pubbuttarā, aparadakkhiṇā, pacchimuttarā. Pubbā ca sā dakkhiṇā ceti vā.🔽9. Byatihāralakkhaṇo yathā – “tattha gahetvā tena paharitvā yuddhe sarūpaṃ”ti suttena🔽samāse kate kesesu ca kesesu ca gahetvā yuddhaṃ pavattaṃ kesākesī, daṇḍehi ca daṇḍehi
analyzed: itthi vācakā sabba ādayaḥ vuttimatte pum eva honti evam pubbuttarā apara dakkhiṇā pacchima uttarā pubbā ca sā dakkhiṇā ca iti vā  byatihāra lakkhaṇaḥ yathā tattha gahetvā tena paharitvā yuddhe sarūpam ti suttena  samāse kate kesesu ca kesesu ca gahetvā yuddham pavattam kesākesī daṇḍehi ca daṇḍehi
translated: The words pubbuttarā, “north-east,” aparadakkhiṇā, “south-west,” and pacchimuttarā, “north-west,” are formed in the same way.🔽The word pubbadakkhiṇā is formed by the addition of the locative case-ending to the words pubbā and dakkhiṇā.🔽The word kesākesī is formed by the addition of the locative case-ending to the words kesā and kesā.🔽The word daṇḍādaṇḍī is formed by the addition of the locative case-ending to the words daṇḍā and daṇḍā.🔽The words kesākesī and daṇḍādaṇḍī are used in the sense of “a fight in which the combatants seize each other by the hair” and “a fight in which the combatants strike each other with sticks.”

original: ca paharitvā yuddhaṃ pavattaṃ daṇḍādaṇḍīti hoti. Ettha ca “cī vītihāre”ti cīpaccaye
analyzed: ca paharitvā yuddham pavattam daṇḍādaṇḍī iti hoti ettha ca cī vītihāre iti cī paccaye
translated: The words kesākesī and daṇḍādaṇḍī are formed by the addition of the locative case-ending to the words kesā and kesā and to the words daṇḍā and daṇḍā.

original: “cismiṃ”ti ākāro, evaṃ muṭṭhāmuṭṭhī.
analyzed: ākāraḥ evam muṭṭhāmuṭṭhī
translated: “In what?” is the mode. Thus it is in the case of each.

original: Sobhaṇo gandho sugandho, so assa atthīti sugandhīhi atthiatthe īpaccayena siddhaṃ.
analyzed: sobhaṇaḥ gandhaḥ su gandhaḥ saḥ assa atthi iti sugandhīhi atthi atthe ī paccayena siddham
translated: A good smell is sugandha. He has that, thus he is sugandhī. The word is formed by the addition of the suffix ī to sugandha.

original: Yasmā ca bhaddāya kāpilāniyā apadāne “puno pattaṃ gahetvāna, sodhayitvā sugandhinā”ti
analyzed: yasmai ca bhaddāya kāpilāniyāḥ apadāne punar pattam gahetvāna sodhayitvā sugandhinā iti
translated: And since it is said in the Bhaddā-Kāpilānī Apadāna: “Then taking a bowl, and purifying it with a good smell,”

original: vuttaṃ, tasmā vuttiyaṃ ikārantassa abhāvadīpanatthaṃ “sugandhi duggandhīti payogā
analyzed: vuttam tasmā vuttiyam ikāra antassa abhāva dīpana attham sugandhi duggandhi iti payogāḥ
translated: it is said in the commentary: “The use of sugandhī and duggandhī🔽is not seen in the texts.

original: na dissatī”ti vuttaṃ. Sugandhināti ekavacane rasso.
analyzed: na dissati iti vuttam sugandhinā iti ekavacane rassaḥ
translated: Sugandhin is a single word with a double meaning.”

original: 19. Catthe
analyzed: catthe
translated: In the sense of “and”

original: Anekaṃsyādyantaṃ catthe ekatthaṃ vā hoti. Samuccayo anvācayo itarītarayogo samāhāroti casaddassa attho catubbidho.
analyzed: an ekaṃsi ādi antam ca tthe ekattham vā hoti samuccayaḥ anvācayaḥ itarītara yogo samāhāraḥ iti ca saddassa attho catubbidho
translated: The word anekaṃsyādyantaṃ is in the sense of “and” or in the sense of “or.” The meaning of the word ca is fourfold: combination, repetition, mutual dependence, and collection.

original: Tattha samuccayā+nvācayesu samāso na hoti, kriyāsāpekkhatāya nāmānaṃ aññamaññaṃ ayuttatthattā,
analyzed: tattha samuccaya anvācayesu samāsaḥ na hoti kriyā sāpekkha tāya nāmānam aññam aññam ayutta attha ttā
translated: Herein, in the case of combination and repetition, there is no compounding, because the names are not related to each other, since they are dependent on different actions,

original: yathā-cīvaraṃ piṇḍapātañca paccayaṃ sayanāsanaṃ adāsi, dānañca dehi, sīlañcarakkhāhi.
analyzed: yathā cīvaram piṇḍapātam ca paccayam sayanāsanam adāsi dānam ca dehi sīlam ca rakkhāhi
translated: as in the case of “robes, alms food, and requisites,” and “give a gift, and observe virtue.”

original: Itarītarayoge samāhāre ca aññamaññāpekkhattā samāso.
analyzed: itarītara yoge samāhāre ca aññamañña apekkha ttā samāsaḥ
translated: In the case of mutual dependence and collection, there is compounding, because they are dependent on each other.

original: Ubhayatthapadhāne catthe katha+mekatthībhāvo sambhave+ti ce, vuttañhi –🔽Sappadhānāpi yattha+tthā, mitho sāpekkhatā iva;🔽Kriyāsambandhasāmaññā, catthe+katthaṃ ta+duccateti.🔽Yasmā ekatthībhāvepi satīyasatīyatthe padhānaṃ, tasmā idaṃ vuccate –
analyzed: ubhayattha padhāne catthe katham ekatthībhāvaḥ sambhave iti ce vuttam hi  sa padhānā api yatthatthā mitho sa apekkha tā iva  kriyā sambandha sāmaññā catthekattham tad uccatā iti  yasmai ekatthībhāve pi satīya satīya tthe padhānam tasmai idam vuccate
translated: “But how can there be a single meaning in the case of the two terms ‘with predominance’ and ‘with object’?”—For it is said:🔽“Though with predominance and with object,🔽They are as if mutually dependent,🔽Because of the similarity of function and relation,🔽The single meaning in the case of the two terms is stated thus.”🔽And since there is predominance in the case of the more and the less, this is said:

original: Na+ññamaññaṃ visesenti, catthe atthā padāniva;🔽Satthavutyī ato tesaṃ, padhānatthaṃ+bhiyujjate.🔽Itarītarayogo ca, samāhārotya+yaṃ dvidhā;🔽Samāso tu imaṃ aññe, jānante dvandanāmato.🔽Itarītarayogasmiṃ+vayavatthassa sambhavo;🔽Samudāyatirobhāvo, paraṃva liṅga+massa ca.🔽Samudāyabbhavo yasmiṃ+vayavā ca tirohitā;🔽Samāhārotya+yaṃ cattho, so ca hoti napuṃsake.🔽Itarītarayogo yathā-sāriputto ca moggallāno ca sāriputtamoggallānā, bho sāriputtamoggallānā
analyzed: naññam aññam visesenti ca tthe atthā padān iva 🔽sattha vutyī atas tesam 🔽ca dvidhā 🔽samāsaḥ tu imam aññe jānante dvanda nāmataḥ 🔽sambhavaḥ 🔽samudāya tirobhāvo ca 🔽ca tirohitā 🔽samāhāraḥ iti ayam cattho saḥ ca hoti napuṃsake 🔽itarītara yogaḥ yathā sāriputtaḥ ca moggallānaḥ ca sāriputta moggallānāḥ bho sāriputta moggallānā
translated: If it be said: “How can there be a single-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the case of the two-meaning in the

original: iccādi. Avayavapadhānattā bahuvacanameva. Samaṇā ca brāhmaṇā ca samaṇabrāhmaṇā, evaṃ
analyzed: i t ca ādi bahuvacanam eva samaṇā ca brāhmaṇā ca samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ evam
translated: etc. The plural is used because of the predominance of the component parts. Ascetics and brahmans are samaṇabrāhmaṇā, so too

original: brāhmaṇagahapatikā, khattiyabrāhmaṇā, devamanussā, candimasūriyā.
analyzed: brāhmaṇa gahapatikā khattiya brāhmaṇāḥ deva manussā candima sūriyā
translated: brāhmaṇagahapatikā, khattiyabrāhmaṇā, devamanussā, candimasūriyā.

original: 64. Vijjāyonisambandhīna+mā tatra cattheti
analyzed: tatra cattha iti
translated: . Ā is for those connected with knowledge and those connected with origin

original: Vijjāsambandhīnaṃ yonisambandhīnañca catthe ā hotīti ukārassa ā, hotā ca potā ca hotāpotāro. Evaṃ mātāpitaro.
analyzed: vijjā sambandhīnam yoni sambandhīnam ca catthe ā hoti iti ukārassa ā hotā ca potā ca hotāpotāraḥ evam mātā pitaraḥ
translated: Ā is for those connected with knowledge and those connected with origin. Ā is for the ukāra. Hotā and potā are hotāpotāro. So too mātāpitaro.

original: 65. Putteti
analyzed: putta iti
translated: . Putteti

original: Putte uttarapade pitādīna+mā hoti catthe. Pitā ca putto ca pitāputtā, evaṃ mātāputtā.
analyzed: putte uttara pade hoti catthe pitā ca puttaḥ ca pitā puttā evam mātā puttā
translated: Ho is for those beginning with pitā in the sense of “child” when putta is the following word. Pitā and putto are pitāputtā, so too mātāputtā.

original: 78. Jāyāya jayaṃ patimhi
analyzed: jāyāya jayam patimhi
translated: . Jayaṃ patimhi jāyāya

original: Patimhi pare jāyāya jayaṃ hoti. Jāyā ca pati ca jayampatayo. Jānipatīti pakatantarena siddhaṃ, jāni ca pati ca jānipati. Evaṃ jampati dampatīti.
analyzed: patimhi pare jāyāya jayam hoti jāyā ca pati ca jayampatayaḥ jānipati iti pakata antarena siddham jāni ca pati ca jānipati evam jampati dampati iti
translated: Jayaṃ is for jāyāya when pati is the following word. Jāyā and pati are jayampatayo. Jānipati is established by the other method. Jāni and pati are jānipati. So too jampati, dampatī.

original: Kvaci appasaraṃ pubbaṃ nipatati, yathā-cando ca sūriyo ca candasūriyā, nigamā ca janapadā ca nigamajanapadā. Evaṃ surāsuragaruḍamanujabhujagagandhabbā.
analyzed: kvaci appasaram pubbam nipatati yathā cando ca sūriyo ca canda sūriyāḥ nigamā ca janapadā ca nigama janapadāḥ evam sura asura garuḍa manuja bhujaga gandhabbāḥ
translated: Sometimes the first member of a compound is abbreviated, e.g. candasūriyā (the moon and sun), nigamajanapadā (the towns and the country districts). In the same way surāsuragaruḍamanujabhujagagandhabbā.

original: Kvaci ivaṇṇu+vaṇṇantānaṃ pubbanipāto, yathā-aggidhumā, gatibuddhibhujapaṭhaharakarasayā, dhātuliṅgāni.
analyzed: kvaci i va ṇ u vaṇ antānam pubba nipātaḥ yathā aggi dhumāḥ gati buddhi bhuja paṭha hara kara sayā dhātu liṅgāni
translated: Sometimes the first member of a compound is in the contracted form, e.g. aggidhumā (fire and smoke), gatibuddhibhujapaṭhaharakarasayā (going, knowing, taking, eating, carrying, and giving), dhātuliṅgāni (elements and signs).

original: Kvaci sarādiakārantaṃ pubbaṃ nipatati, yathā-atthadhammā, atthasaddā, saddatthā vā.
analyzed: kvaci sara ādi akāra antam pubbam nipatati yathā attha dhammāḥ attha saddāḥ saddatthāḥ vā
translated: Sometimes the first member of a compound is in the contracted form and ends in a vowel, e.g. atthadhammā (meaning and things), atthasaddā (meaning and sounds), saddatthā (sounds and meaning).

original: Aññamaññasāpekkhānameva tirohitāvayavabhedo samudāyapadhāno samāhāro, yathā-chattañca upāhanā ca chattupāhanaṃ.
analyzed: aññam añña sa apekkhānam eva tirohita avayava bhedo samudāya padhāno samāhāraḥ yathā chattam ca upāhanā ca chattupāhanam
translated: A compound is a combination of words, the members of which are mutually dependent, in which the first member is predominant and the other members are subordinate, and in which the subordinate members are hidden by the predominance of the first member, e.g. chattupāhanaṃ (umbrella and shoes).

original: 20. Samāhāre napuṃsakanti
analyzed: samāhāre napuṃsaka nti
translated: In a compound the gender is neuter.

original: Samāhāre sabbattha napuṃsakaliṅgaṃ bhavati, samāhārasse+kattā ekavacanameva.🔽23. Syādīsu rassoti
analyzed: samāhāre sabbattha napuṃsaka liṅgam bhavati samāhārassa ekattā ekavacanam eva  sya ādīsu rassaḥ iti
translated: In a compound the gender is always neuter, and the number is always singular, because the compound is a single unit.🔽In the case of syādīsu the ending is rassa.

original: Napuṃsake vattamānassa syādīsu rasso. Bho chattupāhana, chattupāhanaṃ, chattupāhanena iccādi.
analyzed: napuṃsake vattamānassa si ādīsu rassaḥ bho chattupāhana chattupāhanam chattupāhanena iccādi
translated: In the case of the neuter, the ending in syādīsu is rassa. Bho chattupāhana, chattupāhanaṃ, chattupāhanena.

original: Te ca samāhāritarītarayogā bahulaṃvidhānā niyatavisayāyeva honti, tatrā+yaṃ visayavibhāgo-niruttipiṭakāgato-pāṇi+tūriya+yogga+senaṅgānaṃ,
analyzed: te ca bahulam vidhānāḥ niyata visayāya iva honti tatra ayam
translated: The words pāṇa, tūriya, yogga, senāṅga,

original: niccaverīnaṃ, saṅkhyāparimāṇasaññānaṃ, khuddajantukānaṃ, pacanacaṇḍālānaṃ, caraṇasādhāraṇānaṃ,
analyzed: saṅkhyā parimāṇa saññānam khudda jantukānam pacana caṇḍālānam caraṇa sādhāraṇānam
translated: niccaverī, saṅkhā, parimāṇa, saññā, khuddhajanta, pacana, caṇḍāla, caraṇa,

original: ekajjhāyanapāvacanānaṃ, liṅgavisesānaṃ, vividhaviruddhānaṃ, disānaṃ, nadīnañca niccasamāhārekatthaṃ bhavati.
analyzed: ekajjhāyana pāvacanānam liṅga visesānam vividha viruddhānam disānam nadīnam ca nicca samāhāra ekattham bhavati
translated: ekajjhāyana, pāvacana, liṅga, viruddha, disā, and nadī are always used in the singular.

original: Pāṇaṅgānaṃ-cakkhu ca sotañca cakkhusotaṃ, mukhañca nāsikā ca mukhanāsikaṃ, “syādīsu
analyzed: ca sotam ca cakkhu sotam mukham ca nāsikā ca mukha nāsikam syādīsu
translated: Pāṇaṅga: cakkhu ca sotañca = cakkhusotaṃ, mukhañca nāsikā ca = mukhanāsikaṃ, “syādīsu

original: rasso”ti napuṃsake vattamānassa rasso. Hanu ca gīvā ca hanugīvaṃ, kaṇṇā ca nāsā ca
analyzed: rasso ti napuṃsake vattamānassa rassaḥ hanu ca gīvā ca hanu gīvam kaṇṇā ca nāsā ca
translated: rasso”ti napuṃsake vattamānassa rasso. Hanu ca gīvā ca = hanugīvaṃ, kaṇṇā ca nāsā ca =

original: kaṇṇanāsaṃ, pāṇi ca pādo ca pāṇipādaṃ, chavi ca maṃsañca lohitañca chavimaṃsalohitaṃ,
analyzed: kaṇṇa nāsam pāṇi ca pādaḥ ca pāṇi pādam chavi ca maṃsam ca lohitam ca chavi maṃsa lohitam
translated: kaṇṇanāsaṃ, pāṇi ca pādo ca = pāṇipādaṃ, chavi ca maṃsañca lohitañca = chavimaṃsalohitaṃ,

original: nāmañca rūpañca nāmarūpaṃ, jarā ca maraṇañca jarāmaraṇaṃ.
analyzed: nāman ca rūpam ca nāma rūpam jarā ca maraṇañca jarā maraṇam
translated: nāmañca rūpañca = nāmarūpaṃ, jarā ca maraṇañca = jarāmaraṇaṃ.

original: Tūriyaṅgānaṃ-alaso ca tālambaro ca alasatālambaraṃ, murajo ca gomukho ca murajagomukhaṃ,
analyzed: ca tālambaraḥ ca alasa tālambaram murajaḥ ca gomukhaḥ ca muraja gomukham
translated: The sound of the musical instruments: the alasa and the tālambara are the alasa-tālambara, the muraja and the gomukha are the muraja-gomukha,

original: saṃkho ca paṇavo ca deṇḍimo ca, saṃkhā ca paṇavā ca deṇḍimā cāti vā saṃkhapaṇavadeṇḍimaṃ,🔽paṇavādayo dvepi bherivisesā, maddaviko ca pāṇaviko ca maddavikapāṇavikaṃ, gītañca
analyzed: saṃkhaḥ ca paṇavaḥ ca deṇḍimaḥ ca saṃkhā ca paṇavā ca deṇḍimā ca ati vā saṃkha paṇava deṇḍimam  paṇava ādayaḥ dve pi bheri visesāḥ maddaviko ca pāṇavikaḥ ca maddavika pāṇavikam gītam ca
translated: the conch, the paṇava, and the deṇḍima, the saṅkhapāṇavadeṇḍima,

original: vāditañca gītavāditaṃ, sammañca tāḷañca sammatāḷaṃ, sammaṃti kaṃsatālaṃ, tāḷaṃti hatthatāḷaṃ.
analyzed: vāditam ca gīta vāditam sammañca tāḷam ca samma tāḷam sammanti kaṃsa tālam tāḷanti hattha tāḷam
translated: the paṇava and the maddavika and the pāṇavika are the maddavika-pāṇavika, the singing and the playing of instruments are the gītavādita, the clapping of hands and the beating of time are the sammatāḷa, the sammā is a bronze-tael, the tāḷa is a hand-tael.

original: Yoggaṅgānaṃ-phālo ca pācanañca phālapācanaṃ, yugañca naṅgalañca yuganaṅgalaṃ.
analyzed: ca pācanam ca phālapācanam yugam ca naṅgalam ca yuganaṅgalam
translated: The yoking parts: the plough and the ploughshare are the phālapācana, the yoke and the plough are the yuganaṅgala.

original: Senaṅgānaṃ-hatthino ca assā ca hatthiassaṃ, rathā ca pattikā ca rathapattikaṃ, asi
analyzed: senaṅga anaṃhatthinaḥ ca assā ca hatthi assam rathā ca pattikā ca ratha pattikam asi
translated: The parts of the army: the elephants and the horses are the hatthīassa, the chariots and the infantry are the rathapattika, the sword

original: ca satti ca tomarañca piṇḍañca asisattitomarapiṇḍaṃ, asi ca cammañca asicammaṃ, cammanti
analyzed: ca satti ca tomaram ca piṇḍam ca asi satti tomara piṇḍam asi ca cammam ca asi cammam cammanti
translated: and the spear and the lance and the javelin are the asisattitomarapiṇḍa, the sword and the shield are the asicamma, the shield

original: saravāraṇa-phalakaṃ. Dhanu ca kalāpo ca dhanukalāpaṃ, kalāpo=tuṇīraṃ. Paharaṇañca
analyzed: saravāraṇa phalakam dhanu ca kalāpo ca dhanu kalāpam kalāpa utuṇīram paharaṇam ca
translated: is a shield made of the skin of a rhinoceros. The bow and the quiver are the dhanukalāpa, the quiver is a bamboo case. The weapon🔽and the sword are the paharaṇadaḷha.

original: āvaraṇañca paharaṇāvaraṇaṃ.
analyzed: āvaraṇam ca paharaṇa āvaraṇam
translated: and the covering is the covering of the obstruction.

original: Niccaverīnaṃ-ahi ca nakulo ca, ahī ca nakulā cāti vā ahinakulaṃ. Evaṃ biḷāramūsikaṃ, antassa rassattaṃ. Kākolukaṃ, sappamaṇḍūkaṃ, garuḷasappaṃ, nāgasupaṇṇaṃ.
analyzed: ca nakulo ca ahī ca nakulā ca ati vā ahi nakulam evam biḷāra mūsikam antassa rassattam kākolukam sappa maṇḍūkam garuḷa sappam nāga supaṇṇam
translated: The enemies of the fixed abode are the snake and the mongoose, or the snake and the mongoose-family, thus the snake-mongoose. So too, the cat and the rat, the smallness of the end. The crow and the hen-bird, the serpent and the frog, the garuḍa and the serpent, the nāga and the supaṇṇa.

original: Saṅkhyāparimāṇasaññānaṃ-ekakañca dukañca ekakadukaṃ. Evaṃ, dukatikaṃ, tikacatukkaṃ,
analyzed: saṅkhyā parimāṇa saññānam ekakam ca dukam ca ekaka dukam evam duka tikam tika catukkam
translated: The number and the measure are the one and the two, the one and the two. So too, the two and the three, the three and the four,

original: catukkapañcakaṃ. Dasakañca ekādasakañca dasekādasakaṃ, “titālīsa” iti caka-bhāgalopaniddesena kakārassa lopo.
analyzed: catukka pañcakam dasakam ca ekādasakam ca dasa ekādasakam ti tālīsaḥ iti caka bhāga lopa niddesena kakārassa lopo
translated: the four and the five. The ten and the eleven, the ten and the eleven, “thirty-two” thus the elision of the syllable ka by the method of the division of the parts.

original: Khuddajantukānaṃ-kīṭā ca paṭaṅgā ca kīṭapaṭaṅgaṃ, kīṭā=kapālapiṭṭhikapāṇā. Evaṃ kunthakipillikaṃ,
analyzed: khudda jantuka anaṃkīṭā ca paṭaṅgā ca kīṭa paṭaṅgam kīṭā kapāla piṭṭhika pāṇāḥ evam kuntha kipillikam
translated: The small creatures are the insects and the locusts, the insects and the locusts, the insects = the back-bone-less. So too, the ant and the termite,

original: ḍaṃsā ca makasā ca ḍaṃsamakasaṃ, makkhikā ca kipillikā ca makkhikakipillikaṃ, kīṭā
analyzed: ḍaṃsā ca makasā ca ḍaṃsa makasam makkhikā ca kipillikā ca makkhika kipillikam kīṭā
translated: the mosquito and the gadfly, the mosquito and the gadfly, the fly and the termite, the insects

original: ca sariṃsapā ca kīṭasariṃsapaṃ. Tattha kunthā=sukhumakipillikā.
analyzed: ca sariṃsapā ca kīṭasariṃsapam kunthā sukhuma kipillikā
translated: and the spiders, the insects and the spiders. Herein, the ant = the small termite.

original: Khuddajantu anaṭṭhī vā, atha kho khuddakopi vā;
analyzed: khudda jantu anaṭṭhī vā atha kho khudda kopi vā
translated: The small creature is without a backbone, or else it is small.

original: Sataṃ vā pasato yesaṃ, keci ānatulā iti.🔽Pacanacaṇḍālānaṃ-orabbhikā ca sūkarikā ca orabbhikasūkarikaṃ, evaṃ sākuntikamāgavikaṃ.
analyzed: satam vā iti  pacana caṇḍālānam orabbhikā ca sūkarikā ca orabbhika sūkarikam evam sākuntika māgavikam
translated: Those who are of a hundred or a thousand, who are not equal to him.🔽Butchers of sheep and pigs, butchers of sheep and pigs, so poultry-keepers and hunters.

original: Sapāko ca caṇḍālo ca sapākacaṇḍālaṃ, pukkusachavaḍāhakaṃ, venarathakāraṃ, tattha
analyzed: sa pākaḥ ca caṇḍālo ca sa pāka caṇḍālam pukkusa chava ḍāhakam vena rathakāram tattha
translated: A butcher and an outcaste, a butcher and an outcaste, so a sweeper and a hunter, a bamboo-worker and a cartwright, there

original: venā=tacchakā, rathakārā=cammakārā.
analyzed: rathakārā cammakārā
translated: bamboo-workers = basket-makers, cartwrights = leather-workers.

original: Caraṇasādhāraṇānaṃ-atiso ca bhāradvājo ca atisabhāradvājaṃ, kaṭṭho ca kapālo ca kaṭṭhakapālaṃ,
analyzed: ca bhāradvājaḥ ca atisa bhāradvājam kaṭṭhaḥ ca kapālo ca kaṭṭha kapālam
translated: Those who have the same feet, Atis and Bhāradvāja, Atis and Bhāradvāja, so Kaṭṭha and Kapāla,

original: sīlañca paññāṇañca sīlapaññāṇaṃ, samatho ca vipassanā ca samathavipassanaṃ, vijjā
analyzed: sīlam ca paññāṇam ca sīla paññāṇam samathaḥ ca vipassanā ca samatha vipassanam vijjā
translated: virtue and wisdom, virtue and wisdom, so calm and insight, calm and insight, knowledge

original: ca caraṇañca vijjācaraṇaṃ, evaṃ nāmarūpaṃ, hirottappaṃ, satisampa-jaññaṃ, lobhamohaṃ,
analyzed: ca caraṇam ca vijjā ācaraṇam evam nāma rūpam hirottappam sati sampajaññam lobha moham
translated: and conduct, knowledge and conduct, so mind and body, shame and moral dread, mindfulness and full awareness, greed and delusion,

original: dosamohaṃ, ahirikānottappaṃ, thinamiddhaṃ, uddhaccakukkucca+miccādi.
analyzed: dosa moham ahirika anottappam thinam iddham uddhacca kukkuccam iccādi
translated: hatred and delusion, lack of shame and moral dread, torpor and sleepiness, agitation and worry, and so on.

original: Ekajjhāyanapāvacanānaṃ-dīgho ca majjhimo ca dīghamajjhimaṃ, evaṃ ekuttara saṃyuttakaṃ, khandhakavibhaṅgaṃ.
analyzed: evam eka uttara saṃyuttakam khandhaka vibhaṅgam
translated: Those who have the same recitation, long and medium, long and medium, so the Ekuttara, the Saṃyuttaka, the Khandhaka and the Vibhaṅga.

original: Liṅgavisesānaṃ-itthī ca pumā ca itthipumaṃ, dāsī ca dāso ca dāsidāsaṃ, cīvarañca🔽piṇḍapāto ca senāsanañca gilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhāro ca cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhāraṃ,
analyzed: liṅga visesānam itthī ca pumā ca itthi pumam dāsī ca dāso ca dāsi dāsam cīvaram ca  piṇḍapāto ca senāsanañca gilāna paccaya bhesajja parikkhāro ca cīvara piṇḍapāta senāsana gilāna paccaya bhesajja parikkhāram
translated: Of different genders: a woman and a man are a woman and a man, a female slave and a male slave are a female slave and a male slave, a robe and …🔽… a requisite of medicine are a robe, almsfood, a resting place, and a requisite of medicine.

original: tiṇañca kaṭṭho ca sākhā ca palāsañca tiṇakaṭṭhasākhāpalāsaṃ. “Lābhī hoti cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhārānaṃ”tipi dissati.
analyzed: tiṇam ca kaṭṭhaḥ ca sākhā ca palāsam ca tiṇa kaṭṭha sākhā palāsam lābhī hoti cīvara piṇḍapāta senāsana gilāna paccaya bhesajja parikkhārānam tipi dissati
translated: Grass and sticks and branches and leaves are grass, sticks, branches, and leaves. “He is a receiver of robes, almsfood, resting place, and requisite of medicine” is also seen.

original: Vividhaviruddhānaṃ-kusalañca akusalañca kusalākusalaṃ, evaṃ sāvajjānavajjaṃ, hīnapaṇītaṃ,
analyzed: vividha viruddha anaṃkusalam ca akusalam ca kusala akusalam evam sāvajja anavajjam hīna paṇītam
translated: Of various opposites: wholesome and unwholesome are wholesome and unwholesome, so too blameworthy and blameless, low and refined,

original: kaṇhasukkaṃ, chekapāpakaṃ, sukhadukkhaṃ, adhamuttamaṃ, paṭighānunayaṃ, chāyātapaṃ,🔽ālokandhakāraṃ. Rattiñca divā ca rattindivaṃ, “rattindivadāragavacaturassā”ti apaccaye
analyzed: kaṇha sukkam cheka pāpakam sukha dukkham adham uttamam paṭigha anunayam chāyā ātapam  āloka ndhakāram rattim ca divā ca rattiṃdivam a paccaye
translated: black and white, bad and good, painful and pleasant, un-Dhamma and Dhamma, inimical and friendly, shade and sunlight,🔽light and dark. Night and day are night and day. “Night and day, four quarters” is without a preposition.

original: kate numaāgamo. Aho ca ratti ca ahorattaṃ, “dīghā+hovassekadesehi ca ratyā”ti apaccaye
analyzed: kate numa āgamaḥ aho ca ratti ca ahorattam dīgha aho vassa ika desehi ca rati āti a paccaye
translated: Day and night are day and night. “Long day and night in the countries of the north” is without a preposition.

original: kate “manādyāpādīna+mo maye ce”ti okāro.
analyzed: kate man ādi āp ādi namaḥ maye ca iti okāraḥ
translated: In the compound “manādyāpādīna+mo maye ce” the vowel “o” is changed to “ā” by the rule.

original: Disānaṃ-pubbā ca aparā ca pubbāparaṃ, evaṃ puratthimapacchimaṃ, dakkhiṇuttaraṃ, pubbadakkhiṇaṃ, pubbuttaraṃ, aparadakkhiṇaṃ, aparuttaraṃ.
analyzed: disānaṃ pubbā ca aparā ca pubba aparam evam puratthima pacchimam dakkhiṇa uttaram pubba dakkhiṇam pubba uttaram apara dakkhiṇam apara uttaram
translated: The east and the west are the east and west, the south and the north are the south and north, the east and south are the east and south, the east and north are the east and north, the west and south are the west and south, the west and north are the west and north.

original: Nadīnaṃ-gaṅgā ca yamunā ca gaṅgāyamunaṃ, evaṃ mahīsarabhū.🔽Tiṇa+rukkha+pasu+sakuṇa+dhana+khañña+byañjana+janapadānaṃ vā. Tiṇavisesānaṃ-usīrāni🔽ca bīraṇāni ca usīrabīraṇaṃ usīrabīraṇāni vā. Evaṃ muñjapabbajaṃ muñjapabbajāni vā,
analyzed: nadīnaṃgaṅgā ca yamunā ca gaṅgā yamunam evam mahī sara bhū  tiṇa rukkha pasu sakuṇa dhana khañña byañjana janapadānam vā tiṇa visesānam usīrāni  ca bīraṇāni ca usīra bīraṇam usīra bīraṇāni vā evam muñja pabbajam muñja pabbajāni vā
translated: The Ganges and the Yamunā are the Ganges and Yamunā, the Mahī and the Sarabhū are the Mahī and Sarabhū.

original: kāsakusaṃ kāsakusā vā.🔽Rukkhavisesānaṃ-assatthā ca kapiṭṭhā ca assatthakapiṭṭhaṃ assatthakapiṭṭhā vā, evaṃ
analyzed: kāsakusam kāsakusāḥ vā  rukkha visesānaṃ assatthā ca kapiṭṭhā ca assattha kapiṭṭham assattha kapiṭṭhā vā evam
translated: The different kinds of grass are the usīra and the vīraṇa, the usīra and vīraṇa are the usīra and vīraṇa, the muñja and the pabbaja are the muñja and pabbaja, the muñja and pabbaja are the muñja and pabbaja, the kāsa and the kusā are the kāsa and kusā.

original: ambapanasaṃ ambapanasā, khadirapalāsaṃ khadirapalāsā, dhavāssakaṇṇaṃ dhavāssakaṇṇā,
analyzed: amba panasam amba panasā khadira palāsam khadira palāsā dhava assakaṇṇam dhava assakaṇṇā
translated: The different kinds of trees are the assattha and the kapittha, the assattha and kapittha are the assattha and kapittha, the mango and the breadfruit are the mango and breadfruit, the khadira and the palāsa are the khadira and palāsa, the dhava and the asvakarṇa are the dhava and asvakarṇa,

original: pilakkhanigrodhaṃ pilakkhanigrodhā, sākasālaṃ sākasālā.
analyzed: pilakkhanigrodham pilakkhanigrodhā sākasālam sākasālā
translated: the pilukka and the nigrodha are the pilukka and nigrodha, the sāka and the sāla are the sāka and sāla.

original: Pasuvisesānaṃ-gajā ca gavajā ca gajagavajaṃ gajagavajā vā, ajā ca eḷakā ca ajeḷakaṃ🔽ajeḷakā, hatthī ca gāvo ca assā ca vaḷavā ca hatthīgavassavaḷavaṃ hatthīgavassavaḷavā,
analyzed: ca gavajā ca gajagavajam gajagavajāḥ vā ajā ca eḷakā ca ajeḍakam  ajeḷakā hatthī ca gāvaḥ ca assā ca vaḷavā ca hatthīga vassa vaḷavam hatthīga vassa vaḷavā
translated: Of special animals: elephants and oxen are the elephant-oxen; the goats and the sheep are the goat-sheep;🔽the elephants and the oxen and the horses and the mares are the elephant-ox-horse-mares;

original: rassattaṃ. Evaṃ gomahisaṃ gomahisā, eṇeyyavarāhaṃ eṇeyyavarāhā, sīhabyagghataracchaṃ🔽sīhabyagghataracchā, kukkuṭasūkaraṃ kukkuṭasūkarā, eṇeyyagomahisaṃ eṇeyyagomahisā.
analyzed: rassattam evam go mahisam go mahisā eṇeyya varāham eṇeyya varāhā sīha byaggha taraccham  sīha byagghataracchā kukkuṭa sūkaram kukkuṭa sūkarāḥ eṇeyya go mahisam eṇeyya go mahisā
translated: the long-haired cattle are the long-haired cattle. So too, the bulls and the buffaloes are the bull-buffaloes; the deer and the boars are the deer-boars;🔽the lions and the tigers and the leopards are the lion-tiger-leopard; the cocks and the pigs are the cock-pigs; the deer and the bulls and the buffaloes are the deer-bull-buffaloes.

original: Sakuṇavisesānaṃ-haṃsā ca bakā ca haṃsabakaṃ haṃsabakā. Evaṃ kāraṇḍavacakkavākaṃ kāraṇḍavacakkavākā, mayūrakoñcaṃ mayūrakoñcā, sukasālikaṃ sukasālikā, bakabalākaṃ bakabalākā.
analyzed: ca bakā ca haṃsa bakam haṃsa bakā evam kāraṇḍava cakkavākam kāraṇḍava cakkavākā mayūra koñcam mayūra koñcā sukasālikam sukasālikā baka balākam baka balākā
translated: Of special birds: the geese and the cranes are the goose-cranes; so too, the ducks and the Brahmani ducks are the duck-Brahmani ducks; the peacocks and the herons are the peacock-herons; the parrots and the mainas are the parrot-minais; the cranes and the storks are the crane-storks.

original: Dhanānaṃ-hiraññañca suvaṇṇañca hiraññasuvaṇṇaṃ hiraññasuvaṇṇāni. Evaṃ jātarūparajataṃ jātarūparajatāni, maṇisaṅkhamuttaveḷuriyaṃ maṇisaṅkhamuttaveḷuriyā.
analyzed: dhanānam hiraññam ca suvaṇṇam ca hirañña suvaṇṇam hirañña suvaṇṇāni evam jātarūpa rajatam jātarūpa rajatāni maṇi saṅkha mutta veḷuriyam maṇi saṅkha mutta veḷuriyā
translated: Of treasures: gold and silver are the gold-silver; so too, the refined gold and the silver are the refined-gold-silver; the gems, the pearl, the lapis lazuli, the conch shell, the coral are the gems-pearl-lapis lazuli-conch-shell-coral.

original: Dhaññānaṃ-sālī ca yavā ca sāliyavaṃ sāliyavā vā. Evaṃ tilamuggamāsaṃ tilamuggamāsāni, nippāvakulatthaṃ nippāvakulatthā.
analyzed: dhaññānaṃsālī ca yavā ca sāli yavam sāli yavā vā evam tila mugga māsam tila mugga māsāni nippāva kulattham nippāva kulatthā
translated: Of grains: rice and barley is rice and barley, or rice and barley. Thus: sesame and green gram is sesame and green gram, kidney bean and black gram is kidney bean and black gram.🔽

original: Byañjanānaṃ-sāko ca suvā ca sākasuvaṃ sākasuvā. Evaṃ gabyamāhisaṃ gabyamāhisā, eṇeyyavarāhaṃ eṇeya, varāhā. Migamayūraṃ migamayūrā.🔽Janapadānaṃ-kāsi ca kosalā ca kāsikosalaṃ kāsikosalā, vajjī ca mallā ca vajjimallaṃ
analyzed: ca suvā ca sākasuvam sākasuvāḥ evam gabya māhisam gabya māhisāḥ eṇeyya varāham eṇeya varāhāḥ miga mayūram miga mayūrā  janapadānaṃkāsi ca kosalā ca kāsi kosalam kāsi kosalā vajjī ca mallā ca vajji mallam
translated: Of grains: rice and barley is rice-and-barley, rice-and-barley is rice-and-barley. Thus: sesame and green gram and kidney beans is sesame-and-green-gram-and-kidney-beans, sesame-and-green-gram-and-kidney-beans is sesame-and-green-gram-and-kidney-beans.🔽Of vegetables: garlic and leeks is garlic-and-leeks, garlic-and-leeks is garlic-and-leeks. Thus: onions and egg-plants is onions-and-egg-plants, onions-and-egg-plants is onions-and-egg-plants. deer and peacocks is deer-and-peacocks, deer-and-peacocks is deer-and-peacocks.

original: vajjimallā, aṅgā ca magadhā ca aṅgamagadhaṃ aṅgamagadhā, evaṃ cetivaṃsaṃ cetivaṃsā,
analyzed: vajjimallāḥ aṅgā ca magadhā ca aṅgamagadham aṅgamagadhāḥ evam cetivaṃsam cetivaṃsā
translated: Of countries: Kāsi and Kosala is Kāsi-and-Kosala, Kāsi-and-Kosala is Kāsi-and-Kosala. Vajjī and Malla is Vajjī-and-Malla, Vajjī-and-Malla is Vajjī-and-Malla. Aṅga and Magadha is Aṅga-and-Magadha, Aṅga-and-Magadha is Aṅga-and-Magadha. Thus: Ceti and Vamsa is Ceti-and-Vamsa, Ceti-and-Vamsa is Ceti-and-Vamsa.

original: macchasūrasenaṃ macchasūrasenā, kurupañcālaṃ kurupañcālā. Nāmañca rūpañca nāmarūpañca
analyzed: maccha sūrasenam maccha sūrasenā kuru pañcālam kuru pañcālāḥ nāman ca rūpam ca nāma rūpam ca
translated: Maccha and Surasena is Maccha-and-Surasena, Maccha-and-Surasena is Maccha-and-Surasena. Kuru and Pañcāla is Kuru-and-Pañcāla, Kuru-and-Pañcāla is Kuru-and-Pañcāla. Name and form is name-and-form,

original: nāmarūpanāmarūpanti caturekapañcavokāravasena vattabbe bahulādhikārā sarūpekasesaṃ
analyzed: nāma rūpa nāma rūpanti catur eka pañca vokāra vasena vattabbe bahula adhikārā sarūpa ikasesam
translated: name-and-form is name-and-form. In the case of what should be said by way of the four, the one, the many, the five, the many, the repetition of the same is done by way of the general and the particular,

original: katvā nāmarūpanti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: katvā nāma rūpam ti vuttam
translated: and it is said: name-and-form.

original: Etasmiṃ ekatthībhāvakaṇḍe yaṃ vuttaṃ pubbaṃ, tadeva pubbaṃ nipatati, kamātikkame
analyzed: etasmin ekatthībhāva kaṇḍe yam vuttam pubbam tat eva pubbam nipatati kama atikkame
translated: In this section on the state of having one meaning, what was said before, that is just before, falls into place, after the transgression of desire,

original: payojanassā+bhāvā. Kvaci vipallāsopi hoti, bahulādhikārato, dantānaṃ rājā rājadanto.
analyzed: kvaci hoti bahula adhikārataḥ
translated: because of the absence of a purpose. In some instances there is a perversion, too, because of the frequency of the use, as in the case of “the king of the tuskers” (dantānaṃ rājā = rājadanto).

original: Catthe samāhāre “sabhāparisāyā”ti ñāpakā kvaci napuṃsakaliṅgaṃ na bhavati, ādhipaccañca🔽parivāro ca ādhipaccaparivāro. Evaṃ chandapārisuddhi, paṭisandhipavattiyaṃ.
analyzed: catthe samāhāre sabhā parisāya āti ñāpakā kvaci napuṃsaka liṅgam na bhavati ādhipaccam ca  parivāro ca ādhipacca parivāro evam chanda pārisuddhi paṭisandhi pavattiyam
