translated: In the three compounds beginning with “sabhāparisāyā” the feminine gender does not occur, and there is🔽dominion and retinue. So too, in the case of “purity of desire” and “rebirth-linking and becoming.”

original: 40. Samāsantva
analyzed: samāsantva
translated: The ending of the compound is

original: Upari aya+madhikarīyati.
analyzed: upari ayam adhikarīyati
translated: Now this matter is being considered.

original: 41. Pāpādīhi bhūmiyā
analyzed: pāpa ādīhi bhūmiyā
translated: With pāpa, etc., the ending of the compound is a

original: Pāpādīhi parā yā bhūmi, tassā samāsanto a hoti. Pāpā bhūmi yasminti pāpabhūmaṃ, jātiyā upalakkhitā bhūmi jātibhūmaṃ.
analyzed: pāpa ādīhi parā yā bhūmi tassā hoti pāpā bhūmi yasmin ti pāpa bhūmam jātiyā upalakkhitā bhūmi jāti bhūmam
translated: when it is a matter of a state that is beyond the state beginning with pāpa. The state that is beyond the state of evil is pāpabhūmaṃ . The state that is characterized by birth is jātibhūmaṃ .

original: 42. Saṃkhyāhiti
analyzed: saṃkhyā hiti
translated: With saṅkhyā

original: Saṃkhyāhi parāya bhūmiyā a hoti. Dve bhūmiyo assa dvibhūmaṃ. Evaṃ tibhūmaṃ.
analyzed: parāya bhūmiyāḥ hoti dve bhūmiyaḥ assa dvi bhūmam evam ti bhūmam
translated: The ending of the compound is a when it is a matter of a state that is beyond a number. It has two states is dvibhūmaṃ . So too, tibhūmaṃ .

original: 43. Nadīgodhāvarīnaṃ
analyzed: nadī godhā varī nam
translated: With nadī, godhā, and avarī

original: Saṃkhyāhi parāsaṃ nadīgodhāvarīnaṃ samāsanto a hoti. Pañcannaṃ nadīnaṃ samāhāro pañcanadaṃ. Evaṃ sattagodhāvaraṃ.
analyzed: saṃkhyāhi hoti pañcannam nadīnam samāhāraḥ pañca nadam evam satta godhāvaram
translated: The ending of the compound is a when it is a matter of a number of rivers, etc. The compound of five rivers is pañcanadaṃ . So too, sattagodhāvaraṃ .

original: 44. Asaṃkhyehi cā+ṅgulyā+nāññāsaṃkhyatthesuti
analyzed: asaṃkhyehi ca aṅguli an āñc a saṃkhyatthesu ti
translated: And with asaṅkhyeya, aṅgula, and other words that denote a number in the sense of “not a number”

original: Asaṃkhyehi saṃkhyāhi ca parāya aṅguliyā samāsanto a hoti. Niggata+maṅgulīhi niraṅgulaṃ,🔽dve aṅguliyo samāhaṭā dvaṅgulaṃ. Anaññāsaṃkhyatthesūti kiṃ, pañca aṅguliyo asmiṃ🔽hattheti pañcaṅguli, aṅguliyā samīpaṃ upaṅguli.
analyzed: a saṃkhyehi saṃkhyāhi ca parāya aṅguliyā hoti niggatam aṅgulīhi niraṅgulam  dve aṅguliyaḥ samāhaṭāḥ dvi aṅgulam kim pañca aṅguliyaḥ asmin  hattha iti pañca aṅguli aṅguliyā samīpam upaṅguli
translated: The word a is the equivalent of asaṅkhyeyya, “incalculable,” and of aṅguli, “finger.” Niraṅgulaṃ is from niggata+maṅgulīhi, “having fingers removed.”🔽Dvaṅgulaṃ is from dve aṅguliyo samāhaṭā, “two fingers put together.”

original: 45. Dīghāhovassekadesehi ca rattyāti🔽Dīghādīhi parāya rattiyā a hoti. Dīghā ca sā ratti cāti dīgharattaṃ. Aho ca ratti
analyzed: dīgha aha uvassa eka desehi ca ratti ā ati  dīgha ādīhi parāya rattiyai a hoti dīghā ca sā ratti ca ati dīgha rattam aho ca ratti
translated: Anaññāsaṃkhyatthesūti kiṃ, “What is the purpose of the word a in the sense of an incalculable number?” Pañcaṅguli is from pañca aṅguliyo asmiṃ hatthe, “five fingers in this hand.” Upaṅguli is from aṅguliyā samīpaṃ, “the vicinity of a finger.”

original: ca ahorattaṃ, āpādittā o. Vassāsu ratti vassārattaṃ. Pubbā ca sā ratti cāti pubbarattaṃ.
analyzed: ca ahorattam āpādittā o vassāsu ratti vassārattam pubbā ca sā ratti ca ati pubbarattam
translated: Dīghādīhi parāya rattiyā a hoti. Dīghā ca sā ratti cāti dīgharattaṃ. Aho ca ratti ca ahorattaṃ, āpādittā o. Vassāsu ratti vassārattaṃ. Pubbā ca sā ratti cāti pubbarattaṃ.

original: Evaṃ apararattaṃ, aḍḍharattaṃ, atikkanto rattiṃ atiratto. Dve rattiyo samāhaṭā dvirattaṃ.🔽Anaññāsaṃkhyatthesu tveva, dīghā ratti asminti dīgharatti, hemanto. Rattiyā samīpaṃ
analyzed: evam apara rattam aḍḍha rattam atikkantaḥ rattim atirattaḥ dve rattiyaḥ samāhaṭāḥ dvi rattam  anaññā saṃkhya tthesu tu eva dīghā ratti asmin ti dīgharatti hemantaḥ rattiyā samīpam
translated: Evaṃ apararattaṃ, aḍḍharattaṃ, atikkanto rattiṃ atiratto. Dve rattiyo samāhaṭā dvirattaṃ.

original: uparatti. Bahulaṃvidhānā kvaci hoteva, rattiparimāṇānurūpaṃ yathārattaṃ.
analyzed: uparatti kvacid hotā iva ratti parimāṇa anurūpam yathārattam
translated: Anaññāsaṃkhyatthesūti kiṃ, dīghā ratti asminti dīgharatti, hemanto. Rattiyā samīpaṃ upa ratti. Bahulaṃvidhānā kvaci hoteva, rattiparimāṇānurūpaṃ yathārattaṃ.

original: 46. Gotva+catthe cā+lope
analyzed: go tvacatthe ca a lope
translated: . Gotva+catthe cā+lope

original: Gosaddā alopavisaye samāsanto a hoti na ce catthādīsu samāso. Rañño go rājagavo.
analyzed: go saddāḥ a lopa visaye samāsa antaḥ a hoti na ce cattha ādīsu samāsaḥ raññaḥ go rājagavaḥ
translated: The compound of gosaddā with alopavisaya is a- ; but there is no compound in the other cases. The king’s bull is rājagavo.

original: Paramo ca so go cāti paramagavo. Pañcannaṃ gunnaṃ samāhāro pañcagavaṃ, “gossā+vaṅa”ti
analyzed: paramaḥ ca saḥ go ca ati paramagavaḥ pañcannam samāhāraḥ pañcagavam
translated: And that is the best of cows, thus it is paramagavo. The compound of the five cows is pañcagavaṃ. The cow’s tail is gossā+vaṅa.

original: avaṅa. Taṃ dhana+massāti pañcagavadhano. Dasagavaṃ.
analyzed: tam pañcagava dhanaḥ dasagavam
translated: That is avaṅa. That wealth is pañcagavadhano. Dasagavaṃ.

original: 47. Rattindiva+dāragava+caturassā
analyzed: rattindiva dāragava caturassā
translated: Rattindiva+dāragava+caturassā

original: Ete saddā a-antā nipaccante. Ratti ca divā ca rattindivaṃ, imināva numāga mā. Dārā ca gavo ca dāragavaṃ. Catasso assiyo assa caturasso.
analyzed: ete saddāḥ a antāḥ nipaccante ratti ca divā ca rattindivam dārā ca gavaḥ ca dāragavam catassaḥ assiyaḥ assa caturassaḥ
translated: These words ending in a are declined. Night and day are rattindivaṃ, by this method. Wife and cows are dāragavaṃ. Four horses are caturasso.

original: 48. Āyāme+nugavaṃ
analyzed: āyāmenugavam
translated: Āyāme+nugavaṃ

original: Anugavaṃti nipaccate āyāmegamyamāne. Gavassa āyāmo anugavaṃ sakaṭaṃ, asaṅkhyasamāso.🔽49. Akkhismā+ññatthe🔽Akkhismā samāsanto a hoti aññatthe. Visālāni akkhīni yassa so visālakkho.🔽50. Dārumya+ṅgulyā
analyzed: anugavam ti nipaccate āyāme gamyamāne gavassa āyāmaḥ anugavam sakaṭam asaṅkhya samāsaḥ 🔽akkhisma aññatthe 🔽akkhismā samāsantaḥ a hoti aññatthe visālāni akkhīni yassa saḥ visālakkhaḥ 🔽dārumyā aṅgulyā
translated: Anugavaṃ is declined when it means ‘length’. The cart of the length of a cow is anugavaṃ, a compound without a number.

original: Aṅgulantā aññatthe dārumhi samāsanto a hoti. Dve aṅguliyo avayavā asseti dvaṅgulaṃ dāru, evaṃ pañcaṅgulaṃ. Aṅgulisadisāvayavaṃ dhaññādīnaṃ vikkhepakaṃ dārūti vuccate.
analyzed: aṅgula antā aññatthe dārumhi samāsa antaḥ a hoti dve aṅguliyaḥ avayavāḥ assa iti dvaṅgulam dāru evam pañca aṅgulam aṅguli sadisa avayavam dhañña ādīnam vikkhepakam dāru iti vuccate
translated: In the sense of ‘other’ it is a in a measure of two finger-breadths, and it is a in a piece of wood. Two finger-breadths are the parts of it, thus it is two finger-breadths long. So too, five finger-breadths. A piece of wood that has parts like finger-breadths is called a ‘grain-separator’.

original: 54. Uttarapade
analyzed: uttara pade
translated: In the last part🔽This should be added in all cases.

original: Idaṃ sabbattha adhikātabbaṃ.🔽55. Imassi+danti
analyzed: idam sabbattha adhikātabbam  imas sidanti
translated: In this

original: Uttarapade imassa idaṃ, imāya attho idamaṭṭho, thassa ṭho, idamaṭṭho assa atthīti
analyzed: uttara pade imassa idam imāya atthaḥ idamaṭṭho thassa ṭhaḥ idamaṭṭho assa atthi iti
translated: In the last part this is its, this is the meaning of this, the meaning of this is that, the ṭho of thassa, this is the meaning of this, this has the meaning of this,

original: idamaṭṭhī, idamaṭṭhino bhāvo idamaṭṭhitā. Imesaṃ paccayā idappaccayā, niggahītalopo passa ca dvibhāvo.
analyzed: idamaṭṭhī idamaṭṭhinaḥ bhāvaḥ idamaṭṭhitāḥ imesam paccayāḥ idappaccayāḥ niggahīta lopaḥ passa ca dvi bhāvaḥ
translated: thus it has the meaning of this, the state of having the meaning of this is that of this, the conditions of these are these conditions, the elided sign is dropped, and the double-headed arrow is seen.

original: 57. Ṭa ntantūnanti
analyzed: ṭa ntantūnanti
translated: In the last part of ntantūna

original: Ntantūnaṃ uttarapade ṭa hoti. Bhavanto patiṭṭhā amhanti bhavaṃpatiṭṭhā mayaṃ, niggahītāgamo, vagganto, yossa ṭā ca. Bhagavā mūlaṃ etesaṃti bhagavaṃmūlakā no dhammā.
analyzed: n ta ntūnam uttara pade ṭa hoti bhavantaḥ patiṭṭhāḥ amhanti bhavaṃpatiṭṭhāḥ mayam niggahīta āgamaḥ vagga antaḥ yossa ṭā ca bhagavā mūlam etesam ti bhagavaṃmūlakāḥ no dhammā
translated: ṭa is in the last part of ntantūn. You are the support of us, thus we are supported by you, the sign of the elided sign is dropped, the vagga sign, and the ṭā of it. The Blessed One is the root of these, thus our ideas have the Blessed One as their root.

analyzed: a
translated: In the last part of ntantūn

original: Iti ntantūnaṃ a hoti. Guṇavanto patiṭṭhā mamāti guṇavantapatiṭṭho+smi.🔽60. Parassa saṃkhyāsuti
analyzed: iti nta ntūnam a hoti guṇavantaḥ patiṭṭhā mama ati guṇavanta patiṭṭhaḥ asmi 🔽parassa saṃkhyā su ti
translated: a is in the last part of ntantūn. You are the support of the virtuous, thus I am the support of the virtuous.

original: Saṃkhyāsu parassa o, paro satasmā adhikā parosataṃ.
analyzed: saṃkhyāsu parassa o paraḥ satasmai adhikā parosatam
translated: In the numerals, the genitive of the other, after satam, is parosatam.

original: 61. Jane puthassuti
analyzed: jane puthassuti
translated: In puthujjana,

original: Puthassa jane u hoti. Puthagevā+yaṃ janoti puthujjano, jassa dvittaṃ.
analyzed: puthassa jane u hoti puthak eva ayam janoti puthujjanaḥ jassa
translated: Puthassa jane u is the affix. Puthagevā+yaṃ jano = puthujjano. The dvitta is jassa.

original: 62. So chassā+hā+yatane vā
analyzed: saḥ chas sāha āyatane vā
translated: So is the affix in chassā+hā+yatane vā,

original: Ahe āyatane ca uttarapade chassa so hoti vā. Sāhaṃ chāhaṃ, saḷāyatanaṃ chaḷāyatanaṃ. (Sambaraṃ)
analyzed: ahe āyatane ca uttara pade chassa saḥ hoti vā sāham chāham saḷāyatanam chaḍāyatanam sambaram
translated: In āyatana, the affix so is the affix in chassa, or in the following word. Sāhaṃ, chāhaṃ, saḷāyatanaṃ, chaḷāyatanaṃ. (Sambaraṃ)

original: 63. Ltu+pitādīna+māravaraṅa
analyzed: l tup ita ādi ina māra varaṅa
translated: Ltu+pitādīna+māravaraṅa

original: Ltupaccayantānaṃ pitādīnañca yathākkama+māravaraṅa vā hontu+ttarapade. Satthuno dassanaṃ satthāradassanaṃ, kattāraniddeso. Mātarapitaro. Vātveva, satthudassanaṃ, mātujāyo.
analyzed: ltu paccaya antānam pitā ādīnam ca vā hontu uttara pade satthunaḥ dassanam satthāra dassanam kattāra niddesaḥ mātara pitaraḥ satthu dassanam
translated: The affix ltu is the affix in pitā, etc., or in the following word, in order. Satthuno dassanaṃ = satthāradassanaṃ. The katta is niddeso. Mātarapitaro. Vātveva, satthudassanaṃ, mātujāyo.

original: 68. Kvaci paccayeti
analyzed: kvaci paccaya iti
translated: Kvaci paccayeti

original: Paccaye pumabhāve atisayena byattā byattatarā, byattatamā. “Tassaṃ tatra, tāya tato,
analyzed: paccaye pumabhāve atisayena byattā byattatarā byattatamā tassam tatra tāya tato
translated: In the feminine, in the state of being a male, byattā, byattatarā, byattatamā are very clever, cleverer, cleverest. “Tassaṃ tatra, tāya tato,

original: tassaṃ velāyaṃ tadā”“… etthantare rūpāni ācariyasaṃgharakkhita mahāsāmittheramatena
analyzed: tadā etthantare rūpāni
translated: Tassaṃ velāyaṃ tadā” “… etthantare rūpāni ācariyasaṃgharakkhita mahāsāmittheramatena

original: imināva “kvaci paccayeti suttena siddhāni, teneva tāni imasmiṃ sutte udāhaṭāni. ācariyamoggallānamahātheramatena
analyzed: iminā ava kvaci paccaya iti suttena siddhāni tena iva tāni imasmim sutte udāhaṭāni ācariya moggallāna mahā thera matena
translated: By this very “kvacci paccayeti” Sutta, these are established, and they are mentioned in this Sutta by that very (Sutta). But by the opinion of the Teacher Moggallāna Mahā Thera

original: pane+tāni “sabbādayo vuttimatteti suttena siddhāni. toādīnaṃ vibhatyatthe vihitapaccayattā,
analyzed: pana itāni sabba ādayaḥ vuttimattā iti suttena siddhāni to ādīnam vibhati atthe vihita paccaya ttā
translated: they are established by the Sutta “sabbādayo vuttimatte.” Because of the fact that the case endings beginning with “to” are made with the preposition “pacca,”

original: tadanthānañca ṇādivuttittā dvinnampi therānaṃ matā aviruddhā.
analyzed: tad anthānam ca matā aviruddhā
translated: and because of the fact that the endings beginning with “ṇā” are the endings of the preposition, the opinions of both Theras are not in conflict.

original: 71. Saññāya+mudo+dakassa
analyzed: saññāyamudodakassa
translated: . The elision of udak in saññāya+mudo+dakassa

original: Saññāya+mudakassu+ttarapade udādeso hoti. Udadhi, udapānaṃ.
analyzed: saññā ayam udakaḥ uttara pade ud ādesaḥ hoti udadhi udapānam
translated: The elision of udak occurs in the word following saññāya+mudo+dakassa. Udadhi, udapānaṃ.

original: 72. Kumbhādīsu vā
analyzed: kumbha ādīsu vā
translated: . Or in kumbhādīsu+vā

original: Kumbhādīsu+ttarapadesu udakassa udādeso vā hoti. Udakumbho, udakakumbho. Udapatto udakapatto. Udabindu udakabindu. Ākatigaṇo+yaṃ.
analyzed: kumbha ādīsu uttara padesu udakassa udādesaḥ vā hoti uda kumbhaḥ udaka kumbhaḥ uda pattaḥ udaka pattaḥ uda bindu udaka bindu
translated: The elision of udak occurs in the words following kumbhādīsu+vā. Udakumbho, udakakumbho. Udapatto udakapatto. Udabindu udakabindu. This is the Ākaṭi class.

original: 73. Sotādīsū+lopo
analyzed: so ta ādi sū lopaḥ
translated: . The elision of ussa in sotādīsū+lopo

original: Sotādīsu+ttarapadesu udakassa ussa lopo hoti. Dakasotaṃ, dakarakkhaso.
analyzed: sota ādīsu uttara padesu udakassa ussa lopaḥ hoti daka sotam daka rakkhaso
translated: The elision of ussa occurs in the words following sotādīsū+lopo. Dakasotaṃ, dakarakkhaso.

original: 26. Itthiya+matvā
analyzed: itthiyam atvā
translated: . The addition of āpacca to itthiya+matvā

original: Itthiyaṃ vattamānato akārantato nāmasmā āpaccayo hoti. Dhammadinnā.🔽27. Nadādito ṅī
analyzed: itthiyam vattamānataḥ a kāra antataḥ nāmasmai ā paccayaḥ hoti dhamma dinnā 🔽nada āditaḥ ṅī
translated: The addition of āpacca occurs to the noun ending in akā from itthiyaṃ vattamānato. Dhammadinnā.

original: Nadādīhi itthiyaṃ vīpaccayo hoti. Nadī mahī kumārī taruṇī vāruṇī gotamī.🔽Goto vā
analyzed: nada ādīhi itthiyam vīpaccayaḥ hoti nadī mahī kumārī taruṇī vāruṇī gotamī  gotaḥ vā
translated: The feminine of nadī, etc., is formed by adding -ī. Nadī, mahī, kumārī, taruṇī, vāruṇī, gotamī.🔽The feminine of go is formed by adding -ī.

original: Gāvī go. Ākatigaṇo+yaṃ. Va-kāro “ntantūnaṃ vīmhi to vā”ti visesanattho.🔽28. Yakkhāditvi+nī ca
analyzed: gāvī go ā kati gaṇaḥ yam vakāraḥ n ta ntūnam vīmhi taḥ vā ti visesana tthaḥ  yakkha āditvinī ca
translated: The feminine of āka is formed by adding -ī. The -v- is for the purpose of distinguishing it from the -v- of the following rule.

original: Yakkhādito itthiyaṃ inī hoti vī ca. Yakkhinī yakkhī, nāginī nāgī, sīhinī sīhī.🔽29. Ārāmikādīhi
analyzed: yakkha aditaḥ itthiyam inī hoti vī ca yakkhinī yakkhī nāginī nāgī sīhinī sīhī  ārāmika ādīhi
translated: The feminine of yakkha, etc., is formed by adding -inī and -ī. Yakkhinī, yakkhī, nāginī, nāgī, sīhinī, sīhī.

original: Ārāmikādito inī hoti+tthiyaṃ. Ārāmikinī, anantarāyikinī.🔽Saññāyaṃ mānuso mānusinī, aññatra mānusī.
analyzed: ārāmika ādeḥ hotitthiyam ārāmikinī anantarāyikinī  saññā ayam mānusaḥ mānusinī aññatra mānusī
translated: The feminine of ārāmika, etc., is formed by adding -inī. ārāmikinī, anantarāyikinī.

original: 30. Yuvaṇṇehi nī
analyzed: yuvaṇṇehi nī
translated: In the abstract noun, mānusī is feminine, mānusinī is feminine, mānusī is feminine.

original: Itthiya+mivaṇṇuvaṇṇantehi nī hoti bahulaṃ. Sadāpayatapāṇinī, daṇḍinī, bhikkhunī, khattabandhunī, paracittavidunī. Mātuādito kasmā na hoti, itthipaccayaṃ vināpi itthattābhidhānato.🔽31. Ttimhā+ññatthe
analyzed: nī hoti bahulam daṇḍinī bhikkhunī khattabandhunī paracittavidunī mātu āditaḥ kasmā na hoti itthi paccayam vinā api itthattā abhidhānato 🔽tti mhāñ ña tthe
translated: The feminine of yuvaṇa, etc., is formed by adding -inī. Sadāpayatapāṇinī, daṇḍinī, bhikkhunī, khattabandhunī, paracittavidunī. Why is the feminine not formed from mātuā, etc.? Because they are called feminine even without a feminine ending.

original: Ttimhā+ññattheyeva itthiyaṃ nī hoti bahulaṃ. Sā+haṃ ahiṃsāratinī, tassā muṭṭhassatiniyā, sā gāvī vacchagiddhinī. Aññattheti kiṃ, dhammarati.
analyzed: itthiyam nī hoti bahulam sā aham ahiṃsā ratinī tassā muṭṭha ssatiniyā sā gāvī vaccha giddhinī aññattha iti kim dhamma rati
translated: In the feminine, it is often used in the sense of ‘other’ (aññattha). I am one who delights in harmlessness, of that forgetful one, that cow who is eager for her calf. What in the sense of ‘other’? Dhammarati.

original: Chaṭṭhīyantā nāmasmā vā ṇapaccayo hoti apacce+bhidheyye. Apaccasaddasambandhittena🔽apaccavantato katasarapaccayo samatthyato chaṭṭhyantato hotīti “chaṭṭhīyantā nāmasmā”ti
analyzed: chaṭṭhī yantāḥ nāmasmā vā ṇa paccayaḥ hoti a pacca ibhidheyye a pacca sadda sambandhi ttena  a paccavantataḥ katasara paccayo samatthyataḥ chaṭṭhī antataḥ hoti iti chaṭṭhīyantāḥ nāma asma iti
translated: The affix ṇapaccayo is added to a noun in the sixth case when the meaning is ‘less than’.🔽The affix katasarapaccayo is added to a noun in the sixth case when the meaning is ‘more than’.

original: sutte avuttampi vuttaṃ. Ṇādīnaṃ taddhitanti pubbācariyasaññā. Ṇakāro vuddhyattho.
analyzed: sutte a vuttam pi vuttam ṇa ādīnam taddhitan ti pubba ācariya saññā ṇakāraḥ vuddhi atthaḥ
translated: The words ‘a noun in the sixth case’ in the sutta is said although it is not stated. The words ṇādīnaṃ taddhitam are the designation of the former teachers. The letter ṇ has the meaning ‘increase’.

original: Eva+maññatrāpi. Ṇādivuttittā “ekatthatāyaṃ”ti vibhattilopo.
analyzed: evam aññatra api vibhatti lopaḥ
translated: In the same way in other instances. The words ṇādīnaṃ vutti are ‘ekatthatāyaṃ’, and the case-ending is elided.

original: 124. Sarāna+mādissā+yuvaṇṇassā+eo ṇānubandhe
analyzed: sara anam ādi ssa yu vaṇ ṇassā eaḥ ṇa anubandhe
translated: . Sarāna+mādissā+yuvaṇṇassā+eo ṇānubandhe

original: Sarāna+mādibhūtā ye akāri+vaṇṇu+vaṇṇā, tesaṃ ā+e+o vā honti yathākkamaṃ ṇānubandheti
analyzed: sarānama ādi bhūtāḥ ye tesam āeaḥ vā honti yathākkamam
translated: The letters ā+e+o are added to the letters a, i, u, and ṇ, respectively, when the letter ṇ follows.

original: akārassa ākāro. Ā+e+onaṃ vuddhītipi pubbācariyasaññā. Vasiṭṭhassā+paccaṃ vāsiṭṭho.🔽Vīmhi vāsiṭṭhī. Veti vasiṭṭhassā+paccaṃti vākyassa ca vasiṭṭhāpaccaṃti samāsassa
analyzed: akārassa ākāraḥ vuddhi itipi pubba ācariya saññā vasiṭṭhassa a paccam vāsiṭṭhaḥ  vāsiṭṭhī vā iti vākyassa ca samāsassa
translated: The letter a becomes the letter ā. The words ā+e+onaṃ vuddhīti are the designation of the former teachers. Vasiṭṭhassā+paccaṃ = vāsiṭṭho.🔽Vīmhi vāsiṭṭhī. Veti vasiṭṭhassā+paccaṃ = vāsiṭṭhāpaccaṃ.

original: ca vikappatthaṃ. So ca vāsaddo yāva “sakatthe”ti adhikarīyati.
analyzed: ca vikappa attham saḥ ca vā saddaḥ yāva saka tthā iti adhikarīyati
translated: The words vāsiṭṭhāpaccaṃ are a compound word and a separate word for the purpose of the exception. And that word vās is governed by the words ‘in the sense of own’ as far as the words ‘in the sense of own’.🔽.

original: Napuṃsakena liṅgena, saddo+dāhu pumena vā;
analyzed: napuṃsakena liṅgena pumena vā
translated: The sound of a neuter noun, or of a masculine noun,

original: Niddissatīti ñātabba+mavisese pani+cchiteti –
analyzed: niddissati iti ñātabbam avisese
translated: is to be known as the same, if the ending is the same.

original: Vuttatthā apaccasaddassa napuṃsakatthepi puttaputtīnaṃ dvinnampi vācako hoti.
analyzed: vutta tthāḥ a pacca saddassa napuṃsaka atthe pi putta puttīnam dvinnam pi vācakaḥ hoti
translated: The meaning of the neuter is also expressed by the words putta and puttī, which are masculine and feminine, respectively.

original: Ṇādayo+bhidheyyaliṅgā, apacce tva+napuṃsakā;
analyzed: ṇa ādayaḥ abhidheyya liṅgāḥ a pacce tu a napuṃsakā
translated: Ṇā and the others are nouns of the declinable kind; apacca is not neuter.

original: Napuṃsake sakatthe ṇyo, bhiyyo bhāvasamūhajā;
analyzed: napuṃsake sakatthe ṇyaḥ bhiyyaḥ bhāva samūha jā
translated: In the neuter, the meaning of the neuter is expressed by ṇyo, bhiyyo, bhāva, and samūha.

original: Tā tu+tthiya+masaṃkhyāne, tvādicīpaccayantakā.
analyzed: tā tutthi yama saṃkhyāne tu ādi cī pacca yantakā
translated: But tā, tu, tthi, and asa are not in the neuter; and the endings beginning with tvā are not in the neuter.

original: Bhāradvājassa apaccaṃ=putto bhāradvājo, evaṃ vessāmitto, gotamo. Ettha ca a+yuvaṇṇantābhāvā
analyzed: bhāradvājassa apaccaṃputtaḥ bhāradvājaḥ evam vessāmittaḥ gotamaḥ ettha ca
translated: The son of Bhāradvāja is Bhāradvāja, the son of Vessāmitta is Vessāmitta, the son of Gotama is Gotama. And here, because there is no vowel at the end,

original: ā+e+onaṃ na vuddhi. Vāsudevassa apaccaṃ vāsudevo, baladevo. Cittakotiādīsu pana saṃyogantattā
analyzed: na vāsudevassa apaccam vāsudevaḥ baladevaḥ cittaka uti ādīsu pana saṃyoga anta ttā
translated: the lengthening of ā, e, and o does not take place. The son of Vāsudeva is Vāsudeva, the son of Balādeva is Balādeva. But in the words Cittakoti, etc., because there is a compound ending,

original: “saṃyoge kvacī”ti kvaci na vuddhi. Upaguno apaccaṃ opagavo opagavī. Ettha “uvaṇṇassā+vaṅa
analyzed: saṃyoge kvaci iti kvaci na upagunaḥ a paccam opagavaḥ opagavī ettha
translated: the lengthening of ā, e, and o does not take place by the rule “kvaci in the compound.” The son of Upagutta is Upagavo, Upagavī. Here, because of the rule “uvaṇṇassā+vaṅa

original: sare”ti ukārassa avaṅa.
analyzed: sara iti ukārassa avaṅa
translated: sare,” the vowel u is not lengthened.

original: Vacchassā+paccanti viggayha pubbasuttena ṇapaccaye kate puna vacchassā+paccaṃti viggaho.
analyzed: viggayha pubba suttena ṇa paccaye kate puna viggahaḥ
translated: The son of Vaccha is Vacchā+pacca. Having analyzed this, the ṇapaccaya is formed by the previous rule. Then the analysis is made again.

original: 2. Vacchādito ṇāna+ṇāyanā
analyzed: vacchāditaḥ
translated: 2. The -āno, -āyano formations from -accha, etc., and from gotra, etc.

original: Vacchādīhi apaccapaccayantehi gottādīhi ca saddehi ṇāna+ṇāyanapaccayā vā honti apacce.
analyzed: vaccha ādīhi a pacca paccaya ntehi gotta ādīhi ca saddehi ṇāna ṇāyana paccayāḥ vā honti a pacce
translated: The -āno, -āyano formations are made from the words ending in -accha, etc., and from the words gotra, etc., by adding -āno, -āyano, but not in appositional compounds.

original: Vacchāno, vacchāyano, “saṃyoge kvacī”ti na vuddhi. Katissā+paccaṃ kacco, “ṇya diccādīhī”ti
analyzed: saṃyoge kvaci iti na kaccaḥ kaccaḥ ṇya dicca ādīhi iti
translated: Vacchāno, vacchāyano; “saṃyoge kvacī”ti na vuddhi. Katissā+paccaṃ kacco, “ṇya diccādīhī”ti

original: ṇyo, “lopo+vaṇṇi+vaṇṇānaṃ”ti akāralope cavaggapubbarūpāni. Kaccassā+paccaṃ kaccāno,
analyzed: ṇyaḥ lopaḥ vaṇṇi vaṇṇānam ti akāra lope ca vagga pubbarūpāni kaccassāpaccam kaccāno
translated: ṇyo; “lopo+vaṇṇi+vaṇṇānaṃ”ti akāralope cavaggapubbarūpāni. Kaccassā+paccaṃ kaccāno,

original: kaccāyano, yāgame kātiyāno. Muggassā+paccaṃ=nattādīti vākye vuddhi+ikāralopa+pubbarūpāni.
analyzed: kaccāyanaḥ yāgame kātiyānaḥ vākye vuddhi i kāra lopa pubbarūpāni
translated: kaccāyano; yāgame kātiyāno. Muggassā+paccaṃ=nattādīti vākye vuddhi+ikāralopa+pubbarūpāni.

original: Moggallassā+paccaṃti punaṇāna+ṇāyanā honti, moggallāno moggallāyano. Ime cattāro
analyzed: punaṇānaṇāyanāḥ honti moggallānaḥ moggallāyanaḥ ime cattāraḥ
translated: Moggallassā+paccaṃti punaṇāna+ṇāyanā honti, moggallāno moggallāyano. Ime cattāro

original: apaccapaccayantā. Gottādito yathāsakaṭassā+paccaṃ nattādīhi sakaṭāno sakaṭāyano.
analyzed: a pacca pacca yantāḥ gotta āditaḥ yathā sakaṭassa a paccam natta ādīhi sakaṭānaḥ sakaṭāyanaḥ
translated: apaccapaccayantā. Gottādito yathāsakaṭassā+paccaṃ nattādīhi sakaṭāno sakaṭāyano.

original: Kaṇhassā+paccaṃ nattādi kaṇhāno kaṇhāyano. Evaṃ aggivessāno aggivessāyano, muñjāno
analyzed: kaṇhassa apaccam natta ādi kaṇhānaḥ kaṇhāyanaḥ evam aggivessānaḥ aggivessāyanaḥ muñjānaḥ
translated: Kaṇhassā+paccaṃ nattādi kaṇhāno kaṇhāyano. Evaṃ aggivessāno aggivessāyano, muñjāno

original: muñjāyano, kuñjāno kuñjāyano. Sabbattha saṃyogattā na vuddhi. Ākatigaṇo+yaṃ.
analyzed: muñjāyano kuñjāno kuñjāyano sabbattha saṃyoga ttā na
translated: muñjāyano, kuñjāno kuñjāyano. Sabbattha saṃyogattā na vuddhi. Ākatigaṇo+yaṃ.

original: 3. Kattikāvidhavādīhi ṇeyyaṇerā🔽Kattikādīhi vidhavādīhi ca ṇeyyaṇerappaccayā honti vā yathākkamaṃ. Kattikāya apaccaṃ🔽kattikeyyo, garuḷo vinatāya=supaṇṇamātuyā apaccaṃ venateyyo. Rohiṇiyā apaccaṃ rohiṇeyyo,🔽gaṅgāya apaccaṃ gaṅgeyyo. Evaṃ bhāgineyyo, nādeyyo, anteyyo, āheyyo, kāpeyyo, suciyā🔽apaccaṃ soceyyo, bāleyyo. Ṇere-vidhavāya apaccaṃ vedhavero. Bandhakiyā=abhisārikāya
analyzed: kattikā vidhavā ādīhi ṇeyya ṇerā  kattikā ādīhi vidhavā ādīhi ca honti vā yathākkamam kattikāya  kattikeyyaḥ garuḷaḥ vinatāya supaṇṇamātuyāḥ apaccam venateyyaḥ rohiṇiyāḥ apaccam rohiṇeyyaḥ  gaṅgāya apaccam gaṅgeyyaḥ evam bhāgineyyaḥ nādeyyaḥ anteyyaḥ āheyyaḥ kāpeyyaḥ suciyā  apaccam soceyyaḥ bāleyyaḥ ṇerevidhavāya apaccam vedhaveraḥ bandhakiyā abhisārikāya
translated: 3. The words Kattikāvidhavādīhi ṇeyyaṇerā

original: apaccaṃ bandha-kero. Samaṇassa upajjhāyassā+paccaṃ sāmaṇero, nāḷikero iccādi.
analyzed: apaccam bandhakero samaṇassa upajjhāyassa apaccam sāmaṇero nāḷikero iccādi
translated: Kattikā, etc., and vidhavā, etc., have the forms ṇeyya and ṇerā respectively, according to the order, when they are the names of the fathers. Kattikā is the mother of Kattikeyya. Garuḷa is the son of Vinatā, i.e. Supaṇṇamātā. Rohiṇī is the mother of Rohiṇeyya. Gaṅgā is the mother of Gaṅgeyya. In the same way, Bhāgineyya, Nādeyya, Anteyya, Āheyya, Kāpeyya, Soceyya, Bāleyya. Vedhavero is the son of Ṇere-vidhavā. Bandha-kero is the son of Bandhaki, i.e. Abhisārikā. Sāmaṇero is the son of the ascetic Upajjhāya. Nāḷikero, etc.

original: 4. Ṇya diccādīhi
analyzed: ṇya dit ca ādīhi
translated: . Ṇya after diccādīhi

original: Ditippabhutīhi ṇyo hoti apacce.
analyzed: diti ppabhutīhi ṇyaḥ hoti a pacce
translated: The form ṇya is used for the names of the fathers of Diti, etc.

original: 125. Saṃyoge kvaci
analyzed: saṃyoge kvaci
translated: . In saṃyoga, sometimes

original: Saṃyogavisaye kvaci ā+e+ovuddhiyo honti ṇānubandhe.
analyzed: saṃyoga visaye kvaci ā e o vuddhiyaḥ honti ṇa anubandhe
translated: In the sphere of saṃyoga, the augmentations ā, e, o are used sometimes, after the affix ṇa.

original: 131. Lopo+vaṇṇi+vaṇṇānaṃ
translated: . The loss of the vowel and the consonant

original: Avaṇṇi+vaṇṇānaṃ lopo hoti yakārādo paccaye. Ditiyā=asuramātuyā apaccaṃ decco ādicco. Kuṇḍaniyā apaccaṃ koṇḍañño, nassa ññe pubbarūpaṃ. Aditīti devamātā.
analyzed: a vaṇṇi vaṇṇānam lopaḥ hoti yakārāt paccaye ditiyā asura mātuyāḥ a paccam deccaḥ ādiccaḥ kuṇḍaniyāḥ a paccam koṇḍaññaḥ nassa ññe pubba rūpam aditi iti deva mātā
translated: The syllable yak is dropped from the last syllable of a word ending in a vowel, and from the last syllable of a word ending in a consonant, when the latter is followed by a word beginning with a vowel. Ditiyā = asuramātuyā apaccaṃ decco ādicco. Kuṇḍaniyā apaccaṃ koṇḍañño, nassa ññe pubbarūpaṃ. Aditīti devamātā.

original: Bhātuno apaccaṃ bhātabyo, “yamhi gossa cā”ti yamhi ussa avaṅa akāralopapubbarūpāni.
analyzed: bhātunaḥ a paccam bhātabyaḥ yamhi gossa ca ati yamhi avaṅaḥ akāra lopa pubbarūpāni
translated: Bhātuno apaccaṃ bhātabyo, “yamhi gossa cā”ti yamhi ussa avaṅa akāralopapubbarūpāni.

original: 5. Ā ṇi
analyzed: ā ṇi
translated: 5. The letter ṇ

original: Akārantato ṇi vā hota+pacce bahulaṃ. Ā=ti nāmavisesanattā a-kārantatoti vuttaṃ. Dakkhassā+paccaṃ
analyzed: a kāra antataḥ ṇi vā hota pacce bahulam ā ti nāma visesana ttā a kāra antataḥ ti vuttam dakkhassa a paccam
translated: Akārantato ṇi vā hota+pacce bahulaṃ. Ā=ti nāmavisesanattā a-kārantatoti vuttaṃ. Dakkhassā+paccaṃ

original: dakkhi, datti, doṇi, vāsavi, vāruṇi. Jinadattassā+paccaṃ jenadatti, suddhodani, ānuruddhi iccādi.
analyzed: dakkhi datti doṇi vāsavi vāruṇi jinadattassa apaccam jenadatti suddhodani ānuruddhi iccādi
translated: dakkhi, datti, doṇi, vāsavi, vāruṇi. Jinadattassā+paccaṃ jenadatti, suddhodani, ānuruddhi iccādi.

original: 6. Rājato ñño jātiyaṃ
analyzed: rājataḥ ññaḥ jātiyam
translated: Rājato ñño jātiyaṃ

original: Rājato ñño vā hota+pacce khatthiyajātiyaṃ gamyamānāyaṃ. Rañño apaccaṃ rājañño. Jātīyanti kiṃ, rājāpaccaṃ.
analyzed: rājataḥ vā hotapacce khatthiya jātiyam gamyamānā ayam raññaḥ apaccam rājaññaḥ jātīyanti kim rājāpaccam
translated: Rājato ñño vā hota+pacce khatthiyajātiyaṃ gamyamānāyaṃ. Rañño apaccaṃ rājañño. Jātīyanti kiṃ, rājāpaccaṃ.

original: 7. Khattā yi+yā
analyzed: khattā yiyā
translated: Khattā yi+yā

original: Tijātiyaṃ apacce ya+iyā honti. Khattassā+paccaṃ khatyo khattiyo. Jātiyaṃ tveva, khatti.
analyzed: ti jātiyam apacce yaiyāḥ honti khattassa apaccam khatyaḥ khattiyaḥ jātiyam tu eva khatti
translated: Tijātiyaṃ apacce ya+iyā honti. Khattassā+paccaṃ khatyo khattiyo. Jātiyaṃ tveva, khatti.

original: 8. Manuto ssa+saṇa
analyzed: manutaḥ ssasaṇa
translated: Manuto ssa+saṇa

original: Manuto jātisamudāye ssa+saṇa hontu+pacce. Manuno apaccaṃ manusso mānuso, manussī mānusī. Jātiyaṃ tveva, mānavo, nassa ṇo, māṇavo.🔽9. Janapadanāmasmā khattiyā raññe ca ṇo🔽Janapadassa yaṃ nāmaṃ, taṃ nāmasmā khattiyā apacce raññe ca ṇo hoti. Pañcālānaṃ apaccaṃ
analyzed: manutaḥ jāti samudāye hontu pacce manunaḥ apaccam manussaḥ mānusaḥ manussī mānusī jātiyam tu eva mānavaḥ nassa ṇo māṇavaḥ  janapada nāmasmā khattiyāḥ raññe ca ṇo  janapadassa yam nāmam tam nāmasma khattiyāḥ apacce raññe ca no hoti pañcālānam apaccam
translated: The suffix -ssa is added to the word manuja, and then -no to that. The word manuja becomes manussa, manusso, mānusso, mānujo. But māṇavo is formed by adding -no to the word mānavo, which is formed by adding -no to the word mānujo.🔽9. The suffix -no is added to the names of countries and to khattiya and rājā🔽The suffix -no is added to the names of countries, and to khattiya and rājā when they are not in apposition.

original: rājā vā pañcālo, kosalo, māgadho, okkāko. Janapadanāmasmāti kiṃ, dāsarathi. Khattiyāti🔽kiṃ, pañcālassa brāhmaṇassā+paccaṃ pañcāli.🔽10. Ṇya kurusivīhi🔽Kurusivīhi apacce raññe ca ṇyo hoti. Kurūnaṃ apaccaṃ rājā vā korabyo. “Yamhi gossa cā”timinā avaṅa, bakārapubbarūpāni. Sebbo, ilopo. (Apaccataddhitaṃ).🔽11. Ṇa rāgā tena rattaṃ🔽Rāgavācītatiyantato ratta+micce+tasmiṃ atte ṇo hoti. Kusumbhādīhi vaṇṇantarapattaṃ
analyzed: rājā vā pañcālaḥ kosalaḥ māgadhaḥ okkākaḥ kim dāsarathi khattiyā iti 🔽kim pañcālassa brāhmaṇassa apaccam pañcāli 🔽ṇya kurusivīhi 🔽kuru sivīhi apacce raññe ca ṇyaḥ hoti kurūnam apaccam rājā vā korabyaḥ yamhi gossa ca atiminā avaṅa ba kāra pubba rūpāni sebbaḥ i lopaḥ a pacca taddhitam 🔽ṇa rāgā tena rattam 🔽rattam iti etasmin atte ṇo hoti kusumbha ādīhi
translated: The affix ṇo is added to the word manuja, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā, manussī, manussā

original: rattaṃ nāma. Kasāvena rattaṃ kāsāvaṃ. Evaṃ kusumbhena rattaṃ kosumbhaṃ, hāliddaṃ,
analyzed: rattam nāma kasāvena rattam kāsāvam evam kusumbhena rattam kosumbham hāliddam
translated: Red means: Red with turmeric is turmeric. Thus red with safflower is safflower, red with lac is lac, red with madder is madder, red with crimson is crimson, red with turmeric is turmeric. Here blue and yellow are not (included).🔽Because of the word “quality”, even without the suffix ṇo,

original: pattaṅgaṃ, mañjeṭṭhaṃ, kuṅkumaṃ. Idha na hoti nīlaṃ pītanti, guṇavacanattā ṇena vināpi🔽dabbassā+bhidhānato.
analyzed: pattaṅgam mañjeṭṭham kuṅkumam idha na hoti nīlam pītam ti guṇavacana ttā ṇena vinā api  dabbassa abhidhānataḥ
translated: it is called “turmeric” because of the word “turmeric”.

original: 12. Nakkhatteni+nduyuttena kāle
analyzed: nakkhattena indu yuttena kāle
translated: At the time of the constellation and the moon

original: Tatiyantato nakkhattā tena lakkhite kāle ṇo hoti, taṃ ce nakkhatta+minduyuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: tatiya ntatas nakkhattā tena lakkhite kāle no hoti tam ce nakkhattam indu yuttam hoti
translated: The suffix ṇo is added to the third case of the word for the constellation, if it is connected with the moon.

original: Phussena induyuttena lakkhitā puṇṇamāsī phussī ratti, phusso aho, maghāya induyuttāya
analyzed: phussena indu yuttena lakkhitā puṇṇamāsī phussī ratti phussaḥ ahaḥ maghāya indu yuttāya
translated: The full moon night marked by the constellation Puppha and connected with the moon is the Puppha night, the Puppha day. The full moon night marked by the constellation Magha and connected with the moon

original: lakkhitā puṇṇamāsī māghī, māgho.
analyzed: lakkhitā puṇṇamāsī māghī māghaḥ
translated: is the Magha night, the Magha day.

original: 13. Sā+ssa devatā puṇṇamāsī
analyzed: sā assa devatā puṇṇamāsī
translated: The full moon night of that deity

original: Seti paṭhamantā asseti chaṭṭhiyatthe ṇo hoti, yaṃ paṭhamantaṃ, sā ce devatā puṇṇamāsī
analyzed: sā iti paṭhama antā assa iti chaṭṭhiya tthe ṇo hoti yam paṭhama antam sā ce devatā puṇṇamāsī
translated: The suffix ṇo is added to the sixth case of the word for the deity, if it is the full moon night of the deity mentioned first.

original: vā. Sugato devatā assa sogato, māhindo, yāmo, vāruṇo. Buddho assa devatāti buddho.
analyzed: vā sugataḥ devatā assa sogataḥ māhindaḥ yāmaḥ vāruṇaḥ buddhaḥ assa devatā ati buddhaḥ
translated: The full moon night of the deity Sugata is the Sugata full moon, the Sugata day. The full moon night of the deity Mahinda is the Mahinda full moon, the Mahinda day. The full moon night of the deity Yama is the Yama full moon, the Yama day. The full moon night of the deity Varuṇa is the Varuṇa full moon, the Varuṇa day. The full moon night of the deity Buddha is the Buddha full moon, the Buddha day.

original: Phussī puṇṇamāsī assa sambandhinīti phusso māso. Evaṃ māgho, phagguno, citto, vesākho,
analyzed: phussī puṇṇamāsī assa sambandhinī iti phussaḥ māsaḥ evam māghaḥ phaggunaḥ cittaḥ vesākho
translated: So too the Māgha, Phāgguna, Citta, Vesākha,

original: jeṭṭhamūlo, āsāḷho, sāvaṇo, poṭṭhapādo, assayujo, kattiko, māgasiro. Puṇṇamāsī ca
analyzed: jeṭṭhamūlaḥ āsāḷhaḥ sāvaṇaḥ poṭṭhapādaḥ assayujaḥ kattikaḥ māgasiraḥ puṇṇamāsī ca
translated: Jeṭṭha, Āsāḷha, Sāvana, Pausa, Magha, Kattika, and Āsāḷhi months. The full moon🔽is not connected with the Bhadda month, but it is full, thus it is called “full moon” (punnamāsī).

original: bhatakamāsasambandhinī na hoti, puṇṇo mā assanti nibbacanā, ato eva nipātanā ṇo, sāgamo ca.
analyzed: bhataka māsa sambandhinī na hoti puṇṇaḥ mā assanti atas eva nipātanā ṇo sa āgamaḥ ca
translated: The ṇo is formed by the reduplication of the vowel, and the addition of the affix sa.

original: 14. Ta+madhīte taṃ jānāti ka+ṇikā ca
analyzed: tam adhīte tam jānāti kaṇikā ca
translated: He who has studied that, he who knows that, and a small particle.

original: Dutiyantato ta+madhīte taṃ jānātīti etesva+tthesu ṇo hoti ko ṇiko ca. Ettha casaddo
analyzed: tam adhīte tam jānāti iti etesu atthesu ṇo hoti kaḥ ṇikaḥ ca ettha ca saddaḥ
translated: The ṇo is formed in the sense of “he who has studied that, he who knows that” and so on. The word ca

original: ko caṇiko ca hotīti samuccino, no ṇapaccayaṃ. Byākaraṇa+madhīte jānātīti vā veyyākaraṇo,🔽vi+ā+karaṇanti vicchijja katayādesassi+kārassa “tadādesā tadīva bhavantī”ti ñāyā
analyzed: kaḥ caṇikaḥ ca hoti iti samuccinaḥ naḥ ṇa paccayam byākaraṇam adhīte jānāti iti vā veyyākaraṇaḥ  tad ādesā tadīva bhavanti iti ñāyā
translated: in this place is a conjunction, meaning “he who has studied that, he who knows that, and a small particle.” The ṇo is not formed by the ṇapaccayas. He who has studied grammar is a grammarian (veyyākaraṇa).🔽The word vi+ā+karaṇa is analyzed as follows: the prefix vi is a separator, the prefix ā is a prefix, and the root karaṇa is a root. The word vi+ā+karaṇa is formed by the rule “The root and the prefix become as if they were one” (tadādesā tadīva bhavantī).

original: “sarāna”miccādinā ekāre yāgamadvittāni. Evaṃ mohutto, nemitto, aṅgavijjo, vatthuvijjo,
analyzed: ekāre evam mohuttaḥ nemittaḥ aṅga vijjaḥ vatthu vijjaḥ
translated: The word vi+ā+karaṇa is formed by the rule “The vowel of the root becomes ā” (sarāna) and so on, and the vowel i is formed by the rule “The vowel of the root becomes i” (ekāre yāgamadvittāni). So too the deluded, the diviner, the one who knows the parts, the one who knows the subject matter,

original: chandaso, “manā, dīnaṃ saka” iti sakāgamo. Kamako, padako, venayiko, suttantiko,
analyzed: chandasaḥ manā dīnam sakaḥ iti saka āgamaḥ kamakaḥ padakaḥ venayikaḥ suttantikaḥ
translated: The affix -aka is added to the words kamaka, padaka, venayika, suttantika,

original: ābhidhammiko. Dvitaggahaṇaṃ ajjhenajānane ca visuṃ visuṃ paccayavidhānatthaṃ, ajjhenavisayadassanatthaṃ,
analyzed: ābhidhammikaḥ dvita ggahaṇam ajjhena jānane ca visum visum paccaya vidhāna attham ajjhena visaya dassana attham
translated: and abhidhammika. The repetition of the word “two” is for the purpose of showing the two kinds of conditions, and for the purpose of showing the two kinds of objects,

original: pasiddhupasaṃharaṇatthañca.
analyzed: pasiddha upasaṃharaṇa ttham ca
translated: and for the purpose of summarizing the established rules.

original: 15. Tassa visaye dese
analyzed: tassa visaye dese
translated: . In the object of that, in the country

original: Chaṭṭhiyantā visaye desasarūpe ṇo hoti. Vasātīnaṃ visayo deso vāsāto. Deseti kiṃ, cakkhussa visayo rūpaṃ, devadattassa visayo+nuvāko.
analyzed: chaṭṭhi yantāḥ visaye desa sarūpe ṇo hoti vasātīnam visayaḥ desaḥ vāsātaḥ deseti kim cakkhussa visayaḥ rūpam devadattassa visayaḥ anuvākaḥ
translated: In the object, in the country, in the form, ṇo is added. The country of the Vasātī is Vāsāto. What is shown? The object of the eye is form. The object of Devadatta is a follower.

original: 16. Nivāse tannāme
analyzed: nivāse tad nāme
translated: . In the dwelling, in that name

original: Ti tannāme nivāse dese ṇo hoti. Sivīnaṃ nivāso deso sebbo. Ettha “yavā sare”ti yakāre bakārapubbarūpāni. Vāsāto.
analyzed: ti tad nāme nivāse dese ṇo hoti sivīnam nivāsaḥ desaḥ sebbaḥ ettha yavā sarā iti yakāre bakāra pubbarūpāni
translated: In the dwelling, in the country, in that name, ṇo is added. The dwelling of the Sivī is Sebbo. Here, “yavā sare” means the forms beginning with bakārapubba and yakāra. Vāsāto.

original: 17. Adūrabhaveti
analyzed: adūra bhava iti
translated: . In the near vicinity

original: Ṇo, vidisāya adūrabhavaṃ vedisaṃ.
analyzed: ṇaḥ vidisāya adūra bhavam vedisam
translated: ṇo, in the near vicinity of the quarter, Vedisa.

original: 18. Tena nibbatteti
analyzed: tena nibbattā iti
translated: . By that, he produces

original: Tatiyantā nibbattatthe ṇo hoti. Kusambena nibbattā kosambī nagaraṃ, evaṃ kākandī, mākandī, sahassena nibbattā sāhassī parikhā, hetumhi kattari karaṇe ca yathāyogaṃ tatiyā.
analyzed: tatiya antā nibbatta atthe ṇaḥ hoti kusambena nibbattā kosambī nagaram evam kākandī mākandī sahassena nibbattā sāhassī parikhā hetumhi kattari karaṇe ca yathāyogam tatiyā
translated: The 3rd case ending becomes ṇo in the sense of “originated from”: Kosambī city originated from the Kusa grass, thus Kākandī, Mākandī. The moat originated from a thousand (coins), thus Sāhassī. In the sense of “instrument” and “means” the 3rd case ending becomes ṇo according to the rule.

original: 19. Ta+midha+tthi
analyzed: tam idha atthi
translated: . Ta+midha+tthi

original: Tanti paṭhamantā idhāti sattamyatthe dese tannāme ṇo hoti, yaṃ taṃ paṭhamanta+matthi ce. Udumbarā asmiṃ dese santīti odumbaro, bādaro, pabbajo.
analyzed: paṭhama antāḥ idha ati sattamī atthe dese tad nāme ṇaḥ hoti yam tam paṭhama antam atthi ce udumbarāḥ asmin dese santi iti odumbaraḥ bādaraḥ pabbajaḥ
translated: The 3rd case ending becomes ṇo in the sense of “here” (idha) in the sense of “place” (desanāma), if there is a tree (taṃ) there. The trees called Udumbara are here, thus Udumbara. Bādara, Pabbaja.

original: 20. Tatra bhaveti
analyzed: tatra bhava iti
translated: . Tatra bhaveti

original: Sattamyantā bhavatthe ṇo. Udake bhavo odako, oraso, jānapado, māgadho, kāpilavatthavo,🔽kosambo, manasi bhavaṃ mānasaṃ sukhaṃ, sakāgamo. Sāraso sakuṇo, sārasī sakuṇī, sārasaṃ
analyzed: sattamī antāḥ bhavatthe ṇo udake bhavaḥ odakaḥ orasaḥ jānapadaḥ māgadhaḥ kāpilavatthavaḥ  kosambaḥ manasi bhavam mānasam sukham sakāgamaḥ sārasaḥ sakuṇaḥ sārasī sakuṇī sārasam
translated: The 3rd case ending becomes ṇo in the sense of “originated there” (bhavattha). The water originated there, thus Odaka. Orasa, Jānapada, Māgadha, Kāpilavatthu,

original: pupphaṃ. Mitte bhavā mettā mettī vā. Pure bhavā porī vācā. Pāvuse bhavo pāvuso megho.🔽Pāvusā ratti, pāvusaṃ abbhaṃ. Sārado, sāradā, sāradaṃ pupphaṃ. Mādhuro jano, mādhurā
analyzed: puppham mitte bhavā mettā mettī vā pure bhavā porī vācā pāvuse bhavaḥ pāvusaḥ meghaḥ 🔽pāvusā ratti pāvusam abbham sāradaḥ sāradā sāradam puppham mādhuraḥ janaḥ mādhurā
translated: Kosamba. The happiness called “mind-born” (manasā bhavaṃ) is mānasa. The bird called “self-born” (sakāgamo) is sārasa. The flower called “self-born” (sāradaṃ) is sārada. The people called “sweet” (mādhura) are mādhurā.

original: gaṇikā, mādhuraṃ vatthaṃ.
analyzed: gaṇikā mādhuram vattham
translated: a courtesan, a sweet cloth.

original: 21. Ajjādīhi tanoti
analyzed: tanoti
translated: . Today, etc.

original: Bhavatthe tano. Ajja bhavo ajjatano, svātano, hiyyatano. “Eona+ma vaṇṇe”ti eonaṃ a hoti.
analyzed: bhavatthe tano ajja bhavaḥ ajjatano svātano hiyyatano eonama vaṇṇā iti eonam a hoti
translated: In the sense of “existence” (bhava) there is -tana. Today’s existence is ajjatana, self-existence is svātana, yesterday’s existence is hiyyatana. In eona vaṇṇe, eona has a.

original: 22. Purāto ṇo cati
analyzed: purā taḥ ṇaḥ ca ti
translated: . Before, -ṇo and -cati

original: Bhavatthe ṇo tano ca. Ettha ṇakāro avayavo, nevā+nubandho. Purāṇo, purātano.
analyzed: bhavatthe ṇo tano ca ettha ṇakāraḥ avayavaḥ purāṇaḥ purātanaḥ
translated: In the sense of “existence” there is -ṇo and -tana. Here the -ṇo is a component, not a suffix. Ancient is purāṇa, ancient before is purātana.

original: 23. Amātva+ccoti
analyzed: amātvat ca uti
translated: . Without, -cco

original: Bhavatthe acco hoti. Amā=saha bhavo amacco.
analyzed: bhavatthe accaḥ hoti bhavaḥ amaccaḥ
translated: In the sense of “existence” there is -cco. Without existence is amacca.

original: 24. Majjhāditvi+moti
analyzed: majjha ādi tvimā iti
translated: . Middle, etc.

original: Bhavatthe imo, majjhe bhavo majjhimo. Evaṃ antimo, heṭṭhimo, uparimo, orimo, pārimo, pacchimo, abbhantaridho, paccantimo.🔽25. Kaṇa+ṇeyya+ṇeyyaka+yi+yāti🔽Bhavatthe kaṇaādayo honti. Kaṇa-kusinārāyaṃ bhavo kosinārako, māgadhako, āraññako🔽vihāro, rājagahako, kosambako, indapattako, kāpilako, bhārukacchako, nāgarako. Aṅgesu
analyzed: bhavatthe imaḥ majjhe bhavaḥ majjhimaḥ evam antimaḥ heṭṭhimaḥ uparimaḥ orimaḥ pārimaḥ pacchimaḥ abbhantaridho paccantimaḥ 🔽kaṇaṇeyyaṇeyyakayiyāti 🔽bhavatthe kaṇa ādayaḥ honti kaṇa kusināra ayam bhavaḥ kosinārakaḥ māgadhakaḥ āraññakaḥ 🔽vihāraḥ rājagahakaḥ kosambakaḥ indapattakaḥ kāpilakaḥ bhārukacchakaḥ nāgarakaḥ aṅgesu
translated: In the sense of “existence” there is -imo. In the middle of existence is majjhimo. Thus: last, lowest, highest, this side, that side, behind, farthest, innermost, farthest.

original: jāto aṅgako, kosalako, vedehako, kambojako, gandhārako, sovīrako, sindhavako, assako
analyzed: jātaḥ aṅgakaḥ kosalakaḥ vedehakaḥ kambojakaḥ gandhārakaḥ sovīrakaḥ sindhavakaḥ assako
translated: born in Aṅga, born in Kosala, born in Videha, born in Kamboja, born in Gandhāra, born in Sovira, born in Sindhu, born in Assaka,

original: iccādi. Ṇeyya-gaṅgeyyo, pabbateyyo, vāneyyo. Ṇeyyaka-kosaleyyako, bārāṇaseyyako,
analyzed: iccādi ṇeyyagaṅgeyyaḥ pabbateyyaḥ vāneyyaḥ ṇeyyaka kosaleyyakaḥ bārāṇaseyyakaḥ
translated: and so on. Born in the Negaṃbhu River, born in the mountains, born in the forest. Born in the Negaṃbhu River and Kosala, born in Bārāṇasī,

original: campeyyako, silāya jātaṃ seleyyakaṃ, mithileyyako. Bārāṇaseyyakotyādīsu “dissanta+ññepi
analyzed: campeyyakaḥ silāya jātam seleyyakam mithileyyakaḥ bārāṇaseyyaka utyādīsu
translated: born in Campā, born in Seliya, born in Mithilā. In Bārāṇasī, etc., “they are seen even

original: paccayā”ti eyyako, evaṃ upari sutte dassitapaccayato visuṃ paccaye dassite iminā
analyzed: paccayā ti eyyakaḥ evam upari sutte dassita paccayataḥ visum paccaye dassite iminā
translated: as conditions,” thus it is a condition. Thus, apart from the conditions shown in the sutta above, the conditions shown separately by this

original: suttenāti daṭṭhabbaṃ. Ya-gammo, yamhi akāralope pubbarūpaṃ rasso ca. Dibbo. Iya-udariyo,
analyzed: suttena ati daṭṭhabbam ya gammaḥ yamhi akāra lope pubba rūpam rassaḥ ca dibbaḥ
translated: sutta should be seen. The Y-stem, in which the akāra is elided and the preceding vowel is lengthened. Dibba. The Iya-stem,

original: diviyo, pañcāliyo, bodhipakkhiyo, lokiyo.
analyzed: diviyaḥ pañcāliyaḥ bodhi pakkhiyaḥ lokiyaḥ
translated: in heaven, in the five regions, in the factors of enlightenment, in the world.

original: 26. Ṇiko
analyzed: ṇ ikaḥ
translated: . The Ṇiko

original: Sattamyantā bhavatthe ṇiko hoti. Sarade bhavo sāradiko divaso, sāradikā ratti.
analyzed: sattamī antāḥ bhavatthe ṇikaḥ hoti sarade bhavaḥ sāradikaḥ divasaḥ sāradikā ratti
translated: The Ṇiko is formed from the locative case ending, meaning “in.” The day in autumn is sāradika, the night in autumn is sāradikā.

original: 27. Ta+massa sippaṃ sīlaṃ paṇyaṃ paharaṇaṃ payojanaṃ
analyzed: tamassa sippam sīlam paṇyam paharaṇam payojanam
translated: . Ta+massa sippaṃ sīlaṃ paṇyaṃ paharaṇaṃ payojanaṃ

original: Paṭhamantā sippādivācakā asseti chaṭṭhyatthe ṇiko hoti. Vīṇāvādanaṃ sippa+massa veṇiko,
analyzed: paṭhama antā sippa ādi vācakā assa iti chaṭṭhī atthe hoti vīṇā vādanam sippam assa veṇikaḥ
translated: The Ṇiko is formed from the first case ending, meaning “of,” in the six cases beginning with “the craft, etc., of.” The craft of playing the lute is veṇika,

original: vīṇāvādanaṃ abhedopacārena vīṇā nāma. Modiṅgiko, vaṃsiko. Paṃsukūladhāraṇaṃ sīla+massa🔽paṃsukūliko, tecīvariko. Gandho paṇya+massa gandhiko, teliko, goḷiko, pūviko, paṇṇiko,🔽tambuliko, loṇiko. Cāpopaharaṇa+massa cāpiko, tomariko, muggariko, mosaliko. Upadhi=kkhandhādi
analyzed: vīṇā vādanam abheda upacārena vīṇā nāma modiṅgikaḥ vaṃsiko paṃsukūla dhāraṇam sīlam assa  paṃsukūlikaḥ tecīvarikaḥ gandhaḥ paṇyam assa gandhikaḥ telikaḥ goḷikaḥ pūvikaḥ paṇṇiko  tambulikaḥ loṇikaḥ cāpa upaharaṇam assa cāpikaḥ tomarikaḥ muggarikaḥ mosalikaḥ upadhi khandha ādi
translated: The playing of the lute is called the lute by way of a derivation from the non-division of the lute. The player of the lute, the flute-player. The wearing of rags is the rag-robe wearer, the triple-robe wearer. The scent is the perfume-wearer, the oil-wearer, the fat-wearer, the marrow-wearer, the leaf-wearer,🔽the betel-wearer, the salt-wearer. The carrying of the bow is the bow-wearer, the tomara-wearer, the mugga-wearer, the mallet-wearer. The aggregates of clinging, etc.

original: payojana+massa opadhikaṃ, sātikaṃ, sāhassikaṃ.🔽28. Taṃ hanta+rahati gacchatu+ñchati+carati🔽Dutiyantā hantīti evamādīsva+tthesu ṇiko hoti. Pakkhino hantīti pakkhiko, sākuṇiko,🔽māyūriko, macche hantīti macchiko, meniko. Mige hantīti māgaviko, vakārāgamo. Migassa🔽“tadaminā”dinā magavādesepi māgaviko. Orabbhiko, hāriṇiko. Sūkarikoti iko. Sata+marahatīti

original: anukaraṇattā vā taddhitassa abhidhānalakkhaṇattā vā bahulaṃvidhānena vā paccayo.
analyzed: anukaraṇa ttā vā taddhitassa abhidhāna lakkhaṇa ttā vā bahulaṃvidhānena vā paccayaḥ
translated: or because of the meaning of imitation, or because of the meaning of designation, or because of the frequent use of the word.”🔽The words sāhassiko, kumbhiko, doṇiko, addhamāsiko, kahāpaṇiko, āsītikā gāthā, nāvutikā, sahassāti

original: Sāhassiko, kumbhiko, doṇiko, addhamāsiko, kahāpaṇiko, āsītikā gāthā, nāvutikā. Sahassiyoti
analyzed: sāhassikaḥ kumbhikaḥ doṇikaḥ addhamāsikaḥ kahāpaṇikaḥ āsītikā gāthā nāvutikā sahassiyā ti
translated: are formed by the addition of the affix -ika to the words sāhassi, kumbha, doṇa, addhamāsa, kahāpaṇa, āsīti, nava, sahass, and the affix is added🔽by the rule “The affix -ika is added to the words beginning with tyādyanta,🔽or because of the meaning of imitation, or because of the meaning of designation, or because of the frequent use of the word.”

original: iyo. Paradāraṃ gacchatīti pāradāriko, maggiko, paññāsayojaniko, pathiko. Badare uñchatīti
analyzed: paradāram gacchati iti pāradārikaḥ maggiko paññāsayojaniko pathikaḥ badare uñchati iti
translated: The word pāradāriko is formed by the addition of the affix -ika to pāradāraṃ gacchati, “he goes to another’s wife.” The words maggiko, paññāsayojaniko, pathiko are formed by the addition of the affix -ika to magga, paññāsayojana, and patha,🔽and the affix is added by the rule “The affix -ika is added to the words beginning with tyādyanta,🔽or because of the meaning of imitation, or because of the meaning of designation, or because of the frequent use of the word.” The word bādariko is formed by the addition of the affix -ika to badare uñchati, “he begs for jujube fruit,”

original: bādariko, sāmākiko. Dhammaṃ caratīti dhammiko, adhammiko.🔽29. Tena kataṃ kītaṃ baddha+mabhisaṅkhataṃ saṃsaṭṭhaṃ hataṃ hanti jitaṃ jayati dibbati khanati tarati carati vahati jīvatiti
analyzed: bādarikaḥ sāmākikaḥ dhammam carati iti dhammikaḥ adhammikaḥ  tena katam kītam baddham abhisaṅkhatam saṃsaṭṭham hatam hanti jitam jayati dibbati khanati tarati carati vahati jīvatiti

original: Katādīsva+tthesu ṇiko. Kāyena kataṃ kāyikaṃ, vācasikaṃ, mānasikaṃti sakāgamo. Vātena🔽kato ābādho vātito, semhiko, pittiko. Satena kītaṃ sātikaṃ, sāhassikaṃ, vatthena
analyzed: kata ādīsu atthesu ṇikaḥ kāyena katam kāyikam vācasikam mānasikam iti saka āgamaḥ vātena 🔽kataḥ ābādhaḥ vātitaḥ semhiko pittiko satena kītam sātikam sāhassikam vatthena
translated: or because of the meaning of imitation, or because of the meaning of designation, or because of the frequent use of the word.” The words kata, kīta, baddha,

original: kītaṃ vatthikaṃ, kumbhikaṃ, sovaṇṇikaṃ, ghātikaṃ. Mūlatova paccayo, amūlavācittā
analyzed: kītam vatthikam kumbhikam sovaṇṇikam ghātikam mūlataḥ va paccayaḥ a mūla vāci tā
translated: a wager, a stake, a pot, a goldsmith, a slaughterhouse. From the root itself is the condition, not from the root by speech.

original: devadattena kītoti na hoti, tadatthāppatītiyā. Varatthāya baddho vārattiko, āyasiko,
analyzed: devadattena kītaḥ iti na hoti varatthāya baddhaḥ vārattikaḥ āyasikaḥ
translated: What is staked by Devadatta is not a wager, because of the non-attainment of that meaning. What is bound for the sake of a boon is a boon, an iron (stake),

original: pāsiko, suttiko. Ghatena abhisaṅkhataṃ saṃsaṭṭhaṃ vā ghātikaṃ, goḷikaṃ, dadhikaṃ,🔽mārīcikaṃ. Jālena hato hantīti vā jāliko, bālisiko. Akkhehi jitaṃ akkhikaṃ dhanaṃ,
analyzed: pāsikaḥ suttikaḥ ghatena abhisaṅkhatam saṃsaṭṭham vā ghātikam goḷikam dadhikam  mārīcikam jālena hataḥ hanti iti vā jālikaḥ bālisikaḥ akkhehi jitam akkhikam dhanam
translated: a snare, a net. What is determined by a pot is mixed with a slaughterhouse, a dice, a curd,🔽a mirage. What is killed by a net kills, or a net, a fish-trap. What is won by dice is a dice,

original: sālākikaṃ, tindukiko, ambaphaliko. Akkhehi jayati dibbati vā akkhiko. Khaṇittiyā
analyzed: sālākikam tindukikaḥ ambaphalikaḥ akkhehi jayati dibbati vā akkhikaḥ khaṇittiyā
translated: a gambling house, a tinduka fruit, a mango fruit. What is won by dice is paid, or a dice. What is dug

original: khanatīti khāṇittiko, kuddāliko. Devadattena jitaṃ, aṅgulyā khanatīti na hoti, tadatthānavagamā.🔽Uḷumpena taratīti oḷumpiko, uḷumpikoti iko. Kulliko, gopucchiko, nāviko. Sakaṭena
analyzed: khanati iti khāṇittikaḥ kuddālikaḥ devadattena jitam aṅgulyā khanati iti na hoti  uḷumpena tarati iti oḷumpikaḥ uḷumpikaḥ iti kullikaḥ gopucchikaḥ nāvikaḥ sakaṭena

original: caratīti sākaṭiko, rathiko. Parappikoti iko. Khandhena vahatīti khandhiko. Aṃsiko,
analyzed: carati iti sākaṭikaḥ rathiko parappiko ti khandhena vahati iti khandhikaḥ aṃsiko
translated: by a cart is a cart, a chariot. What is borrowed from another is borrowed, a handcart. What is carried on the shoulder is a shoulder-load, a shoulder-pole.

original: sīsikoti iko. Vetanena jīvatīti vetaniko, bhatiko, kayiko, vikkayiko, kayavikkayikoti iko.
analyzed: sīsikā uti i kaḥ vetanena jīvati iti vetanikaḥ bhatikaḥ kayikaḥ vikkayikaḥ kayavikkayikaḥ iti i kaḥ
translated: Sīsika means iko. One who lives by wages is a vetaniko, a bhatiko, a kayiko, a vikkayiko, a kayavikkayiko.

original: 30. Tassa saṃvattati
analyzed: tassa saṃvattati
translated: . It occurs in him

original: Catutthyantā saṃvattatīti asmiṃ attheṇiko hoti. Punabbhavāya saṃvattatīti ponobbhaviko,
analyzed: catutthī antā saṃvattati iti asmin hoti punabbhavāya saṃvattati iti ponobbhavikaḥ
translated: In the sense “it occurs in the end of the fourth” he is an asmiṇṇhiko. In the sense “it occurs again for rebirth” he is a ponobbhaviko,

original: itthiyaṃ ponobbhavikā. Lokāya saṃvattatīti lokiko. Suṭṭhu aggoti saggo, saggāya saṃvattatīti🔽sovaggiko, sasso+vaka tadaminādīpāṭhā. Dhanāya saṃvattatīti dhaññaṃ.
analyzed: itthiyam ponobbhavikā lokāya saṃvattati iti lokiko suṭṭhu aggo ti saggo saggāya saṃvattati iti  dhanāya saṃvattati iti dhaññam
translated: in a woman a ponobbhavikā. In the sense “it occurs in the world” he is a lokiko. In the sense “he has gone well” he is a saggo, in the sense “it occurs for heaven” he is a sovaggiko. In the sense “it occurs for wealth” he is a dhañña.

original: 31. Tato sambhūta+māgataṃ
analyzed: tatas sambhūtam āgatam
translated: . From that it is produced, come

analyzed: pañcamī antā sambhūtam āgatam iti etesu atthesu ṇikaḥ hoti mātitas sambhūtam āgatam vā iti
translated: In the sense “produced from that, come from that” he is ṇiko. In the sense “produced from the mother, come from the mother”

analyzed: ettha ca vākyam 🔽mattikam pettikam dissanti surabhitaḥ sambhūtam sorabhyam
translated: here “from the mother and from the sister” the word “from the mother” is by the rule “mātito ca bhaginiyaṃccho” . In the sense “from the mother and from the father”🔽here “from the mother and from the father” the word “from the mother” is by the rule “mātito ca bhaginiyaṃccho” . In the sense “from the mother and from the sister”🔽here “from the mother and from the sister” the word “from the mother” is by the rule “mātito ca bhaginiyaṃccho” . In the sense “from the mother and from the father”🔽here “from the mother and from the father” the word “from the mother” is by the rule “mātito ca bhaginiyaṃccho” . In the sense “from the mother and from the sister”🔽here “from the mother and from the sister” the word “from the mother” is by the rule “mātito ca bhaginiyaṃccho” . In the sense “from the mother and from the father”🔽here “from the mother and from the father” the word “from the mother” is by the rule “mātito ca bhaginiyaṃccho” . In the sense “from the mother and from the sister”🔽here “from the mother and from the sister” the word “from the mother” is by the rule “mātito ca bhaginiyaṃccho” .

original: Yamhi thaññaṃ. Ubhayattha “lopo+vaṇṇi+vaṇṇānaṃ”ti lopo. Riyaṇa-pituto sambhūto pettiyo,
analyzed: yamhi thaññam ubhayattha lopaḥ vaṇṇi vaṇṇānam ti lopaḥ sambhūtaḥ pettiyaḥ
translated: The word pettiyo is formed from petti, the feminine of pitā, “father,” by the addition of the feminine ending -iyo.🔽The word mattiyo is formed from matā, “mother,” by the addition of the feminine ending -iyo.

original: mātiyo, “rānubandhe+ntasarādissā”ti ulopo, mattiyo. Ryamhi-ulopo, cavaggapubbarūpāni, macco vā.
analyzed: mātiyoḥ ra anubandha inta sara ādissa āti u lopaḥ mattiyoḥ ryam hi u lopaḥ ca vagga pubbarūpāni maccaḥ vā
translated: The word macco is formed from macca, “mortal,” by the addition of the masculine ending -o.

original: 32. Tattha vasati vidito bhatto niyutto🔽Sattamyantā vasatītvevamādīsva+tthesu ṇiko hoti. Rukkhamūle vasatīti rukkhamūliko,
analyzed: tattha vasati viditaḥ bhattaḥ niyuttaḥ  sattamī antā vasati iti evamādīsu atthesu ṇikaḥ hoti rukkha mūle vasati iti rukkhamūliko
translated: . He who dwells there, known, fed, appointed🔽The suffix ṇiko is added to words ending in the locative case to denote the meaning “dwelling there.”

original: āraññiko, rājagahiko, māgadhiko, sosāniko. Loke vidito lokiko. Catumahārājesu bhattā🔽cātummahārājikā. Dvāre niyutto dovāriko, dassoka tadaminādipāṭhā. Bhaṇḍāgāriko. Ike-navakammiko,
analyzed: āraññikaḥ rājagahikaḥ māgadhiko sosānikaḥ loke viditaḥ lokiko catu mahārājesu bhattā  cātummahārājikāḥ dvāre niyuttaḥ dovārikaḥ bhaṇḍāgārikaḥ
translated: One who dwells at the foot of a tree is a rukkhamūliko; one who dwells in the forest is an āraññiko; one who dwells in Rājagaha is a rājagahiko; one who dwells in Magadha is a māgadhiko; one who dwells in a charnel ground is a sosāniko. One who is known in the world is a lokiyo. One who is fed by the Four Great Kings is a cātummahārājiko.

original: ādikammiko. Kiye-jātikiyo, andhakiyo.
analyzed: ādi kammikaḥ kiyejātikiyaḥ andha kiyaḥ
translated: One who is appointed at the gate is a dovāriko. The words bhaṇḍāgāriko, ika-navakammiko, ādikammiko, kiye-jātikiyo, andhakiyo are formed in the same way.

original: 33. Tassi+daṃ
analyzed: tassidam
translated: . This is his🔽The suffix ṇiko is added to words ending in the sixth case to denote the meaning “this.”

original: Chaṭṭhiyantā ida+micca+smiṃ atthe ṇiko hoti. Saṅghassa idaṃ saṅghikaṃ, puggalikaṃ,
analyzed: chaṭṭhi yantāḥ idam iccasmin atthe ṇikaḥ hoti saṅghassa idam saṅghikam puggalikam
translated: This belongs to the Sangha is saṅghikaṃ; this belongs to an individual is puggalikaṃ.

original: sakyaputtiko, nāṭaputtiko, jenadattiko. Kiye-sassa idaṃ sakiyo, parakiyo. Niyeattaniyaṃ.
analyzed: sakyaputtikaḥ nāṭa puttikaḥ jenadattikaḥ idam sakiyaḥ parakiyaḥ
translated: Sakyaputtiya, Nāṭaputtiya, Jenadattiya. Kiye-sassa idaṃ sakiyaṃ, parakiyaṃ. Niyeattaniyaṃ.

original: Ke-sako, rañño idaṃ rājakaṃ bhaṇḍaṃ.
analyzed: kesakaḥ rañño idam rājakam bhaṇḍam
translated: Ke-sako, rañño idaṃ rājakaṃ bhaṇḍaṃ.

original: 34. Ṇo
analyzed: ṇaḥ

original: Chaṭṭhiyantā ida+micca+smiṃ atthe ṇo hoti. Kaccāyanassa idaṃ kaccāyanaṃ, byākaraṇaṃ, sogataṃ sāsanaṃ, māhisaṃ maṃsādi.
analyzed: chaṭṭhi yantāḥ idam iccasmin atthe ṇo hoti kaccāyanassa idam kaccāyanam byākaraṇam sogatam sa āsanam māhisam maṃsa ādi
translated: Chaṭṭhiyantā ida+micca+smiṃ atthe ṇo hoti. Kaccāyanassa idaṃ kaccāyanaṃ, byākaraṇaṃ, sogataṃ sāsanaṃ, māhisaṃ maṃsādi.

original: 35. Gavādīhi yo
analyzed: go ādīhi yaḥ
translated: . Gavādīhi yo

original: Gavādīhi chaṭṭhiyantehi ida+micca+smiṃ atthe yo hoti. Gunnaṃ idaṃ gabyaṃ, avaṅa, maṃsādi. Ilope kabbaṃ. Duno idaṃ dabbaṃ.
analyzed: go ādīhi chaṭṭhi yantehi idam iccasmin atthe yaḥ hoti gunnam idam gabyam avaṅa maṃsa ādi i lope kabbam dunaḥ idam dabbam
translated: Gavādīhi chaṭṭhiyantehi ida+micca+smiṃ atthe yo hoti. Gunnaṃ idaṃ gabyaṃ, avaṅa, maṃsādi. Ilope kabbaṃ. Duno idaṃ dabbaṃ.

original: 36. Pitito bhātari reyyaṇa
analyzed: pititaḥ bhātari reyyaṇa
translated: . Pitito bhātari reyyaṇa

original: “Pitito mātito”ti tena tena suttanipāteneva ussa i. Pitusaddā tassa bhātari reyyaṇa. Pitu bhātā petteyyo.
analyzed: pititaḥ mātitaḥ iti tena tena sutta nipātena iva pitu saddā tassa bhātari pitu bhātā petteyyaḥ
translated: “Pitito mātito”ti tena tena suttanipāteneva ussa i. Pitusaddā tassa bhātari reyyaṇa. Pitu bhātā petteyyo.

original: 37. Mātito ca bhaginiyaṃ ccho
analyzed: ca bhaginiyam ccho
translated: . Mātito ca bhaginiyaṃ ccho

original: Mātuto ca pituto ca tesaṃ bhaginiyaṃ ccho hoti. Mātu bhagini mātucchā, pitu bhagini pitucchā. Kathaṃ “mātu bhātā mātulo”ti, “mātulāditvānī”ti nipātanā lapaccayo.
analyzed: mātutaḥ ca pitutaḥ ca tesam bhaginiyam cchaḥ hoti mātu bhagini mātucchā pitu bhagini pitucchā katham mātu bhātā mātulaḥ iti mātula ādi tvāni iti nipātanā la paccayaḥ
translated: And the sister of the mother and the father has the form tesaṃ bhaginiṃ ccho. The mother’s sister is the mātucchā, the father’s sister is the pitucchā. How is it that the mother’s brother is the mātula? The affix -la is added by the rule “mātula, etc.”

original: 38. Mātāpitūsvā+maho🔽Mātāpitūhi tesaṃ mātāpitūsvā+maho hoti. Mātu mātā mātāmahī, mātu pitā mātāmaho. Pitu🔽mātā pitāmahī, pitu pitā pitāmaho. Na yathāsaṅkhyaṃ paccekābhisambandhato visuṃ visuṃ
analyzed: mātā pitūsvāmaho  tesam hoti mātu mātā mātāmahī mātu pitā mātāmahaḥ pitu  mātā pitāmahī pitu pitā pitāmahaḥ na yathāsaṅkhyam pacceka abhisambandhataḥ visum visum
translated: . The mother and father have the form +maho🔽The mother and father have the form +maho. The mother’s mother is the mātāmahī, the mother’s father is the mātāmaho. The father’s mother is the pitāmahī, the father’s father is the pitāmaho. Not in the order of enumeration, because of the connection with each individual.🔽. The mother and father have the form +maho

original: mātāpitusaddehi tesaṃ mātāpitunnaṃ atthe paccayo hoti.🔽39. Hite reyyaṇa🔽Mātāpitūhi hite reyyaṇa hoti. Mātu hito matteyyo, petteyyo.
analyzed: mātā pitu saddehi tesam mātā pitunnam atthe paccayaḥ hoti  hite reyyaṇa  mātā pitūhi hite hoti mātu hitaḥ matteyyaḥ petteyyaḥ
translated: The mother and father have the form +maho. The mother’s mother is the mātāmahī, the mother’s father is the mātāmaho. The father’s mother is the pitāmahī, the father’s father is the pitāmaho. Not in the order of enumeration, because of the connection with each individual.🔽. The mother and father have the form +maho

original: 40. Nindā+ññāta+ppa paṭibhāga rassa dayā saññāsu ko🔽Nindādīsva+tthesu nāmasmā ko hoti. Nindāyaṃ-nindito muṇḍo muṇḍako, evaṃ samaṇako,
analyzed: nindā aññātappa paṭibhāga rassa dayā saññāsu ko  nindā ādīsu atthesu nāmasma kaḥ hoti muṇḍaḥ muṇḍako evam samaṇako
translated: The mother and father have the form +maho. The mother’s mother is the mātāmahī, the mother’s father is the mātāmaho. The father’s mother is the pitāmahī, the father’s father is the pitāmaho. Not in the order of enumeration, because of the connection with each individual.🔽. The mother and father have the form +maho🔽The mother and father have the form +maho. The mother’s mother is the mātāmahī, the mother’s father is the mātāmaho. The father’s mother is the pitāmahī, the father’s father is the pitāmaho. Not in the order of enumeration, because of the connection with each individual.🔽. The mother and father have the form +maho

original: paṇḍitako, brāhmaṇako, veyyākaraṇako. Aññāte-kassā+yaṃ asso assako, payogasāmatthiyā
analyzed: paṇḍitakaḥ brāhmaṇakaḥ veyyākaraṇakaḥ aññāta ikassa ayam assaḥ assako payoga sāmatthiyā
translated: The mother and father have the form +maho. The mother’s mother is the mātāmahī, the mother’s father is the mātāmaho. The father’s mother is the pitāmahī, the father’s father is the pitāmaho. Not in the order of enumeration, because

original: sambandhivisesānāvagamo+vagamyate. Appatthe-appakaṃ telaṃ telakaṃ, ghatakaṃ. Paṭibhāgatthe-hatthī
analyzed: sambandhi visesa an avagamaḥ uvagamyate appa tthe appakam telam telakam ghatakam paṭibhāga tthe hatthī
translated: The meaning of a word is understood as the particular relation (of the word to its meaning). In the sense of a small amount: a little oil is telakaṃ, a little pot is ghatakaṃ. In the sense of a counterpart: an elephant is hatthī.

original: viya hatthiko, assako, balībaddhako. “Ime no hatthikā assā, balībaddhā ca no ime”tyādipāṭhe
analyzed: viya hatthikaḥ assakaḥ balībaddhakaḥ ime naḥ hatthikāḥ assāḥ balībaddhā ca no ime ityādi pāṭhe
translated: The meaning of a particular relative is understood. In the sense of a small amount: a little oil is telakaṃ, a little ghee is ghātakaṃ. In the sense of a counterpart: an elephant is hatthiko, a horse is assako, a sacrificial animal is balībaddhako. In the passage “These are our elephants, these are our horses, these are our sacrificial animals” and so on,

original: “lopo”ti kapaccayalopena vā abhedopacārena vā daṭṭhabbaṃ, ime ca dāruādīhi katarūpāni.🔽Rasserasso mānuso mānusako, rukkhako, pilakkhako. Dayāyaṃ-dayito=nukampito putto🔽puttako, vacchako. Saññāyaṃ-moro viya morako, katako, bhatako.
analyzed: lopaḥ iti ka paccaya lopena vā abheda upacārena vā daṭṭhabbam ime ca dāru ādīhi kata rūpāni  rasserassaḥ mānusaḥ mānusakaḥ rukkhakaḥ pilakkhakaḥ dayāyan dayitaḥ nukampito putto  puttakaḥ vacchakaḥ saññāyaṃmoraḥ viya morako katakaḥ bhatako
translated: the word lopa should be regarded as a locative case-ending lost or as a non-distinction. And these are of wood, etc.

original: 41. Ta+massa parimāṇaṃ ṇiko ca
analyzed: tamassa parimāṇam ṇikaḥ ca
translated: In the sense of a human being: a man is rassassa, a human being is mānusako, a tree is rukkhako, a bamboo is pilakkhako. In the sense of affection: a son is dayāyaṃ, a son is dayito, a calf is dayako, a calf is vacchako. In the sense of resemblance: a peacock is morassa, a peacock is morako, a cat is marakassa, a cat is katako, a servant is bhatassa, a servant is bhatako.🔽The suffix ṇiko is used to denote a measure of that.

original: Paṭhamantā asseti asmiṃ atthe ṇiko hoti ko ca, tañce paṭhamantaṃ parimāṇaṃ bhavati.
analyzed: paṭhama antāḥ assa iti asmin atthe ṇ ikaḥ hoti kaḥ ca paṭhama antam parimāṇam bhavati
translated: In the sense of a horse: in the sense of a horse, the suffix ṇiko is used, and if that ṇiko is a measure,

original: Doṇādīnaṃ parimitavīhādīnaṃ karaṇattā “parimīyantya+nenāti parimāṇa”nti hoti. Doṇo
analyzed: doṇa ādīnam parimita vīha ādīnam karaṇa ttā parimīyanti anena ati hoti doṇaḥ
translated: it is a measure because it is the means of measuring such limited things as a doṇa of rice, etc. A doṇa is doṇassa, a doṇa is doṇiko.

original: parimāṇa+massāti doṇiko vīhi, khārasatiko, khārasahassiko, āsītiko vayo, upaḍḍhakāyo
analyzed: parimāṇam assa ati doṇikaḥ vīhi khāra satikaḥ khāra sahassikaḥ āsītikaḥ vayaḥ upaḍḍha kāyo
translated: A measure of weight: a doṇika of rice, a khārasatika, a khārasahassaka, a vayo of twenty, a vayo of twenty-five

original: parimāṇa+massa upaḍḍhakāyikaṃ bimbohanaṃ. Pañcakaṃ, chakkaṃ.
analyzed: parimāṇam assa upaḍḍhakāyikam bimbohanam pañcakam chakkam
translated: A measure of weight: a vayo of twenty-five is a bimbohana. A set of five, a set of six.

original: 42. Ya+te+tehi+ttako
analyzed: yat e te hittakaḥ
translated: . As many as that

original: Yādīhi paṭhamantehi asseti chaṭṭhyatthe ttako hoti, tañce paṭhamantaṃ parimāṇaṃ bhavati.🔽Yaṃ parimāṇa+massa yattakaṃ, tattakaṃ, “etasseṭa ttake”ti etassa eṭa, ettakaṃ. Āvatake-yaṃ
analyzed: ya ādīhi paṭhama antehi assa iti chaṭṭhī atthe ttakaḥ hoti paṭhama antam parimāṇam bhavati  yam parimāṇam assa yattakam tattakam etassa iṭa etassa ettakam
translated: As many as that is ttaka when the first word is a measure of weight in the sixth case, and that first word is a measure.

original: parimāṇa+massa yāvatako, tāvatako.
analyzed: parimāṇam assa yāvatakaḥ tāvatakaḥ
translated: As many as that of a measure of weight is that much, “That much has eṭa,” that much is eṭṭhaka. As many as that of a measure of weight is as many as that, that much.🔽. As many as that🔽As many as that is āvantu when the first word is a measure of weight in the sixth case, and that first word is a measure. As many as that of a measure of weight is as many as that, that much.

original: 43. Sabbā cā+vantu
analyzed: sabbā ca avantu
translated: . All and so on

original: Sabbato paṭhamantā yādīhi ca asseti chaṭṭhyatthe āvantu hoti, tañce paṭhamantaṃ parimāṇaṃ bhavati. Sabbaṃ parimāṇa+massa sabbāvantaṃ, “aṃṅaṃ napuṃsake”ti aṃ. Yāvantaṃ, tāvantaṃ.
analyzed: sabbatas paṭhama antāḥ ya ādīhi ca assa iti chaṭṭhī atthe hoti tat ce paṭhamantam parimāṇam bhavati sabbam parimāṇam assa sabbāvantam napuṃsaka iti aṃ yāvantam tāvantam
translated: All and so on is āvantu when the first word is a measure of weight in the sixth case, and that first word is a measure. All of a measure of weight is as much as all, “aṃ is for neuter,” aṃ. As many as that, as much as that.

original: 44. Kimhā rati+rīva+rīvataka+rittakā
analyzed: kimhā
translated: . As much as what? rati, rīva, rīvataka, rittaka

original: Kimhā paṭhamantā asseti chaṭṭhyatthe rati+rīva+rīvataka+rittakā honti. Kiṃsaṅkhyānaṃ
analyzed: kimhā paṭhamantāḥ assa iti chaṭṭhī atthe rati rīva rīvataka rittakāḥ honti kiṃsaṅkhyānam
translated: As much as what is rati, rīva, rīvataka, rittaka when the first word is a measure of weight in the sixth case. As many as what is

original: parimāṇa+mesaṃ kati, rānubandhattā iṃbhāgalopo. Kīva, kīvatakaṃ, kittakaṃ. Rīvanto sabhāvato asaṃkhyo.
analyzed: kati iṃ bhāga lopaḥ kīva kīvatakam kittakam rīvantaḥ asaṃkhyaḥ
translated: How much, how many, how much? The measure of the sky is not reckoned by the number of its parts.

original: 45. Sañjātaṃ tārakāditvi+toti
analyzed: sañjātam
translated: The measure of the stars, etc., is not reckoned by the number of their parts.

original: Sañjātatthe ito. Tārakā sañjātā assa tārakitaṃ gaganaṃ, pupphāni sañjātāni assa pupphito rukkho, pallavitā latā.🔽46. Māne matto
analyzed: sañjāta tthe itas tārakā sañjātā assa tārakitam gaganam pupphāni sañjātāni assa pupphitaḥ rukkho pallavitā latā  māne matto
translated: The measure of the sky is not reckoned by the number of its parts. The stars are born in the sky, therefore the sky is star-filled. Flowers are born in a tree, therefore the tree is flower-filled. Creepers are born in a forest, therefore the forest is creeper-filled.

original: Paṭhamantā mānavuttito asseti asmiṃ atthe matto hoti. Palaṃ ummāna+massa palamattaṃ.🔽Hattho paṇāma+massa hatthamattaṃ. Sataṃ māna+massa satamattaṃ. Doṇo parimāṇa+massa
analyzed: paṭhama antā māna vuttitaḥ assa iti asmin atthe mattaḥ hoti palam ummānam assa pala mattam  hatthaḥ paṇāmam assa hattha mattam satam mānam assa sata mattam doṇaḥ parimāṇam assa
translated: The measure of the stars, etc., is not reckoned by the number of their parts.🔽The measure of the stars, etc., is not reckoned by the number of their parts. The stars are born in the sky, therefore the sky is star-filled. Flowers are born in a tree, therefore the tree is flower-filled. Creepers are born in a forest, therefore the forest is creeper-filled.

original: doṇamattaṃ. Abhedopacārā doṇotipi hoti. Mīyate+nenāti mānaṃ, mānassa sambandhittā
analyzed: abheda upacārāḥ hoti mīyate enā iti mānam mānassa sambandhi ttā
translated: The measure of the stars, etc., is not reckoned by the number of their parts. The stars are born in the sky, therefore the sky is star-filled. Flowers are born in a tree, therefore the tree is flower-filled. Creepers are born in a forest, therefore the forest is creeper-filled.🔽The measure of the stars, etc., is not reckoned by the number of their parts. The stars are born in the sky, therefore the sky is star-filled. Flowers are born in a tree, therefore the tree is flower-filled. Creepers are born in a forest, therefore the forest is creeper-filled.🔽The measure of the stars, etc., is not reckoned by the number of their parts. The stars are born in the sky, therefore the sky is star-filled. Flowers are born in a tree, therefore the tree is flower-filled.
