The stars are born in the sky, therefore the sky is star-filled. Flowers are born in a tree, therefore the tree is flower-filled. Creepers are born in a forest, therefore the forest is creeper-filled.

original: chaṭṭhyantabhūtānameva vidhi hoti. Ettha ca –🔽Uddhamānantu ummānaṃ, parimāṇantu sabbato;🔽Pamāṇaṃ hoti āyāmo, saṃkhyāseso tu sabbato.🔽47. Taggho cu+ddhaṃ
analyzed: chaṭṭhī anta bhūtānam eva ettha ca 🔽uddha mānantu ummānam parimāṇantu sabbatas 🔽pamāṇam hoti āyāmaḥ saṃkhyā sesaḥ tu sabbatas 🔽taggha u cuddham
translated: The measure of the stars, etc., is not reckoned by the number of their parts. The stars are born in the sky, therefore the sky

original: Uddhamānavuttito taggho hoti matto ca. Jaṇṇu parimāṇa+massa jaṇṇutagghaṃ, jaṇṇumattaṃ.
analyzed: uddha māna vuttitaḥ tagghaḥ hoti mattaḥ ca jaṇṇu parimāṇam assa jaṇṇu taggham jaṇṇu mattam
translated: The word taggha is used in the sense of “above” and “drunk”. The word jaṇṇutaggha is used in the sense of “the length of a knee”. Jaṇṇumattaṃ = “the length of a knee”.

original: 48. Ṇo ca purisāti
analyzed: ṇaḥ ca purisa ati
translated: . Ṇo ca purisāti

original: Purisā ṇo hoti mattādayo ca. Puriso parimāṇa+massa porisaṃ, purisamattaṃ+purisatagghaṃ.
analyzed: purisāḥ ṇo hoti matta ādayaḥ ca purisaḥ parimāṇam assa porisam purisa mattam purisa taggham
translated: The word ṇo is used in the sense of “man” and the words mattā, etc. The word porisaṃ is used in the sense of “the length of a man”. Purisamattaṃ = “the length of a man”. Purisatagghaṃ = “the length of a man”.

original: 49. Ayu+bhadvitīhaṃ+se
analyzed: ayubha dvitīya haṃse
translated: . Ayu+bhadvitīhaṃ+se

original: Ubhadvitīhi avayavavuttīhi ayo hoti. Ubho aṃsā assa ubhayaṃ, dvayaṃ, tayaṃ. Aṃsasambandhena🔽samudāye vidhi hotīti na ubhayādito bahuvacananti ce, “rāhuno siro” tyādo abhedepi
analyzed: ubha dvitīhi avayava vuttīhi ayaḥ hoti ubho aṃsā assa ubhayam dvayam tayam aṃsa sambandhena  samudāye na ubhaya ādeḥ abhede pi
translated: The word aya is used with the words ubha, dvaya, taya, which are used in the sense of “part”. Ubhayaṃ = “both”. Sambandhaṃ = “the connection”.

original: bhedavivakkhāya labbhamānato bahuvacanaṃ hoteva.
analyzed: bheda vivakkhāya labbhamānataḥ bahuvacanam hotā iva
translated: If it is argued that the rule applies to a collection, and therefore the plural is not used after ubhaya, etc., then it may be said that in such expressions as “Rāhuno siro” the plural is used in order to distinguish the two things, although there is no difference in the words.

original: 50. Saṅkhyāya saccu+tī+sā+sa+dasantāyā+dhikā+smiṃ satasahasse ḍo
analyzed: saṅkhyāya sat cuti isa asat asantāya adhikā asmin sata sahasse ḍaḥ
translated: . Saṅkhyāya saccu+tī+sā+sa+dasantāyā+dhikā+smiṃ satasahasse ḍo

original: Satyantāya utyantāya īsantāya āsantāya dasantāya saṅkhyāya paṭhamantāya asminti sattamyatthe
analyzed: sati antāya uti antāya īsantāya āsantāya dasantāya saṅkhyāya paṭhama antāya asmin ti sattamī atthe
translated: The word ḍo is used in the sense of “number” and in the sense of “truth”, “end”, “beginning”, “existence”, “ten”, and “more” in the locative case.

original: ḍo hoti, sā ce saṅkhyā adhikā hoti, ya+dasminti, taṃ ce sataṃ sahassaṃ satasahassaṃ
analyzed: ḍaḥ hoti sā ce saṅkhyā adhikā hoti yat asmin ti tam ce satam sahassam sata sahassam
translated: If that number is more than one hundred thousand, then the word ḍo is used in the locative case. Sataṃ sahassaṃ = “a hundred thousand”.

original: vā hoti. Vīsati adhikā asmiṃ sateti vīsaṃsataṃ.
analyzed: vā hoti vīsati adhikāḥ asmin sata iti
translated: and so on. Twenty more than this hundred is two hundred.

original: 139. Ḍe satissa tissati
analyzed: ḍe sati ssati
translated: The thirty of sat is tissati.

original: Ḍe pare satyantassa tikārassa lopo hoti. Ekavīsaṃsataṃ sahassaṃ satasahassaṃ vā.🔽Tiṃsati adhikā asmiṃ satādiketi tiṃsasataṃ ekatiṃsasataṃ iccādi. Utyantāyanavuti
analyzed: ḍe pare sati antassa tikārassa lopaḥ hoti ekavīsaṃsatam sahassam sata sahassam vā  tiṃsati adhikā asmin sata ādikā iti tiṃsa satam eka tiṃsa satam iti ca ādi uti anta ayana vuti
translated: The thirty of sat becomes tissati. Twenty-one hundred is ekavīsaṃsataṃ, or twenty-one thousand is ekavīsaṃsataṃ.

original: adhikā asmiṃ satādiketi navutaṃsataṃ sahassaṃ satasahassaṃ vā. Īsantāya-cattālīsaṃ
analyzed: adhikā asmin sata ādikā iti navutaṃsatam sahassam sata sahassam vā
translated: Thirty more than this hundred and so on is tiṃsasataṃ, ekatiṃsasataṃ, and so on. Ninety more than this hundred and so on is navutaṃsataṃ, or ninety thousand is navutaṃsataṃ.

original: adhikā asmiṃ sate sahasse satasahasseti cattālīsasata+miccādi. Āsantāya evaṃ, paññāsaṃsata+miccādi.
analyzed: adhikā asmim sate sahasse sata sahassā iti cattālīsa satam iccādi āsantāya evam paññāsaṃsatam iccādi
translated: Forty more than this hundred, thousand, or hundred thousand is cattālīsasataṃ, and so on. Fifty more than this hundred, thousand, or hundred thousand is paññāsaṃsataṃ, and so on.

original: Dasantāya-ekādasaṃsata+miccādi.🔽51. Tassa pūraṇe+kādasādito vā
analyzed: dasantāya ekādasam satam iti ādi  tassa pūraṇa ikādasa āditaḥ vā
translated: Eleven more than this hundred, thousand, or hundred thousand is ekādasaṃsataṃ, and so on.🔽In the filling of that, the number ending in -tya has -dasā- and so on, or -to.

original: Chaṭṭhiyantāye+kādasādikāya saṃkhyāya ḍo hoti pūraṇatthe vibhāsā. Sā saṃkhyā pūriyate
analyzed: cha ṭṭhi yantāya ekādasa ādikāya saṃkhyāya ḍaḥ hoti pūraṇa atthe vibhāsā sā saṃkhyā pūriyate
translated: The vibhasa is that the number ending in -dasā- and so on has -do in the sense of filling. That number is filled

original: yena taṃ pūraṇaṃ. Ekādasannaṃ pūraṇo ekādaso. Aññatra “ma pañcādikatīhī”ti mo, ekādasamo.
analyzed: yena tam pūraṇam pūraṇaḥ ekādasaḥ aññatra ma ekādasamaḥ
translated: by that, that is the filling. The one who fills eleven is ekādaso. Elsewhere, by “ma pañcādikatīhī” it is mo, ekādasamo.

original: Vīsatiyā pūraṇo vīso vīsatimo, tiṃso, tiṃsatimo. Vāsaddassa vavatthitavibhāsattā
analyzed: vīsatiyā pūraṇaḥ vīsaḥ vīsatimaḥ tiṃsaḥ tiṃsatimaḥ vā saddassa vavatthita vibhāsa ttā
translated: The twenty-first is vīsatimo, the thirtieth is tiṃsatimo.

original: niccaṃ cattālīso paññāso.
analyzed: niccam cattālīsaḥ paññāsaḥ
translated: The forty-first is cattālīso, the fifty-first is paññāso.

original: 52. Ma pañcādikatīhiti
analyzed: ma pañca ādi kati h iti
translated: . The fifth, etc., is -kati.

original: Mapaccaye pañcamo, pañcamī. Sattamo, sattamī. Aṭṭhamo, aṭṭhamī. Katimo, katimī iccādi.
analyzed: ma paccaye pañcamaḥ pañcamī sattamaḥ sattamī aṭṭhamaḥ aṭṭhamī katimaḥ katimī iccādi
translated: The fifth is pañcamo, the fifth is pañcamī. The seventh is sattamo, the seventh is sattamī. The eighth is aṭṭhamo, the eighth is aṭṭhamī. The tenth is katimo, the tenth is katimī, etc.

original: 53. Sathādīna+mi cati
analyzed: sa tha ādī nami cati
translated: . The thirty-first, etc., is -ati.

original: Satādīnaṃ mo ca antādeso i ca. Satassa pūraṇo satimo, sahassimo.
analyzed: sata ādīnam maḥ ca anta ādesaḥ i ca satassa pūraṇaḥ satimaḥ sahassimaḥ
translated: The thirty-first is tiṃsatimo, the thousandth is sahassimo.

original: 54. Chā ṭṭha+ṭṭhamāti🔽Chasaddā pūraṇatthe ṭṭha+ṭṭhamā. Channaṃ pūraṇo chaṭṭho, chaṭṭhamo. Itthiyaṃ chaṭṭhī,🔽chaṭṭhamī. “Catutthadutiyesve+saṃ tatiyapaṭhamā”ti nipātanā pūraṇatthe dvito tiyo
analyzed: chā ṭṭha ṭṭhamā ati  cha saddā pūraṇa atthe ṭṭha ṭṭhamā channam pūraṇaḥ chaṭṭhaḥ chaṭṭhamaḥ itthiyam chaṭṭhī  cha ṭṭhamī catuttha dutiyesu esam tatiya paṭhama ati nipātanā pūraṇa atthe dvitaḥ tiyaḥ
translated: . The sixth, etc., is -ṭṭha+ṭṭhamā.🔽The sixth is chaṭṭho, the sixth is chaṭṭhamā. In the feminine: the sixth is chaṭṭhī,🔽the sixth is chaṭṭhamī. “In the fourth and second, the third and first” (is added). In the sense of “full,” the second is dvito, the third is titho,

original: dvissa du ca, ticatūhi tissa a, tiya+tthā ca yathākkamaṃ, dutiyo tatiyo, catuttho.🔽55. Ekā kā+kya+sahāye
analyzed: dvissa du ca ti catūhi tissa a ca yathākkamam dutiyaḥ tatiyaḥ catutthaḥ 🔽ekā kākya sahāye
translated: the second is du, the third is ti, the fourth is catu, the third and fourth are tissa and catussa, the second and third are dvīhi and tīhi, the second and fourth are dvīhi and catūhi, the second and third are dvīhi and ticatūhi, the second and third are dvīhi and ticatūhi, the second and third are dvīhi and ticatūhi, the second and third are dvīhi and ticatūhi, the second and third are dvīhi and ticatūhi, the second and third are dvīhi and ticatūhi, the second and third are dvīhi and ticatūhi, the second and third are dvīhi and ticatūhi, the second and third are dvīhi and ticatūhi, the second and third are dvīhi and ticatūhi, the second and third are dvīhi and ticatūhi, the second and third are dvīhi and ticatūhi, the second and third are dvīhi and ticatūhi, the second and third are dvīhi and ticatūhi, the second and third are dvīhi and ticatūhi, the second and third are dvīhi and ticat

original: “Sati byabhicāre visesanaṃ sātthakaṃ”ti ñāyā saṃkhyāto visesetuṃ “asahāye”ti vuttaṃ. Ekasmā asahāyatthe ka+ākī honti vā. Ekova ekako, ekākī, eko vā.
analyzed: sati byabhicāre visesanam sātthakam ti ñāyā saṃkhyātaḥ visesetum asahāya iti vuttam ekasmai asahāya tthe kaākī honti vā ekaḥ uva ekakaḥ ekākī ekaḥ vā
translated: “When there is a distinction, a distinction is useful,” so, in order to distinguish, “without a companion” is said. In the sense of “without a companion” ka+ākī is. One alone is ekako, ekākī, eko.

original: 56. Vacchādīhi tanutte taro
analyzed: vacchādīhi tanutte taro
translated: . Taro is made by vacchā, etc.

original: Vacchādīnaṃ sabhāvassa tanutte=kiñcimattāvasese taro hoti. So=sako bhāvo sabhāvo🔽attaniyapavattinimittaṃ. Susuttassa tanutte vacchataro, itthiyaṃ vacchatarī. Yobbanassa
analyzed: vaccha ādīnam sabhāvassa tanu tte kiñcimatta avasese taraḥ hoti sosakaḥ bhāvaḥ sabhāvaḥ  attaniya pavatti nimittam susuttassa tanutte vacchataraḥ itthiyam vacchatarī yobbanassa
translated: Taro is made by the nature of vacchā, etc. = by a little remainder. That = the state of being alone, the nature

original: tanutte okkhataro. Okkhā=dutiyavayaṭṭhagoṇo. Assabhāvassa tanutte assataro. Gāvoti
analyzed: tanutte okkhataro assa bhāvassa tanutte assataro gāvaḥ iti
translated: of one’s own going-forth. In the state of being a good sleeper, vacchatarī. In the state of being a young woman, okkhataro. Okkhā = a bull of the second age. In the state of being a horse, assataro. In the state of being a cow, usabhataro.

original: jātisāmatthiyassa tanutte usabhataro. Ettha tanuttaṃ appabalatā.🔽57. Kimhā niddhāraṇe ratara+ratamā
analyzed: jāti sāmatthiyassa tanutte usabhataraḥ ettha tanuttam appabala tā  kimhā niddhāraṇe ratararatamā
translated: Here, tanutta = weakness.🔽. Ratara+ratamā in kimhā, the definition

original: Kiṃsaddā niddhāraṇe ratara+ratamā honti. Ko evāti kataro bhavataṃ devadatto, kataro
analyzed: niddhāraṇe honti kaḥ eva ati kataraḥ
translated: Ratara+ratamā are in kimhā, the definition. Who is this? Which of you is Devadatta? Which is

original: bhavataṃ kaṭṭho. Katamo bhavataṃ devadatto, katamo bhavataṃ kaṭṭho. Bhāradvājānaṃ katamo+si brahme.
analyzed: bhavatam kaṭṭho katamaḥ bhavatam devadatto katamaḥ bhavatam kaṭṭhaḥ bhāradvājānam katamaḥ asi brahme
translated: What is Devadatta to you? What is Kaṭṭha to you? To the Bhāradvājas who are you, O Brahman?

original: 58. Tena datte li+yāti🔽Datte+bhidheyye la+iyā honti bahulādhikārā manussasaññāyaṃ. Devena datto devalo deviyo,
analyzed: tena datte  datta ibhidheyye laiyāḥ honti bahula adhikārāḥ manussa saññā ayam devena dattaḥ devalaḥ deviyaḥ
translated: . When given by him, it becomes

original: brahmalo brahmiyo. Sīvalo sīviyo sissa dīgho. Deva+brahma+sivāti tannāmakā manussā.
analyzed: brahmalaḥ brahmiyaḥ sīvalaḥ sīviyaḥ sissa dīghaḥ devabrahmasivā ati tad nāmakāḥ manussā
translated: When the meaning is ‘man’, the forms ending in -lo, -liyo, -lo, -liyo are formed from the words deva, brahma, sīva, sissa, dīgha, when given by a god, a brahman, a physician, a pupil, a long (person). (The words) deva, brahma, sīva are the names of men.

original: (Rattamiccādianekatthataddhitaṃ).
analyzed: rattam it ca ādi aneka attha taddhitam
translated: (The forms ending in -tā, etc. are formed from the words meaning ‘red’, etc. in the same way).

original: 59. Tassa bhāvakammesutta+tā+ttana+ṇya+ṇeyya+ṇi+ya+ṇiyā
analyzed: tassa bhāva kamma sutta tātta naṇya ṇeyya ṇiya ṇiyā
translated: . Its state, action, suffix, itself, other, to be done, instrument, and manner

original: Chaṭṭhiyantā bhāve kamme ca ttādayo honti bahulaṃ. Na sabbe paccayā sabbato honti aññatratta+tāhi. Bhavanti etasmā buddhisaddāti bhāvo saddapavattinimittaṃ. Vuttañca –
analyzed: chaṭṭhi yantāḥ bhāve kamme ca tta ādayaḥ honti bahulam na sabbe paccayā sabbatas honti aññatra tta tāhi bhavanti etasmai buddhi saddā ti bhāvaḥ sadda pavatti nimittam vuttam ca
translated: The forms ending in -tā, etc. are formed from the words meaning ‘state’ and ‘action’ in the locative case. Not all conditions are formed from all (words). The forms ending in -tā, -tā are exceptions. The state is the cause of the occurrence of the word. It is said:

original: Hontya+smā saddabuddhīti, bhāvo taṃ saddavuttiyā;
analyzed: honti asmai tam sadda vuttiyā
translated: The forms ending in -tā, -tā are the state, which is the cause of the occurrence of the word.

original: Nimittabhūtaṃ nāmañca, jāti dabbaṃ kriyā guṇoti.
analyzed: nimitta bhūtam nāman ca jāti dabbam kriyā
translated: The name, which is the cause, and the class, the root, the action, the quality.

original: Nīlassa paṭassa bhāvo nīlattaṃ nīlatāti guṇo bhāvo. Ettha nīlaguṇavasena paṭe nīlasaddassa🔽vuttiyā paṭabuddhiyā nimittaṃ bhāvo nāma. Nīlassa guṇassa bhāvo nīlattaṃ nīlatāti
analyzed: nīlassa paṭassa bhāvaḥ nīlattam nīla tā ati guṇaḥ bhāvaḥ ettha nīla guṇa vasena paṭe nīla saddassa  vuttiyā paṭa buddhiyā nimittam bhāvaḥ nāma nīlassa guṇassa bhāvaḥ nīlattam nīla tā ati
translated: The state of being blue of the cloth is blueness, the quality, the state. Herein, the state is the cause of the cloth being understood as blue by the word “blue”

original: nīlaguṇajāti, ettha nīlaguṇajāti nimittaṃ hutvā nīlasaddassa guṇavuttiyā nīlaguṇajāti
analyzed: nīla guṇa jāti ettha nīla guṇa jāti nimittam hutvā nīla saddassa guṇa vuttiyā nīla guṇa jāti
translated: because of the quality of blueness. The blueness of the quality of blueness is the state of the quality of blueness, the quality of blueness. Herein, the quality of blueness is the cause of the word “blue” being used in the sense of quality by being the cause of the word “blue.”

original: nimittaṃ. Gottaṃ gotāti gojāti, ettha jātisaddānaṃ dabbavuttiyā sati jāti nimittaṃ.
analyzed: nimittam gottam gotāti go jāti ettha jāti saddānam dabba vuttiyā sati jāti nimittam
translated: The state of being of the clan is the clan, the clan-nature. Herein, the clan-nature is the cause of the word “clan” being used in the sense of clan.

original: Pācakassa bhāvo pācakattaṃti kriyāsambandhittaṃ bhāvo, ettha pacanakriyāsambandhittaṃ
analyzed: pācakassa bhāvaḥ pācaka ttam ti kriyā sambandhi ttam bhāvaḥ ettha pacana kriyā sambandhi ttam
translated: The state of being of the cooking is cookableness. Herein, the state of being is the connection with the action of cooking.

original: bhāvo. Daṇḍittaṃ visāṇittaṃ rājapurisattaṃti daṇḍa+visāṇa+rājadabbānaṃ sambandhittaṃ
analyzed: bhāvaḥ daṇḍittam visāṇittam rāja purisattam ti daṇḍa visāṇa rāja dabbānam sambandhittam
translated: The state of being of the stick, the state of being of the horn, the state of being of the king’s servant is the connection with the stick, the horn, the king’s court.

original: bhāvo, daṇḍītyādisaddapavattiyā nimittattā.
analyzed: bhāvaḥ daṇḍī ityādi sadda pavattiyā nimitta ttā
translated: Herein, the state of being is the cause of the words “stick-holder,” etc., being used.

original: Devadattassa bhāvo devadattattaṃ, candattaṃ, sūriyattaṃti tadavatthā visesasāmaññaṃ,
analyzed: devadattassa bhāvaḥ devadattattam candattam sūriyattam ti tad avatthā visesa sāmaññam
translated: The state of being of Devadatta is Devadatta-ness, moon-ness, sun-ness. Herein, the state of being is the common characteristic of those individual essences.

original: devadattassa bālatādiavatthābhedo, candassa kalādiavatthabhedo ca, sūriyassa mandapaṭutādiavatthābhedo
analyzed: devadattassa bāla tā ādi avattha abhedo candassa kalā ādi avattha bhedo ca sūriyassa manda paṭu tā ādi avattha abhedo
translated: The difference in the state of Devadatta’s foolishness, etc., and the difference in the state of the moon’s crescent, etc., and the difference in the state of the sun’s mildness, sharpness, etc.,

original: ca sāmaññaṃ, tadettha nimittaṃ. Ettha vijjamānapadatthānaṃ visayabhūtasaññāsaddānaṃ
analyzed: ca sāmaññam tat ettha nimittam ettha vijjamāna pada tthānam visaya bhūta saññā saddānam
translated: are the commonality. That is the reason here. The reason for the occurrence of the terms and ideas that have the existent meaning as their domain

original: pavattinimittaṃ vuttaṃ. Ākāsattaṃ abhāvattaṃti, tattha ghaṭākāsa+pīṭharākāsa, paṭābhāva+ghaṭābhāvādinā
analyzed: pavatti nimittam vuttam ākāsattam ti tattha paṭa abhāva ghaṭa abhāva ādinā
translated: is said here. The state of space, the state of non-existence, there the state of space in a pot, the state of space in a chair, the non-existence of a cloth, the non-existence of a pot, etc.,

original: upacaritabhedasāmaññaṃ bhāvo.
analyzed: upacarita bheda sāmaññam bhāvaḥ
translated: are the commonality of the difference of the figurative distinction.

original: Ttana-puthujjanattanaṃ. Vedanāya bhāvo vedanattanaṃ, rasso. Evaṃ jāyattanaṃ, jārattanaṃ.
analyzed: ttana puthujjanattanam vedanāya bhāvaḥ vedanattanam rassaḥ evam jāyattanam jārattanam
translated: The state of oneself, the state of an ordinary person. The state of feeling is the state of feeling, a pleasant feeling. Thus the state of birth, the state of aging.

original: Ṇya-alasassa bhāvo kammaṃ vā ālasyaṃ, ettha “lopo+vaṇṇi+vaṇṇānaṃ”ti a-lope “sarāna+mādissā”dinā
analyzed: bhāvaḥ kammam vā ālasyam ettha a lope
translated: The state of laziness, or laziness, is the action of laziness. Here, by the “omission of a and the vowels i and u” and by “the addition of a to the final of sarana, etc.,”

original: ākāro, eva+mupari ca. Brāhmaṇassa bhāvo brahmaññaṃ, ññakārapubbarūpāni. Cāpalyaṃ,
analyzed: ākāraḥ evam upari ca brāhmaṇassa bhāvaḥ cāpalyam
translated: the form is like that above. The state of a brahmin is brahminhood, the forms with the suffix -ñña. Fickleness,

original: nepuññaṃ, pesuññaṃ, rañño bhāvo rajjaṃ, ādhipaccaṃ, dāyajjaṃ, vesammaṃ, vesamaṃ,
analyzed: nepuññam pesuññam raññaḥ bhāvaḥ rajjam ādhipaccam dāyajjam vesammam vesamam
translated: slander, talebearing, the state of a king is kingship, sovereignty, inheritance, adultery, adultery,

original: ṇapaccayo. Sakhino bhāvo sakhyaṃ, vāṇijjaṃ, ārogyaṃ, odagyaṃ, ānaṇyaṃ, dubbalyaṃ,
analyzed: ṇa paccayaḥ sakhinaḥ bhāvaḥ sakhyam vāṇijjam ārogyam odagyam ānaṇyam dubbalyam
translated: The state of being a friend is friendship, the state of being a merchant is trade, the state of being healthy is health, the state of being upright is uprightness, the state of being free from debt is freedom from debt, the state of being weak is weakness,

original: balyaṃ, paṇḍiccaṃ, bāhussaccaṃ, porohiccaṃ. Muṭṭhassatissa bhāvo muṭṭhassaccaṃ, ilopo.
analyzed: balyam paṇḍiccam bāhussaccam porohiccam muṭṭha ssatissa bhāvaḥ muṭṭhassaccam i lopaḥ
translated: the state of being strong is strength, the state of being wise is wisdom, the state of being learned is learning, the state of being a priest is priesthood. The state of being absent-minded is absent-mindedness, the state of being a fool is foolishness.

original: Kosallaṃ, vepullaṃ. Samānassa bhāvo sāmaññaṃ, perissaṃ, somanassaṃ, domanassaṃ, sovacassaṃ,🔽dovacassaṃ, nipakassa bhāvo nepakkaṃ, ādhikkaṃ, dubhagassa bhāvo dobhaggaṃ, sarūpassa
analyzed: kosallam vepullam samānassa bhāvaḥ sāmaññam perissam somanassam domanassam sovacassam  dovacassam nipakassa bhāvaḥ nepakkam ādhikkam dubhagassa bhāvaḥ dobhaggam sarūpassa
translated: The state of being a Kosalan is a Kosalan, the state of being extensive is extent. The state of being the same is sameness, the state of being a friend is friendship, the state of being joyful is joyfulness, the state of being sorrowful is sorrowfulness, the state of being easy to correct is easiness to correct,🔽the state of being crafty is craftiness, the state of being superior is superiority, the state of being poor is poverty, the state of being similar is similarity,

original: bhāvo sāruppaṃ, opammaṃ, sokhummaṃ, tathassa bhāvo tacchaṃ. Dummedhassa bhāvo dummejjhaṃ.
analyzed: bhāvaḥ sāruppam opammam sokhummam tathassa bhāvaḥ taccham dummedhassa bhāvaḥ dummejjham
translated: the state of being a simile is a simile, the state of being subtle is subtlety, the state of being such is suchness. The state of being stupid is stupidity.

original: Bhesajassa bhāvo bhesajjaṃ, byāvaṭassa kammaṃ veyyāvaccaṃ yathā veyyākaraṇaṃ.
analyzed: bhesajassa bhāvaḥ bhesajjam byāvaṭassa kammam veyyāvaccam yathā veyyākaraṇam
translated: The state of being a medicine is medicine, the state of being a servant is service, the state of being a reply is a reply.

original: Ṇeyya-sucino bhāvo soceyyaṃ, ādhipateyyaṃ, kapissa bhāvo kāpeyyaṃ. Saṭhassa bhāvo kammaṃ vā sāṭheyyaṃ.
analyzed: ṇeyyasucinaḥ bhāvaḥ soceyyam ādhipateyyam kapissa bhāvaḥ kāpeyyam saṭhassa bhāvaḥ kammam vā sāṭheyyam
translated: The state of being one who should be purified is purity, the state of being a lord is lordship, the state of being a garment is a garment. The state of being deceitful is deceitfulness, or the state of being a deed of a deceiver is deceitfulness.

original: Ṇa-garūnaṃ bhāvo gāravaṃ, u avaṅa. Pāṭavaṃ, ajjavaṃ, maddavaṃ, “kosajjā”dinā ussa attaṃ dvittañca. Paramānaṃ bhāvo pāramī, vīpaccayo. Samaggānaṃ bhāvo sāmaggī.🔽Iya-adhipatino bhāvo adhipatiyaṃ, paṇḍitiyaṃ, bahussutiyaṃ, naggiyaṃ, sūriyaṃ.🔽Ṇiya-alasassa bhāvo kammaṃ vā ālasiyaṃ, tālusiyaṃ, mandiyaṃ, dakkhiyaṃ, porohitiyaṃ, veyyattiyaṃ.🔽Kathaṃ rāmaṇīyakaṃti, sakatthe kantā ṇena siddhā. Kammaṃ=kriyā, tattha alasassa kammaṃ alasattaṃ alasatā alasattanaṃ ālasyaṃ ālasiyaṃ vā.
analyzed: bhāvaḥ gāravam pāṭavam ajjavam maddavam kosajja ādinā attam paramānam bhāvaḥ pāramī samaggānam bhāvaḥ sāmaggī  iyaadhipatinaḥ bhāvaḥ adhipatiyam paṇḍitiyam bahussutiyam naggiyam sūriyam  bhāvaḥ kammam vā ālasiyam tālusiyam mandiyam dakkhiyam porohitiyam veyyattiyam  katham sa katthe kantā ṇena siddhā kammaṃkriyā tattha alasassa kammam alasattam alasa tā alasattanam ālasyam ālasiyam vā
translated: The state of being heavy is heaviness; the state of being low is lowness; firmness is firmness; straightforwardness is straightforwardness; gentleness is gentleness; the state of being lazy is laziness; the state of being two is duality. The state of being supreme is supremacy; the state of being a condition is conditionality. The state of being united is unity.🔽The state of being a lord is lordship; the state of being wise is wisdom; the state of being learned is learning; the state of being a monk is monkhood; the state of being a sun is sunhood.🔽The state of being lazy is laziness; the state of being slow is slowness; the state of being dull is dullness; the state of being bright is brightness; the state of being small is smallness; the state of being great is greatness.🔽How is it that ramaṇīyakaṃ is formed by adding ṇ to the noun ramaṇīya? Kammaṃ = kriyā, there the state of being lazy is laziness or laziness.

original: 122. Sakattheti🔽Sakatthepi yathāyogaṃ ttādayo honti. Yathābhūtameva yathābhuccaṃ, kāruññaṃ, pattakallaṃ.🔽Ākāsānantameva ākāsānañcaṃ, ettha akāralopo, tassa ce pubbarūpe ca kate “tadaminā”dinā
analyzed: sakatthā iti 🔽saka tthe pi yathāyogam tta ādayaḥ honti yathābhūtam eva yathābhuccam kāruññam pattakallam 🔽ākāsa anantam eva ākāsa anañcam ettha akāra lopaḥ tassa ce pubbarūpe ca kate
translated: The state of being heavy is heaviness; the state of being low is lowness. Firmness is firmness; straightforwardness is straightforwardness; softness is softness. The state of being lazy, etc., is laziness, etc. The state of being high is height. The state of being far is farness. The state of being near is nearness. The state of being long is length. The state of being short is shortness. The state of being round is roundness. The state of being square is squarishness. The state of being great is greatness. The state of being small is smallness. The state of being good is goodness. The state of being bad is badness. The state of being good is goodness. The state of being bad is badness. The state of being good is goodness. original: nassa ñño ca lopo ca hoti, kāyapāguññatā.
analyzed: nassa ññaḥ ca lopaḥ ca hoti kāya pāguñña tā
translated: and nassa, ñño, and lopo, and kāyapāguññatā.

original: 60. Bya vaddhadāsā vā
analyzed: bya vaddhadāsā vā
translated: . Bya vaddhadāsā vā

original: Chaṭṭhiyantā vaddhā dāsā ca byo hoti bhāvakammesu. Vaddhassa bhāvo kammaṃ vā vaddhabyaṃ, vaddhatā. Dāsassa bhāvo kammaṃ vā dāsabyaṃ, dāsyaṃ, dāsatā. Kathaṃ vaddhavaṃti, ṇe vāgamo.
analyzed: vaddhāḥ dāsā ca byaḥ hoti bhāva kammesu vaddhassa bhāvaḥ kammam vā vaddhabyam vaddha tā dāsassa bhāvaḥ kammam vā dāsabyam dāsyam dāsa tā katham vaddhavanti ne vā āgamaḥ
translated: In the sense of “state” and “action,” vaddhā and dāsā take byo in the sixth case. The state of being vaddhā is vaddhabya, or vaddhatā. The state of being dāsā is dāsabya, dāsya, or dāsatā. How is vaddhabya formed? The suffix ṇe is added.

original: 61. Nasa yuvā bo ca vassa
analyzed: nasa yuvā baḥ ca vassa
translated: . Nasa yuvā bo ca vassa

original: Chaṭṭhiyantā yuvasaddā bhāvakammesu naṇa vā hoti vassa bo ca. Yuvassa bhāvo yobbanaṃ, yuvattaṃ yuvatā vā.
analyzed: chaṭṭhi yantāḥ yuva saddāḥ bhāva kammesu vā hoti vassa bo ca yuvassa bhāvaḥ yobbanam yuvattam yuvatā vā
translated: In the sense of “state” and “action,” the word yuva takes naṇa, vā, and bo in the sixth case. The state of being yuva is yobbana, yuvatta, or yuvatā.

original: 62. Aṇvāditvi+moti
analyzed: aṇu ādi tvimaḥ iti
translated: . Aṇvāditvi+moti

original: Bhāve vā imo. Aṇuno bhāvo aṇimā, laghimā, mahato bhāvo mahimā. Kisassa bhāvo kasimā.🔽133. Kisa+mahata+mime kasa, mahāti
analyzed: bhāve vā imaḥ aṇunaḥ bhāvaḥ aṇimā laghimā mahataḥ bhāvaḥ mahimā kisassa bhāvaḥ kasimā  kisamahatam ime
translated: In the sense of “state,” the suffix i is added. The state of being aṇu is aṇimā. The state of being laghu is laghimā. The state of being mahat is mahimā. The state of being kisa is kasimā.🔽. Kisa+mahata+mime kasa, mahāti

original: Imamhi mahato maho ca kisassa kasādeso ca hoti.
analyzed: imamhi mahataḥ mahaḥ ca kisassa kasa ādesaḥ ca hoti
translated: In the sense of “state,” the suffix i is added. The state of being mahat is maho. The state of being kisa is kasa.

original: 63. Bhāvā tena nibbatteti
analyzed: bhāvā tena nibbattā iti
translated: . Bhāvā tena nibbatteti

original: Kriyāvācakasaddato imo, pākena nibbattaṃ pākimaṃ, sekimaṃ.
analyzed: kriyā vācaka saddataḥ imaḥ pākena nibbattam pākimam sekimam
translated: In the sense of “state,” the suffix i is added. What is produced by pāka is pākima. What is produced by seka is sekima.

original: 127. Kosajjā+jjava+pārisajja+sohajja+maddavā+rissā+sabhā+jañña+theyya+ bāhusaccā🔽Ete saddā nipaccante ṇānubandhe. Kusītassa bhāvoti bhāve ṇyo hoti, iminā īssa akāre🔽ca tassa je ca kate yassa pubbarūpaṃ, kosajjaṃ. Ujuno bhāve ajjavaṃti ṇo, iminā ussa🔽attaṃ, “uvaṇṇassā+vaṅa sare”ti avaṅaādese jassa dvittaṃ. Parisāsu sādhūti vākye “ṇyo🔽tattha sādhū”ti ṇyo, iminā jāgamo ca, “byañjane dīgharassā”ti āssa rasse ca kate🔽jassa pubbarūpaṃ, pārisajjo. Iminā kamena vākyeneva saddasiddhi veditabbā. Suhadayova
analyzed: kosajja ājjava pārisajja sohajja maddava arissā sabhā ajaññatheyya bāhusaccā  ete saddāḥ nipaccante ṇa anubandhe kusītassa bhāvaḥ iti bhāve ṇyaḥ hoti iminā īssa akāre  ca tassa je ca kate yassa pubbarūpam kosajjam ujunaḥ bhāve ajjavanti no iminā  attam sara iti avaṅa ādese jassa dvittam parisāsu sādhu iti vākye ṇyaḥ  tattha sādhu iti ṇyaḥ iminā jāgamaḥ ca byañjane dīgha rassā ati āssa rasse ca kate  iminā kamena vākyena iva veditabbā su ha dayā uva
translated: 127. Sloth, straightforwardness, being good in an assembly, being good-natured, gentleness, being a hermit, a gathering, being known, being concealed, being learned.🔽These words are declined in the same way as the words in §126. The state of a sloth is slothfulness, the state of a straight one is straightforwardness, the state of one good in an assembly is being good in an assembly, the state of one good-natured is being good-natured, the state of a gentle one is gentleness, the state of a hermit is being a hermit, the state of a gathering is a gathering, the state of one known is being known, the state of one concealed is being concealed, the state of one learned is being learned.

original: 135. Jo vuddhassi+yi+ṭṭhesu
analyzed: jaḥ vuddhassiyiṭṭhesu

original: Vuddhassa jo hoti iyaiṭṭhesu. Atisayena vuddho jeyyo jeṭṭho, jādese pubbasaralope luttā sarā issa ekāre ca yassa dvittaṃ.
analyzed: vuddhassa jaḥ hoti iya eṭṭhesu atisayena vuddhaḥ jeyyaḥ jeṭṭhaḥ ja ādese pubba sara lope luttāḥ sarāḥ issaḥ ekāre ca yassa dvittam
translated: Jo is added to the above in the sense of ‘great’.

original: 136. Bāḷha+ntika+pasatthānaṃ sādha+neda+sā🔽Iyaiṭṭhesu bāḷha+ntika+pasatthānaṃ sādha+neda+sā honti yathākkamaṃ. Atisayena bāḷho

translated: Bāḷha+ntika+pasatthānaṃ sādha+neda+sā🔽Sādha, neda and sā are added to the above in the sense of ‘great’, respectively.

original: sādhiyo sādhiṭṭho. Atisayena antiko nediyo nediṭṭho. Atisayena pasattho seyyo seṭṭho,
analyzed: sādhiyaḥ sādhiṭṭhaḥ atisayena antikaḥ nediyaḥ nediṭṭhaḥ atisayena pasatthaḥ seyyaḥ seṭṭhaḥ
translated: Atisayena bāḷho = sādhiyo, sādhiṭṭho. Atisayena antiko = nediyo, nediṭṭho. Atisayena pasattho = seyyo, seṭṭho.

original: pubbeva sare lutte issa e dvittañca.
analyzed: pubbā iva sare lutte i saḥ e dvittam ca
translated: Pubbeva sare lutte issa e dvittañca.

translated: Kaṇa and kanā are added to the above in the sense of ‘small’, respectively. Atisayena appo = kaṇiyo, kaṇiṭṭho. Atisayena yuvā = kaniyo, kaniṭṭho.

analyzed: satimā satiyaḥ satiṭṭhaḥ atisayena guṇavā guṇiyaḥ guṇiṭṭhaḥ ettha yathākkamam mantu atthe

analyzed: pakatiyāḥ uttaram avatthantaram vikāro vikāra ivayave ca ṇa ādayaḥ  honti bahulam vikāraḥ āyasam bandhanam saka āgamaḥ udumbarassa avayavaḥ vikāraḥ  vā odumbaram bhasmam paṇṇam vā kāpotam maṃsam satti vā ṇika kappāsassa vikāraḥ kappāsikam
translated: are often formed from a noun in the sixth case, in the sense of ‘modification’ and ‘part’.🔽Ṇa-A modification of iron is iron, a fetter, with the addition of the prefix sakā. original: vatthaṃ. Ṇeyya-eṇissa vikāro+vayavo vā eṇeyyaṃ. Kosānaṃ vikāro koseyyaṃ vatthaṃ.
analyzed: vattham vikāra uvayavaḥ vai eṇeyyam kosānam vikāraḥ koseyyam vattham
translated: cloth. Ṇeyya-A modification or part of an antelope is an antelope. A modification of the kosambaka plant is kosambaka, cloth.

original: Maya-tiṇānaṃ vikāro tiṇamayaṃ, dārumayaṃ, naḷamayaṃ, mattikāmayaṃ, suvaṇṇamayo ratho,
analyzed: maya tiṇānam vikāraḥ tiṇa mayam dāru mayam naḷa mayam mattikā mayam suvaṇṇa mayaḥ rathaḥ
translated: Made of reeds is reed-made, made of wood is wood-made, made of rushes is rush-made, made of clay is clay-made, made of gold is gold-made, made of silver is silver-made.

original: rūpiyamayaṃ. “Aññasmiṃ”ti mayo, gunnaṃ karīsaṃ gomayaṃ.🔽67. Jatuto ssaṇa vā
analyzed: rūpiya mayam aññasmin ti mayaḥ gunnam karīsam gomayam  jatu taḥ ssaṇa vā
translated: Cow-dung is dung of cows.🔽. In the case of a modification and a part, either -ssaṇa or -vā is added.

original: Vikārāvayavesu jatuto ssaṇa vā hoti. Ettha “vikārāvayavesū”ti vattantesupi bahulādhikārā vikāreyeva hoti. Jatuno vikāro jātussaṃ jatumayaṃ.🔽123. Lopoti🔽Bahulaṃ paccayalopopi. “Phalitassa rukkhassa phala+mavayavo vikāro ca, pallavitasseva
analyzed: vikāra avayavesu vā hoti ettha vikāra avayavesu iti vattante supi bahula adhikārā hoti jatunaḥ vikāraḥ jātussam jatu mayam  lopa u ti  bahulam paccaya lopaḥ pi phalitassa rukkhassa phalam avayavaḥ vikāro ca pallavitassa iva
translated: Herein, although the words “in the case of a modification and a part” are used, it is only a modification that is added in the majority of instances. A modification of reed is reed-made.🔽. In the case of a fruit, etc.,🔽. In the majority of instances the preposition is omitted. “The fruit of a flowering tree is a modification and a part of it, and so too the shoot of a flowering tree is its shoot” .🔽Therefore fruits, etc., are both parts and modifications.

original: pallavaṃ”ti vuttattā phalādayo avayavā vikārā ca honti, tasmā idaṃ vuccati phalapupphamūlesu
analyzed: pallavanti vutta ttā phala ādayaḥ avayavāḥ vikārāḥ ca honti tasmai idam vuccati phala puppha mūlesu

analyzed: vikāra avayavesu piyālassa phalāni piyālāni mallikāya pupphāni mallikā usīrassa mūlam
translated: . In the case of a modification and a part, too, the fruits of the piyal tree are piyal fruits, the flowers of the jasmine are jasmine flowers, the root of the usīra reed is usīra root.

original: usīraṃ. Taṃsaddena vā tadabhidhānaṃ abhedopacārena, tasmā paccayalopaṃ vināpi sijjhati.

translated: Or the word “that” is used figuratively without distinction. Therefore it is established without omission of the preposition.

original: Arahatthe ṇeyyo. Dakkhiṇaṃ arahatīti dakkhiṇeyyo.
analyzed: arahatthe ṇeyyaḥ dakkhiṇam arahati iti dakkhiṇeyyaḥ
translated: Dakkhiṇāyā+raheti is a gerundive. Dakkhiṇāyā+raheti means “to be worthy of an offering.”

original: 77. Rāyo tumantāti
analyzed: rāyaḥ tumantā ati
translated: Rāyo tumantāti

original: Arahatthe tumantā rāyo vā. Ghātetuṃ arahatīti ghātetāyaṃ, “rānubandhe+ntasarādissā”ti uṃlopo. Jāpetāyaṃ, pabbājetāyaṃ. Vāti kiṃ, ghātetuṃ. (Saṃkiṇṇataddhitaṃ).
analyzed: arahatthe tumantā rāyaḥ vā ghātetum arahati iti ghāteta ayam uṃ lopaḥ jāpeta ayam pabbājeta ayam vā ati kim ghātetum saṃkiṇṇa taddhitam
translated: Rāyo tumantāti is a gerundive. Rāyo tumantāti means “to be worthy of being killed.” Ghātetuṃ arahatīti ghātetuṃ means “to be worthy of being killed.” Jāpetuṃ means “to be worthy of being made to recite.” Pabbajetuṃ means “to be worthy of being sent forth.” Vāti kiṃ means “what is it?” Ghātetuṃ means “to be worthy of being killed.” (Compound with a gerundive as the last member.)

original: 78. Ta+mettha+ssa+tthīti mantu
analyzed: tam etthassatthi iti mantu
translated: Ta+mettha+ssa+tthīti mantu

original: Paṭhamantā ettha assa atthīti etesva+tthesu mantu hoti. Gāvo ettha dese assa vā purisassa santīti gomā, gomanto iccādi guṇavantusamaṃ.
analyzed: ettha assa atthi iti etesu atthesu mantu hoti gāvaḥ ettha dese assa vā purisassa santi iti gomā gomantaḥ iccādi
translated: Ta+mettha+ssa+tthīti mantu means “if it is there, it is in these.” Gomā means “having cows.” Gomanto means “having a cow.” (The gerundive is the same as the word for a quality.)

original: Atthīti vattamānakālopādānato bhūtāhi bhavissantīhi vā gohi na gomā. Kathaṃ gomā
analyzed: atthi iti vattamāna kāla upādānataḥ bhūtāhi bhavissantīhi vā gohi na gomā katham gomā
translated: Because of the use of the present tense in atthīti, it is not gomā because of past or future cows. How is it gomā?

original: āsi, gomā bhavissatīti. Tadāpi vattamānāhiyeva gohi gomā, āsi bhavissatīti padantarā
analyzed: āsi gomā bhavissati iti tadā api go hi gomā āsi bhavissati iti padantarā
translated: Āsi, gomā bhavissatīti. Even then it is gomā because of present cows. Āsi, bhavissatīti is a different word.

original: kālantaraṃ. Itisaddato visayaniyamo. Vuttañhi –🔽Pahūte ca pasaṃsāyaṃ, nindāyañcā+tisāyane;🔽Niccayoge ca saṃsagge, honti+me mantuādayoti.
analyzed: visaya niyamaḥ  pahūte ca pasaṃsāyam nindāyan ca atisāyane  nicca yoge ca saṃsagge honti ime mantu ādayaḥ ti
translated: and at another time. The meaning is determined by the word iti. For this is said:

original: 134. Āyussā+yasa mantumhi
analyzed: āyuḥ sa āyasa mantumhi
translated: “In abundance, in praise,🔽in blame, in constant application, and in association,🔽these are mantu and so on.”

original: Mantumhi āyussa āyasādeso hoti. Āyu assa atthīti āyasmā. Go assoti jātisaddānaṃ dabbābhidhāna-
analyzed: mantumhi āyussa āya sa ādesaḥ hoti āyu assa atthi iti go assa iti jāti saddānam
translated: In āyu, in āyussa, mantu is āyasā. The meaning is: he has life, therefore he is āyasmā. Go assoti jātisaddānaṃ dabbābhidhāna-

original: sāmatthiyā mantvādayo na honti, tathā guṇasaddānaṃ seto paṭoti. Yesaṃ tu guṇasaddānaṃ
analyzed: sāmatthiyāḥ mantu ādayaḥ na honti tathā guṇa saddānam yesam tu guṇa saddānam
translated: sāmatthiyā mantvādayo na honti, tathā guṇasaddānaṃ seto paṭoti. Yesaṃ tu guṇasaddānaṃ

original: dabbābhidhānasāmatthiyaṃ natthi, tehi honteva, buddhi assa atthīti buddhimā. “Vantva+vaṇṇā”ti
analyzed: dabba abhidhāna sāmatthiyam natthi tehi hontā iva buddhi assa atthi iti buddhimā
translated: dabbābhidhānasāmatthiyaṃ natthi, tehi honteva, buddhi assa atthīti buddhimā. “Vantva+vaṇṇā”ti

original: vantumhi rūpavā rasavā gandhavā saddavā. “Daṇḍāditvi+kaī vā”ti ika+ī, rasī rasiko,
analyzed: vantumhi rūpavā rasavā gandhavā saddavā daṇḍa ādi tvikaī vāti rasī rasikaḥ
translated: vantumhi rūpavā rasavā gandhavā saddavā. “Daṇḍāditvi+kaī vā”ti ika+ī, rasī rasiko,

original: rūpī rūpiko, gandhī gandhikoti.
analyzed: rūpī rūpikaḥ gandhī gandhikā uti
translated: rūpī rūpiko, gandhī gandhikoti.

original: 79. Vantva+vaṇṇāti
analyzed: vantu avaṇṇāti
translated: . Vantva+vaṇṇāti

original: Vantu. Pasatthaṃ sīla+massa atthīti sīlavā. Pahutā pasatthā vā paññā assa atthīti paññavā.
analyzed: vantu pasattham sīlam assa atthi iti sīlavā pahutā pasatthā vā paññā assa atthi iti paññavā
translated: Vantu. Pasatthaṃ sīla+massa atthīti sīlavā. Pahutā pasatthā vā paññā assa atthīti paññavā.

original: 80. Daṇḍāditvi+ka+ī vāti
analyzed: daṇḍa āditvika ī vāti
translated: . Daṇḍāditvi+ka+ī vāti

original: Ika+ī honti vā mantatthe. Bahulaṃvidhānā kutocisaddato dve honti, kuto ce+kamekaṃva. Niccayutto daṇḍo assa atthīti daṇḍiko daṇḍī. Gandhiko gandhī. Vātveva, daṇḍavā.
analyzed: honti vā manta atthe bahulam vidhānā kutoci saddataḥ dve honti kuto ca ikam ekam iva nicca yuttaḥ daṇḍaḥ assa atthi iti daṇḍikaḥ daṇḍī gandhikaḥ gandhī vā atvā eva daṇḍavā
translated: The forms ika and ī are used in the sense of “a little”. The forms dve and eko are used from kutoci, “from somewhere”, because of the frequent use of the word kuto. The forms daṇḍiko and daṇḍī are used because of the fixed use of the word daṇḍa, “stick”, in the sense of “he has a stick”. The forms gandhiko and gandhī are used because of the fixed use of the word gandha, “smell”, in the sense of “he has a smell”. The forms daṇḍavā and vāteva are used because of the fixed use of the word daṇḍa, “stick”, in the sense of “he has a stick”.

original: “Uttamiṇeva dhanā iko”ti gaṇasuttena iko dhaniko. Añño dhanī dhanavā.
analyzed: uttamiṇā iva dhanā i kaḥ ti gaṇa suttena i kaḥ dhanikaḥ aññaḥ dhanī dhanavā
translated: The forms dhaniko and dhanī are used because of the fixed use of the word dhana, “wealth”, in the sense of “he has wealth”.

original: “Asannihite atthā” asannihito attho assa atthīti atthiko atthī. Sannihite atthavā. “Tadantā ca” puññattho assa atthīti puññatthiko puññatthī.
analyzed: asannihite atthā asannihitaḥ atthaḥ assa atthi iti atthikaḥ atthī sannihite atthavā tad antā ca puññatthaḥ assa atthi iti puññatthikaḥ puññatthī
translated: The forms atthiko and atthī are used because of the fixed use of the word attha, “meaning”, in the sense of “he has a meaning”. The forms atthavā and sannihito are used because of the fixed use of the word attha, “meaning”, in the sense of “he has a meaning”. The forms puññatthiko and puññatthī are used because of the fixed use of the word puñña, “merit”, in the sense of “he has merit”.

original: “Vaṇṇantā īyeva”. Brahmavaṇṇaṃ assa atthīti brahmavaṇṇī, devavaṇṇī.
analyzed: vaṇṇantā īya iva brahma vaṇṇam assa atthi iti brahma vaṇṇī deva vaṇṇī
translated: The forms brahmavaṇṇī and devavaṇṇī are used because of the fixed use of the word vaṇṇa, “colour”, in the sense of “he has the colour of Brahmā” or “he has the colour of a god”.

original: “Hatthadantehi jātiyaṃ”. Hattha+massa atthīti hatthī, dantī. Aññatra hatthavā dantavā.
analyzed: hattha dantehi jātiyam hattham assa atthi iti hatthī dantī aññatra hatthavā dantavā
translated: The forms hatthī and dantī are used because of the fixed use of the word hattha, “hand”, in the sense of “he has an elephant”. The forms hatthavā and dantavā are used because of the fixed use of the word hattha, “hand”, in the sense of “he has an elephant”.

original: “Vaṇṇato brahmacārimhi”. Vaṇṇo assa atthīti vaṇṇiko brahmacārī.
analyzed: vaṇṇataḥ brahmacārimhi vaṇṇaḥ assa atthi iti vaṇṇikaḥ brahmacārī
translated: The forms vaṇṇiko and vaṇṇī are used because of the fixed use of the word vaṇṇa, “colour”, in the sense of “he has a colour”.

original: “Pokkharādito dese”. Pokkharaṃ jalaṃ padumaṃ vā assa atthīti pokkharī, “yuvaṇṇehi
analyzed: pokkhara ādeḥ dese pokkharam jalam padumam vā assa atthi iti pokkharī yuvaṇṇehi
translated: The forms pokkharī and pokkharavā are used because of the fixed use of the word pokkhara, “lotus”, in the sense of “he has a lotus”. The forms pokkhar

original: nī”ti nīmhi “gharaṇyādayo”ti īssa attaṃ, nassa ṇo ca, pokkharaṇī, uppalinī, kumudinī,
analyzed: ni iti nīmhi īssa attam nassa ṇo ca pokkharaṇī uppalinī kumudinī
translated: “Nī” is in “nīgharaṇī” . “Ghāraṇyādayo” is in “īssa attaṃ, nassa ṇo ca, pokkharaṇī, uppalinī, kumudinī,

original: bhisinī, mulālinī, sālukinī.
analyzed: bhisinī mulālinī sālukinī
translated: bhisinī, mulālinī, sālukinī” .

original: “Kvacā+desepi”. Paduma+massa atthīti padumī paduminī paduminīpaṇṇaṃ. Desato+ññatra pokkharavā hatthī.
analyzed: kva ca ādese pi padumam assa atthi iti padumī paduminī paduminī paṇṇam desataḥ uññatra pokkharavā hatthī
translated: “Kvacā+desepi” . “Paduma+massa atthīti padumī paduminī paduminīpaṇṇaṃ” . “Desato+ññatra pokkharavā hatthī” .

original: “Nāvāyi+ko” nāviko. Sikhī, bālī, sīlī, balī.
analyzed: nāvāyikaḥ nāvikaḥ sikhī bālī sīlī balī
translated: “Nāvāyi+ko” is in “nāviko” . “Sikhī, bālī, sīlī, balī” .

original: “Sukhadukkhā ī”. Sukhī dukkhī. “Balā bāhūrupubbā ca”. Bāhubalī, ūrubalī.
analyzed: sukha dukkhā ī sukhī dukkhī balā bāhu ūru pubbā ca bāhu balī ūru balī
translated: “Sukhadukkhā ī” is in “sukhī dukkhī” . “Balā bāhūrupubbā ca” is in “bāhubalī, ūrubalī” .

original: 81. Tapādīhi ssīti
analyzed: tapa ādīhi ssi iti
translated: . Tapādīhi ssī

original: Ssī. Tapo assa atthīti tapassī, yasassī, tejassī, manassī, payassī. Vātveva, yasavā.
analyzed: tapaḥ assa atthi iti tapassī yasassī tejassī manassī payassī vātvā iva yasavā
translated: Ssī is in “tapo assa atthīti tapassī, yasassī, tejassī, manassī, payassī” . “Vātveva, yasavā” .

original: 82. Mukhādito roti
analyzed: mukha āt itaḥ ra o ti
translated: . Mukhādito roti

original: Ro. Ninditaṃ mukha+massa atthīti mukharo. Susi=chiddaṃ assa atthīti susiro. Ūso=khāramattikā
analyzed: ninditam mukham assa atthi iti mukharo susi chiddam assa atthi iti susiraḥ ūsokhāramattikā
translated: Ro is in “ninditaṃ mukha+massa atthīti mukharo” . “Susi=chiddaṃ assa atthīti susiro” . “Ūso=khāramattikā

original: asmiṃ atthīti ūsaro. Madhuro guḷo, madhurā sakkharā, madhuraṃ khīraṃ. Khaṃ=gīvāya
analyzed: asmin atthi iti ūsaraḥ madhuraḥ guḷaḥ madhurā sakkharā madhuram khīram
translated: asmiṃ atthīti ūsaro” . “Madhuro guḷo, madhurā sakkharā, madhuraṃ khīraṃ” . “Khaṃ=gīvāya

original: vivaraṃ assa atthīti kharo gadrabho. Kuñjo=hanu assa atthīti kuñjaro. Nagaro.
analyzed: vivaram assa atthi iti kharaḥ gadrabhaḥ kuñjohanu assa atthi iti kuñjaraḥ nagaraḥ
translated: He has a rough jaw, thus he is a rough-jawed ass. He has a jaw, thus he is a jaw-elephant. A city.

original: “Dantassa ca unnatadante”ti gaṇasuttena dantassa u ca, unnataṃ danta+massa atthīti danturo.
analyzed: dantassa ca unnata dantā iti gaṇa suttena dantassa u ca unnatam atthi iti
translated: “And of a tusk, and of a high tusk” : of a tusk and also of a high tusk, thus he is a tusker.

original: 83. Tuṭṭhyādīhi bhoti
analyzed: tuṭṭhi ādīhi bhoti
translated: With “satisfied” and so on

original: Bho vā. Tuṭṭhi assa atthīti tuṭṭhibho, sālibho, vālibho.
analyzed: bho vā tuṭṭhi assa atthi iti tuṭṭhibho sālibho vālibho
translated: He has satisfaction, thus he is satisfied, he is a rice-eater, he is a grass-eater.

original: 84. Saddhāditva
analyzed: saddha ādi tva
translated: With “faith” and so on

original: Iti vā a hoti. Atisayā saddhā assa atthīti saddho, pañño, paññavā, saddhā kaññā, saddhaṃ kulaṃ.
analyzed: iti vā a hoti atisayā saddhā assa atthi iti saddho pañño paññavā saddhā kaññā saddham kulaṃ
translated: Thus, a is added. He has faith in excess, thus he is faithful, he is wise, he is wise, he is a faithful girl, he is a faithful family.

original: 85. Ṇo tapāti
analyzed: ṇaḥ tapāti
translated: With “ascetic” and so on

original: Ṇo, tāpaso, sakāgamo. Tāpasī.
analyzed: tāpasaḥ tāpasī
translated: He is an ascetic, a derivation from sakā. He is an ascetic woman.

original: 86. Ālva+bhijjhādīhiti
analyzed: ālu abhijjha ādī h iti
translated: With “covetousness” and so on

original: Ālu vā. Abhijjhā assa atthīti abhijjhālu, sītālu, dhajālu, dayālu, dayāvā. Abhijjhālu eva abhijjhāluko.
analyzed: ālu vā abhijjhā assa atthi iti abhijjhālu sītālu dhajālu dayālu dayāvā abhijjhālu eva abhijjhālukaḥ
translated: He has covetousness, thus he is covetous, he is cold, he is bannered, he is compassionate, he is compassionate. Covetous itself is covetous.

original: 87. Picchāditvi+loti
analyzed: piccha ādi tu ilaḥ oti
translated: With “grease” and so on

original: Ilo vā. Piccha+massa atthīti picchilo, picchavā. Pheṇilo, jaṭilo, tuṇḍilo. Ninditā vācā assa atthīti vācāloti parassaralopo.🔽88. Sīlādito voti
analyzed: ilaḥ vā piccham assa atthi iti picchilaḥ picchavā pheṇilaḥ jaṭilaḥ tuṇḍilaḥ ninditā vācā assa atthi iti vācālaḥ iti parassara lopaḥ 🔽sīla āditaḥ vā u ti
translated: He has grease, thus he is greasy, he is greasy. He is frothy, he is matted, he is crooked. He has contemptible speech, thus he is a talker, the -r- of parassar- is elided.

original: Vo hoti vā. Sīlavo, sīlavā. Kesavo, kesavā.
analyzed: vaḥ hoti vā sīlavaḥ sīlavā kesavaḥ kesavā
translated: He has a tail. He is virtuous. He has hair. He has hair.

original: “Aṇṇā niccaṃ” aṇṇavo. “Gaṇḍīrājīhi saññāyaṃ” gaṇḍī=meṇḍasiṅgaṃ assa atthīti gaṇḍīvaṃ dhanu, rājīvaṃ paṅkajaṃ.
analyzed: aṇṇāḥ niccam gaṇḍī rājīhi saññāyam assa atthi iti gaṇḍīvam dhanu rājīvam paṅkajam
translated: Aṇṇavo, “Gaṇḍīrājīhi saññāyaṃ” (Gaṇḍī=meṇḍasiṅgaṃ assa atthīti gaṇḍīvaṃ dhanu, rājīvaṃ paṅkajaṃ).

original: 89. Māyā medhāhi vīti
analyzed: māyā medhāhi vīti
translated: Māyā medhāhi vīti

original: Vī. Māyāvī, medhāvī pumā. Nīmhi medhāvinī. Medhāvī kulaṃ, “ekavacanayosva+ghonaṃ”ti simhi rasso. Evaṃ māyāvī.
analyzed: māyāvī medhāvī pumān simhi medhāvī kulam evam māyāvī
translated: Vī. He is deceitful. He is wise. I am wise. He is wise. “Ekavacanayosva+ghonaṃ”ti simhi rasso. Evaṃ māyāvī.

original: 90. Si+ssare āmyu+vāmī
analyzed: sissare āmi uvāmī
translated: . Si+ssare āmyu+vāmī

original: Issare+bhidheyye sasaddā āmī+uvāmī honti mantvatthe. Saṃ=āyattaṃ assa atthīti sāmī suvāmī. Suvāminī kaññā.
analyzed: issara ibhidheyye sa saddāḥ āmī uvāmī honti mantu atthe saṃāyattam assa atthi iti sāmī suvāmī suvāminī kaññā
translated: Issare+bhidheyye sasaddā āmī+uvāmī honti mantvatthe. Saṃ=āyattaṃ assa atthīti sāmī suvāmī. Suvāminī kaññā.

original: 91. Lakkhyā ṇo a ca
analyzed: lakkhyā ṇaḥ a ca
translated: . Lakkhyā ṇo a ca

original: Lakkhīsaddā ṇo hoti mantvatthe a ca+ntassa. Lakkhī assa atthīti lakkhaṇo.
analyzed: lakkhī saddāḥ ṇa hoti mantu atthe a cantassa lakkhī assa atthi iti lakkhaṇaḥ
translated: Lakkhīsaddā ṇo hoti mantvatthe a ca+ntassa. Lakkhī assa atthīti lakkhaṇo.

original: 92. Aṅgā no kalyāṇeti
analyzed: aṅgā naḥ kalyāṇā iti
translated: . Aṅgā no kalyāṇeti

original: Aṅgasmā no hoti. Kalyāṇāni sobhaṇāni aṅgāni assā atthīti aṅganā.
analyzed: aṅgasmai naḥ hoti kalyāṇāni sobhaṇāni aṅgāni assā atthi iti aṅganā
translated: Aṅgasmā no hoti. Kalyāṇāni sobhaṇāni aṅgāni assā atthīti aṅganā.

original: 93. So lomāti
analyzed: saḥ loma ati
translated: . So lomāti

original: Lomā so, pahūtā lomā assa atthīti lomaso, lomasā kaññā.
analyzed: lomā so pahūtā lomā assa atthi iti lomasaḥ lomasā kaññā
translated: Lomā so, pahūtā lomā assa atthīti lomaso, lomasā kaññā.

original: 94. Imi+yāti
analyzed: imiyāti
translated: . Imi+yāti

original: Ima+iyā honti, putto assa atthīti puttimo, kittimo, puttiyo, kappiyo, jaṭiyo, hānabhāgiyo, seniyo. (Atthyatthataddhitaṃ).
analyzed: honti puttaḥ assa atthi iti puttimaḥ kittimaḥ puttiyaḥ kappiyaḥ jaṭiyaḥ hānabhāgiyaḥ seniyaḥ atthi attha taddhitam
translated: The following are formed with the suffix -iyo: ima+iyo = ima+iyā honti, putto assa atthīti puttimo, kittimo, puttiyo, kappiyo, jaṭiyo, hānabhāgiyo, seniyo. (Atthyatthataddhitaṃ).

original: 95. To pañcamyā
analyzed: taḥ pañcamyā
translated: . To pañcamyā

original: Pañcamyantā bahulaṃ to hoti vā. Toādipaccayantā nipphannanipātā, tehi parāsaṃ vibhattīnaṃ🔽“asaṃkhyehi sabbāsaṃ”ti lopova. Gāmato āgacchatīti gāmasmā āgacchati, corato bhāyatīti
analyzed: pañcamī antā bahulam to hoti vā to ādi paccaya antā nipphanna nipātā tehi parāsam vibhattīnam  asaṃkhyehi gāmataḥ āgacchati iti gāmasmai āgacchati corataḥ bhāyati iti
translated: To is often added to the locative case. The locative case is formed by adding the suffixes to, etc., to the nominative case.

original: corehi bhāyati, satthato parihīno satthā parihīno. Evaṃ purisato, rājato, aggito,
analyzed: corehi bhāyati satthataḥ parihīnaḥ satthā parihīnaḥ evam purisataḥ rājataḥ aggitaḥ
translated: “With all the indeclinables” means with lopa. Gāmato āgacchati = gāmasmā āgacchati, corato bhāyati = corehi bhāyati, satthato parihīno = satthā parihīno. Thus: purisato, rājato, aggito,

original: hatthito, hetuto, yuttito, itthito, bhikkhunito, yāguto, jambuto, cittato, āyuto.
analyzed: hatthitaḥ hetutaḥ yuttitaḥ itthitaḥ bhikkhunitaḥ yāgutaḥ jambutaḥ cittataḥ āyutaḥ
translated: hatthito, hetuto, yuttito, itthito, bhikkhunito, yāguto, jambuto, cittato, āyuto.

original: Sabbādito-sabbato, yato, tato iccādi.
analyzed: sabba ādi tas sabbataḥ yataḥ tataḥ i t ca ādi
translated: Sabbādito-sabbato, yato, tato, etc.

original: 96. Ito+te+tto kuto
analyzed: itaḥ ta it taḥ kutaḥ
translated: . Ito+te+tto kuto

translated: Tomhi imassa ṭi nipaccate etassa ṭa+eṭa kiṃ saddassa kuttañca. Ito imasmā, ato etto etasmā, kuto kasmā.

original: 97. Abhyādīhiti

translated: . Abhyādīhiti

original: To. Abhito, parito, pacchato, heṭṭhato.
analyzed: taḥ abhitas paritas pacchatas heṭṭhatas
translated: To. Abhito, parito, pacchato, heṭṭhato.

original: 98. Ādyādīhiti
analyzed: ādi ādi hi ti
translated: Ādyādīhi

original: Sattamyantehi to hoti. Ādo ādito, majjhato, antato, piṭṭhito, passato, mukhato. Paṭhamantā yato+dakaṃ ta+dādittaṃ, yaṃ udakaṃ, tadevā+dittanti attho.
analyzed: sattamī antehi taḥ hoti ādaḥ āditaḥ majjhataḥ antataḥ piṭṭhitaḥ passataḥ mukhataḥ paṭhama antāḥ yatā udakam tat ādittam yam udakam tat eva ādittam ti atthaḥ
translated: To is used with the locative case endings. Ādo ādito, majjhato, antato, piṭṭhito, passato, mukhato. Paṭhamantā yato+dakaṃ ta+dādittaṃ, yaṃ udakaṃ, tadevā+dittanti attho.

original: Sabbādīhi sattamyantehi tra+tthā vā honti. Sabbatra sabbattha sabbasmiṃ, yatra yattha, tatra tattha iccādi. Bahulādhikārā na tumhaamhehi.

translated: Sabbādīhi sattamyantehi tra+tthā vā honti. Sabbatra sabbattha sabbasmiṃ, yatra yattha, tatra tattha iccādi. Bahulādhikārā na tumhaamhehi.

original: 100. Katthe+ttha+kutrā+tra kve+hi+dha

translated: Etehi “sabbādito”tiādinā tra+tthā. Sesādesā ca paccayā ca imināva nipaccante. Iminā

analyzed: kissa ka ku ca etassa ṭe ṭā ca va paccaye kissa i lopaḥ ca ha dha paccayesu imassa

original: 101. Dhi sabbā vāti
analyzed: dhi sabbā vāti
translated: . Dhi sabbā vāti

original: Sabbasmā dhi vā. Sabbasmiṃ sabbadhi sabbatra.🔽102. Yā hinti
analyzed: sabbasmā dhi vā sabbasmin sabbadhi sabbatra 🔽yā hinti
translated: Sabbasmā dhi vā. Sabbasmiṃ sabbadhi sabbatra.

original: Yasaddā hiṃ, yasmiṃ yahiṃ yatra.

translated: Yasaddā hiṃ, yasmiṃ yahiṃ yatra.

original: 103. Tā hañcati
analyzed: tāḥ hañcati
translated: . Tā hañcati

translated: . Kuhiṃ kahanti

analyzed: him haṃ nipaccante kissa kukā ca kuhim kaham kuhiñcanaṃ ti nipāta antaram
translated: Hiṃ haṃ nipaccante kissa ku+kā ca. Kuhiṃ kahaṃ. Kuhiñcanaṃti nipātantaraṃ.

original: 105. Sabbe+ka+ñña+ya+tehi kāle dā
analyzed: sabba ekañña yatehi kāle dā
translated: . Sabbe+ka+ñña+ya+tehi kāle dā

original: Etehi kāle dā hoti vā. Sabbasmiṃ kāle sabbadā, ekadā, aññadā, yadā, tadā.
analyzed: etehi kāle hoti vā sabbasmin kāle sabbadā ekadā aññadā yadā tadā
translated: Etehi kāle dā hoti vā. Sabbasmiṃ kāle sabbadā, ekadā, aññadā, yadā, tadā.

original: 106. Kadā kudā sadā+dhune+dāni
analyzed: kadā kudā sadā adhunā idāni
translated: . Kadā kudā sadā+dhune+dāni

original: Ete saddā nipaccante. Kasmiṃkāle kadā kudā, sabbasmiṃ kāle sadā, imasmiṃ kāle adhunā idāni.
analyzed: ete saddāḥ nipaccante kasmiṃkāle kadā kudā sabbasmin kāle sadā imasmin kāle adhunā idāni
translated: Ete saddā nipaccante. Kasmiṃkāle kadā kudā, sabbasmiṃ kāle sadā, imasmiṃ kāle adhunā idāni.

original: 107. Ajja sajjva+parajjve+tarahi karahā
analyzed: ajja karahā
translated: . Ajja sajjva+parajjve+tarahi karahā

original: Pakati paccayo ādeso kālavisesoti sabba+metaṃ nipātanā labbhati. Imassa ṭo jjo cā+hani
analyzed: paccayaḥ ādesaḥ kāla visesaḥ iti sabbam etam nipātanā labbhati imassa ṭaḥ j jaḥ ca ahani
translated: Pakati paccayo ādeso kālavisesoti sabba+metaṃ nipātanā labbhati. Imassa ṭo jjo cā+hani

original: nipaccante, asmiṃ ahani ajja. Samānassa sa-bhāvo jju cā+hani. Samāne ahani sajju.
analyzed: nipaccante asmim ahani ajja samānassa sabhāvaḥ ca ahani samāne ahani sajju
translated: nipaccante, asmiṃ ahani ajja. Samānassa sa-bhāvo jju cā+hani. Samāne ahani sajju.

original: Aparasmā jju, aparasmiṃ ahani aparajju. Imassa eto, kāle rahi ca, imasmiṃkāle etarahi.
analyzed: aparasmai aparasmin ahani aparajju imassa kāle ca imasmin kāle etarahi
translated: Aparasmā jju, aparasmiṃ ahani aparajju. Imassa eto, kāle rahi ca, imasmiṃkāle etarahi.

original: Kiṃ saddassa ko, raha cā+najjatane. Kasmiṃ kāle karaha.🔽108. Sabbādīhi pakāre thā
analyzed: kim saddassa kaḥ ca anajjatane kasmin kāle  sabba ādīhi pakāre thā
translated: What is the meaning of sadda? What is the meaning of raha? What is the meaning of cā+najjatane? What is the meaning of kasmiṃ? What is the meaning of kāle? What is the meaning of karaha?🔽. The particle thā is used with sabba, etc.

original: Sāmaññassa bhedako viseso pakāro, tasmiṃ thāpaccayo hoti. Sabbena pakārena sabbathā, yathā, tathā.
analyzed: sāmaññassa bhedakaḥ visesaḥ pakāraḥ tasmim thā paccayaḥ hoti sabbena pakārena sabbathā yathā tathā
translated: Pakāra means a division or classification. The particle thā is used with it. Sabbena pakārena means in every way, in every respect. Sabbathā means in every way, in every respect.

original: 109. Katha+mitthaṃ
analyzed: katham ittham
translated: . What is the meaning of katha?

original: Ki+mimehi thaṃpaccayo, ka+ittaṃ tesaṃ yathākkamaṃ. Kena pakārena kathaṃ, iminā pakārena itthaṃ.
analyzed: kim imehi thaṃ paccayaḥ kaittam tesam yathākkamam kena pakārena katham iminā pakārena ittham
translated: What is the meaning of iminā? What is the meaning of itthaṃ? What is the meaning of tesaṃ? What is the meaning of yathākkamaṃ? What is the meaning of kena? What is the meaning of pakārena? What is the meaning of kathaṃ? What is the meaning of itthaṃ?

original: 110. Dhā saṅkhyāhiti
analyzed: dhā saṅkhyā h iti
translated: . The particle dhā is used with saṅkhyā.

original: Pakāre dhā hoti. Dvīhi pakārehi dve vā pakāre karoti dvidhā karoti, bahudhā karoti, ekaṃ rāsiṃ pañcappakāraṃ karoti pañcadhā karoti. Pañcappakāra+mekappakāraṃ karoti ekadhā karoti.🔽111. Ve+kā+jjhanti🔽Ekasmā pakāre jjhaṃ vā hoti. Ekena pakārena ekaṃ vā pakāraṃ karoti ekajjhaṃ karoti, ekadhā karoti vā.🔽112. Dvitīhe+dhāti🔽Edhā vā. Dvīhi pakārehi dve vā pakāre karoti dvedhā, tedhā. Dvidhā tidhā.
analyzed: pakāre dhā hoti dvīhi pakārehi dve vā pakāre karoti dvidhā karoti bahudhā karoti ekam rāsim pañca ppakāram karoti pañcadhā karoti pañca ppakāram eka ppakāram karoti ekadhā karoti 🔽vā ika a c hanti 🔽ekasmai pakāre vā hoti ekena pakārena ekam vā pakāram karoti ekajjham karoti ekadhā karoti vā 🔽dvitīha idhāti 🔽edhā vā dvīhi pakārehi dve vā pakāre karoti dvedhā tedhā dvidhā tidhā
translated: The particle dhā is used with pakāra. With two pakāras, he makes two pakāras, he makes in two ways. He makes in many ways. He makes one heap in five ways, he makes in five ways. He makes five ways in one way, he makes in one way.

original: 113. Tabbati jātiyo
analyzed: tabbati jātiyaḥ
translated: 113. The words for ‘time’

original: Pakāravati taṃsāmaññavācakā saddā jātiyo hoti. Paṭujātiyo, mudujātiyo.
analyzed: pakāravati saddāḥ jātiyaḥ hoti paṭu jātiyaḥ mudu jātiyaḥ
translated: The words for ‘time’ are words for ‘class’ that express a particular time. The words paṭu-jātiyo, mudu-jātiyo.

original: 114. Vārasaṅkhyāya kkhattuṃ
analyzed: vāra saṅkhyāya kkhattum
translated: . Kkhattuṃ with a number connected with a ‘time’

original: Vārasambandhiniyā saṃkhyāya kkhattuṃ hoti. Dve vāre bhuñjati dvikkhattuṃ divasassa bhuñjati. Vāraggahaṇaṃ kiṃ, pañca bhuñjati. Saṅkhyāyāti kiṃ, pahūte vāre bhuñjati.
analyzed: vāra sambandhiniyā saṃkhyāya hoti dve vāre bhuñjati dvi khattum divasassa bhuñjati vāra ggahaṇam kim pañca bhuñjati saṅkhyāya ati kim pahūte vāre bhuñjati
translated: Khattuṃ is used with a number connected with a ‘time’. He eats two times, he eats twice a day. The word vāra is stated to show that it is not used when there is no ‘time’. He eats five times. The word saṅkhyā is stated to show that it is not used when there is no number. He eats a lot of times.

original: 115. Katimhāti
analyzed: katimhā ati
translated: . Kati-kkhattuṃ

original: Kkhattuṃ hoti. Kati vāre bhuñjati katikkhattuṃ bhuñjati.
analyzed: kkhattum hoti kati vāre bhuñjati katikkhattum bhuñjati
translated: Khattuṃ is used. How many times does he eat? He eats katikkhattuṃ.

original: 116. Bahumhā dhā ca paccāsattiyaṃ🔽Vārasambandhiniyā bahusaṃkhyāya dhā hoti kkhattuñca, vārānaṃ ce paccāsatti hoti.
analyzed: bahumhā dhā ca paccāsattiyam  vāra sambandhiniyā bahu saṃkhyāya dhā hoti kkhattum ca ce paccāsatti hoti
translated: . Bahudhā and paccāsattiyaṃ with a number connected with a ‘time’🔽Bahudhā is used with a number connected with a ‘time’ and khattuṃ, and paccāsattiyaṃ is used with a ‘time’.

original: Bahuvāre bhuñjati bahudhā divasassa bhuñjati, bahukkhattuṃ vā. Paccāsattiyaṃti kiṃ,
analyzed: bahu vāre bhuñjati bahudhā divasassa bhuñjati bahu khattum vā kim
translated: He eats a lot of times, he eats bahudhā a day, or bahukkhattuṃ. The word paccāsattiyaṃ is stated to show that it is not used when there is no paccāsatti.

original: bahukkhattuṃ māsassa bhuñjati.
analyzed: bahu khattum māsassa bhuñjati
translated: He eats bahukkhattuṃ a month.

original: 117. Sa kiṃ vāti
analyzed: sa kim vāti
translated: . Sa kiṃ vāti

original: Kiṃpaccayo ekassa sādeso ca nipaccate. Ekaṃ vāraṃ bhuñjati sakiṃ bhuñjati, ekakkhattuṃ vā.
analyzed: kiṃpaccayaḥ ekassa sa ādesaḥ ca nipaccate ekam vāram bhuñjati sakim bhuñjati eka khattum vā
translated: The particle sa is used with kiṃ to express the same as one. He eats one time, he eats sakiṃ, or ekakkhattuṃ.

original: 118. So vicchā+pakāresu
analyzed: saḥ vicchā apakāresu
translated: 118. He makes it white, etc.,

original: Vicchāyaṃ pakāre ca so hoti. Khaṇḍaṃ khaṇḍaṃ karoti khaṇḍaso karoti. Puthuppakārena puthuso. Sabbena pakārena sabbaso.
analyzed: vicchāyam pakāre ca saḥ hoti khaṇḍam khaṇḍam karoti khaṇḍaso karoti puthuppakārena puthuso sabbena pakārena sabbaso
translated: He is in the state of making white, etc. He makes it into pieces, he makes it into fragments. By means of a separate making, separately. By means of the whole making, wholly.

original: 119. Abhūtatabbhāve karā+sa+bhūyoge vikārā cī
analyzed: a bhūta tad bhāve kara asa bhū yoge vikārā cī
translated: 119. In the non-existence of what was not, in the making, in the connection with what is, in the alteration, the verbal nouns

original: Avatthāvato+vatthantarenā+bhūtassa tāyā+vatthāya bhāve karā+sa+bhūhi sambandhe sati
analyzed: tāya avatthāya bhāve sambandhe sati
translated: When there is the non-existence of what was not, in the state of that non-existence, in the making, in the connection with what is,

original: vikāravācakācī hoti. Adhavalaṃ dhavalaṃ karoti dhavalī karoti. Adhavalo dhavalo siyā🔽dhavalī siyā. Adhavalo dhavalo bhavati dhavalī bhavati. Abhūtatabbhāveti kiṃ, ghaṭaṃ
analyzed: vikāra vācakācī hoti adhavalam dhavalam karoti dhavalī karoti adhavalaḥ dhavalaḥ siyā  dhavalī siyāḥ adhavalaḥ dhavalaḥ bhavati dhavalī bhavati abhūta tad bhāvā iti kim ghaṭam
translated: the verbal nouns expressing alteration are formed. He makes the unwhite white, he makes it white. The unwhite may be white,

original: karoti, dadhi atthi, ghaṭo bhavati. Karāsabhūyogeti kiṃ, adhavalo dhavalo jāyate.
analyzed: karoti dadhi atthi ghaṭaḥ bhavati kim adhavalaḥ dhavalaḥ jāyate
translated: it may be white. The unwhite becomes white, it becomes white. In the non-existence of what was not: what is the meaning of this? He makes a pot, there is curd, a pot will come into existence. In the making, in the connection with what is: what is the meaning of this? The unwhite becomes white.

original: Vikārāti kiṃ, pakatiyā mā hotu, suvaṇṇaṃ kuṇḍalī karoti. (Nipātataddhitaṃ).
analyzed: kim pakatiyā mā hotu suvaṇṇam kuṇḍalī karoti nipāta taddhitam
translated: In the alteration: what is the meaning of this? Let it not be as it was naturally, he makes gold into an earring. (The gerundive termination).

original: 120. Dissanta+ññepi paccayāti
analyzed: paccayā ti
translated: 120. And also in the state of being a condition.

original: Vuttato+ññepi paccayā dissanti. Vividhā mātaro vimātaroti visesanasamāso, tāsaṃ puttā🔽vemātikāti rikaṇapaccaye rānubandhattā ulope vuddhimhi kate vemātikā. Pathaṃ gacchantīti
analyzed: paccayāḥ dissanti vividhāḥ mātaraḥ vimātaraḥ ti visesana samāsaḥ tāsam puttā  vemātikā ati ri kaṇa paccaye ra anubandha ttā u lope vuddhimhi kate vemātikā patham gacchanti iti
translated: And other conditions are seen in the way stated. The compound of the words ‘various mothers’ and ‘non-mothers’ is a ‘distinctive compound’ . Their offspring🔽are ‘various-mothered’ . When the ‘u’ is lengthened in the word ‘vemātika’ , it is because of the ‘rikaṇapaccayas’ .🔽They ‘go by the path’ ,🔽so they are ‘path-farers’ . The ‘ī’ is lengthened in the word ‘āvī’ because of the ‘ā’ in the word ‘āgā’ .🔽He has envy , so he is ‘envious’ . The ‘ī’ is lengthened in the word ‘issukī’ because of the ‘uk’ in the word ‘ukkhittaka’ .

original: pathāvino, āvī. Issā assa atthīti issukī, ukī. Dhuraṃ vahantīti dhorayhā, yhaṇa.
analyzed: pathāvinaḥ āvī issā assa atthi iti issukī ukī dhuram vahanti iti
translated: They carry the yoke , so they are ‘oxen’ . The ‘ī’ is lengthened in the word ‘dhorayhā’ because of the ‘yha’ in the word ‘yahanta’ .

original: Sāmaññañca viseso ca, bhāvajo ca nipātajo;
analyzed: sāmaññañca viseso ca bhāva jo ca nipāta jo
translated: ‘Community’ and ‘distinctive’, ‘state’ and ‘prefix’,

original: Iti viññūhi viññeyyo, taddhito tu catubbidho.
analyzed: iti viññūhi viññeyyaḥ taddhitaḥ tu catubbidhaḥ
translated: So it should be known by the wise, but it is of four kinds in the ‘tatiya’

original: Iti payogasiddhiyaṃ ṇādikaṇḍo pañcamo.
analyzed: iti pañcamaḥ
translated: Thus ends the fifth chapter in the Payogasiddhi called ‘The Section on ṇā and so on’.

original: 6. Tyādikaṇḍa
analyzed: tya ādi kaṇḍa
translated: . The Section on ty and so on

original: Atha tyādayo kriyāvācīhi dhātūhi vuccante.
analyzed: atha tya ādayaḥ kriyā vācīhi dhātūhi vuccante
translated: Now ty and so on are stated with verbs.

original: Kriyaṃ ācikkhatīti ākhyātanti kriyāpadassa pubbācariyasaññā. Kāla+kāraka+purisaparidīpakaṃ kriyālakkhaṇaṃ tyādyantaṃ aliṅgañca, vuttampi ce+taṃ –
analyzed: kriyam ācikkhati iti ākhyātam ti kriyā padassa pubba ācariya saññā kāla kāraka purisa paridīpakam kriyā lakkhaṇam aliṅgam ca vuttam api
translated: The name given by the teachers of old for the verb is ‘ākhyāta’ , which means ‘it tells the action’ . It has the characteristic of action, and it ends in ty and so on, and it is without gender, and though it is stated thus:🔽‘That which has three times, three persons,

original: Yaṃ tikālaṃ tipurisaṃ, kriyāvācī tikārakaṃ;
analyzed: yam ti kālam ti purisam kriyā vācī ti kārakam
translated: And three cases, and is a verb,🔽And has no gender, and is dual,

original: Atiliṅgaṃ dvivacanaṃ, ta+dākhyātanti vuccati.
analyzed: ati liṅgam dvivacanam vuccati
translated: That is called ākhyāta’ ,

original: 14. Kriyatthā bahulaṃ –ti
analyzed: kriyatthāḥ bahulam ti
translated: 14. The word “kriyā” is used in the sense of “kriyā” in the majority of cases.🔽It is used in all the above cases. The word “kriyā” is used in the sense of “kriyā” in the majority of cases.🔽The word “kriyā” is used in the sense of “kriyā” in the majority of cases.
