original: Ṇa-karaṇaṃ kārā, “assā ṇānubandhe”ti ā hoti, eva+muparipi. Haraṇaṃ hārā muttāvali. Taraṇaṃ tārā, dharaṇaṃ dhārā. Araṇaṃ ārā.
analyzed: ṇa karaṇam kārā assā ṇa anubandhā iti hoti evam upari pi haraṇam hārā muttā āvali taraṇam tārā dharaṇam dhārā araṇam ārā
translated: The making of a necklace is a hārā; “assā ṇānubandhe” means a necklace is so called because it follows the neck. So too with the rest. The carrying away is a hārā, a pearl necklace. The crossing is a tārā, a star. The bearing is a dhārā, a stream. The not quarrelling is an ārā, a monastery.🔽In any way at all in a sound,

original: Yathākathañci saddamhi, ruḷhiyā atthanicchayo.
analyzed: yathā kathañci saddamhi attha nicchayo
translated: the meaning-desire is by derivation.

original: Kti-sambhuvanaṃ sambhuti. “Na te”ccādinā na vuddhi. Savanaṃ suti. Nayanaṃ nayati
analyzed: savanam suti nayanam nayati
translated: The becoming is a sambhuti. “Na te” etc. means not growth. The hearing is a suti. The leading is a nīti.

original: etāyāti vā nīti. Maññatīti mati, “gamādirānaṃ lopontabyañjanassā”ti gamādittā nalopo.
analyzed: vā ni iti maññati iti mati
translated: Or it is so called because it leads by this. The thinking is a mati. “Gamādirānaṃ lopontabyañjanassā” means the loss of the n is by the rule.

original: Gamanaṃ gantabbāti vā gati. Upahananaṃ upahati. Ramanti etāya ramanaṃ vā rati. Tananaṃ
analyzed: gamanam vā gati upahananam upahati ramanti etāya ramanam vā rati tananam
translated: The going is a gati. The striking is an upahati. They delight by this, or it is a delight, a rati. The spreading out is a tanati.

original: tati. Niyamanaṃ niyati. Bhuñjanaṃ bhutti. Yuñjanaṃ yutti, pararūpaṃ. Evaṃ samāpajjanaṃ
analyzed: tati niyamanam niyati bhuñjanam bhutti yuñjanam yutti para rūpam evam samāpajjanam
translated: The restraining is a niyati. The eating is a bhutti. The yoking is a yutti, a reason. So too the attaining is an samāpatti.

original: samāpajjateti samāpatti. Sampatti. Yaja=devapūjāsaṅgatikaraṇadānesu, yajanaṃ iṭṭhi,
analyzed: samāpajjata iti samāpatti sampatti yaja deva pūjā saṅgati karaṇa dānesu yajanam iṭṭhi
translated: The attainment is a samāpatti. The prosperity is a sampatti. Yaja = in the worship of gods, in the making of connection, in giving, the sacrificing is an iṭṭhi.

original: “yajassa yassa ṭiyī”ti ṭiādeso, “pucchādito”ti tassa ṭho, pararūpapaṭhamakkharā ca.
analyzed: ya jassa yassa ṭ iyi iti ṭi ādesaḥ puccha āditaḥ ti tassa ṭhaḥ para rūpa paṭhama kkharā ca
translated: “Yajassa yassa ṭiyī” means the substitution of ṭi, etc., and “pucchādito” means the ṭho of that, and the first letter of the other form.

original: Sāsanaṃ siṭṭhi, “sāsassa sisa vā”ti sisa, sānantarassa tassa ṭho”ti ṭhādeso. Bhedanaṃ
analyzed: sāsanam siṭṭhi sāsassa sisa vāti sisa sa anantarassa tassa ṭhaḥ iti ṭha ādesaḥ bhedanam
translated: “The Dispensation is the head of the Sāsana,” and “the head of that is the Sāsana,” and “the place of that is the ṭhādeso.” The breaking up of the Dispensation is the bhedana.

original: bhijjateti vā bhitti. Bhaja=sevāyaṃ, bhajanaṃ bhatti. Tana=vitthāre, tanotīti tanti, nassa niggahītādi.
analyzed: bhijjate iti vā bhitti bhaja sevāyam bhajanam bhatti tana vitthāre tanoti iti tanti nassa niggahīta ādi
translated: The Teaching is the “head” of the Sāsana, “the head of the Sāsana”, thus it is Sisa. The “th” is the locative of the preceding Sisa. The “splitting” is the “breaking up” or “splitting” (of the Teaching). The “enjoying” is the “enjoyment”, the “eating”. The “stretching out” is the “stretching”, thus it is Tanti, the “n” is suppressed, etc.

original: Ka-guhantī etthāti guhā, okāranivutti. Rujatīti rujā. Modanti etāyāti mudā nāma muditā.
analyzed: ettha ati guhā okāra nivutti rujati iti rujā modanti etāyā ati mudā nāma muditā
translated: The “guha” is the “cave” in which the “ka” is hidden, it is a locative of the place. The “ruja” is the “pain”. The “moda” is the “joy”, the “gladness”.

original: Yaka-vida=ñāṇe, vidanaṃ vidanti etāyāti vā vijjā, dassa je pubbarūpaṃ. Yajanaṃ ijjā, ṭiādeso.🔽Ya-sayanti etthāti seyyā, dvittaṃ. Aja=vaja=gamane, samajanaṃ samajanti etthāti vā
analyzed: ya ka vida ñāṇe vidanam vidanti etāya ati vā vijjā dassa je pubbarūpam yajanam ijjā ṭi ādesaḥ  yasayanti etthā ati seyyā dvittam aja vaja gamane samajanam samajanti etthā ati vā
translated: The “vidana” is the “knowledge”, or they “know” by means of it, thus it is Vijjā, the “j” is the prefix of the preceding “j”. The “yajana” is the “going forth”, the “ṭ” is the locative.

original: samajjā. Papubbo, pabbajanaṃ pabbajjā. Tavaggavaraṇā”dimhi “cavaggabayañā”ti yogavibhāgena
analyzed: sa majjā papubbaḥ pabbajanam pabbajjā ta vagga varaṇa ādimhi ca vagga ba yañā iti yogavibhāgena
translated: The “seyyā” is the “bed” in which they “say” (or lie), the “y” is the prefix of the preceding “y”. The “ajana” is the “going”, the “samajana” is the “meeting”, they “meet” there, thus it is Samajjā. The “pabbajana” is the “going forth”, the “j” is the prefix of the preceding “j”. In the words “cavaggabayañā” the “ca” is the prefix of the preceding “ca”,

original: vassa be dvittaṃ. Ūmhi paricaraṇaṃ paricariyā. Jāgaraṇaṃ jāgariyā.
analyzed: paricaraṇam paricariyā jāgaraṇam jāgariyā
translated: the “g” is the prefix of the preceding “g”, the “v” is the prefix of the preceding “v”, the “ya” is the prefix of the preceding “ya”, the “ñ” is the prefix of the preceding “ñ”. The “paricariyā” is the “service”, the “jāgariyā” is the “keeping awake”.

original: Ana-payojake kāriyadhātuto kattuṃ payojanaṃ kāraṇaṃ, ekāranisedho nassa ṇo ca. Evaṃ
analyzed: anapayojake kāriya dhātutaḥ kattum payojanam kāraṇam ekāra nisedhaḥ nassa ṇo ca evam
translated: The “kāraṇa” is the “reason”, the “purpose” of the action of the causative verbs, the “n” is suppressed, and the “ṇ” is substituted.

original: harituṃ payojanaṃ hāraṇaṃ. Vida=anubhave, vitti vedayatīti vā vedanā. Vanda=abhivādanathutīsu,
analyzed: payojanam hāraṇam vida anubhave vitti vedayati iti vā vedanā vanda abhivādana thutīsu
translated: The meaning of “to carry off” is “to carry away” (hāranaṃ). Vida = to experience; or feeling (vedanā) is that which experiences (vedayatīti). Vanda = in saluting and praising;🔽saluting (vandanaṃ) is saluting (vandanaṃ). Upāsanaṃ is worshipping. Cita = in volition; volition (cetanā) is that which wills (cetayati). Desiyati = teaching;

original: vandanaṃ vandanā. Upāsanaṃ upāsanā. Cita=saṃcetanāyaṃ, cetayatīti cetanā. Desiyatīti
analyzed: vandanam vandanā upāsanam upāsanā citasaṃcetanā ayam cetayati iti cetanā
translated: teaching (desanā) is that which is taught (desanā). Bhāviyati = developing;

original: desanā. Bhāviyatīti bhāvanā.
analyzed: desanā bhāviyati iti bhāvanā
translated: developing (bhāvanā) is that which is developed (bhāvanā).

original: 50. Jāhāhi ni
analyzed: jāhāhi ni
translated: . Jāhāhi ni

original: Jā=vayohānimhi, hā=cāge, imehi itthiyaṃ ni hoti. Jānaṃ=vayaparipāko jāni. Hānaṃ hāni.
analyzed: imehi itthiyam ni hoti jānaṃvaya paripākaḥ hāni hāni
translated: Jā = in abandoning and casting off; hā = in giving up; ni is added to these in the feminine. Jānaṃ = the maturing of life is jāni. Hānaṃ = loss is hāni.

original: 51. Karā ririyo
analyzed: karā
translated: . Karā ririyo🔽Ririyo is added to kara in the feminine. Because of the following of ra, there is elision of the a in the feminine, and the ri is elided in the feminine. The ri is followed by the ka.🔽. I+ki+tī sarūpe

original: Karato ririyo hoti+tthiyaṃ. Rānubandhattā aralope karaṇaṃ kiriyā. “Kriyā”ti “tuṃtāye”ccādimhi “kriyāyaṃ”ti yogavibhāgā riyaramhi aralopo, rikāro kakāre+nubandho hoti.
analyzed: ra anubandha ttā ara lope karaṇam kiriyā kriyāti yogavibhāgāḥ ara lopaḥ rikāraḥ kakāra inubandhaḥ hoti
translated: These are added to the feminine of a root in order to make it feminine. And the root itself is the feminine. Thus in the feminine of yudhi, the feminine is yudhi. “Karotissa kho” = because of the announcement of the vikaraṇa, the feminine is lo by the rule “kattari lo”. Pacati. The a is followed by the ka by the rule “akāro kakāroti ghaṇantena”.

original: 52. I+ki+tī sarūpe🔽Dhātussa sarūpe+bhidheyye ete honti. Vacaicca+yaṃ dhātu eva vaci. Evaṃ yudhi. “Karotissa
analyzed: i k itī sarūpe  dhātussa sarūpa ibhidheyye ete honti vacaiccayam dhātu eva vaci evam yudhi karotissa
translated: . I+ki+tī sarūpe

original: kho”ti vikaraṇassa ñāpitattā “kattari lo”ti lo, pacati. Akāro kakāroti ghaṇantena
analyzed: kho ti vikaraṇassa ñāpitattā kattari lo ti lo pacati akāro kakāro ti ghaṇa antena
translated: These are added to the feminine of a root in order to make it feminine. And the root itself is the feminine. Thus in the feminine of yudhi, the feminine is yudhi. “Karotissa kho” = because of the announcement of the vikaraṇa, the feminine is lo by the rule “kattari lo”. Pacati. The a is followed by the ka by the rule “akāro kakāroti ghaṇantena”.

original: kārasaddena chaṭṭhīsamāso.
analyzed: kāra saddena chaṭṭhī samāsaḥ
translated: The sixth case is compounded with the word kāra.

original: 53. Sīlā+bhikkhaññā+vassakesu ṇī
analyzed: sīlā bhikkhaññā vassakesu ṇī
translated: The sixth case is compounded with sīla, abhikkhaṇa, and vassaka.

original: Kriyatthā ṇī hoti sīlādīsu. Saṃsa=pasaṃsane, piyapubbo, piyaṃ pasaṃsati sīlenāti
analyzed: kriyatthā ṇī hoti sīla ādīsu saṃsa pasaṃsane piya pubbaḥ piyam pasaṃsati sīlena ati
translated: The sixth case is compounded with sīla, etc., in the sense of action. Saṃsa = praise, piya is the prefix, he praises the dear one with sīla,

original: piyapasaṃsī rājā. Atha vā piyaṃ pasaṃsati sīlena vā dhammena vā tasmiṃ sādhu vāti
analyzed: piya pasaṃsī rājā atha vā piyam pasaṃsati sīlena vā dhammena vā tasmim sādhu vāti
translated: therefore he is piyapasaṃsī, the king. Or he praises the dear one with sīla or with dhamma, it is good in him,

original: piyapasaṃsī, piyapasaṃsanī, piyapasaṃsi kulaṃ, āvuddhimhi tathā saccavādī, dhammavādī.
analyzed: piya pasaṃsī piya pasaṃsanī piya pasaṃsi kulaṃ āvuddhimhi tathā sacca vādī dhamma vādī
translated: therefore he is piyapasaṃsī, piyapasaṃsanī, piyapasaṃsi kulaṃ, in the same way saccavādi, dhammavādi, in avuddhi.

original: Sīghayāyīti “assā+ṇāpimhī yuka” iti yuka. Pāpakārī, mālakārī iccādi. Uṇhaṃ bhuñjati
analyzed: sīgha yāyī iti iti pāpa kārī māla kārī iccādi uṇham bhuñjati
translated: Sīghāyaṇī, “we are pleased with you” = yuka. Pāpakārī, mālakārī, etc. He eats hot food,

original: sīlenāti uṇhabhojī, “lahussupantassā”ti okāro.
analyzed: sīlena ati uṇha bhojī lahu supantassa ati okāraḥ
translated: therefore he is uṇhabhojī. “He sleeps little” = okāra.

original: Ābhikkhaññe-punappuna khīraṃ pivatīti khīrapāyī, yuka. Avassaṃ karotīti avassakārī.
analyzed: khīram pivati iti khīra pāyī avassam karoti iti avassa kārī
translated: He drinks milk again and again, therefore he is khīrapāyī, yuka. He makes a request, therefore he is avassakārī.

original: “Syādi syādine+katthaṃ”ti samāse vibhattilope ca kate “lopo”ti niggahītalopo. Satandāyīti
analyzed: syādi syādinā ekattham ti samāse vibhatti lope ca kate lopo iti niggahīta lopo
translated: “Syādi syādine+katthaṃ” = in a compound and when the case ending is elided, “lopo” is elided by niggahīta. Satandāyī,

original: ettha bahulaṃvidhānā vibhattialope amādisamāsapaṭisedhe ca kate vaggantaṃ.
analyzed: ettha bahulam vidhānā vibhatti a lope am ādi samāsa paṭisedhe ca kate vak g antam
translated: here, because of the frequent rule, when the case ending is elided and the compound beginning with a vowel is prohibited, it is vagganta.

original: Aññasmiṃ atthepi “ṇī”ti yogavibhāgena siddhaṃ. Sādhukārī, brahmacārī, assaddhabhojī. Paṇḍitaṃ attānaṃ maññatīti paṇḍitamānī, bahussutadhārī iccādi.
analyzed: aññasmin atthe pi ṇi iti yogavibhāgena siddham sādhu kārī brahmacārī assaddha bhojī paṇḍitam attānam maññati iti paṇḍita mānī bahu ssuta dhārī iccādi
translated: “He is a doer of what is good” is a formation of the -ṇī affix in the sense of “doing” by the rule “ṇī is added to the root in the sense of doing.” “He is a celibate” is a formation of the -ṇī affix in the sense of “having” by the rule “ṇī is added to the root in the sense of having.” “He is one who eats the food of the faithless” is a formation of the -ṇī affix in the sense of “eating” by the rule “ṇī is added to the root in the sense of eating.” “He thinks himself wise” is a formation of the -ṇī affix in the sense of “thinking” by the rule “ṇī is added to the root in the sense of thinking.” “He is one who bears in mind what he has learned” is a formation of the -ṇī affix in the sense of “bearing in mind” by the rule “ṇī is added to the root in the sense of bearing in mind.”

original: Sādhukaraṇaṃ sādhukāro, so assa atthīti sādhukārīti ghaṇantā ī.
analyzed: sādhu karaṇam sādhu kāro saḥ assa atthi iti sādhu kārī iti
translated: “He is one who makes the exclamation ‘Sādhu!’” is a formation of the -ṇī affix in the sense of “making” by the rule “ṇī is added to the root in the sense of making.”

original: 54. Thāvari+ttara bhaṅgura bhidura bhāsura bhassarā
analyzed: bhaṅgura bhidura bhāsura bhassarā
translated: Thāvari+ttara bhaṅgura bhidura bhāsura bhassarā

original: Ete saddā nipaccante sīle gamyamāne. Iminā nipātanā varapaccayo ca thāssa tho ca,
analyzed: ete saddāḥ nipaccante sīle gamyamāne iminā nipātanā vara paccayaḥ ca tha assa thaḥ ca
translated: These words are contracted when sīla is the subject. By this rule and by the rule “thā becomes tho when followed by a vowel,” thā becomes tho.

original: tiṭṭhati sīlenāti thāvaro. I=ajjhenagatīsu, ttarapaccayo, gacchati sīlenāti ittaro.
analyzed: tiṭṭhati sīlena ati thāvaraḥ ttara paccayaḥ gacchati sīlena ati ittaro
translated: “He stands by sīla” is thāvaro. By the rule “i becomes i when followed by a vowel,” i becomes i. “He goes by sīla” is ittaro.

original: Bhañja=omaddane, bhajjate sayameva bhajjati vā attanā attānanti bhaṅguro, kamme kattari
analyzed: bhañjaomaddane bhajjate sayam eva bhajjati vā attanā bhaṅguro kamme kattari
translated: Bhañja=omaddane, bhajjate sayameva bhajjati vā attanā attānanti bhaṅguro, kamme kattari

original: vā gurapaccayo. Bhijjate sayameva bhindati vā attānanti bhidūro, ettha kūrapaccayo,
analyzed: vā gura paccayaḥ bhijjate sayam eva bhindati vā attā ananti bhidūraḥ ettha kūra paccayaḥ
translated: vā gurapaccayo. Bhijjate sayameva bhindati vā attānanti bhidūro, ettha kūrapaccayo,

original: kakāro+nubandho. Parabhañjanavisayesupi udāharaṇesu na hoti. Tatthāpi keci “dosandhakārabhidūro”ti
analyzed: udāharaṇesu na hoti tattha api keci
translated: kakāro+nubandho. Parabhañjanavisayesupi udāharaṇesu na hoti. Tatthāpi keci “dosandhakārabhidūro”ti

original: idaṃ sandhāya icchanti. Bhāsati dippatīti bhāsuro, urapaccayo. Sarapaccaye bhassaro,
analyzed: idam sandhāya icchanti bhāsati dippati iti bhāsuraḥ ura paccayaḥ sara paccaye bhassaro
translated: This is what they want. “He shines, he lights up” is bhāsuro, a suffix. In the suffix sarapaccayo, bhassaro.

original: “byañjane dīgharassā”ti rasso. (Tekālikappaccayā).
analyzed: byañjane dīgha rassā ati rassaḥ te kālika ppaccayā
translated: “In the case of a long vowel in a consonant” (Pāṇini 1.1.56), it is long. (The suffix is added at the same time).

original: 55. Kattari bhūte ktavantu+ktāvī
analyzed: kattari bhūte ktavantu ktāvī
translated: . Ktavantu+ktāvī in the agent

original: Bhūte atthe vattamānato kriyatthā ktavantu+ktāvī honti kattari. Vijinīti vijitavā
analyzed: bhūte atthe vattamānataḥ kriyatthā ktavantu ktāvī honti kattari vijinīti vijitavā
translated: In the sense of the past, ktavantu+ktāvī are used in the sense of the action in the present tense in the agent. Vijinīti vijitavā

original: vijitāvī, kānubandhattā na vuddhi. Guṇavantu daṇḍisamaṃ. Hu=havane, aggiṃ ahavīti
analyzed: vijitāvī na guṇavantu daṇḍi samam huhavane aggim
translated: vijitāvī, because of the connection with the vowel, there is no lengthening. Guṇavantu daṇḍisamaṃ. Hu=havane, aggiṃ ahavīti

original: hutavā hutāvī, hutāvinī hutavānī. “Bhūte”ti yāva “āhāratthā”ti adhikāro.
analyzed: hutavā hutāvī hutāvinī hutavānī bhūtā iti yāva adhikāro
translated: hutavā hutāvī, hutāvinī hutavānī. “Bhūte”ti yāva “āhāratthā”ti adhikāro.

original: 56. Kto bhāvakammesuti
analyzed: ktaḥ bhāva kammesu ti
translated: . Kto in the sense of the state and the action

original: Bhāve kamme ca bhūte kto hoti. Asanaṃ āsitaṃ bhavatā, ñi. Karīyitthāti kato kaṭo bhavatā, “gamādirānaṃ” tyādinā ralopo. Eva+muparipi.
analyzed: bhāve ca bhūte ktaḥ hoti asanam āsitam bhavatā karīyittha ati kataḥ kaṭaḥ bhavatā tya ādinā ra lopaḥ evam upari pi
translated: In the sense of the past, kto is used in the sense of the state and the action. Asanaṃ āsitaṃ bhavatā, ñi. Karīyitthāti kato kaṭo bhavatā, “gamādirānaṃ” tyādinā ralopo. Eva+muparipi.

original: 57. Kattari cā+rambhe
analyzed: kattari ca ārambhe
translated: . Ktavantu+ktāvī in the agent and in the beginning

original: Kriyārambhe kattarikto hoti yathāpattañca, pakarīti pakato bhavaṃ kaṭaṃ. Pakarīyitthāti pakato kaṭo bhavatā. Pasupīti pasutto bhavaṃ. Pasupīyitthāti pasuttaṃ bhavatā, pararūpaṃ.
analyzed: kriyā ārambhe katta riktaḥ hoti yathāpattam ca pakarīti pakataḥ bhavam kaṭam pakarīyittha ati pakataḥ kaṭaḥ bhavatā pasupīti pasuttaḥ bhavam pasupīyittha ati pasuttam bhavatā para rūpam
translated: He is called a cutter in the beginning of an action, and he is called a cutter in the way he has obtained. He is called a cook in the sense of becoming cooked. He is called a cook in the sense of having been cooked by you. He is called a sleeper in the sense of becoming asleep. He is called a sleeper in the sense of having been made to sleep by you, in the sense of another’s form.

original: 58. Ṭhā+sa vasa silisa sī ruha jara janīhi
analyzed: ṭhāsa vasa silisa sī ruha jara janīhi
translated: . With ṭhā+sa, vasa, silisa, sī, ruha, jara, janī

original: Ṭhādīhi kattari kto hoti yathāpattañca. Upaṭṭhāsīti upaṭṭhīto bhavaṃ guruṃ. Upaṭṭhīyitthāti
analyzed: ṭha ādīhi kattari ktaḥ hoti yathāpattam ca upaṭṭhāsi iti upaṭṭhītaḥ bhavam gurum upaṭṭhīyittha ati
translated: He is called a cutter with ṭhā+sa, etc., in the way he has obtained. He is called a waiter in the sense of having waited on the teacher. He is called a waiter in the sense of having been waited on by you,

original: upaṭṭhito guru bhotā, “ṭhāssī”ti ṭhāssa i. Evaṃ upāsīti upāsito. Upāsīyitthāti upāsito.
analyzed: upaṭṭhitaḥ guru bhotā ṭhāssi iti ṭhāsso i evam upāsi iti upāsitaḥ upāsīyittha ati upāsitaḥ
translated: “ṭhāssī” means ṭhāssa. Thus he is called a worshipper in the sense of having worshipped. He is called a worshipper in the sense of having been worshipped.

original: “Ñi byañjanassā”ti ñi. Anuvusi anuvusīyitthāti vā anuvusīto. “Assū”ti assa ukāro.
analyzed: ñi byañjanassa ati ñi anuvusi anuvusīyittha ati vā anuvusītaḥ assu iti assaḥ ukāraḥ
translated: “Ñi byañjanassā” means ñi. He is called a follower in the sense of having been followed. “Assū” means assa ukāra.

original: Āpubbo silisa=āliṅgane, āsilesi āsilesīyitthāti vā āsiliṭṭho. “Sānantarassa tassa
analyzed: āpubbaḥ silisa āliṅgane āsilesi āsilesīyittha ati vā āsiliṭṭhaḥ sā anantarassa tassa
translated: Āpubbo silisa=āliṅgane, he is called an embracer in the sense of having embraced. He is called an embracer in the sense of having been embraced by you. “Sānantarassa tassa

original: ṭho”ti ṭhe pararūpaṃ paṭhamakkharañca. Adhisayi adhisīyitthāti vā adhisayito khaṭopikaṃ
analyzed: ṭho ti ṭhe para rūpam paṭhama kkharam ca adhisayi adhisīyittha ati vā adhisayitaḥ kha ṭopikam
translated: ṭho” means ṭhe in the sense of another’s form and the first letter. He is called a superior in the sense of having been made superior. He is called a superior in the sense of having been made superior by you, a broom.

original: bhavaṃ, adhisayitā khaṭopikā bhotā. Evaṃ āruhi āruhīyitthāti vā āruḷho rukkhaṃ bhavaṃ,🔽āruḷho rukkho bhotā, “ruhādīhi ho ḷa cā”ti tassa hakāro pubbahakārassa ca ḷo. Anujīri
analyzed: bhavam adhisayitā khaṭopikā bhotā evam āruhi āruhīyittha ati vai āruḍhaḥ rukkham bhavam  āruḷhaḥ rukkhaḥ bhotā ruha ādīhi ho ḷa ca ati tassa hakāraḥ pubba hakārassa ca ḷaḥ anujīri
translated: “He climbed the tree,” “The tree was climbed by him,” “He climbed the tree,” “The tree was climbed by him.”

original: anujīrīyitthāti vā anujiṇṇo vasaliṃ bhavaṃ, anujiṇṇā vasalī bhotā, “tarādīhi riṇṇo”ti🔽ktassa riṇṇādeso “rānubandhe”tyādinā arabhāgassa lopo ca. Anvajāyi anvajāyitthāti
analyzed: anujīrīyittha ati vai anujiṇṇaḥ vasalim bhavam anujiṇṇā vasalī bhotā tara ādīhi riṇṇoti  ktassa riṇṇa ādesaḥ ra anubandha ityādinā ara bhāgassa lopo ca anvajāyi anvajāyittha iti
translated: “He went along the low-caste woman,” “The low-caste woman was gone along by him,” “He went along the low-caste woman,” “The low-caste woman was gone along by him.”🔽“He followed,” “He was followed,” “He followed,” “He was followed.”

original: vā anujāto māṇavako māṇavikaṃ, anujātā māṇavikā māṇavakena, “janissā”ti nassa ā.🔽59. Gamanatthā+kammakā+dhāre ca
analyzed: vā anujātaḥ māṇavakaḥ māṇavikam anujātā māṇavikā māṇavakena janissāti nasse ā  gamana attha akammaka ādhāre ca
translated: “He was born after,” “He was born after,” “The youth was born after the girl,” “The girl was born after the youth.”

original: Gamanatthato akammakato ca kriyatthā ādhāre kto hoti kattari ca yathāpattañca. Yā=pāpuṇane,
analyzed: gamana atthataḥ a kammakato ca kriyatthāḥ ādhāre ktaḥ hoti kattari ca yathāpattam ca yā pāpuṇane
translated: +Kta is used in the sense of going, and in the sense of action, with a passive meaning, and with the agent. Yā=pāpuṇane,

original: yātavanto asminti yātaṃ ṭhānaṃ. Yātavanto yātā, yānaṃ yātaṃ. Ettha santampi kammaṃ
analyzed: yātavantaḥ asmin ti yātam ṭhānam yātavantaḥ yātāḥ yānam yātam ettha santam pi kammam
translated: yātavanto asminti yātaṃ ṭhānaṃ. Yātavanto yātā, yānaṃ yātaṃ. Ettha santampi kammaṃ

original: anicchitaṃ. Yāyitāti yāto patho. “Ye gatyatthā, te buddhyatthā. Ye buddhyatthā, te
analyzed: an icchitam pathaḥ ye gati atthā te buddhi atthā ye buddhi atthā te
translated: not desired. Gone to destruction: gone to the path of destruction. “Those that have the meaning of going have the meaning of understanding. Those that have the meaning of understanding have the meaning of being known.

original: gatyatthā”ti vuttattā tathalakkhaṇaṃ yāthāvato āgato abhisambuddhoti tathāgato itipi
analyzed: gati atthā ati vutta ttā tatha lakkhaṇam yāthāvataḥ āgataḥ abhisambuddhaḥ ti tathāgataḥ iti pi
translated: Unwanted. Gone to the end of: gone to the end of the path. Because it is said, “Those that have the meaning of going have the meaning of knowing, and those that have the meaning of knowing have the meaning of going,” the characteristic of that is gone to, reached, fully known, as it really is, thus he is the “Tathāgata.”

original: hoti. Āsitavanto asminti āsitaṃ. Āsitavanto āsitā. Āsana+māsitaṃ.
analyzed: hoti āsitavantaḥ asmin ti āsitam āsitavantaḥ āsitāḥ āsanam āsitam
translated: Dwelt in this: dwelt. Those who have dwelt are dwelt. Dwelling is dwelt.

original: 60. Āhāratthā
analyzed: āhāratthā
translated: The meaning of eating,

original: Ajjhohāratthā ādhāre kto hoti yathāpattañca. Bhuttavanto+sminti bhuttaṃ. Evaṃ pītaṃ,🔽“gāpāna+mī”ti ī. Bhuñjanaṃ bhuttaṃ pānaṃ pītaṃ. Bhuñjīyitthāti bhutto odano. Evaṃ
analyzed: ādhāre ktaḥ hoti yathāpattam ca bhuttavantaḥ asmin ti bhuttam evam pītam  bhuñjanam bhuttam pānam pītam bhuñjīyittha ati bhuttaḥ odanaḥ evam
translated: The meaning of eating what is taken in, the instrumental is formed as in the case of the word “patta” (bowl). Those who have eaten in this: eaten. Thus drunk.

original: pītaṃ udakaṃ. Akattatthaṃ bhinnayogakaraṇaṃ. Bahulādhikārā kattaripi “apiviṃsūti🔽pītā gāvo”ti hoteva. Sida=pāke, passijjīti passanno, “gamanattha” dinā kto, “bhidā”
analyzed: pītam udakam akattattham bhinna yoga karaṇam bahula adhikārā  pītāḥ gāvaḥ iti hotā iva sida pāke passijji iti passannaḥ gamana attha dinā ktaḥ bhidā
translated: “Gāpāna” (drink) is “ī.” Eating is eaten, drinking is drunk. The rice has been eaten is “bhutto odano.” Thus the water has been drunk is “pītaṃ udakaṃ.” The meaning of not done, the separation of the compound. Because of the frequent occurrence, in the agent also it is “apiviṃsūti gāvo pītā.”

original: dinā tassa no pararūpañca. Amaññitthāti mato. Icchīyitthāti iṭṭho. Abujjhitāti buddho,
analyzed: dinā tassa no para rūpañca amaññittha ati mataḥ icchīyittha ati iṭṭhaḥ abujjhitā ati buddhaḥ
translated: Sida=cooking, “passa” (see) is “passanno.” The instrumental is given in the sense of going. The instrumental is given in the sense of splitting. The form of the other is not. “Amaññittha” (thought) is “mata.” “Icchīyittha” (desired) is “iṭṭha.” “Abujjhi” (knew) is “buddha.”

original: “dho dhahabhehī”ti tassa dho. Pūjīyitthāti pūjito, curādittā ṇi. Evaṃ sīlīyitthāti🔽sīlito. Rakkhīyitthāti rakkhito. Khamīyitthāti khanto, massa niggahītaṃ. Akkocchīyitthāti🔽akkuṭṭho, āssa rasso. Rusa=rose, arosīti ruṭṭho, “gamanatthā” dinā kattari kto. Ñimhi🔽rusito. Hara=haraṇe, abhi+ vi+āpubbo, abhibyāharīyitthāti abhibyāhaṭo. Daya=dānagatihiṃsādānesu,
analyzed: dho dhaha bhehi iti tassa dho pūjīyittha ati pūjitaḥ curā ādittā ṇi evam sīlīyittha iti  sīlitaḥ rakkhīyittha ati rakkhitaḥ khamīyittha ati khantaḥ massa niggahītam akkocchīyittha ati  akkuṭṭhaḥ āssa rassaḥ rusa rose arosi iti ruṭṭhaḥ gamana atthā dinā kattari ktaḥ ñimhi  rusitaḥ hara haraṇe abhi abhibyāharīyittha ati abhibyāhaṭaḥ daya dāna gati hiṃsā dānesu
translated: “Dho dhahabhehī” means “dho”. Pūjīyitthāti means “pūjito”, the ṇi is elided. Thus sīlīyitthāti means “sīlito”. Rakkhīyitthāti means “rakkhito”. Khamīyitthāti means “khanto”, the -m- is elided. Akkocchīyitthāti means “akkuṭṭho”, the -c- is elided. Rusa=rose, arosīti ruṭṭho, “gamanatthā” means “dinā kattari”, the -r- is elided. Ñimhi means “rusito”. Hara=haraṇe, abhi+ vi+āpubbo, abhibyāharīyitthāti means “abhibyāhaṭo”. Daya=dānagatihiṃsādānesu,

original: adayīyitthāti dayito. Hasa=ālikye, ahasīti haṭṭho. Kāmīyitthāti kanto, “ṇiṇāpīnaṃ🔽tesū”ti ettha “ṇiṇāpīnaṃ”ti yogavibhāgā curādiṇilopo. Saṃyamīti saṃyato. Nañapubbo,🔽na marīti amato, nañasamāse nassa ṭo.
analyzed: adayīyittha iti dayitaḥ ahasi iti haṭṭhaḥ kāmīyittha iti kantaḥ 🔽tesu iti ettha yogavibhāgā curādi ṇi lopaḥ saṃyamī iti saṃyataḥ nañ pubbaḥ 🔽na mari iti a mataḥ naña samāse nassa ṭaḥ
translated: “Dho dhahabhehī” means “dho”. Pūjīyitthāti means “pūjito”, the ṇi is dropped after curādi. Thus sīlīyitthāti means “sīlito”. Rakkhīyitthāti means “rakkhito”. Khamīyitthāti means “khanto”, the massa is elided. Akkocchīyitthāti means “akkuṭṭho”, the āssa is elided. Rusa=rose, arosīti means “ruṭṭho”, “gamanatthā” is added. Ñimhi means “rusito”. Hara=haraṇe, abhi+ vi+āpubbo, abhibyāharīyitthāti means “abhibyāhaṭo”. Daya=dānagatihiṃsādānesu means “dayito”. Hasa=ālikye, ahasīti means “haṭṭho”. Kāmīyitthāti means “kanto”, “ṇiṇāpīnaṃ tesū” means “ṇiṇāpīnaṃ” is the division of the compound, the curādiṇilopa is elided. Saṃyamī means “saṃyato”. Nañapubbo means “na marīti amato”, the ṭo is elided in the compound.

original: Kaṭṭhaṃ dukkhaṃ āpannoti phalabhūte dukkhe kaṭṭhasaddassa vattanato phalassa bhāvittā bhūteyeva kto. Kasa=gatihiṃsāvilekhanesu, akasi=hiṃsīti kaṭṭhaṃ.
analyzed: kaṭṭham dukkham āpanno ti phala bhūte dukkhe kaṭṭha saddassa vattanataḥ phalassa bhāvittā kasa gati hiṃsā vilekhanesu a kasi hiṃsi iti kaṭṭham
translated: The word kaṭṭha is used in the sense of the result, namely, suffering, in the expression kaṭṭhaṃ dukkhaṃ āpanno . The word kaṭṭha is derived from the root ka, to go, with the nominal affix ṭha, and the prefix ak. The root ka has the meanings of going, violence, and scraping.

original: 150. Bhidādito no kta+ktavantūnaṃ
analyzed: bhida āditaḥ na kta ktavantu ūnam
translated: The word kaṭṭha is used in the sense of the result, i.e. suffering, in the phrase kaṭṭhaṃ dukkhaṃ āpanno, thus the kta affix is used in the sense of the result. Kasa=going, hurting, scratching, akasi=he hurt, thus kaṭṭha.

original: Bhidādīhi paresaṃ kta+ktavantūnaṃ tassa no hoti. Ākatigaṇo+yaṃ. “Kto bhāvakammesū”ti
analyzed: bhida ādīhi paresam kta ktavantūnam tassa no hoti ā kati gaṇaḥ yam ktaḥ bhāva kammesu iti
translated: Bhidādīhi paresaṃ kta+ktavantūnaṃ tassa no hoti. Ākatigaṇo+yaṃ. “Kto bhāvakammesū”ti

translated: Ṇo. Upari sabbattha kta+ktavantūnaṃti yojetabbaṃ. Kira = in scattering, akirīyitthāti kiṇṇo. Akirīti kiṇṇavā. Apurīti puṇṇo puṇṇavā. Akhīyitthāti khīṇo. Akhīyīti khīṇavā.

translated: Paricīyittha means ciṇṇa. Paricīyī means ciṇṇavā. And here, because of the rule of permutation, paricita, upacita, etc., are also established.

original: Mucā paresaṃ kta+ktavantūnaṃ tassa ko vā hoti. Muca=mocane, muccīti mukko mutto.🔽Amucīti mukkavā muttavā. Sakko-tiṇvādīsu “i bhī kā” dinā siddhaṃ. Asakkhīti sakko.🔽Kta+ktavantūsu satto sattavātveva hoti.🔽106. Muha+bahānañca te kānubandhe+tve🔽Muha+bahānaṃ duhissa ca dīgho hoti takārādo kānubandhe tvāna+tvāvajjite. Muha=vecitte,🔽baha+braha+brūha vuddhiyaṃ. Muyhitta bayhitthāti mūḷho bāḷho, “gamanatthā” dinā akammakattā
analyzed: mucā paresam kta ktavantūnam tassa kaḥ vā hoti muca mocane muccī iti mukkaḥ muttaḥ  amuci iti mukkavā muttavā sakkotiṇu ādīsu i bhī kā dinā siddham asakkhi iti sakko  kta ktavantūsu hoti  muha baha anañca te ka anubandha itve  duhissa ca dīghaḥ hoti takārāt ka anubandhe muha vecitte  vuddhiyam muyhitta bayhittha ati mūḍhaḥ bāḷhaḥ gamana tthā dinā a kammakattā
translated: “Let him be freed from the debt of others’ debts,” who is he?🔽Muca = in the sense of “to be freed,” one who is freed is mukko, mutto.🔽Amucīti = mukkavā, muttavā. In sakko-tinvādīsu, the form is siddha by i bhī kā. Asakkhīti = sakko.🔽In kta+ktavantūnaṃ, satto becomes sattavātveva.🔽106. And in the case of muha+bahānañca te kānubandhe+tve🔽In the case of muha+bahānaṃ, duhissa, and dīgho, the long vowel is in kānubandhe tvāna+tvāvajjite. Muha = in the sense of “to be deluded,”🔽baha+braha+brūha = in the sense of “to be increased.” Muyhitta bayhitthāti = mūḷho bāḷho. In gamanatthā, because of the absence of the kammadhāraya compound,🔽

original: Dhā=dhāraṇe+timassa hi hoti vā te. Nidhīyitthāti nihito. Nidahīti nihitavā nihitāvī.
analyzed: hi hoti vā te nidhīyittha ati nihitaḥ nidahīti nihitavā nihitāvī
translated: Dhā=in bearing, in the sense of ‘he has’ or ‘they have’. Nidhīyittha = was deposited. Nidahī = he deposited, he caused to be deposited.

original: 109. Gamādirānaṃ lopo+ntassa🔽Gamādīnaṃ rakārantānañca antassa lopo hoti te. Agamīti gato. Khaññitthāti khato,🔽kamme. Evaṃ haññitthāti hato. Tana=vitthāre, taññitthāti tato. Yama=uparame, saṃyamīti
analyzed: gam ādi rānam lopaḥ u ntassa  gama ādīnam rakāra antānam ca antassa lopaḥ hoti te agami iti gataḥ khaññittha ati khataḥ  evam haññittha ati hatas tana vitthāre taññittha ati tatas yama auparame saṃyamī iti
translated: . Of gamā, etc., the final is elided🔽The final of gamā, etc., and of those ending in -ak is elided in te. Agamī = gone. Khaññittha = was cut.

original: saññato, “gamanatthā” dinā kattari kto, “ye saṃssā”ti niggahītassa ño pubbarūpañca.
analyzed: saññataḥ gamana atthāḥ dinā kattari ktaḥ ye saṃssā ti niggahītassa ñaḥ pubbarūpam ca
translated: In the passive. Evaṃ haññittha = was killed. Tana = in the sense of ‘spreading out’, taññittha = from that. Yama = in the sense of ‘ceasing’, saṃyamī = restrained. “Gamanatthā” dinā = in the sense of ‘going’, in the passive, kto. “Ye saṃssā” ti = of the reduplicated aorist, the ño is elided, and the preceding vowel is lengthened.

original: Evaṃ aramīti rato. Karīyitthāti kato.
analyzed: evam aramīti rato karīyittha ati
translated: Evaṃ aramī = was delighted. Karīyittha = was made.

original: 110. Vacādīnaṃ vassu+ṭa vā🔽Vacādīnaṃ vassa uṭa vā hoti kānubandhe atve. Vuccitthāti uttaṃ. Assa u vuttaṃ, ubhayattha🔽pararūpaṃ. Vasa=nivāse, vasanaṃ avasi vasiṃsu etthāti vā utthaṃ vutthaṃ, “gamanatthā”
analyzed: vacā ādīnam vassuṭa vā  vaca ādīnam vassa uṭa vā hoti ka anubandhe a tve uttam assa u vuttam ubhayattha  para rūpam vasa nivāse vasanam avasi vasiṃsu etthā ati vai uttham vuttham gamana atthā
translated: . Of vacā, etc., the final is -u or -a🔽The final of vacā, etc., is -u or -a in the passive. Vuccittha = was said. Assa u vuttaṃ = was said. In both cases

original: dinā kto, “sāsa vasa saṃsa saṃsā tho”ti tassa tho.🔽112. Vaddhassa vā
analyzed: dinā ktaḥ sāsa vasa saṃsa saṃsā tho ti tassa tho 🔽vaddhassa vā
translated: the form of the other is used. Vasa = in the sense of ‘dwelling’, vasanaṃ avasi vasiṃsu ettha = was dwelt, was dwelt here. “Gamanatthā” dinā = in the sense of ‘going’, in the passive, kto. “Sāsa vasa saṃsa saṃsā tho” ti = of that, the tho.

original: Vaddhassa assa vā u hoti kānubandhe atve. Avaddhīti vuddho vaddho, kattari kte “dho
analyzed: vaddhassa assa vā u hoti ka anubandhe a tve vuddhaḥ vaddhaḥ kattari kte dhaḥ
translated: The affix u is added to vaddha in the sense of “to be bound to” (kānu-bandha), and the affix atve is added to avaddhi (vaddha) in the sense of “to be bound to” (kānu-bandha).🔽

original: dha+habhehī”ti tassa dho, tatiyakkharado ca saṃyogādilopo ca. Vuttīti “sabbādayo🔽vuttimatte”ti yogavibhāgā assa u. Vattītipi yathālakkhaṇaṃ.🔽113. Yajassa yassa ṭi+yī
analyzed: dhaha bhehi iti tassa dhaḥ tatiya kkhara daḥ ca saṃyoga ādi lopaḥ ca vutti iti sabba ādayaḥ  vuttimattā iti yogavibhāgāḥ assa u vatti itipi yathālakkhaṇam  yajassa yassa ṭiyī
translated: The form of Vaddha is Vaddho in the passive, and Vaddhassa in the genitive. Vuddho is the form of Vaddha in the nominative, and Vaddhassa in the genitive.🔽The form of Vutti is Vuttī in the nominative, and Vuttassa in the genitive.

original: Yajassa yassa ṭi+yī honti kānubandhe atve. Yajanaṃti kto, “pucchādito”ti tassa ṭhe pararūpādimhi kate iṭṭhaṃ yiṭṭhaṃ.🔽114. Ṭhāssi🔽Ṭhāssa i hoti kānubandhe atve. Aṭṭhāsīti ṭhito.🔽115. Gā+pāna+mī
analyzed: yajassa yassa ṭiyī honti ka anubandhe a tve tassa ṭhe para rūpa ādimhi kate iṭṭham yiṭṭham  ṭhā assi  ṭhāssaḥ i hoti ka anubandhe a tve aṭṭhāsi iti ṭhitaḥ  gāpānamī
translated: The form of Yajja is Yajja in the nominative, and Yajjassa in the genitive.🔽The form of Ṭhāna is Ṭhāna in the nominative, and Ṭhānassa in the genitive.

original: Gā+pāna+mī hoti kānubandhe atve. Gānaṃ gītaṃ. Pānaṃ pītaṃ. Bahulādhikārā pitvā.🔽116. Janissā
analyzed: gā pānamī ka anubandhe a tve gānam gītam pānam pītam bahula adhikārā pitvā  janiḥ sā
translated: The form of Gāyana is Gāyana in the nominative, and Gāyanassa in the genitive.

original: Janissa ā hoti kānubandhe atve. Ajanīti jāto, “chaṭṭhiyantassā”ti antassa ā hoti.
analyzed: janissa ā hoti ka anubandhe a tve ajani iti jātaḥ chaṭṭhiyantassa ati antassa ā hoti
translated: The form of Janita is Janita in the nominative, and Janitassa in the genitive.

original: 117. Sāsassa sisa vā
analyzed: sāsassa sisa vā
translated: The form of Sāsana is Sāsana in the nominative, and Sāsanassa in the genitive.

original: 145. Dho dha+ha+tehi
analyzed: dho dhahata ihi
translated: Dho dha+ha+tehi

original: Dhakāra hakāra bhakārantehi parassa tassa dha hoti. Vaddhitthāti kamme kte tassa
analyzed: dhakāra hakāra bhakāra antehi parassa tassa dha hoti vaddhittha ati kamme kte tassa
translated: Dhakāra hakāra bhakārantehi parassa tassa dha hoti. Vaddhitthāti kamme kte tassa

original: dhakārādimhi ca “vaddhassa vā”ti ukāre kate saṃyogādilopo, vuddho. Duyhitthāti duddhaṃ.
analyzed: dhakāra ādimhi ca vaddhassa vāti ukāre kate saṃyoga ādi lopaḥ vuddhaḥ duyhittha ati duddham
translated: Duyhitthāti = duddhaṃ.

original: Labhīyitthāti laddhaṃ.
analyzed: labhīyittha ati laddham
translated: Labhīyitthāti = laddhaṃ.

original: 146. Dahā ḍho
analyzed: dahā ḍhaḥ
translated: Dahā ḍho

original: Dahā parassā+nantarassa tassa ḍha hoti. Dayhitthāti daḍḍho, pararūpādimhi kate “catutthadutiye” ccādinā ḍakāro.
analyzed: dahā parassa anantarassa tassa ḍha hoti dayhittha ati daḍḍhaḥ para rūpa ādimhi kate catuttha dutiye c c ādinā ḍakāraḥ
translated: The vowel a of the preceding word becomes ḍha after the vowel of the preceding word. Dayhitthāti = daḍḍho. In the case of the form pararūpādimhi, the vowel ḍakāro is added by the rule catutthadutiye.

original: 147. Bahassu+ma ca
analyzed: bahassuma ca
translated: Bahassu+ma ca

original: Bahā parassā+nantarassa tassa ḍha hoti bahassu+ma ca ḍhasanniyogena. Baha+braha+brūha=vuddhiyaṃ. Abahīti buḍḍho.
analyzed: bahā parassa anantarassa tassa ḍha hoti ca ḍha sanniyogena baha braha brūha vuddhiyam a bahi iti buḍḍhaḥ
translated: The vowel a of the preceding word becomes ḍha after the vowel of the preceding word, in the case of bahassu+ma, by the combination of ḍha and the preceding vowel. Baha+braha+brūha = vuddhiyaṃ. Abahīti = buḍḍho.

original: 148. Ruhādīhi ho ḷa ca
analyzed: ruha ādi hi haḥ ḷa ca
translated: Ruhādīhi ho ḷa ca

original: Ruhādīhi parassā+nantarassa tassa ha hoti ḷo ca+ntassa. Āruhīti āruḷho. Guyhitthāti guḷho. Abahīti bāḷho. Dvīsu “muhabahā” dinā dīgho.
analyzed: ruha ādīhi parassa anantarassa tassa ha hoti ḷaḥ ca antassa āruhi iti āruḷhaḥ guyhittha ati guḷhaḥ dvīsu muha bahā dinā dīghaḥ
translated: The vowel ha of the preceding word becomes ḷo after the vowel of the preceding word, in the case of the words beginning with ruha. Āruhīti = āruḷho. Guyhitthāti = guḷho. Abahīti = bāḷho. In the case of the forms dvīsu “muhabahā”, the vowel is lengthened.

original: 149. Muhā vāti
analyzed: muhā vāti
translated: Muhā vāti

original: Ktatassa hakāro antassa vā ḷo ca. Amohīti muḷho, muddho, tassa dho. (Atītakālikapaccayavidhānaṃ).
analyzed: kta tassa hakāraḥ antassa vā ḷaḥ ca muḷhaḥ muddhaḥ tassa dhaḥ atīta kālika paccaya vidhānam
translated: The vowel ha of the preceding word becomes ḷo after the vowel of the preceding word. Amohīti = muḷho, muddho. The vowel of the preceding word becomes ḍho. (The rule for the past tense and the conditions of the verb).

original: 64. Nto kattari vattamāne
analyzed: n taḥ kattari vattamāne
translated: Nto kattari vattamāne

original: Vattamānatthe vattamānato kriyatthā nto hoti kattari. Tiṭṭhatīti tiṭṭhanto, “kattari lo”ti lo, “ṭhāpānaṃ tiṭṭhapivā”ti tiṭhādeso. Kattari māna+nta+tyādisu imināva lo.
analyzed: vattamāna atthe vattamānataḥ kriya tthā ntaḥ hoti kattari tiṭṭhati iti tiṭṭhantaḥ kattari lo ti lo ṭhā pānam tiṭṭha ādesaḥ kattari
translated: In the sense of the present state, the present participle is formed from the present tense by adding -anto to the agent noun. “He stands” = tiṭṭhanto. “To the agent lo” = lo. “To the causative of ṭhā” = tiṭhādeso. In the case of māna, -nta, -tya, etc., the lo is formed by this very rule.

original: 65. Mānoti
analyzed: mā anoti
translated: . Māna

original: Kattari māno. Tiṭṭhamāno.
analyzed: kattari mānaḥ tiṭṭhamānaḥ
translated: To the agent māna is added. Tiṭṭhamāno.

original: 66. Bhāvakammesuti
analyzed: bhāva kammesu ti
translated: . Bhāva, kamma

original: Bhāvakammesu māno. Ṭhānaṃ ṭhīyamānaṃ. “Kyo bhāvakammesva+parokkhesu māna+nta+tyādīsū”ti bhāve kamme ca kyo. “Kyassā”ti īma. Pacīyatīti paccamā no. Kye pubbarūpaṃ.
analyzed: bhāva kammesu mānaḥ ṭhānam ṭhīyamānam kyaḥ bhāva kammesu aparokkhesu mānanta tyādīsu iti bhāve kamme ca kyaḥ kyassa ati īma pacīyati iti paccamā no kye pubbarūpam
translated: In the case of bhāva and kamma, māna is added. Ṭhānaṃ ṭhīyamānaṃ. “Kyo bhāvakammesva+parokkhesu māna+nta+tyādīsū”ti bhāve kamme ca kyo. “Kyassā”ti īma. Pacīyati = paccamāno. Kye pubbarūpaṃ.

original: 67. Te ssapubbā+nāgate🔽Anāgate atthe vattamānato kriyatthā tentamānā ssapubbā honti, le āssa lopo, ṭhassatīti
analyzed: te ssa pubba anāgate  anāgate atthe vattamānataḥ kriyatthā tentamānāḥ ssapubbāḥ honti le āssa lopaḥ ṭhassati iti
translated: . Te ssapubbā+nāgate

original: ṭhassanto ṭhassamāno. Ṭhīyissatīti ṭhīyissamānaṃ, kye ī, “ñibyañjanassā”ti ñi. Assa
analyzed: ṭhassantaḥ ṭhassamānaḥ ṭhīyissati iti ṭhīyissamānam kye ī ñi byañjanassa ati ñi assa
translated: In the future, the present participle is formed from the present tense by adding -anto to the agent noun, and the -le is elided. Ṭhassatīti ṭhassanto ṭhassamāno. Ṭhīyissatīti ṭhīyissamānaṃ. Kye ī. “Ñibyañjanassā”ti ñi. Assa

analyzed: dinā iña na hoti saha carita ttā ssa assa paccissati iti
translated: tyādivisayattā “āīssā” dinā iña na hoti, aīhi sahacaritattā ssāssa. Paccissatīti🔽.

original: paccissamāno odano. “Rā nassa ṇo”ti ṇe patte –
analyzed: paccissamānaḥ odanaḥ rā nassa ṇo ti ṇe patte
translated: is rice that is being cooked. In the locative case of the word ‘rā’ (in the word ‘rā nassa’),

original: 5,172. Na nta+māna+tyādīnaṃ
analyzed: na nta māna tya ādīnam
translated: . The ‘na’ of ‘na nta+māna+tyādīnaṃ’

original: Rantato paresaṃ nta+māna+tyādīnaṃ nassa ṇo na hoti. Karotīti karonto kurumāno, “tanāditvo”ti o.
analyzed: ra ntataḥ paresam nta māna ti ādīnam nassa ṇaḥ na hoti karoti iti karontaḥ kurumānaḥ
translated: The ‘na’ of ‘na nta+māna+tyādīnaṃ’ is not ‘na’ when it is at the end of a word. ‘Karotī’ (he makes) = ‘karonto’ (making), ‘kurumāno’ (making). ‘Tanāditvo’ (the ‘a’ is lengthened).

original: 5,173. Gama yami+sāsa disānaṃ vā cchaṅa
analyzed: gama yamisāsa disānam vā chaṅa
translated: . ‘Gama yami+sāsa disānaṃ vā cchaṅa’

original: Etesaṃ vā cchaṅa hoti nta+māna+tyādīsu. Ṅa-nubandhattā antassa hoti, gacchanto gacchamāno.
analyzed: etesam vā hoti nta māna tya ādīsu ṅ anubandha ttā antassa hoti gacchantaḥ gacchamānaḥ
translated: The ‘cchaṅ’ is added to these (words) in ‘nta+māna+tyādīsu’. Because of the ‘ṅa’ that follows, the ‘a’ has ‘ho’ (i.e. ‘gacchanto’ (going), ‘gacchamāno’ (going).

original: Yama=uparame, yacchanto yacchamāno. Icchanto icchamāno. Āsa=upavesane, acchanto acchamāno,
analyzed: yama auparame yacchantaḥ yacchamānaḥ icchantaḥ icchamānaḥ āsa upavesane acchantaḥ acchamānaḥ
translated: ‘Yama’ = ‘uparame’ (ceasing), ‘yacchanto’ (ceasing), ‘yacchamāno’ (ceasing). ‘Icchanto’ (desiring), ‘icchamāno’ (desiring). ‘Āsa’ = ‘upavesane’ (sitting down), ‘acchanto’ (sitting down), ‘acchamāno’ (sitting down).

original: “byañjane”ccādinā rasso. Disa=atisajjane, dicchanto dicchamāno. Vavatthitavibhāsattā
analyzed: byañjana icca ādinā rassaḥ disa ati sajjane dicchantaḥ dicchamānaḥ
translated: By the rule ‘byañjane’ (the ‘a’ is shortened). ‘Disa’ = ‘atisajjane’ (going beyond), ‘dicchanto’ (going beyond), ‘dicchamāno’ (going beyond). Because of the ‘vavatthitavibhāsatta’ (the ‘a’ is lengthened).

original: vāsaddassa aññapaccayesu ca kvaci, icchīyatīti icchitabbaṃ, icchanaṃ icchā, “itthiya+maṇā”
analyzed: vā saddassa añña paccayesu ca kvaci icchīyati iti icchitabbam icchanam icchā itthiyamaṇā
translated: And because of the ‘vāsaddassa aññapaccayesu ca kvaci’ (the ‘a’ is lengthened). ‘Icchīyati’ (is desired) = ‘icchitabbaṃ’ (should be desired), ‘icchanaṃ’ (desire). ‘Itthiya+maṇā’ (the ‘a’ is lengthened).

original: dinā appaccayo. Icchitaṃ, icchitabbaṃ, icchituṃ. Aññesañca yogavibhāgā, pavecchanto.🔽174. Jara+marāna+mīyaṅa
analyzed: dinā ap paccayaḥ icchitam icchitabbam icchitum aññesam ca yogavibhāgā 🔽jara mara anam īyaṅa
translated: By the rule ‘dinā appaccayo’ (the ‘a’ is lengthened). ‘Icchitaṃ’ (desired), ‘icchitabbaṃ’ (should be desired), ‘icchituṃ’ (to desire). And because of the ‘aññesañca yogavibhāgā’ (the ‘a

original: Etesa+mīyaṅa vā hoti nta+māna+tyādīsu. Jīyanto. “Jarasadā” diccādinā īma. Jīranto. Jīyamāno jīramāno. Mīyanto maranto, mīyamāno maramāno.🔽175. Ṭhāpānaṃ tiṭṭhapivā🔽Ṭhāpānaṃ tiṭṭhapivā honti vā ntādīsu. Tiṭṭhanto, tiṭṭhamāno. Pivanto pivamāno.🔽176. Gama+vada+dānaṃ ghamma+vajja+dajjā

translated: In the case of these, the forms are īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ, īyaṃ

Gheppanto gheppamāno.🔽179. Ṇo niggahītassa

original: Gahassa niggahītassa ṇo hoti, “maṃ vā rudhādīnaṃ”ti maṃ, gaṇhitabbaṃ, gaṇhituṃ, gaṇhanto.
analyzed: gahassa niggahītassa ṇo hoti mam vā mam gaṇhitabbam gaṇhitum gaṇhantaḥ
translated: The affix ṇo is added to gah, which is governed by a preposition, “maṃ, etc.,” maṃ, gaṇhitabbaṃ, gaṇhituṃ, gaṇhanto.

original: 130. Nta+māna+nti+yi+yuṃsvā+dilopoti
analyzed: nta mān anti yi yum su ādi lopa uti
translated: . Nta+māna+nti+yi+yuṃsvā+dilopoti

original: Ādilopo. Asa=bhuvi, bhavatīti santo samāno.
analyzed: ādi lopaḥ bhavati iti santaḥ samānaḥ
translated: The affix ā is added to the root, “asa=bhuvi, bhavatīti santo samāno.”

original: 131. Pādito ṭhāssa vā ṭhaho kvaciti
analyzed: pā t itaḥ ṭha a ssa vā ṭha haḥ kvacid
translated: . Pādito ṭhāssa vā ṭhaho kvaciti

original: Ṭhāssa pādīsu ṭhaho. Saṇṭhahanto. Santiṭṭhanto.
analyzed: pādīsu ṭhahaḥ saṇṭhahantaḥ santiṭṭhantaḥ
translated: The affix ṭhaho is added to ṭhā in the sense of “pādīsu,” saṇṭhahanto, santiṭṭhanto.

original: (Vattamānapaccayantanayo).
analyzed: vattamāna paccaya ntanayaḥ
translated: (The method of the present participle.)

original: 61. Tuṃ tāye tave bhāve bhavissati kriyāyaṃ tadatthāyaṃ
analyzed: tum tāye tave bhāve bhavissati kriyāyam
translated: . Tuṃ tāye tave bhāve bhavissati kriyāyaṃ tadatthāyaṃ

original: Bhavissatiatthe vattamānato kriyatthā bhāve tumādayo honti kriyāyaṃ tadatthāyaṃ patīyamānāyaṃ.🔽Karaṇāya gacchati kātuṃ gacchati. “Tuṃtunatabbesu vā”ti karassa vā ā hoti, pubbarūpe
analyzed: bhavissati atthe vattamānataḥ kriyatthāḥ bhāve tum ādayaḥ honti kriyā ayam tad atthā ayam patīyamānā ayam  karaṇāya gacchati kātum gacchati vā ati karassa vā ā hoti pubbarūpe
translated: The affixes tum, etc., are added to the present participle in the sense of “bhavissati,” in the sense of “bhāve,” in the sense of “kriyā,” and in the sense of “tadatthāyaṃ,” when the action is being considered.

original: kattāye. “Karassā tave”ti niccaṃ ā, kātave. Nipātattā “asaṅkhyehi sabbāsaṃ”ti catutthīsassa
analyzed: kattāye karassā tava iti niccam ā kātave nipāta ttā asaṅkhyehi catutthīsassa
translated: He goes to do, he goes to make. “Tuṃtunatabbesu vā” means that the affix ā is added to kara, “karassā tave” means that ā is always added, “kātave.” Because of the indeclinable, “asaṅkhyehi sabbāsaṃ” means that the fourth case is elided.

original: lopo. Eva+mupari tunādīsu. Kattuṃ kāmetīti kattukāmo, abhisaṅkharitu+mākaṅkhati.
analyzed: lopaḥ evam upari tuna ādīsu kattum kāmeti iti kattu kāmaḥ abhisaṅkharitum ākaṅkhati
translated: Thus also in the affixes tun, etc., above. He desires to do, he desires to make. He longs to form.

original: Saddhammaṃ suṇituṃ, ñimhi nāgame tassa ṇo, nāgamattā na vuddhi. Sotave sotuṃ suṇituṃ
analyzed: saddhammam suṇitum ñimhi na āgame tassa no na āgamattā na vuddhi sotave sotum suṇitum
translated: To hear the true Dhamma, I wish to go to him, I have no increase in going only. To hear, to listen, to hear.

original: vā patthehi. Evaṃ anubhavituṃ, pacituṃ. Gantuṃ, “manānaṃ niggahītaṃ”ti niggahītaṃ.
analyzed: vā patthehi evam anubhavitum pacitum gantum manānam niggahītam ti niggahītam
translated: To desire to experience, to digest, to go, “The mind is restrained” = restrained.

original: Gamituṃ, khantuṃ, khanituṃ, hantuṃ, hanituṃ, mantuṃ, manituṃ, harituṃ, anussarituṃ
analyzed: gamitum khantum khanitum hantum hanitum mantum manitum haritum anussaritum
translated: To go, to endure, to dig, to kill, to kill, to chant, to think, to take away, to remember

original: icchati. Tathā tudituṃ, pavisituṃ, uddisituṃ, bhottuṃ, sayituṃ, netuṃ, juhotuṃ, pajahituṃ,
analyzed: icchati tathā tuditum pavisitum uddisitum bhottum sayitum netum juhotum pajahitum
translated: Thus to strike, to enter, to point out, to eat, to lie down, to lead, to offer, to abandon,

original: pahātuṃ, dātuṃ, roddhuṃ, rundhituṃ, bhottuṃ, bhuñjītuṃ, chettuṃ, chindituṃ, sibbituṃ,
analyzed: pahātum dātum roddhum rundhitum bhottum bhuñjītum chettum chinditum sibbitum
translated: To spit out, to give, to block, to block, to eat, to eat, to cut, to cut, to cut,

original: ūmhi vassa bo, dvittaṃ, buddhuṃ, tassa dho. Bujjhituṃ, yuka. Jānituṃ ñā=avabodhane.🔽Janituṃ. Jetuṃ jinituṃ. Pattuṃ pāpuṇituṃ. Ketuṃ kiṇituṃ. Vinicchetuṃ, issa e, vinicchinituṃ.
analyzed: ūmhi vassa baḥ dvittam buddhum tassa dhaḥ bujjhitum jānitum ñā avabodhane  janitum jetum jinitum pattum pāpuṇitum ketum kiṇitum vinicchetum vinicchinitum
translated: In the present tense, there is bo, the second, to awaken, its dho. To awaken, yuka. To know, ñā = in the sense of understanding.🔽To be born. To conquer, to conquer. To attain, to reach. To take, to buy. To decide, issa e, to decide.

original: Gahetuṃ gaṇhituṃ. Corituṃ coretuṃ corayituṃ, pāletuṃ pālayituṃ. Payojake-bhāvetuṃ
analyzed: gahetum gaṇhitum coritum coretum corayitum pāletum pālayitum payojaka ibhāvetum
translated: To take, to take. To steal, to steal, to steal, to protect, to protect. In the causative - to develop,

original: bhāvayituṃ, kāretuṃ kārayituṃ kārāpetuṃ kārāpayituṃ icchati+ccādi.
analyzed: bhāvayitum kāretum kārayitum kārāpetum kārāpayitum icchat icca ādi
translated: wishes to make, to have made, to have made by another, to have made by many others, etc.

original: Evaṃ kriyatthakriyāyaṃ gamyamānāyaṃ, yathā suboddhuṃ vakkhāmi, evaṃ daṭṭhuṃ gacchati, gantu+mārabhati, gantuṃ payojeti, dassetu+māha iccādi.🔽Arahasakkādīsupi siddhaṃ, tathā kāla samayavelāsu. Ko taṃ ninditu+marahati, rājā🔽bhavitu+marahati, araho bhavaṃ vattuṃ, sakkā jetuṃ dhanena vā, sakkā laddhuṃ, bhassa🔽dho. Kattuṃ sakkhissati. Bhabbo niyāmaṃ okkamituṃ, abhabbo kātuṃ. Anucchaviko bhavaṃ
analyzed: evam kriyattha kriyā ayam gamyamānā ayam yathā su boddhum vakkhāmi evam daṭṭhum gacchati gantum ārabhati gantum payojā iti dassetum āha iccādi  siddham tathā kāla samaya velāsu kaḥ tam ninditum arahati rājā  bhavitum arahati araho bhavam vattum sakkā jetum dhanena vā sakkā laddhum  dho kattum sakkhissati bhabbaḥ niyāmam okkamitum abhabbaḥ kātum anucchavikaḥ bhavam
translated: Thus, when the meaning of action is being conveyed by the verbal noun, I shall explain it so that it may be easily understood. As in: “He goes to see,” “He undertakes to go,” “He sends to go,” “He says to show,” etc.

original: dānaṃ paṭiggahetuṃ, idaṃ kātuṃ anurūpaṃ, dānaṃ dātuṃ yuttaṃ, dātuṃ vattuñca labhati.🔽Evaṃ vaṭṭati bhāsituṃ, chindituṃ na ca kappati iccādi. Tathākālo bhuñjituṃ, samayo
analyzed: dānam paṭiggahetum idam kātum anurūpam dānam dātum yuttam dātum vattum ca labhati  evam vaṭṭati bhāsitum chinditum na ca kappati iccādi tathā kālaḥ bhuñjitum samayaḥ
translated: It is also established in such words as “worthy,” “able,” etc., and likewise in “time,” “occasion,” “moment,” etc. As in: “Who is there that may blame him?” “He may become king,” “He is worthy to speak,” “He is able to conquer with wealth,” “He is able to obtain,” “He is able to do,” “He will be able to do,” “He is able to enter into the certainty of rightness,” “He is unable to do,” “He is worthy to receive,” “This is suitable to do,” “It is proper to give,” “It is proper to say,” “He obtains the right to say,”

original: bhuñjituṃ, velā bhuñjituṃ.
analyzed: bhuñjitum velā bhuñjitum
translated: “It is proper to speak thus,” “It is not proper to cut,” etc. As in: “It is time to eat,” “It is the occasion to eat,” “It is the moment to eat,”

original: Alamatthepi siddhaṃ, alameva dānāni dātuṃ, alameva puññāni kātuṃ.🔽62. Paṭisedhe+laṃkhalūnaṃ ktuna ktvāna ktvā vā🔽Alaṃ+khalusaddānaṃ paṭisedhanatthānaṃ payoge ktunādayo vā honti bhāve. Alaṃpubbo,🔽su=savane, alaṃ savanaṃ katvā khalu savanaṃ katvāti alaṃ sotuna khalu sotuna alaṃ🔽sutvāna khalu sutvāna alaṃ sutvā khalu sutvā. Nipātattā silopo.🔽63. Pubbe+kakattukānaṃ
analyzed: alam atthe pi siddham alam eva dānāni dātum alam eva puññāni kātum  paṭisedha ilaṃkhalūnam vā  alam khalu saddānam paṭisedhana tthānam payoge ktuna ādayaḥ vā honti bhāve alam pubbaḥ  su savane alam savanam katvā khalu savanam katvā ati alam sotunā khalu sotunā alam  khalu sutvāna alam sutvā khalu sutvā si lopaḥ  pubba eka kattukānam
translated: “It is enough” is established even in the sense of “not enough”, it is enough to give gifts, it is enough to perform meritorious deeds.

original: Eko kattā yesaṃ byāpārānaṃ, tesu yo pubbo, tadatthato kriyatthā tunādayo honti bhāve.🔽“Tuṃtunā” dinā karassa ā, so kātuna kammaṃ gacchati, akātuna puññaṃ kilissanti. Ralope🔽kammaṃ katvāna bhadrakaṃ, puññāni katvā saggaṃ gacchati. Abhisaṅkharaṇaṃ katvā abhisaṅkharitvā
analyzed: ekaḥ kattā yesam byāpārānam tesu yaḥ pubbaḥ tad atthataḥ tuna ādayaḥ honti bhāve 🔽tuṃtunā dinā karassa ā saḥ kātuna kammam gacchati a kātuna puññam ra lope 🔽kammam katvāna bhadrakam puññāni katvā saggam gacchati abhisaṅkharaṇam katvā abhisaṅkharitvā

original: karitvā vā. Tathā sibbitvā chādayitvā jānitvā dhammaṃ sutvā sutvāna dhammaṃ modati,
analyzed: karitvā vā tathā sibbitvā chādayitvā jānitvā dhammam sutvā sutvāna dhammam modati
translated: and having done. So too, having scratched, having covered, having known, having heard the Dhamma, having heard the Dhamma, he delights,

original: suṇitvā, patvā pāpuṇitvā, kinitvā, jetvā jinitvā jitvā, coretvā corayitvā, pūjetvā
analyzed: suṇitvā patvā pāpuṇitvā kinitvā jetvā jinitvā jitvā coretvā corayitvā pūjetvā
translated: having listened, having gone, having reached, having bought, having conquered, having won, having stolen, having worshipped,

original: pūjayitvā, tathā mettaṃ bhāvetvā bhāvayitvā, vihāraṃ kāretvā kārayitvā kārāpetvā
analyzed: pūjayitvā tathā mettam bhāvetvā bhāvayitvā vihāram kāretvā kārayitvā kārāpetvā
translated: having worshipped, so too, having developed loving-kindness, having developed, having caused a dwelling to be made, having caused to be made, having caused to be made,

original: kārāpayitvā saggaṃ gamissanti+ccādi. Pubbeti kiṃ, bhuñjati ca pacati ca. “Apatvā
analyzed: kārāpayitvā saggam gamissanti iccādi pubba iti kim bhuñjati ca pacati ca a patvā
translated: having caused to be made, they will go to heaven. What is the past tense? He eats and he cooks. “Without reaching

original: nadiṃ pabbato, atikkamma pabbataṃ nadī”tiādīsu bhūdhātussa sambhavā ekakattukatā
analyzed: nadim pabbataḥ atikkamma pabbatam nadī iti ādīsu bhū dhātussa sambhavāḥ eka kattuka tā
translated: the river, the mountain; having crossed the mountain, the river,” etc.—in these instances the past tense is used for the sake of the unity of the sentence and for the sake of the past time of the earth element.

original: pubbakālatā ca gamyate. “Bhutvā bhutvā gacchatī”ti imināva siddhaṃ, ābhikkhaññantu
analyzed: pubba kāla tā ca gamyate bhutvā bhutvā gacchati iti iminā ava siddham
translated: It is established by this very expression “having eaten, he goes.” But the past tense is understood

original: dvibbacanāva gamyate. Kathaṃ “jīvaggāhaṃ agāhayi, kāyappacālakaṃ gacchatī”ti, ghaṇantena
analyzed: dvip bacanā ava gamyate katham jīva gāham agāhayi kāya ppacālakam gacchati iti ghaṇ antena
translated: in the expression “having gone.” How? “He seized the life-principle; he goes, the body following.” It is established by the verbal noun

original: kriyāvisesanena siddhaṃ, yathā odanapākaṃ sayatīti.
analyzed: kriyā visesanena siddham yathā odana pākam sayati iti
translated: expressing the action. As in “He goes to the cooked rice.”

original: 164. Pyo vā tvāssa samāse
analyzed: pyaḥ vā samāse
translated: . Or the past tense is used in a compound.

original: Tvāssa vā pyo hoti samāse. Pakāro “pye sissā”ti visesanattho. Abhipubbo pādisamāso, abhivadanaṃ katvā abhivādiya bhāsissaṃ. Tathā abhibhuyya, dvittarassāni. Si=saye –
analyzed: vā pyaḥ hoti samāse pakāraḥ pye sissāti visesana atthaḥ abhipubbaḥ pādi samāsaḥ abhivadanam katvā abhivādiya bhāsissam tathā abhibhuyya dvittarassāni sisaye
translated: Or the particle vā is added to the compound. The prefix pakāro is for the purpose of distinguishing. The prefix abhipubbo is a compound with pādi, after paying homage, having paid homage, I will speak. Likewise, having overcome, having the second case endings.

original: 88. Pye sissā
analyzed: pye sissā
translated: . Pye sissā

original: Sissa ā hoti pyādese. Nissayanaṃ katvā nissāya. Pubbarūpe vibhajja vibhajiya. Disa=atisajjane,
analyzed: si ssaḥ ā hoti pi ādese nissayanam katvā nissāya pubbarūpe vibhajja vibhajiya disa atisajjane
translated: Ā is added to sissa in the sense of “after”. Having made a basis, having a basis. Having divided the prior form, having divided. Disa = in the sense of “going beyond”,

original: uddissa. Pavissa pavisiya pavisitvā, upanaya, atiseyya atisayitvā, ohāya ohitvā.
analyzed: uddissa pavissa pavisiya pavisitvā upanaya atiseyya atisayitvā ohāya ohitvā
translated: aiming at. Having entered, having entered in, having entered, having led up, having gone beyond, having gone beyond, having given up, having given up.

original: Ādāya, dāssi+yaṅa, ādiya. Paṭṭhāya, viceyya, viññāya vijānitvā, samāseti kiṃ, patvā.
analyzed: ādāya dāssiyaṅaḥ ādiya paṭṭhāya viceyya viññāya vijānitvā samāseti kim patvā
translated: Having taken, having taken up, having taken up. Beginning with, having examined, having known, having understood, what is compounded? Having gone.

original: Kvacā+ samāsepi bahulādhikārā, lataṃ dantehi chindiya. Tathā bhuñjitvā.
analyzed: tathā bhuñjitvā
translated: And in some cases, even in a compound, by the general principle, having cut the creeper with the teeth. Likewise, having eaten.

original: 165. Tuṃ+yānā
analyzed: tuṃyānā
translated: . Tuṃ+yānā

original: Tvāssa vā tuṃ+yānā honti samāse kvaci. Abhiharaṇaṃ katvā abhihaṭṭhuṃ, abhiharitvā,
analyzed: vā tuṃyānāḥ honti samāse kvaci abhiharaṇam katvā abhihaṭṭhum abhiharitvā
translated: Tvāssa vā tuṃ+yānā are in some cases added to the compound. Having carried off, in order to carry off, having carried off,

original: pādisamāso, “pucchādito”ti tassa ṭho pararūpādi ca. Anumodanaṃ katvā anumodiyāna
analyzed: pa ādi samāsaḥ tassa ṭhaḥ para rūpa ādi ca anumodanam katvā
translated: the compound with pādi. “From pucchādi” is its form in the other case, etc. Having rejoiced, rejoicing,🔽.

original: anumoditvā vā, kānubandhepi “vā kvacī”ti vikappattā “lahussupantassā”ti okāro. Kvacā+samāsepi
analyzed: anumoditvā vā vā kvaci iti vikappattā okāraḥ
translated: Or, after the word anumoditvā, and in kānubandhe, the vowel a is vikappatta, and the vowel o is okāro.🔽In kvacā+samāsepi, the vowel a is bahulādhikārā, and the vowel o is daṭṭhuṃ, disato tvāssa tumādese disassa dasa.

original: bahulādhikārā, daṭṭhuṃ, disato tvāssa tumādese disassa dasa. Aññatra “disā vāna+vā
analyzed: bahula adhikārāḥ daṭṭhum disataḥ tum ādese disassa dasa aññatra disā
translated: Aññatra “disā vāna+vā

original: sa cā”ti tvāssa vāna+vā sa honti, disvā. Evaṃ labhanaṃ katvā laddhā dhanaṃtiādīsu tassa dho bhavati.
analyzed: sa ca ati sa honti disvā evam labhanam katvā laddhā tassa dhaḥ bhavati
translated: sa cā”ti tvāssa vāna+vā sa honti, disvā. Having obtained in this way, the wealth obtained, etc., in these, the vowel a becomes dho.

original: Iti payogasiddhiyaṃ khādikaṇḍo sattamo.
analyzed: iti kha ādi kaṇḍaḥ sattamaḥ
translated: Thus ends the seventh chapter in the treatise called “The Establishment of Grammar” which is the commentary on the first chapter.

original: Payogasiddhi nigamanaṃ
translated: The conclusion of the establishment of grammar

original: Ye nantatantaratanākaramanthanena,
analyzed: ye nanta tanta ratana ākara manthanena
translated: By the churning of the ocean of the three jewels,

original: Manthācalollasitañāṇavarena laddhā;
analyzed: mantha acala ullasita ñāṇa varena laddhā
translated: The supreme jewel of knowledge was obtained by the noble one,

original: Sārāmatā+tisukhitā sukhayanti ca+ññe,
analyzed: sukhayanti caññe
translated: Which brings about the highest bliss and delights others,

original: Te me jayanti guravo guravo guṇehi.
analyzed: te me jayanti guravaḥ guravaḥ guṇehi
translated: May those gurus, who are victorious by their virtues, be victorious.

original: Yassa sādhuguṇubbhūta-kitti sabbatta patthaṭā;
analyzed: yassa patthaṭā
translated: Whose fame, which is the essence of good qualities, is well-known to all,

original: Moggallāno mahāpañño, jayatī so ha sabbadā.
analyzed: moggallānaḥ mahā paññaḥ jayati saḥ ha sabbadā
translated: The one with great wisdom, Moggallāna, may he always be victorious.

original: Paramappicchatā+neka-santosūpasamesinaṃ;🔽Sucisalekhavuttīnaṃ, sadā+raññanivāsinaṃ.
analyzed: param  su cisa lekha vuttīnam sa dārañña nivāsinam
translated: For those who are content with few desires, who are peaceful,🔽Who have pure conduct, who always dwell in delight,

original: Sāsanujotakārīna+māceratta+mupāgataṃ;
analyzed: sā sanujā uta kārīnam ācerat tam upāgatam
translated: For those who illuminate the Dispensation, who have attained the state of a red lotus,

original: Udumbaragirīkhyātā+yatanaṃ yatipuṅgavaṃ.
analyzed: udumbara giri īkhyāta āyatanam yati puṅgavam
translated: The abode of the chief of ascetics, known as Udumbaragiri,

original: Medhaṅkaroti ākhyāta-nāmadheyyaṃ tapodhanaṃ;
analyzed: medhaṅkaroti ākhyāta nāmadheyyam tapodhanam
translated: The one called Medhaṅkara, the one with the wealth of austerities,

original: Theraṃ thiradayā medhā-nidhānaṃ sādhu pūjitaṃ.🔽Sissaṃ sahāya+māgamma, kalyāṇamitta+mattano;
analyzed: theram thira dayā medhā nidhānam sādhu pūjitam  sissam sahāyam āgamma kalyāṇa mittam attano
translated: The elder, the one with a firm heart, the treasure of wisdom, was well worshipped.🔽Having come to his disciple, his friend, his good friend,

original: Sodhetuṃ sāsanaṃ satthu, parakkama+makāsi yo.
analyzed: sodhetum sāsanam satthu parakkamam akāsi yaḥ
translated: He made an effort to purify the Teacher’s Dispensation.

original: Saṅgharakkhitanāmena, mahātherena dhīmatā;
analyzed: saṅgharakkhita nāmena mahā therena dhīmatā
translated: By the wise great elder named Saṅgharakkhita,

original: Nivāsabhūtenā+neka-guṇāna+ppicchatādinaṃ.
analyzed: nivāsa bhūtena aneka guṇān appiccha tā dinam
translated: The resident of many qualities, such as generosity,

original: Moggallānabyākaraṇa-payogakkamasādhakā;🔽Ettāvatā katā esā, payogasiddhi niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: ettāvatā katā esā payoga siddhi niṭṭhitā
translated: The one who accomplished the effort of the application of the prediction of Moggallāna,🔽Up to this point, this application has been accomplished, the accomplishment of application is finished.

original: Teneva racitā sādhu, sāsanodayakārinā;
analyzed: tena iva racitā sādhu sa āsana udaya kārinā
translated: Well composed by him, the one who acts for the rise of the Dispensation,

original: Khuddasikkhāya ṭīkā ca, tathā sambandhacintanā.
analyzed: khudda sikkhāya ṭīkā ca tathā sambandha cintanā
translated: The commentary on the Khuddaka training rules, and likewise the consideration of the connection,

original: Susaddasiddhiṃ yo yoga-nicchayaṃ sabbhi vaṇṇitaṃ;
analyzed: susaddasiddhim yaḥ yoganicchayam vaṇṇitam
translated: The one who composed the well-known accomplishment of correct speech, praised by all,

original: Akā subodhālaṅkāraṃ, tathā sambandhacintanaṃ.
analyzed: subodha alaṅkāram tathā sambandha cintanam
translated: The one who made the Subodhālaṅkāra, and likewise the consideration of the connection,

original: Satthasañcitapuññena, nibbānasādhakaṃ hitaṃ;
analyzed: sattha sañcita puññena nibbāna sādhakam hitam
translated: By the merit accumulated by the Teacher, beneficial for the attainment of Nibbāna,

original: Sādhento lokanāthassa, saddhammo tiṭṭhataṃ ciranti.
analyzed: sādhentaḥ lokanāthassa saddhammaḥ tiṭṭhatam ciranti
translated: Attaining the true Dhamma of the Lord of the World to remain for a long time.

original: Iti saṅgharakkhitamahāsāmitherapādaviracitā
analyzed: iti saṅgharakkhita mahā sāmithera pāda viracitā
translated: Thus composed by the Elder Saṅgharakkhita Mahāsāmī.

original: Payogasiddhi niṭṭhitā.
translated: Thus ends the Payoga-Siddhi composed by the Elder Saṅgharakkhita the Great.

original: (Visesalakkhaṇaṃ). Yathāvuttānaṃ pana payogasiddhinigamana gāthānaṃ ekādasannaṃ pubbeyeva
analyzed: visesa lakkhaṇam yathā vuttānam pana payoga siddhi nigamana gāthānam
translated: (The Special Characteristics). But before the eleven verses of the Payoga-Siddhi-Nigamana, as stated above,

original: vakkhamānā imā gāthāyo dissanti porāṇe sīhaḷamūlapayogasiddhipāṭhe. Tā ca gāthāyo🔽pacchā sīhaḷamūlapayogasiddhisaṃsodhakena medhaṅkaroti garūhi gahitanāmadheyyena
analyzed: vakkhamānāḥ imāḥ gāthāyaḥ dissanti porāṇe tā ca gāthāyaḥ  pacchā sīhaḷa mūla payoga siddhi saṃsodhakena medhaṅkaroti garūhi gahita nāmadheyyena
translated: these verses are found in the ancient Sinhalese root text of the Payoga-Siddhi. And those verses

original: therena pakkhittāti veditabbā, tasmā mayaṃ tā gāthāyo sabbapacchāyeva imasmiṃ-ṭhāne
analyzed: therena pakkhittā ati veditabbā tasmā mayam tāḥ gāthāyaḥ imasmiṃṭhāne
translated: should be known as inserted by the Elder Medhaṅkara, who later took the name Garu, when he was revising the Sinhalese root text of the Payoga-Siddhi. Therefore we place those verses

original: ṭhapema. Tā pana gāthāyo katamāti ce –🔽Cāgavikkamasaddhānu-sampannaguṇasāmino;
analyzed: ṭhapema tā pana gāthāyo katamā ati ce  cāga vikkama saddhā anusampanna guṇa sāminaḥ
translated: here at the very end. But if it is asked what those verses are, they are as follows:🔽The lords of the qualities of generosity, renunciation, faith, and virtue,

original: Parakkamanarindassa, sīhaḷindassa dhīmato.🔽Atrajenā+nujātena, bhūpālakulaketunā;
analyzed: parakkama narindassa sīhaḷindassa dhīmataḥ  atrajena anujātena bhūpāla kula ketunā
translated: The king of exertion, the wise king of the Sinhalese.🔽The one who was permitted by Aṭṭha, the banner of the family of the king,

original: Disantapatthaṭodāra-vikkamena yasassinā.
analyzed: yasassinā
translated: The one with the glorious renunciation that is lofty like the rising sun.

original: Bhuvanekabhujavhena, mahārājena dhīmatā;
analyzed: bhuvana ika bhujavhena mahā rājena dhīmatā
translated: The wise great king, the one with the arm that is the lord of the world,

original: Catupaccayadānena, satataṃ samupaṭṭhito.
analyzed: catu paccaya dānena satatam samupaṭṭhitaḥ
translated: Always attended to by the gift of the four requisites.

original: “Jambudoṇī”ti vikhyātā –
analyzed: jambudoṇī iti vikhyātā
translated: “The Rose-Apple Island” is renowned,

original: Vāse nivasato sato;
analyzed: vāse nivasato sato
translated: Dwelling, living, and being mindful;

original: Sumaṅgalamahatthera –🔽Sāmino sucivuttino.
analyzed: su maṅgala mahatthera  sāminaḥ sucivuttinaḥ
translated: The Elder Sumangala the Great,🔽The Lord’s very well-spoken words.

original: Vaṃse visuddhe saṃjāto,
analyzed: vaṃse visuddhe saṃjātaḥ
translated: Born in a pure lineage,

original: Panthasenāsane rato;
analyzed: panthasena āsane
translated: Delighting in the life of a wanderer;

original: Pariyattimahāsindhu –
translated: The Elder Mahāsindhava the Great,

original: Niyyāmakadhurandharo.
analyzed: niyyāmaka dhurandharo
translated: The controller, the bearer of burdens.

original: Appicchādiguṇūpeto, jinasāsanamāmako;
analyzed: appiccha ādi guṇa upetaḥ jina sāsana māmakaḥ
translated: Endowed with the qualities of fewness of wishes, etc., the ornament of the Conqueror’s Dispensation;

original: Vaneratamahatthero, medhaṅkarasamavhayo.🔽Pāṭavatthāya bhikkhūnaṃ, vinaye suvisārado;
analyzed: medhaṅkara samavhayaḥ  pāṭava tthāya bhikkhūnam vinaye su visāradaḥ
translated: The Elder Vanerata the Great, the one called Medhaṅkara;🔽The Elder Payoga, skilled in the bhikkhus’ Pāṭimokkha, confident in the Discipline;

original: Payogasiddhiṃ sodhayi, sadā sappaññagocaraṃ.
analyzed: payoga siddhim sodhayi sadā
translated: He purified the success of his undertaking, always the domain of the wise.

original: Imaṃ likhitapuññena, mettekyaṃ upasaṃkami;
analyzed: imam likhita puññena mettekyam upasaṃkami
translated: Having approached the Metre called Iti,

original: Patiṭṭhahitvā saraṇe, suppatiṭṭhāmi sāsaneti.
analyzed: patiṭṭhahitvā saraṇe suppatiṭṭhāmi sāsane iti
translated: Having gone for refuge, I am well established in the Dispensation.”

original: Payogasiddhisiddhaṃ.
analyzed: payoga siddhi siddham
translated: The Success of the Undertaking is finished.
